English: BCP Psalter, 1605
Manx: Phillips, 1610

English: The i. day.
Manx: Yn i. la

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Beatus vir qui non abijt. Psal.1.
Manx: Beatus vir qui non abiit. psal. 1.

English: Blessed is the man that hath not walked in the counsaile of the ungodly, nor stand in the way of sinners : and hath not sit in the seat of the scornefull.
Manx: 1. Baniít ta yn dwyne nagh vell ern’ immiaght ayns kowrliy slyei niawghrawi, na shassw ayns rayd peki : as nagh vel er syei ayns ynyd syei ny knaidjoyl.

English: stand] 1636 stood; sit] 1636 sate
2 But his delight is in the Law of the Lord : and in his Law will he exercise himselfe day and night.
Manx: 2. Agh ta y viánsyn ayns lyei yn Chiarn : as ayns y lyêisyn ni eshẏn é héyn y ghlaghty la as yi.

English: 3 And hee shall bee like a tree planted by the water side : that wil bring foorth his fruit in due season.
Manx: 3. As bi eshin kasly rish bille seit liórish leatty yn wisky : ver magh y veǎs ayns tra dwi.

English: 4 His leafe also shall not wither : and looke whatsoever he doeth, it shall prosper.
Manx: 4. Yn dulliag aggesyn niíst, gha jean e fióghy : as jeagh whartýyl[1] t’ é d’ ianw, gowi e bishagh.

English: 5 As for the ungodly it is not so with them : but they are like the chaffe which the wind scattereth away from the face of the earth.
Manx: 5. Ass erson yn niaw ghrawi ghá vell e marshen mariusyn : agh ta ayd kasly rish yn ghow[2] ta yn gýe dy skély er shiul vei ydyn yn talwin.

English: 6 Therefore the ungodly shall not be able to stand in the judgement : neither the sinners in the Congregation of the righteous.
Manx: 6. Shenefá ghá bí yn niaw ghrawi fowndagh dy hassw ayns y vrwinys : na ny peki áyns chýmsaghy yn slyei ynrick.

English: 7 But the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous : and the way of the ungodly shall perish.
Manx: 7. Agh saŵn d’ yn Chiarn ráyd yn klyei ynrick : as héyd ráyd yn niawghrawi mow.

English: Quare fremuerunt gentes? Psal. 2.
Manx: Quare fremuerunt. psal. 2.

English: Why doe the heathen so furiously rage together : and why doe the people imagine a vaine thing?
Manx: 1. Kamma vell ny hangristín gho sownásagh góyl finw[3] kwjaght? as kamma vell yn pobyl smẃnaghy red fardálagh?

English: 2 The Kings of the earth stand up, and the rulers take counsaile together : against the Lorde, and against his Anoynted:
Manx: 2. Ta riaghyn yn talẃin shassw shúas, as ny fy̌ir réeli góyl kowrly kwjaght : nýei yn Chiarn, as nyei y ’er ǎllit.[4]

English: 3 Let us breake their bonds asunder : and cast away their cordes from us.
Manx: 3. Lig ’win nan ganglaghyn y vrishie vei magh elle : as y hilge er shiul nan dydyn[5] voiniyn.

English: 4 He that dwelleth in heaven shall laugh them to scorne : the Lord shall have them in derision.
Manx: 4. Eshin ta vaghe ayns neaw, ni e geraghti ořw ŕỳ knáid : bi aydsyn ag y Chiarn ayns faghid.

English: 5 Then shal he speake unto them in his wrath : and vexe them in his sore displeasure:
Manx: 5. Eish ni eshin lóyrt riusyn ayns y ghorri : as aydsyn y hyaghyn ayns y iumẃiys trowm.

English: 6 Yet have I set my King : upon my holy hill of Sion.
Manx: 6. Fóost ta mi er seiaghy my ríi : er my ghnock ghasserick Seion.

English: 7 I wil preach the Law whereof the Lord hath said unto me: thou art my Sonne, this day have I begotten thee.
Manx: 7. Niyms yn ly̌ei y phrecháel ie ta yn Chiarn erna rá rẃỳms : she my vack us, ju ta mish er dy ieadthyn.
ieadthyn] ms. jeadthyn

English: 8 Desire of mee, and I shall give thee the Heathen for thine inheritance, : and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.
Manx: 8. Shy̌ir orrwyms, as verym dwitt ny hanghristín ghon t’ eirys : as ny harnyn soje magh d’ yn talw ghon dthy ghwmmels.

English: uttermost] 1662 utmost
9 Thou shalt bruise them with a rod of yron : and breake them in pieces like a potters vessell.
Manx: 9. Ni us aydsyn y vrẃ rish slatt iarn : as aydsyn y vrishie ayns stẃkanyn, mar saiagh ’er ny bott.

English: 10 Be wise now therefore, O yee Kings : be learned yee that are Judges of the earth.
Manx: 10. Bigi kríney nish errefa shen, O shiusse riaghyn : bigi ynsiít, shiusse ta nan mrwinyn d’ yn tallw.

English: 11 Serve the Lord in feare : and rejoyce unto him with reverence.
Manx: 11. Shervésigi yn Chiarn ayns agyl : as bigi ganoil hwggesyn rish arym.
Shervésigi] ms. Shervési

English: 12 Kisse the Sonne lest he be angry, and so ye perish from the right way : if his wrath be kindled (yea but a little) blessed are all they that put their trust in him.
Manx: 12. Pagi yn mack nagh bi é korri, as marshen shiuss dy goll mow vei yn ráyd gháyr : ma viís y ghorri fadit (gy jarw agh began) baníit ta aydsyn wlly ta toyrt nan dreistéel aŷnsyn.

English: Domine quid? Psal. 3.
Manx: Domine quid? psal. 3.

English: Lord how are they encreased that trouble mee : many are they that rise against me.
Manx: 1. Hiarn, kyns t’ áyd er mishaghy ta dy my hyaghyn : ta ymmydi aydsyn ta giri m’ yoi.

English: 2 Many one there be that say of my soule : there is no helpe for him in his God.
Manx: 2. Sh’ immy anáyn ta grá dy m’ anym : gha vell kwney erbi dâsyn ayns y Iíh.

English: 3 But thou, O Lord, art my defender : thou art my worship, and the lifter up of my head.
Manx: 3. Agh she us, y Hiarn, m’ ’er fríal : she us m’ ýasly, as y fer ta trogel shuas my ghian.

English: 4 I did call upon the Lord with my voice : and he heard me out of his holy hill.
Manx: 4. Jei mi er y Chiarn rish my ghorá : as ghýyl e mi magh as y ghnock ghasserick.

English: 5 I laid me downe and slept, and rose up againe : for the Lord sustained me.
Manx: 5. Lei mi shíis as ghadjil mi, as jirri mi shuas ríist : erson ghwm yn Chiarn shúas mi.

English: 6 I will not bee afraid for ten thousands of the people : that have set themselves against me round about.
Manx: 6. Gha jeym agyl erson jei mílyghyn dy phobyl : ta ern’ ’an seiaghy héyn m’ ýoi krwyn magiyrt.

English: 7 Up Lorde, and helpe me, O my God : for thou smitest all mine enemies upon the cheeke bone; thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly.
Manx: 7. Shúas, Hiarn, as kwyn liám, O my Iíh : erson tow boaly my noidjyn wlly er knaw yn ghiyl, tow er mrishie fiekylyn yn niaw ghrawi.

English: 8 Salvation belongeth unto the Lord : and thy blessing is upon the people.
Manx: 8. Ta sawálys benelt rish y Chiarn : as ta dthy vanaght er y phobyl.

English: the people] 1660 thy people (as 1539)
Cum inuocarem. Psal. 4.
Manx: Cum inuocarem. psal. 4.

English: Heare me when I call, O God of my righteousnesse : for thou hast set me at libertie when I was in trouble; have mercie upon me, and hearken unto my prayer.
Manx: 1. Klast rẃỳms tra ta mi gemaght, O Iíh dy my ghayrys : erson toŵ er my ghwrr ag remys nar va mi ayns sýaghyn : jean myghin ory̌m, as klast rish my phadjer.

English: for thou hast set] 1662 thou hast set
2 O ye sonnes of men, how long will ye blaspheme mine honour : and have such pleasure in vanitie, and seeke after leasing?
Manx: 2. O shiusse veck déne, káidj víis shiu lóyrt gy molaghtagh dy m’ onyr : as víis leid yn agne aggw ayns fardálys, as shyrre nyre brégyn ?

English: 3 Know this also, that the Lord hath chosen to himselfe the man that is godly : when I call upon the Lord, hee will hear me.
Manx: 3. Bi fyss aǧgw er shó níist, gy vell y Chiarn er ry̌i hwgge héyn yn dwyne ta krawi : nar éiym er y Chiarn, klwini e mi.
hwgge] ms. hwg e

English: 4 Stand in awe and sinne not : commune with your owne heart, and in your chamber, and be still.
Manx: 4. Shassigi ayns agyl, as na jeanigi peky : loyrigi rish nan griaghyn héyn, as ayns nan siambyr, as bigi kiwn.

English: 5 Offer the sacrifice of righteousnesse : and put your trust in the Lord.
Manx: 5. Owrelgi toyrtys kasserick dy gháyrys : as kwrrigi nan dreistéel ayns y Chiarn.

English: 6 There be many that say : who wil shew us any good?
Manx: 6. Sh’ immy ta grá : quei hoilshys dẃìn mei erbi?

English: 7 Lord lift thou up : the light of thy Countenance upon us.
Manx: 7. Hiarn, trog us shuas : soilshe dy gnw̌ys orwiniyn.

English: 8 Thou hast put gladnesse in my heart : since the time that their corne and wine and oyle increased.
Manx: 8. Tow er gwr bogey ayns my ghri : ada yn tra ren yn arẃ acksyn as phien as ẃil bishaghy.

English: 9 I wil lay me downe in peace, and take my rest : for it is thou Lord onely, that makest me dwell in safetie.
Manx: 9. Léìým shíis ayns shí, as góỳm m’ é : erson she us, y[7] Hiarn, dy lomyrkan ta toyrt ǒryms vaghey gyséf.

English: Verba mea auribus. Psal. 5.
Manx: Verba mea auribus. psal. 5.

English: Ponder my words, O Lord : consider my meditation.
Manx: 1. Jean m’ ’okylyn y howys,[8] O Hiarn : smwni er my smwnaghtyn.

English: 2 O hearken thou unto the voyce of my calling, my King and my God : for unto thee will I make my prayer.
Manx: 2. O klast us rish korá m’ émagh, my rí as my Iíh : erson hwyds niyms my phadjer.

English: 3 My voice shalt thou heare betimes, O Lord : earely in the morning will I direct my prayer unto thee, and will looke up.
Manx: 3. My ghorá ni us y ghlastchen trá mei, O Hiarn : gy moghe ayns y vaderyn verym my phadjer hwyds, as jeaghyms shúas.

English: 4 For thou art the God that hast no pleasure in wickednesse : neither shall any evill dwell with thee.
Manx: 4. Erson she us y Jíh nagh vell agney erbí áỳds ayns olkys : ghamw ni olk erbi vaghey máỳrts.

English: 5 Such as be foolish shall not stand in thy sight : for thou hatest all them that worke vanitie.
Manx: 5. Leidsyn as ta ammyjagh, gha jean ayd shassw ayns t’ éanish : erson ta dwoi ayds oriusyn wlly ta gobraghy fardálys.

English: 6 Thou shalt destroy them that speake leasing : the Lord will abhore both the bloodthirstie and deceitfull man.
Manx: 6. Ni us aydsyn y ghwr moẃ ta loyrt brég : ver y Chiarn fúa d’ yn ’er páa nyrg fwil, as d’ yn dwyne kalgwil níist.
moẃ] ms. mẃ

English: 7 But as for mee, I will come into thy house, even upon the multitude of thy mercie : and in thy feare wil I worship toward thy holy Temple.
Manx: 7. Agh er my hons, higgym ayns dthy hei, gy jarw ayns palche dthy vyghin : as ayns t’ agil niym ammys dy dthy hiampyl kasserićk.
dy] ms. dá dy

English: 8 Leade me, O Lord, in thy righteousnesse, because of mine enemies : make thy way plaine before my face.
Manx: 8. Líid mi, O Hiarn, ayns dthy ghayrys erson my nóidjyn : jean dthy ráyd ré fienish m’ edyn.

English: 9 For there is no faithfulnesse in his mouth : their inward parts are very wickednesse.
Manx: 9. Erson gha vell fyirrinys erbi ayns y véal : ta ny harnyn er chew stei acksyn fíir olkys.

English: 10 Their throat is an open sepulchre : they flatter with their tongue.
Manx: 10. Ta yn skornagh ack na yoi foskilt : t’ ayd brynryght lesh ’an jange.

English: 11 Destroy thou them, O God; let them perish through their owne imaginations : cast them out in the multitude of their ungodlinesse, for they have rebelled against thee.
Manx: 11. Kwr us aydsyn mow, O Iíh, lig ’aŵ ve er nan gal tryid nan smẃnaghtyn heyn : tilg ayd magh ayns ymmydi dy nan mighráwiys, erson t’ ayd ern’ ianw kagey t’ yôiys.
t’ yôiys] ms. ty’ óìys

English: 12 And let all them that put their trust in thee, rejoyce : they shall ever be giving of thankes, because thou defendest them, they that love thy Name shall be joyfull in thee;
Manx: 12. As lig ’awsyn wlly ta toyrt nan dreistéel anyds bogey y goyl : bi aydsyn gybragh toyrt bwiys, erson gy vel us d’ an vrial, áydsyn sh’ ýne liô t’ enym, bi ayd ganoil ǎnyds.

English: 13 For thou Lord wilt give thy blessing unto the righteous : and with thy favourable kindnes wilt thou defend him, as with a shield.
Manx: 13. Erson ver us, Hiarn, dthy vanaght d’ yn kly̌ei gháyragh : as rish dthy gheindylys foróyl frielyt us eshyn mar rish skíe.[9]

English: The i. day.
Manx: Yn i. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Domine ne in furore. Psal. 6.
Manx: Domine ne in furore. psal. 6.

English: O Lorde, rebuke me not in thine indignation : neither chasten me in thy displeasure.
Manx: 1. O Hiarn, na tóer aghsan dẃỳs [ayns] t’ arg : namẃ keri mi ayns dthy iwmẃys.

English: 2 Have mercie upon me, O Lord, for I am weake : O Lord heale me, for my bones are vexed.
Manx: 2. Jean myghyn orym, O Hiarn, erson ta mi anẃn : O Hiarn, sláni mi, erson ta my ghnawyn gonit.

English: 3 My soule is also sore troubled : but Lord, how long wilt thou punish mee?
Manx: 3. Ta m’ anym níist ayns syaghyn mẃar : agh, Hiarn, kaid ni us mish y gheraghy?

English: is also] 1662 also is
4 Turne thee, O Lord, and deliver my soule : Oh save me for thy mercies sake.
Manx: 4. Chyndá us, O Hiarn, as lifrée m’ anym : O saw mi erson gráyi dthy vyghin.

English: 5 For in death no man remembreth thee : and who will give thee thankes in the pit?
Manx: 5. Erson ayns báys gha vel dwyne erbi kwinaghtyn ořts : as quei ver bwiys dw̌itch ayns yn yei?

English: 6 I am wearie of my groning; every night wash I my bed : and water my couch with my teares.
Manx: 6. Ta mi ski dy my akan, gygh wlly ýì ta mi ní my liǎbi : as gwiskaghy ynyd my lyi rish my ierw.

English: 7 My beautie is gone for very trouble : and worne away because of all mine enemies.
Manx: 7. Ta my vóid er shiul rish ’rogh hyaghyn : as er géf er shiul kiyntagh rŷ my noidjyn wlly.
my vóid] ms. mi véid

English: 8 Away from me all ye that worke vanitie : for the Lord hath heard the voice of my weeping.
Manx: 8. Ass y ráyd vóỳms, wlly shiusse ta gobraghe fardalys : erson ta yn Chiarn er glastchen korá dy my ghóo.[10]

English: 9 The Lord hath heard my petition : the Lord will receive my prayer.
Manx: 9. Ta yn Chiarn er glastchen m’ aghy̌in : gowi yn Chiarn my phadjer.

English: 10 All mine enemies shall be confounded and sore vexed : they shal be turned backe and put to shame suddenly.
Manx: 10. Bi wlly my nóidjyn er nan gwr mow as gonǐit gy holk : bi áyd er nan jyndá er gẃl, as er nan dort gys náre daltatchym.

English: Domine Deus meus. Psal. 7
Manx: Domine deus meus. psal. 7.

English: O Lorde my God, in thee have I put my trust : save mee from all them that persecute me, and deliver me;
Manx: 1. O Hiarn my Iíh, aňyds ta mi er dórt my hreistéel : saw mi vousyn wlly ta janw trynlás ory̌m, as lifré mi.

English: 2 Lest he devoure my soule like a Lion, and teare it in pieces : while there is none to helpe.
Manx: 2. Er agyl gy strẃi e m’ anym mar lěion, as raby e ayns stwckanyn : ghówd as nagh vel anáyn dy ghwney.

English: 3 O Lord my God, if I have done any such thing : or if there be any wickednesse in my hands;
Manx: 3. O Hiarn my Iíh, my ta mi ern’ ianw red erbi léid shen : na my ta peke erbi ayns my lawyn;

English: 4 If I have rewarded evill unto him that dealt friendly with mee : yea, I have delivered him that without any cause is mine enemie;
Manx: 4. Ma jik mi olk dâsyn ren gy mẃnjeroil rẃỳms : gy jarw, ta mi er lifre eshyin ta gyn óer erbi na nóid dow;
na] ms. va

English: 5 Then let mine enemy persecute my soule, and take me : yea, let him tread my life downe upon the earth, and lay mine honour in the dust.
Manx: 5. Eis ligg e my nóid trynlás y ianw er m’ anym, as my góyl : gy jarw ligg e my vé y stampey shiís er y talw, as m’ onyr kwrr na ly̌i ayns y jan.

English: 6 Stand up, O Lord, in thy wrath, and lift up thy selfe : because of the indignation of mine enemies, arise up for me in the Judgement that thou hast commanded.
Manx: 6. Shass shúas, O Hiarn, ayns dthy ghorri, as trog shúas ẃ heyn : erson farg my noidjyn, irri shúas er my hons ayns y vrwinys tow us erna háre.

English: 7 And so shall the congregation of the people come about thee : for their sakes therefore lift up thy selfe againe.
Manx: 7. As marshen hig shessaght yn phobyl magíỳrt ym̌myds : shenyfá ernan-son-syn trog shúas ẃ héyn ríist.

English: 8 The Lord shall judge the people; give sentence with me, O Lord : according to my righteousnesse, and according to the innocencie that is in me.
Manx: 8. Ni yn Chiarn yn pobyl y vrwinys; tóyr brẃinus liâms, O Hiarn : nýre my gháỳrys, as nýre [yn] niaw-loght ta anyms.

English: 9 O let the wickednesse of the ungodly come to an ende : but guide thou the just.
Manx: 9. O ligg e olkys y niaw-ghráwi chíit gys kian : agh liíd us yn dwyne káyragh.

English: 10 For the righteous God : trieth the very hearts & reines.
Manx: 10. Erson ta yn Jih káyragh : sheirre magh ny kriaghyn as ny harniyn.

English: 11 My help commeth of God : which preserveth them that are true of heart.
Manx: 11. Ta my ghẃney chíit vei Jih : ta d’ an frial-syn ta firrinagh dy ghri.

English: which] 1662 who
12 God is a righteous Judge, strong and patient : and God is provoked every day.
Manx: 12. Ta Jíh na vriu kayragh, láidjer as fwllynagh[11] : as ta Jih dâ vrosnaghy gygh yn lá.[12]

English: 13 If a man will not turne, he will whet his sword : hee hath bent his bow, and made it ready.
Manx: 13. My nagh jean dwyne chynda, liwi e y ghlêiw : t’ e er lwby y vow̌, as erna ianw arlw e.

English: 14 He hath prepared for him the instruments of death : he ordeineth his arrowes against the persecuters.
Manx: 14. T’ e erna ianw arlw dâsyn greinyn yn váas : t’ e erna ianw arlw[13] y heijyn nýoi ny trynlási.
dâsyn] ms. dáùsyn; yn váas] ms. ny váas

English: 15 Behold, he travaileth with mischiefe : hee hath conceived sorrow, and brought foorth ungodlinesse.
Manx: 15. Vack w, t’ e trawelt rish drogh red : t’ e ern’ ienaghtyn triymshe, as er doyrt magh niauwghráwiyght.

English: 16 He hath graven and digged up a pit : and is fallen himselfe into the destruction that he made for other.
Manx: 16. T’ e er gnaw[14] as er gly̌ei shúas lagg : as t’ e héyn er dwytchym ayns y strŵiel ren e ghon fielagh elle.

English: 17 For his travaile shall come upon his owne head : and his wickednesse shall fall on his owne pate.
Manx: 17. Erson hig y hrawelt er y ghian héyn : as twitchi y mighrawiyght er y volag héyn.

English: 18 I will give thankes unto the Lord, according to his righteousnesse : and will prayse the Name of the Lord the most High.
Manx: 18. Verym bẃìas d’ yn Chiarn nýre y gháyrys : as molym enym yn Chiarn smw sh’ ýrje.

English: Domine Dominus. Psal. 8.
Manx: Domine Dominus. psal. 8.

English: O Lord our governour, how excellent is thy Name in all the world : thou that hast set thy glory above the heavens.
Manx: 1. O Hiarn nan fer réel, gho ard-ýasyl ass ta t’ enym ayns y týyl wlly : us ta er seiaghe dthy glóer erskyn ny neawyn.

English: 2 Out of the mouth of very babes and sucklings hast thou ordeined strength, because of thine enemies : that thou mightest still the enemie and the avenger.
Manx: 2. Magh as béal ny’n ’íir nikanyn,[15] as aydsyn ta jóyl, tow us ern’ ordyghe gniart, erson dthy nóidjyn : gy vodaght us y nóid y vínaghe as yn kwílinỳder.

English: 3 For I will consider the heavens, even the works of thy fingers : the Moone and the Starres which thou hast ordeined.
Manx: 3. Erson smẃniym er ny neawaghyn, gy jarw obraghyn dthy véyrs : yn íask as ny rydlagyn ta us erna ordyghey.

English: the heavens] 1662 thy heavens (as 1562)
4 What is man that thou art mindefull of him : and the sonne of man, that thou visitest him?
Manx: 4. Kré ta dwyne, gy vel us agyntagh er : as mack y wyne gy vel us jaghyn er?

English: 5 Thou madest him lower then the Angels : to crowne him with glory and worship.
Manx: 5. Ren us [e] na shiísle na ny hangelyn : dy hoyrt attaghan er rish mole as ýasly.

English: 6 Thou makest him to have dominion of the workes of thy handes : and thou hast put all things in subjection under his feete;
Manx: 6. Tow toyrt ersyn chiarnys ve agge er obraghyn dthy lawyn : as tow er doyrt gygh wlly red shíis fẃom y ghassyn;

English: 7 All sheepe and oxen : yea and the beasts of the field;
Manx: 7. Ny kiri wlly as ny déf : gy jarw, as béin y vagher;

English: 8 The foules of the aire, and the fishes of the sea : and whatsoever walketh through the paths of the Seas.
Manx: 8. Éỳnli yn áer, as ieskyn ny marre : as kre erbí ta gimíaght tryid kassanyn ny varkaghyn.

English: 9 O Lord our governour : how excellent is thy Name in all the world!
Manx: 9. O Hiarn nan gianẃrtus : ghó ard-ýasyl ass ta t’ enym ayns y týyl wlly!

English: The ii. day.
Manx: Yn ii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Confitebor tibi. Psal. 9.
Manx: Confitebor tibi. psal. 9.

English: I will give thankes unto thee, O Lord, with my whole heart : I will speake of all thy marveilous workes.
Manx: 1.Verym bẃias dẃìch, O Hiarn, rish wlly my ghri : niym loyrt dy t’ obraghyns iéntysagh wlly.

English: 2 I will bee glad and rejoyce in thee : yea, my songs will I make of thy Name, O thou most Highest.
Manx: 2. Biŷm gaǹoil as goym boge anyds : gy jarw, niyms m’ orányn dy t’ enyms, O us smẃ sh’ ýrje.

English: 3 While mine enemies are driven backe : they shall fall and perish at thy presence.
Manx: 3. Ghoud as ta my nóidjyn er nan iŷmman er gẃl : twitchi áyd as bi áyd er nan gal ag t’ enish.

English: 4 For thou hast maintained my right, & my cause : thou art set in the Throne that judgest right.
Manx: 4. Erson ta us er gwmmel shúas my gháyr as my ghwsyn : ta us sěit ayns yn iynyd riẃl[16] ta toyrt brwinus káyr.

English: 5 Thou hast rebuked the Heathen, and destroyed the ungodly : thou hast put out their Name for ever and ever.
Manx: 5. Ta us er doyrt aghsan dy ny hangristín, as er gwrr moẃ y niawghrawi : tow er doyrt magh nan enym erson gybragh as gybragh.
aghsan] ms. acksan

English: 6 O thou enemie, destructions are come to a perpetuall ende : even as the cities which thou hast destroyed, their memoriall is perished with them.
Manx: 6. O us y nóid, ta strwielyn er jít gys kian gybragh : gy jarw mar ny hard-valchyn ta us erna gwr moẃ, ta yn kwiny acksyn kalchit mâriu.

English: 7 But the Lord shall endure for ever : hee hath also prepared his seat for Judgement.
Manx: 7. Agh farri yn Chiarn erson gybrágh : t’ e niíst ern’ ianw arlẃ y enyd sy̌i ghon brwinys.

English: 8 For he shall judge the world in righteousnesse : and minister true Judgement unto the people.
Manx: 8. Erson ni e yn sýyl y vrẃinys ayns kayrys : as ver e brwinys fyrrinagh d’ yn phobyl.

English: 9 The Lord also will be a defence for the oppressed : even a refuge in due time of trouble.
Manx: 9. Bi yn Chiarn níist na ghẃne dawsyn ta trynlasit : gy jarw na ghymmyrk ayns ierish kẃi dy hýaghan.

English: 10 And they that know thy Name, will put their trust in thee : for thou, Lord, hast never failed them that seeke thee.
Manx: 10. As aydsyn sawn t’ enym, ver ayd nan dreisteel anyds : erson gha hrég ẃ aydsyn, y Hiarn, riu ta dy dthy hyrrus.

English: 11 O praise the Lord which dwelleth in Sion : shew the people of his doings.
Manx: 11. O moligi yn Chiarn ta vághe ayns Séìon : jéaghigi d’ yn phobyl y ianw-syn.
jéaghigi] ms. jéaghi

English: 12 For when he maketh inquisition for blood, hee remembreth them : and forgetteth not the complaint of the poore.
Manx: 12. Erson nar t’ e janw fysseri erson fwil, t’ e kwinaghtyn orw̌ : as gha vel e jarwd akan ny moght.

English: 13 Have mercy upon mee, O Lord; consider the trouble which I suffer of them that hate me : thou that liftest me up from the gates of death.
Manx: 13. Jean myghin ořym, O Hiarn, smwni er y týaghyn ta mi d’ wllaghtyn iusyn ta dwoi ack ory̌m : us ta dy my hrogel shuas vei dorsyn yn váas;

English: 14 That I may shew all thy praises within the ports of the daughter of Sion : I will rejoyce in thy salvation.
Manx: 14. Gy vodym wlly dthy volaghyns y hoilsaghy er léf [17] stei dy dorsyn iniin Seíòn : gowym boge ayns dthy hawálys.

English: 15 The heathen are sunke down in the pit that they made : in the same net which they hid privily, is their foote taken.
Manx: 15. Ta ny hangristín er dwittym shíis ayns y lagg ren áyd : ayns y liyn kedyn dalli ayd gyn ’yss ta ’an gass goutch.

English: 16 The Lord is knowen to execute Judgement : the ungodly is trapped in the worke of his owne hands.
Manx: 16. Ta fyss gy vel y Chiarn janw káyr : ta yn niawghrawi gow̌it ayns obyr nan lawyn héyn.

English: 17 The wicked shall bee turned into hell : and all the people that forget God.
Manx: 17. Bi aydsyn ta olk ernan jynda gys nifrein : as wlly yn pobyl ta jarẃd Jíh.
ta olk] ms. to olk

English: 18 For the poore shall not alway be forgotten : the patient abiding of the meeke shall not perish for ever.
Manx: 18. Erson gha bi yn boght erna iarẃd goni[18] : gha jean fanaghtyn féagh ny mínid gol mow erson gybrágh.

English: 19 Up Lord, and let not man have the upper hand : let the Heathen be judged in thy sight.
Manx: 19. Shúas, Hiarn, as na lig dy gwyne law yn iyghtyr ve agge : ligg e ny hangristín ve er ’an mrwinys ayns t’ ’éanish.

English: 20 Put them in feare (O Lord) : that the heathen may know themselves to be but men.
Manx: 20. Kwr áyd ayns agyl, O Hiarn : gy vod fyss ve ag ny hangristín nagh vel ayd héyn agh déne.

English: Vt quid Domine. Psal. 10.
Manx: Vt quid domine. psal. 10.

English: Why standest thou so farre off (O Lord) : and hidest thy face in the needfull time of trouble?
Manx: 1. Kre fá ta us shassw ghowd voniyn, O Hiarn : as fallaghy t’ edyn ayns tra ymmyrtsagh dy hyaghan?

English: 2 The ungodly for his owne lust doeth persecute the poore : let them bee taken in the craftie wilinesse that they have imagined.
Manx: 2. Ta yn niawghráwi erson y agney héyn janw trynlás er yn voght : lig ’aw ve er nan góyl ayns ny kalgyn krowtagh ta áyd erna ghwmmey.

English: 3 For the ungodly hath made boast of his owne hearts desire : and speaketh good of the covetous whom God abhorreth.
Manx: 3. Erson ta yn niawghráwi erna ianw bogyssagh dy agne y ghri héyn : as t’ e lort gy méi d’ yn dwyne sâintagh ta Jíh toyrt dwoi gâ.

English: 4 The ungodly is so proud, that hee careth not for God : neither is God in all his thoughts.
Manx: 4. Ta yn niawghráwi gho mórniagh gy kwmmy lesh erson Jíh : ghamẃ ta Jíh ayns y smwnaghtyn wlly.

English: 5 His wayes are alway grievous : thy Judgements are farre above out of his sight, and therefore defieth he all his enemies.
Manx: 5. Ta y raydjyn gȯni dockragh : ta dthy vrwinyssyn fodey erskyn magh as y hilliysyn, as shenyfá t’ e kẁr yn láyn fw y noidjyn wlly.

English: 6 For he hath said in his heart, Tush, I shall never bee cast downe : there shall no harme happen unto me.
Manx: 6. Erson dwyrt e ayns y ghri, piǔ, gha biŷms gybrágh er my hilge shíis : ghá jean skelly erbí taghyrt dŵys.

English: 7 His mouth is full of cursing, deceit, and fraud : under his tongue is ungodlinesse and vanitie.
Manx: 7. Ta y veal láyn dy gwiaghyn, malley, as krout : fẃo y hange ta niawghrawíys as fardálys.

English: 8 He sitteth lurking in the theevish corners of the streets : and privily in his lurking dennes doeth he murther the innocent; his eyes are set against the poore.
Manx: 8. T’ e syěi fallíit ayns ny kwltíin bradagh ny stradjyn : as gyn ’yss ayns y ẃigyn fallíit t’ e dynvárrys yn dwyne gyn-loght; ta y hwylyn sy̌it nyoi ny moght.

English: 9 For hee lyeth waiting secretly, even as a Lion lurketh he in his denne : that he may ravish the poore.
Manx: 9. Erson t’ e ly̌i farkiaght gy falliit, gy jarw mar léion t’ e dy alaghy ayns y ẁig : gy vod e yn boght y góyl er égyn.

English: 10 He doeth ravish the poore : when hee getteth him into his net.
Manx: 10. T’ e janw gniart er yn voght : nar t’ e dy ieadthyn e ayns y liy̌n.
ieadthyn] ms. jeadthyn

English: 11 He falleth downe, and humbleth himselfe : that the congregation of the poore may fall into the handes of his Captaines.
Manx: 11. T’ e twitchym shíis as dâ iíslaghy héyn : gy vod sheissaght yn voght twitchym ayns lawyn y ghianwrtyssyn.

English: 12 He hath said in his heart, Tush, God hath forgotten : he hideth away his face, and he will never see it.
Manx: 12. Dẃyrt e ayns y ghrí, piǔ, ta Jíh erna iarwd : t’ e fallaghy ass y ráyd y edyn, as gha váik e é gybragh.

English: 13 Arise (O Lord God) and lift up thine hand : forget not the poore.
Manx: 13. Irri, O Hiarn Jíh, as trog shúas dthy law : na jarẃd ny boghtyn.

English: 14 Wherefore should the wicked blaspheme God : while he doeth say in his heart, Tush, thou God carest not for it?
Manx: 14. Krefá ienagh yn niawghrawi loyrt gy mólyghtagh dy Iíh : ghowd as t’ e grá ayns y ghrí, pìǔ, kwmmy lǎts, us e[19] Iíh, er y ghon?

English: 15 Surely thou hast seene it : for thou beholdest ungodlinesse and wrong.
Manx: 15. Gy sickir ta us ern akin e : erson tow fakin niaw ghrawiys as agayr.
agayr] ms. gayr

English: 16 That thou mayest take the matter into thine hand : the poore committeth himselfe unto thee; for thou art the helper of the friendlesse.
Manx: 16. Gy vod [us] yn ghwyss y goyl ayns dthy law : ta yn boght dy hymne e héyn hŵyds, erson she us yn fer kwni aggesyn ta gyn ghàrry.

English: 17 Breake thou the power of the ungodly and malicious : take away his ungodlinesse and thou shalt finde none.
Manx: 17. Brish us pẃer yn niawghráwi as gawnlysagh : gow as y rayd y niaw ghrawiys as gha vow veg.

English: 18 The Lord is King for ever and ever : and the heathen are perished out of the land.
Manx: 18. Ta yn Chiarn na ry̌i erson gybrágh as gybrágh : as ta ny hangristín er ’an gàl magh as y talw.

English: 19 Lord, thou hast heard the desire of the poore : thou preparest their heart, and thine eare hearkeneth thereto;
Manx: 19. Hiarn, tow er glastchen agney ny moghtyn : tow ern ianw arlw nan gri, as ta dthy ghlyesh klastchen hwggesyn;

English: 20 To helpe the fatherlesse and poore unto their right : that the man of the earth be no more exalted against them.
Manx: 20. Dy ghẃny lesh yn ghlawn gyn áer as boght gys nan gáyr : nagh bi dwyne yn talwin nasmẃ erna hrogel shúas nan nyoi-syn.

English: In Domino confido. Psal. 11.
Manx: In Domino confido. psal. 11.

English: In the Lord put I my trust : how say yee then to my soule, that she should flee as a bird unto the hill?
Manx: 1. Ayns y Chiarn ta mi toyrt my hreistéel : kyns ta shiu grá eish rish m’ anym, gy jeanagh i ’étlagh mar én gys y ghnock?

English: flee] flie 1660, flee 1662 (as also 1599)
2 For loe, the ungodly bend their bow, and make readie their arrowes within the quiver : that they may privily shoot at them which are true of heart.
Manx: 2. Erson jeagh, ta yn niaw ghrawi bendéel nan mow, as janw arlw nan sêijyn er leyf stei d’ yn ghaever : gy vod ayd gyn ’yss tilge oriusyn ta firrinagh dy ghrí.

English: 3 For the foundations wil be cast downe : and what hath the righteous done?
Manx: 3. Erson bi ny hymsynyn[20] er nan dilge shiís : as kre ta dwyne kayragh erna ianw?

English: 4 The Lord is in his holy Temple : the Lords seate is in heaven.
Manx: 4. Ta yn Chiarn ayns y hiámpyl kasserick : ta ynyd-sy̌i yn Chiarn ayns neaw.

English: 5 His eyes consider the poore : and his eye lids tryeth the children of men.
Manx: 5. Ta y hẃilyn smẃnaghtyn er ny boghtyn : as ferẃghyn y hẃil shirre magh klawn géne.
ferẃghyn] ms. ferẃghy

English: 6 The Lord alloweth the righteous : but the ungodly, and him that delighteth in wickednes, doth his soule abhorre.
Manx: 6. Ta yn Chiarn góyl gy mei rish yn dwyne káyragh : agh yn niawghrawi, as éshyn ta goyl tatnys ayns olkys, ta dŵoi ag y anym er.

English: 7 Upon the ungodly he shall raine snares, fire and brimstone, storme and tempest : this shal be their portion to drinke.
Manx: 7. Er yn niawghráwi ni e flaghy ribbaghyn, angil, as bryimston, styrrym, as dorein : sho víis nan ayrn dy if.

English: 8 For the righteous Lorde loveth righteousnesse : his countenance will behold the thing that is just.
Manx: 8. Erson sh’ yney lesh yn Chiarn kayragh káyrys : jeaghi y edyn er yn red ta káyr.
jeaghi] ms. jeagh

English: The ii. day.
Manx: Yn ii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Saluum me fac. Psal. 12.
Manx: Saluum me fac. psal. 12.

English: Help me Lorde, for there is not one godly man left : for the faithfull are minished from among the children of men.
Manx: 1. Kẃyn liam, Hiarn, erson gha vel yn ’wyne kráwi erna agáel : erson ta yn slyěi krédjoil er nan lýdaghy vei masky klawn géne.

English: 2 They talke of vanitie every one with his neighbour : they doe but flatter with their lips, and dissemble in their double heart.
Manx: 2. T’ áyd taglw d’ ardálys gygh anáyn rŷ nábw : gha vel áyd agh brynryght rish nan meliyn, as maltaryght ayns nan gri dẃbyl.

English: 3 The Lord shall roote out all deceitfull lips : and the tongue that speaketh proud things;
Manx: 3. Rówri yn Chiarn magh wlly ny méliyn kalgagh : as yn chiange ta loyrt redyn morniagh;

English: 4 Which have said, With our tongues wee wil prevaile : we are they that ought to speake, who is lord over us?
Manx: 4. Ta ern’ ’rá, rish nan jange gow meid barriyght : she shuiniyn áydsyn leshiagh loyrt, quei ta na hiárn harrw̌iniyn?

English: wee wil] 1662 will we
5 Nowe for the comfortlesse troubles sake of the needie : and because of the deepe sighing of the poore,
Manx: 5. Nish erson sýaghyn niawgyrjẃyl d’ yn ymmyrtysagh : as erson osney dow̌in ny moghtyn,

English: 6 I will up (sayth the Lord) : and will helpe every one from him that swelleth against him, and will set them at rest.
Manx: 6. Irriym shúas, ta yn Chiarn dy grá : as kwynym lesh gygh anayn věisyn ta gat na yoi, as verym áyd ag fé.

English: them] 1662 him
7 The wordes of the Lord are pure words : even as the silver, which from the earth is tried, and purified seven times in the fire.
Manx: 7. Ta fokylyn yn Chiarn fokelyn glan : gy jarw mar yn argyd ta vei yn talw erna hyrre magh as glannit shaght kiyrtyn ayns yn angil.

English: 8 Thou shalt keepe them, O Lord : thou shalt preserve him from this generation for ever.
Manx: 8. Fríalyt us áydsyn, O Hiarn : ni us eshyn y gháwdy vei yn shilógh sho erson gybrágh.

English: 9 The ungodly walke on every side : when they are exalted, the children of men are put to rebuke.
Manx: 9. Ta yn niawghrawi gimíaght er gygh yn chéf : tra ta áydsyn er nan drogel shuas, ta klawn gene er nan doyrt gys aghsan.

English: Vsquequo Domine. Psal. 13.
Manx: Vsquequo Domine. psal. 13.

English: How long wilt thou forget mee (O Lord) for ever : how long wilt thou hide thy face from me?
Manx: 1. Káidj ni us mish y iarẃd, O Hiarn, erson gybrágh : káidj ni us t’ edyn y ’alaghy voym?

English: 2 How long shall I seeke counsell in my soule, and be so vexed in my heart : how long shall mine enemies triumph over me?
Manx: 2. Káidj heiryms kowrley ayns m’ anym, as vîym gho gonit ayns my ghrí : káidj ni my noidjyn barriyght y goyl harřym?

English: 3 Consider, and heare me, O Lord my God : lighten mine eyes, that I sleepe not in death.
Manx: 3. Smwni as klwy̌n mi, O Hiarn my Iíh : soilshi my hẃilyn, nagh gadliym ayns báas.

English: 4 Lest mine enemie say, I have prevailed against him : for if I be cast downe, they that trouble me, will rejoyce at it.
Manx: 4. Nagh n’abber my nóidj, ta mi ern’ góyl barriyght na ýoi : erson ma viym er my hilge shíis, áydsyn ta dy my hýaghyn, gowi ayd bogey je.

English: 5 But my trust is in thy mercie : and my heart is joyfull in thy salvation.
Manx: 5. Agh ta my hreistéel ayns dthy vyghyn : ta my ghri gannoil ayns dthy hawálys.

English: 6 I wil sing of the Lord, because hee hath delt so lovingly with me : yea, I will praise the Name of the Lord most Highest.
Manx: 6. Goym oráyn d’ yn Chiarn, erson gy vel é ern’ ianw gho gráiygh rẃỳms : gy jarw, molyms enym yn Chiarn smw sýrje.

English: Dixit insipiens. Psal. 14.
Manx: Dixit insipiens. psal. 14.

English: The foole hath said in his heart : there is no God.
Manx: 1. Ta yn ammydan ern’ grá ayns y ghrí : ghá vel Jíh erbi.

English: 2 They are corrupt and become abominable in their doings : there is not one that doeth good (no not one).
Manx: 2. T’ ayd low̌, as er jit dwoiyól ayns nan obraghyn : gha vel anáyn ta janw mei, gha vel anáyn.

English: there is not one] 1662 there is none
Manx: dwoiyól] ms. dwoiyl

English: 3 The Lord looked downe from heaven upon the children of men : to see if there were any that would understand and seeke after God.
Manx: 3. Íàgh yn Chiarn núas vei neaw er klawn géne : dy akin ma veagh anayn erbi bálliesh twigel as sheir̀re nyre Jíh.

English: 4 But they are all gone out of the way, they are altogether become abominable : there is none that doeth good, no not one.
Manx: 4. Agh t’ áyd wlly ern’ ’ol ass y ráyd, t’ áyd wlly kwjaght er jit dwoióyl : gha vel anáyn ta janw mei, gha vel anáyn.

English: 5 Their throat is an open sepulchre, with their tongues have they deceived : the poison of aspes is under their lips.
Manx: 5. Ta nan skorniagh na ýoi foskilt, rish nan jangaghyn t’ ayd er mally : ta pwishwn aspyn fẃò nan méliyn.
skorniagh] ms. storinagh

English: 6 Their mouth is full of cursing and bitternesse : their feet are swift to shed blood.
Manx: 6. Ta nan méal láyn dy gwíaghyn as sherruid : ta nan gassyn lúa dy gýarty fẁil.

English: 7 Destruction and unhappinesse is in their wayes, and the way of peace have they not knowen : there is no feare of God before their eyes.
Manx: 7. Ta dol mow as niawghonagh ayns ny ráydjyn acksyn, as gha bawn daw ráyd yn shí : gha vel agyl erbí dy Iíh refs nan swilyn.

English: 8 Have they no knowledge, that they are all such workers of mischief : eating up my people as it were bread?
Manx: 8. Nagh vel twigel erbi acksyn, gy vel ayd wlly léid ny hobrin shen dy ghrogh red : gi shúas my phobyl mar veagh aran?

English: 9 And call not upon the Lord, there were they brought in great feare, (even where no feare was) : for God is in the generation of the righteous.
Manx: 9. As gyn géym er y Chiarn, aynshen v’ ayd er nan doyrt ayns agyl vẃar, (gy jarw yn iynyd nagh row veg yn agyl) : erson ta Jih ayns shilógh yn slĕi ghayragh.

English: And call not upon the Lord] 1662 this clause is restored to the end of v. 8, where it belongs, and was in the 1539 Great Bible.
Manx: nagh] ms. nag

English: 10 As for you, ye have made a mocke at the counsaile of the poore : because he putteth his trust in the Lord.
Manx: 10. Ass erson shiǔss[21], ta shiŭ ern’ ianw knáid er korliy yn voght : erson gy vel e toyrt y hreistéel ayns y Chiarn.

English: 11 Who shal give salvation unto Israel out of Sion? when the Lord turneth the captivitie of his people : then shall Jacob rejoyce, and Israel shall be glad.
Manx: 11. Quei ver sawálys dy Eisrael magh as Seion ? nar hyndáys yn Chiarn kapy[22] y phobyl, éish gowi Jakob bogey as bi Eisrael ganoil.

English: The iii. day.
Manx: Yn iii.la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Domine quis habitabit. Psal. 15.
Manx: Domine quis habitabit. psal. 15.

English: Lord, who shal dwell in thy tabernacle : or who shall rest upon thy holy hill?
Manx: 1. Hiarn, quei ni vaghey ayns t’ ynyd vághiys : na quei goys fe er dthy ghnock ghasserick?
t’ ynyd] ms. dthy t’ ynyd

English: 2 Even he that leadeth an uncorrupt life : and doeth the thing which is right, and speaketh the trueth from his heart.
Manx: 2. Gy jarw eshyin ta líidjéel bé glann : as ta janw yn red ta káyr, as ta lóyrt yn irin veim y ghrí.

English: 3 Hee that hath used no deceit in his tongue, nor done evill to his neighbour : and hath not slandered his neighbours.
Manx: 3. Eshyn nagh vel er klaghty malle erbi ayns y hangy, na ern’ ianw olk dâ nabẃ : as nagh vel er gwr liûn[23] er y nábwnyn.

English: neighbours] 1660 neighbor
4 He that setteth not by himselfe, but is lowly in his owne eyes : and maketh much of them that feare the Lord.
Manx: 4. Eshyn nagh vel seiaghe beg[24] je héyn, agh ta íshil ayns y hẃilyn heyn : as ta janw mẃar ĵusyn ta goyl agyl roish y Chiarn.

English: 5 He that sweareth unto his neighbour, and disappointeth him not : though it were to his owne hinderance.
Manx: 5. Eshyn ta lẃ dá nábw, as nagh vel dy vally é : gy veagh [é] gys y ghall héyn.

English: 6 He that hath not given his money upon usurie : nor taken reward against the innocent.
Manx: 6. Eshyn nagh vel er doyrt e argyt erson okyr[25] : na ern’ góyl lúagh nýoi yn er gyn loght.

English: 7 Who so doeth these things : shall never fall.
Manx: 7. Eshyn ta janw ny redyn shanoni : gha dwit e gybrágh.

English: Conserua me. Psal. 16.
Manx: Conserua me Domine. psal.16.

English: Preserve me, O God : for in thee have I put my trust.
Manx: 1. Fríal mi, O Iíh : erson aňyds ta mi er dóyrt my hreistéel.

English: 2 O my soule, thou hast said unto the Lord : thou art my God, my goods are nothing unto thee.
Manx: 2. O m’ anym, ta us ern’ ’rá rish y Chiarn : she us my Iíh, gha vel my ghwyds veg dw̌itch.

English: 3 All my delight is upon the saints that are in the earth : and upon such as excell in vertue.
Manx: 3. Ta wlly m’ agney er ny nwaghyn ta ayns y talw : as er ’an léidsyn ass ta smẃ ayns krawíyght.

English: 4 But they that run after another god : shall have great trouble.
Manx: 4. Agh áydsyn ta ry̌ei nyre jíh elle : iew ayd sýaghyn mẃar.

English: 5 Their drinke offerings of blood will I not offer : neither make mention of their names within my lips.
Manx: 5. Nan iŏgh owrel d’ w̌il, gha jeanyms y owrel : ghamẃ níym ’an enym y ymrá er chew sty̌ei dy my veliyn.

English: 6 The Lord himselfe is the portion of mine inheritance, and of my cup : thou shalt maintaine my lot.
Manx: 6. She yn Chiarn héyn arn m’ eiyrys, as dy my ghapan : kwmmyt ẃ shúas my ghranghyr.[26]

English: 7 My lot is fallen unto me in a faire ground : yea, I have a goodly heritage.
Manx: 7. Ta yn kranghyr er dwitchym hwyms ayns talw alyn : gy jarw, ta eirys mei aym.

English: My lot] 1599, 1660, 1662 The lot
8 I will thanke the Lorde for giving me warning : my reines also chasten me in the night season.
Manx: 8. Verym bwias d’ yn Chiarn erson ráw y hoyrt dŵys : ta m’ arniyn[27] níist dy my gheraghy er liés[28] ií.

English: 9 I have set God alwayes before mee : for hee is on my right hand, therefore I shall not fall.
Manx: 9. Ta mi er dóyrt Jíh gygh wlly hrá m’ enish : erson ta éshyn er my law iesh, shenyfá gha jeanym twitchym.

English: 10 Wherefore my heart was glad, and my glory rejoyced : my flesh also shall rest in hope.
Manx: 10. Krefá vá my ghri ganoil, as gow my glóyr bogey : gowi my ’eyl niíst fée ayns treisteel.
as] ms. a

English: 11 For why? thou shalt not leave my soule in hell : neither shalt thou suffer thine holy One to see corruption.
Manx: 11. Erson kamma? gha vág us m’ anym ayns niẃryin : ghamẃ ’wlliys us t’ anáyn kasserick dy akin low̌ys.
t’ anáyn] ms. ta anáyn

English: 12 Thou shalt shewe me the path of life; in thy presence is the fulnesse of joy : and at thy right hand there is pleasure for evermore.
Manx: 12. Jeaghyt us dow kassanyn ny bé; ayns t’ énish ta lanidj dy vogey : as ag dthy law iesh ta gan[30] erson gybrágh.

English: Exaudi Domine iustitiam. Psal. 17.
Manx: Exaudi Domine iuﬆitiam. psal. 17.

English: Heare the right, O Lord, consider my complaint : & hearken unto my prayer, that goeth not out of fained lips.
Manx: 1. Éyst rish yn gháyr, O Hiarn, smẃni er m’ akan : as klast rish my phadjer, nagh vel dol magh [ass] méliyn falsy.

English: 2 Let my sentence come forth from thy presence : and let thine eyes looke upon the thing that is equall.
Manx: 2. Ligg e my vrwinys chiít magh vei t’ énish : as ligg e dthy hẃilyn jeaghyn er yn red ta kor̀ym.
dthy] ms. my

English: 3 Thou hast prooved and visited mine heart in the night season; thou hast tried me, and shalt finde no wickednesse in mee : for I am utterly purposed that my mouth shall not offend.
Manx: 3. Tow er shyre magh as ern’ iaghyn my ghri ayns liêsh ny hy̌i; tow er my ’ýest[31] as gha now drogh red erbi aynym : erson ta mi láyn sowlaghy[32] nagh jean my veal loght.

English: 4 Because of mens workes that are done against the wordes of my lippes : I have kept me from the wayes of the destroyer.
Manx: 4. Erson obraghyn déne ta jeant nýoi fokelyn my véliyns : ta mi er my riâly heyn vei rádjyn yn strwialtagh.

English: my lippes] 1662 (as 1539) thy lips
5 O hold thou up my goings in thy paths : that my footsteps slip not.
Manx: 5. O kẃmm us shúas m’ imíaght ayns dthy ghassanyn : nagh skyr my ghasmedjyn.

English: 6 I have called upon thee, O God, for thou shalt heare me : encline thine eare to me, and hearken unto my words.
Manx: 6. Jei mi oýrts, O Iíh, erson klwinyt us mi : iísli dthy ghlyesh hwyms, as klast rish m’ okelyn.

English: 7 Shew thy marveilous loving kindnesse, thou that art the Saviour of them which put their trust in thee : from such as resist thy right hand.
Manx: 7. Sóilshi dthy gẃghys gráiygh ientysagh, us ta yn sawálagh acksyn ta toyrt nan dreistéel aynyds : vei léidj as ta shassw nýoi dthy law iěsh.

English: 8 Keepe mee as the apple of an eye : hide mee under the shadow of thy wings,
Manx: 8. Frial mi mar ẃyll ny sẃily : falli mi fwo ská dthy skéanyn,

English: 9 From the ungodly that trouble me : mine enemies compass me round about to take away my soule.
Manx: 9. Vei yn niawghrawi ta dy my hyaghyn : ta my noidjyn chíit krwin maŕgíỳrt ymmwm dy goyl er shiul m’ anym.

English: 10 They are inclosed in their owne fat : and their mouth speaketh proud things.
Manx: 10. T’ ayd dw̌niít schagh ayns nan rífridj heyn : as ta nan meal lóyrt redyn morniagh.
dw̌niít] ms. er dw̌niít

English: 11 They lye waiting in our way on every side : turning their eyes downe to the ground;
Manx: 11. T’ ayd ly̌ei farkiaght ayns nan rádjyn er gygh yn chew : chynda nan sẃilyn shiís gys y talw;

English: 12 Like as a Lion that is greedie of his pray : and as it were a Lions whelpe lurking in secret places.
Manx: 12. Mar lěion ta saintagh er y hélg : as mar qwellan lěion lyěi gynnys ayns ynnydyn fallíit.

English: 13 Up Lord, disappoint him, and cast him downe : deliver my soule from the ungodly, which is a sword of thine;
Manx: 13. Shúas, Hiarn, as kwrr dy liǎtty as tilg shíis e : livré m’ anym vei yn niawghráwi, ta na ghleiw lěts;

English: 14 From the men of thy hand, O Lord, from the men, I say, and from the evill world : which have their portion in this life, whose bellies thou fillest with thy hid treasure.
Manx: 14. Vei ny déne dy dthy law, O Hiarn, vei ny dene, ta mi dy grá, as vei yn drogh hýyl : ag vel ’an arn ayns y týyl shó, ny bwilg ack ta us dy liény lesh dthy haskaghyn fallíit.

English: 15 They have children at their desire : and leave the rest of their substance for their babes.
Manx: 15. Ta klawn ǎck nýre nan agney : as t’ ayd fagáel yn ghwid elle d’ an gw̌ids ghon nan glawn veggy.

English: 16 But as for me, I will behold thy presence in righteousnesse : and when I awake up after thy likenesse, I shal be satisfied with it.
Manx: 16. Agh er my hons, jeaghyms t’ enish ayns kayrys : as tra gwiskym shuas nýre dthy ghaslys, biyms bwiagh lesh.

English: The iii. day.
Manx: Yn iii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Diligam te. Psal. 18.
Manx: Diligam te. psal. 18.

English: I will love thee (O Lord) my strength; the Lord is my stony rocke, and my defence : my Saviour, my God, and my might, in whom I will trust, my buckler, the horne also of my salvation, and my refuge.
Manx: 1. Bi gráyi áym oy̌rt, O Hiarn, my gniart; she yn Chiarn my ghreg ghloi, as m’ ’er ríal : my hawálys, my Iíh, as my gniart, ayns níyms treistéel, my vwklér, yn erick[33] níist dy my hawalys, as my ghómrick.

English: 2 I will call upon the Lord, which is worthy to bee praised : so shall I bee safe from mine enemies.
Manx: 2. Éiym er y Chiarn ta fiw dy [ve] erna volley : shenmar víỳms sawchey vei my nóidjyn.

English: 3 The sorowes of death compassed me : and the overflowings of ungodlines made me afraid.
Manx: 3. Ren tryimsey yn váys chíit ymmw̌ym : as ren liény harrish yn niawghráwiys m’ aglaghy.

English: 4 The paines of hell came about me : the snares of death overtooke me.
Manx: 4. Haink pien nifrin magiyrt ymmwym : rwg[34] ribbaghyn y váys ory̌m.

English: 5 In my trouble I will call upon the Lorde : and complaine unto my God.
Manx: 5. Ayns my hyaghyn êiym er y Chiarn : as niym akan gys my Iíh.

English: 6 So shall hee heare my voice out of his holy Temple: and my complaint shall come before him, it shall enter even into his eares.
Manx: 6. Marshen ghlwinys é my ghorá magh as y hiampyl kasserick : as hig m’ akan na ienish, héyd e schiagh gy jarw ayns y ghlŷeshyn.
ghlwinys] ms. ghwinys

English: 7 The earth trembled and quaked : the very foundations also of the hilles shooke and were remooved, because hee was wroth.
Manx: 7. Va yn talw er kréaw as ren e krá : ren ny fíir ýmsynyn[35] níist ny gnwick krá, as v’ ayd er nan arraghy, erson gy row é korri.

English: 8 There went a smoke out in his presence : and a consuming fire out of his mouth, so that coales were kindled at it.
Manx: 8. Ghái jáagh magh ass y ienish : as angil strwiel magh ass y véal, marshen gy row smarágyn er nan ady ag é.

English: 9 Hee bowed the heavens also, and came downe : and it was darke under his feete.
Manx: 9. Ghrom e ny niawaghyn niíst as haink e núas : as v’ é dorghy fwo ma ghassyn.
fwo ma] ms. fwo na

English: 10 He rode upon the Cherubims and did flie : he came flying upon the wings of the winde.
Manx: 10. Varki é er ny cherwbynyn as ren é etlagh : haink e getlagh er skányn ny gy̆i.

English: 11 He made darknesse his secret place : his pavilion round about him, with darke water and thicke clouds to cover him.
Manx: 11. Ren é dorghys y ýnyd fallíit : y bẃag chymmyl magiyrt ymmish, rish wiske dorghy as bojelyn chyw dy ghẃdaghy é.

English: 12 At the brightnesse of his presence his clouds removed : hailestones and coales of fire.
Manx: 12. Ag soilshe y iénish ren y vojelyn skwghy : klaghyn snaghti, as smaragyn angil.

English: 13 The Lord also thundered out of heaven, and the Highest gave his thunder : hailestones, and coales of fire.
Manx: 13. Ren y Chiarn níist tarniagh magh ass neaw, as hwg yn fer s’ ýrje y hárniagh : klaghyn snaghty, as smarágyn angil.

English: 14 Hee sent out his arrowes, and scattered them : hee cast foorth lightnings, and destroyed them.
Manx: 14. Hwgg eshyn magh y hêidjyn as skéyl é áyd : hilg é magh chenaghyn as strẃi e áyd.
chenaghyn] ms. y chenaghyn

English: 15 The springs of waters were seene, and the foundations of the round world were discovered at thy chiding, O Lord : at the blasting of the breath of thy displeasure.
Manx: 15. Va fyrányn wisky er nan vackin, as va bwnn yn týyl ghrw̌in erna ligge rish ag dy hrodjys,[36] O Hiarn : ag séje[37] anel dy dthy iwmẃiys.

English: 16 He shal send downe from the high to fetch me : and shal take me out of many waters.
Manx: 16. Ver e núas vei yn ýrje dy my hort lesh : as gowi é mi magh ass ymmydi wiskaghyn.

English: 17 He shal deliver me from my strongest enemy, and from them which hate me : for they are too mighty for me.
Manx: 17. Ni é mish y ýasly vei my noidj stroshe, as vóùsyn ta dẃoi ack orym : erson t’ ayd róo gniartoil dẃỳs.

English: 18 They prevented mee in the day of my trouble : but the Lord was my upholder.
Manx: 18. Haink áyd m’ ýoi ayns lá my hýaghyn : agh yn Chiarn va m’ er kwmmel shúas.

English: 19 He brought mee foorth also into a place of libertie: hee brought me forth, even because he had a favour unto me.
Manx: 19. Hwg e mi magh níist gys ynyd remys : hwgg e mi magh gy jarw, erson gy row fóer agge dów.

English: 20 The Lord shall reward mee after my righteous dealing : according to the cleannesse of my handes shall he recompense me.
Manx: 20. Ni yn Chiarn my iík nyre m’ ianw kayragh : nyre glenid my lawyn ni e mish y ghwiliny.

English: 21 Because I have kept the wayes of the Lord : and have not forsaken my God as the wicked doeth.
Manx: 21. Erson gy dríal mi rádjyn yn Chiarn : as nagh vel mi er dregáèl my Iíh, mar ta yn niaw-ghrawi dy ianw.

English: 22 For I have an eye unto all his Lawes : and will not cast out his Commandements from me.
Manx: 22. Erson ta sẃil âym gys y lyěinyn wlly : as ghá dilgym magh y abyrtsyn vóỳm.

English: 23 I was also uncorrupt before him : and eschewed mine owne wickednesse.
Manx: 23. Va mi níist gyn lowys kiangóyrt rishyn : as haghyn mi vei m’ olkys heyn.

English: 24 Therefore shall the Lord reward mee after my righteous dealing : & according unto the cleannesse of my hands in his eye sight.
Manx: 24. Shenyfá iîkys yn Chiarn mi nýre m’ ianw kayragh : as nyre glenidj my lawyn ayns shilliy y hẃyly.

English: 25 With the holy, thou shalt be holy : and with a perfect man, thou shalt be perfect.
Manx: 25. Marish-syn kasserick biit us kasserick : as márish yn dwyne jiragh bíit us jíragh.

English: 26 With the cleane, thou shalt be cleane : and with the froward, thou shalt learne frowardnesse.
Manx: 26. Marish yn glan bíit us glan : as márish yn frówyrtagh ynsiyt us frowyrtys.

English: 27 For thou shalt save the people that are in adversitie : and shalt bring downe the high lookes of the proud.
Manx: 27. Erson sáwiyt us yn slyei ta ayns syaghyn : ver ẃ núas ayrd syilliaghyn ny mǒyrn.

English: 28 Thou also shalt light my candle : the Lord my God shall make my darkenes to be light.
Manx: 28. Fádait us níist my ghànil : ni yn Chiarn my Iíh my gorghys dy ve sóìlshé.

English: 29 For in thee I shall discomfit an hoste of men : and with the helpe of my God I shall leape over the wall.
Manx: 29. Erson anyds goym barriyght er maghyr dy gene : as rish kwyne my Iíh liemmym harrish y váll.
dy] ms. dé

English: 30 The way of God is an undefiled way : the word of the Lord also is tried in the fire; hee is the defender of all them that put their trust in him.
Manx: 30. Ta rayd Iíh na rayd niawloẁ : ta gẃ yn Chiarn níist erna hỳrre magh ayns yn angil; ta eshyn na ’er fríal jûsyn wlly ta toyrt nan dreistéel aynsyn.

English: 31 For who is God, but the Lord : or who hath any strength except our God?
Manx: 31. Erson quei ta Jíh agh yn Chiarn : na quei ag ta gníart erbi, agh yn Jíh âin?

English: 32 It is God that girdeth mee with strength of warre: and maketh my way perfect.
Manx: 32. She Jíh ta dy my haǹy[38] rish gniart kagey : as ta janw my ráyd jíragh.

English: 33 Hee maketh my feete like harts feete : and setteth mee up on high.
Manx: 33. T’ e janw my ghassyn mar kassyn fieǔẏ[39] : as dy my hêiaghe shuas er yrjid.

English: 34 He teacheth mine hands to fight : and mine armes shall breake even a bow of steel.
Manx: 34. T’ e gýnsaghy my lawyn dy ghágy : as brishi my ríaghyn gy jarw bow stàlyn.

English: 35 Thou hast given me the defence of thy salvation : thy right hand also shall holde mee up, and thy loving correction shall make me great.
Manx: 35. Tow er doyrt dow frial dy dthy hawálys : kwmmi dthy law iesh níist mi shúas, as ni dthy gherygh grayiẃyl m’y ianw mẃar.

English: 36 Thou shalt make roume ynough under me for to goe : that my footesteps shall not slide.
Manx: 36. Ni us ianw rẃym galiór foŷm dy imíaght : nagh skyr my ghassmedjyn.

English: 37 I wil follow upon mine enemies, and overtake them : neither wil I turne againe till I have destroyed them.
Manx: 37. Eiyrym er my nóidjyn, as berrym ǒrow : ghamw hyndáym ríist naggydere víỳm er nan gwr mow áyd.

English: 38 I will smite them, that they shall not be able to stand : but fall under my feete.
Manx: 38. Boelym áyd, nagh bi áyd foundagh dy hassw : agh twytchym fwo my ghassyn.

English: 39 Thou hast girded mee with strength unto the battell : thou shalt throw downe mine enemies under me.
Manx: 39. Tow er my haǹney rish gniart gys y ghagey : tilgit [w] shíis my noidjyn fẃoym.

English: 40 Thou hast made mine enemies also to turne their backs upon me : and I shall destroy them that hate me.
Manx: 40. Tow er doyrt er my nóidjyn níist nan ’ry̌im y hynda ořyms : as kwrrym mow aydsyn ta dẃoi ack orym.

English: 41 They shal cry, but there shal be none to help them : yea, even unto the Lord shal they cry, but he shal not heare them.
Manx: 41. Éi aydsyn, agh gha bí anáyn dy ghẃyne liêu : gy jarw gys y Chiarn éiys ayd, agh gha glwin e áyd.
glwin] ms. ghwin

English: 42 I wil beat them as smal as the dust before the winde : I will cast them out as the clay in the streets.
Manx: 42. Bóìelym áyd gho mynn ass jàn raeyfs yn gye : tilgym magh áyd mar yn ghre ayns ny stradjyn.

English: 43 Thou shalt deliver mee from the strivings of the people : and thou shalt make me the head of the heathen.
Manx: 43. Livréyt us mish vei striyf yn phobyl : as ni us mish my ghian dy ny hangristíin.

English: 44 A people whom I have not knowen : shall serve me.
Manx: 44. Pobyl nagh baun dow : ni ayd mish y hyrvés.

English: 45 Assoone as they heare of me, they shall obey mee: but the strange children shall dissemble with me.
Manx: 45. Ghó lúe ass ghlwinys áyd jîms, ver ayd arym dow̌ : agh ni yn ghlawn jori brynryght rẃỳm.

English: 46 The strange children shall faile : and bee afraid out of their prisons.
Manx: 46. Ni yn ghlawn jori nardẏ y hóyrt : as bi áyd aglagh magh ass nan brisẃnyn.

English: 47 The Lord liveth, and blessed bee my strong helper : and praised be the God of my salvation;
Manx: 47. Ta yn Chiarn bio, as báníit gy row m’ ’er kẃyne ládjer : as molíit gy row Jíh my hawálys;

English: 48 Even the God that seeth that I be avenged : and subdueth the people unto me.
Manx: 48. Gy jarw yn Jih ta fakkin gy biym kwilínit rish my nóidjyn : as ta toyrt yn phobyl fóỳms.

English: 49 It is he that delivereth me from my (cruel) enemies, and setteth me up above mine adversaries : thou shalt rid me from the wicked man.
Manx: 49. She eshyn ta dy my lifré vei my nóidjyn diêwyl, as dy my heiaghe shuas er nan skiyn-syn ta m’ y̌eis : ni us mish y reaghy vei yn drogh ’wỳne.

English: 50 For this cause wil I give thanks unto thee (O Lord) among the Gentiles : and sing praises unto thy Name.
Manx: 50. Erson yn oer sho věrym bwias dw̌itch, O Hiarn, masky ny hangristín : as góym orányn moli gys t’ enym.

English: 51 Great prosperitie giveth he unto his King : and sheweth loving kindness unto David his anoynted, and unto his seed for evermore.
Manx: 51. Bishagh mẃar t’ e dy hoyrt dâ ry̌i : as soilshaghy dwiys graiygh dy Gavid y ’er àlit,[40] as dâ rass erson gybragh.

English: The iiii. day.
Manx: Yn iiii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Cœli enarrant. Psal. 19.
Manx: Cœli enarrant. psal. 19.

English: The heavens declare the glory of God : and the firmament sheweth his handy worke.
Manx: 1. Ta ny néàwaghyn jinsh[41] gloer Iíh : as yn áer soilshaghe obeyr y lawyn.

English: 2 One day telleth another : and one night certifieth another.
Manx: 2. Ta yn lá gynsh dy lá elle : as yn y̌i toyrt fyss d’ y̌i elle,

English: 3 There is neither speech nor language : but their voyces are heard among them.
Manx: 3. Gha vel taglw na gláyr : agh ta nan góraghyn erna ghlastchyn nan masky.

English: 4 Their sound is gone out into all landes : and their wordes into the endes of the world.
Manx: 4. Ta yn fýer ack ern’ ól magh gys gygh wlly hálw : as ’an goyn gys kíin yn týyl.

English: 5 In them hath he set a tabernacle for the Sunne : which commeth foorth as a bridegrome out of his chamber, and rejoyceth as a Giant to runne his course.
Manx: 5. Ayndŵsyn t’ e er seiaghe tent eglwish ghon y gríany : ta chíit magh mar dwyne pẃst magh ass y hyambyr, as góyl bogey mar fowr dy ry̌i y ghws.[42]

English: 6 It goeth foorth from the uttermost part of the heaven, and runneth about unto the end of it againe : and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof.
Manx: 6. Te dol magh vei yn arn sojemagh d’ yn neaw, as ryi margiyrt gys yn ghian agge ríist : as gha vel veg fallíit vei yn chass agge.

English: 7 The Law of the Lord is an undefiled law, converting the soule : the testimonie of the Lord is sure, and giveth wisedome unto the simple.
Manx: 7. Ta ly̌ei yn Chiarn ly̌ei glan, chyndá yn anym : ta fienysh yn Chiarn sickyr, as toyrt krinyght d’ yn ’ier imbli.

English: 8 The Statutes of the Lord are right, and rejoyce the heart : the Commandement of the Lord is pure, and giveth light unto the eyes.
Manx: 8. Ta slattysyn yn Chiarn j́iragh, as janw bogey d’ yn ghri : ta abeyrts yn Chiarn glann, as toyrt sóilshe dy ny swylyn.

English: 9 The feare of the Lord is cleane, and endureth for ever : the Judgements of the Lord are true and righteous altogether.
Manx: 9. Ta agyl yn Chiarn glan, as faraghtyn erson gybrágh : ta brwinys yn Chiarn firrinagh, as kayragh wlly kwjaght.

English: 10 More to be desired are they then golde, yea, then much fine gold : sweeter also then honie, and the honie combe.
Manx: 10. Nasmw dy ve er nan shirre ta áydsyn na aur, gy jarw, na mwarayn d’ aúr glan : náss milshe níist na mil, as y ghiyr vàlly.
mwarayn] ms. mwrayan

English: 11 Moreover, by them is thy servant taught : and in keeping of them there is great reward.
Manx: 11. Harrish shen, lioríùsyn ta dthy hervaynt ynsíit : as ayns frial acksyn ta lúagh vwar.

English: 12 Who can tell how oft he offendeth : O cleanse thou me from my secret faults.
Manx: 12. Quei ’odys y insh kre ghomenick te janw loghtyn ? O glan us mish vei m’ ’oilchyn fallíit.

English: 13 Keepe thy servant also from presumptuous sinnes, lest they get the dominion over mee : so shall I be undefiled, and innocent from the great offence.
Manx: 13. Fréyl dthy herváynt níist vei pekaghyn roo danagh,[43] nagh vow ayd barriyght hařrym : shen-mar víỳms glan, as gyn loght vei yn pheka vẃar.

English: 14 Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart : be alway acceptable in thy sight,
Manx: 14. Ligg e goyn my véayl, as smẃnaghtyn my ghrí : vé gygh wlly hrá bẃiasoil ayns dthy hilliys,

English: 15 O Lord : my strength, and my Redeemer.
Manx: 15. O Hiarn : my gniart as m’ ’er kani ríist.

English: Exaudiat te Dominus. Psal. 20.
Manx: Exaudiat te Dominus. psal. 20.

English: The Lord heare thee in the day of trouble : the Name of the God of Jacob defend thee;
Manx: 1. Yn Chiarn dy dthy ghlastchyns ayns la yn syaghyn : enym Iíh Iakob dy dthy rials;

English: 2 Send thee helpe from the Sanctuary : and strength thee out of Sion;
Manx: 2. Dy hoyrt hwyds kẃyne vei yn iynyd kasserick : as dy dthy gniartaghy magh ass Seion;

English: strength] 1660 strengthen
3 Remember all thy offerings : and accept thy burnt sacrifice;
Manx: 3. Dy ghẃinaghtyn er t’ owrelyn wlly : as dy góyl gy mei rish t’ owrelyn losk;

English: 4 Grant thee thy hearts desire : and fulfill all thy minde.
Manx: 4. Dy ialtyn dwitch agne dthy ghri : as dy líèny t’ agne wlly.

English: 5 Wee will rejoyce in thy salvation, and triumph in the Name of the Lord our God : the Lord performe all thy petitions.
Manx: 5. Gow měid bogey ayns dthy hawálys, as barriyght ayns enym yn Chiarn nan Iíh : yn Chiarn dy ghwiliny t’ aghyns wlly.
aghyns] ms. aghnys

English: 6 Now know I that the Lord helpeth his anointed, and will heare him from his holy heaven : even with the wholesome strength of his right hand.
Manx: 6. Nish ta fyss aŷms gy vel yn Chiarn kwyne lesh y ’er àlit, as gy glwyn e eshyn vei ma neaw kasserick : gy jarw rish gniart slaintóil y law iesh.

English: 7 Some put their trust in charets, and some in horses : but we will remember the Name of the Lord our God.
Manx: 7. Ta payrt tóyrt nan dreistéel ayns charedyn, as payrt ayns kabil : agh kwini medjyn er enym yn Chiarn narn[44] Iíh.

English: 8 They are brought downe and fallen : but we are risen, and stand upright.
Manx: 8. T’ aydsyn er nan doyrt núas as er dwitchym : agh ta shwiniyn ern’ iri as shassw jiragh.

English: 9 Save Lord, and heare us, O King of heaven : when we call upon thee.
Manx: 9. Saw, Hiarn, as klast rẃìn, O ríi neaw : tra ta shwin gemagh oy̌rts.

English: Domine in virtute. Psal. 21.
Manx: Domine in virtute. psal. 21.

English: The King shall rejoyce in thy strength, O Lord : exceeding glad shall he be of thy salvation.
Manx: 1. Gowi yn ríi bogey ayns dthy gniaŕt, O Hiarn : fíir iannoil víis e dy dthy hawálys.

English: 2 Thou hast given him his hearts desire : and hast not denied him the request of his lips.
Manx: 2. Tow er doyrt dâ agney y ghrí : as gha dobb w da aghein y veliyn.

English: 3 For thou shalt prevent him with the blessings of goodnesse : and shalt set a Crowne of pure golde upon his head.
Manx: 3. Erson ver w dâsyn rêyf law banaght yn věiys : as ver w attaghyn d’ aúr glan er y ghiansyn.

English: 4 Hee asked life of thee, and thou gavest him a long life : even for ever and ever.
Manx: 4. Hy̌ir e sýyl oyrts, as hwgg w dâ sýyl fodey : erson gybrágh as gybragh.

English: 5 His honour is great in thy Salvation : glorie and great worship shalt thou lay upon him.
Manx: 5. Ta yn onyr aggesyn mẃar ayns dthy hawálys : glóyr as ammys vwar ver us ersyn.

English: 6 For thou shalt give him everlasting felicitie : and make him glad with the joy of thy countenance.
Manx: 6. Erson ver us dâsyn maynrys gybragh : as ni us eshyn gannoil rish bogey t’ edyns.

English: 7 And why? because the King putteth his trust in the Lord : and in the mercie of the most Highest he shall not miscarie.
Manx: 7. As kamma? erson gy vel yn ríi ta tóyrt y hreistéel ayns y Chiarn : as ayns myghin yn smw sýrje, gha jean é skirr.
ta] ms. tr

English: 8 All thine enemies shall feele thine hand : thy right hand shall finde out them that hate thee.
Manx: 8. Áni[45] wlly dthy nóidjyns dthy law : iew dthy law iesh magh aydsyn ta dwoi ack oyrts.

English: 9 Thou shalt make them like a fiery oven in time of thy wrath : the Lord shall destroy them in his displeasure, and the fire shall consume them.
Manx: 9. Ni us aydsyn kasly rish óygh angilagh ayns iérish dy ghori : ni yn Chiarn aydsyn y strẃiel ayns y iwmẃiys, as ni yn angil ’an doyrt mow áyd.

English: 10 Their fruit shalt thou root out of the earth : and their seed from among the children of men.
Manx: 10. Rowryt us yn meass acksyn magh as y tallw : as nan rass vei masky klawn géne.

English: 11 For they intended mischiefe against thee : and imagined such a device as they are not able to performe.
Manx: 11. Erson ren áyd olk y howlaghy t’ yěiys : as smwni áyd léid y sáys ass nagh vel ayd fowndagh y ghwiliny.

English: 12 Therefore shalt thou put them to flight : & the strings of thy bow shalt thou make ready against the face of them.
Manx: 12. Shenyfá ver w oriusyn ché : as ni us arlw strengyn dy vow nyoi yn edyn acksyn.

English: 13 Be thou exalted Lord in thine owne strength : so will we sing and praise thy power.
Manx: 13. Bi us trogit shúas, Hiarn, ayns dthy gniart héyn : shen mar gow meid orayn as vol meid dthy phwer.

English: The iiii. day.
Manx: Yn iiii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Deus, Deus meus. Psal. 22.
Manx: Deus deus meus. psal. 22.

English: My God, my God (look upon mee) why hast thou forsaken mee : and art so farre from my health, and from the words of my complaint?
Manx: 1. My Iíh, my Iíh, jeagh oryms; kámma vel us er my hreigéel : as ghoud ass y ráyd vei my láint, as vei fokelyn m’ akans?

English: 2 O my God, I cry in the day time, but thou hearest not : and in the night season also I take no rest.
Manx: 2. O my Iih, ta mi gémagh ayns iérish y lá, agh gha vel us klastcheyn : as er léys ny hy̌i níist gha vel mi goyl veg yn ’é.

English: 3 And thou continuest holy : O thou worship of Israel.
Manx: 3. As tow us fanaghtyn kasserick : O us ýasly Eisrael.

English: 4 Our fathers hoped in thee : they trusted in thee, and thou diddest deliver them.
Manx: 4. Ren nan aéraghyn treistéel anyds : hreist áyd ǎynyds, as lifré us áyd.

English: 5 They called upon thee, and were holpen : they put their trust in thee, and were not confounded.
Manx: 5. Jěi áyd oy̌rts, as fóyr ayd kẃyne : hwgg ayd nan dreistéel anyds, as gha row ayd er nan gwr moẃ.

English: 6 But as for me, I am a worme, & no man : a very scorne of men, and the outcast of the people.
Manx: 6. Agh er my hons, shé bestchieg mi, as ghanie dwyne : fíir knaid dy géne, as bonlyght d’ yn phobyl.

English: 7 All they that see me, laugh me to scorne : they shoot out their lips, and shake their heads, saying,
Manx: 7. Aydsyn wlly híi mi, t’ ayd knaid ymmwm geraghti : t’ ayd shiney magh nan méliyn, as krá nan gian, grá,

English: 8 He trusted in God, that hee would deliver him : let him deliver him, if he will have him.
Manx: 8. Hréist e ayns Jíh, gy lifréagh eshyn é : ligg e y lifre é, my salliesh ve agge e.

English: 9 But thou art hee that tooke mee out of my mothers wombe : thou wast my hope, when I hanged yet upon my mothers breasts.
Manx: 9. Agh she us eshyn gow mish magh as brẃ my váyry : va us my hreistéel [...][47] fóyst er kíaghyn my váyrey.

English: 10 I have bene left unto thee ever since I was borne: thou art my God, even from my mothers wombe.
Manx: 10. Va mi er m’ agél dw̌itch riu ada rwg mi : she us my Iíh, gy jarw vei brẃ my váyry.

English: 11 O go not fro me, for trouble is hard at hand : and there is none to helpe me.
Manx: 11. O na gow vóỳms, erson ta twilliel argere ag láw : as gha vel veg dy ghẃne layms.

English: 12 Many oxen are come about mee : fat Bulles of Basan close me in on every side.
Manx: 12. Ta ymmydi dy geyf er jít mágiyrt ymmwyms : ta terywf rawry Vasan dy my gwiny schiagh er gygh yn cheyf.
gwiny] ms. ghwiny

English: 13 They gape upon me with their mouthes : as it were a ramping and a roaring Lion.
Manx: 13. T’ ayd foskely rǎnn[48] meillyn ory̌ms : mar véagh léion rapy as bwrriwgh.
meillyn] ms. melilyn

English: 14 I am powred out like water, and all my bones are out of joynt : my heart also in the middest of my body is even like melting waxe.
Manx: 14. Ta mi diêrtid magh mar wisky; ta my ghnawyn wlly ass yn ynyd : ta my ghri niist ayns méan my ghorp gy jarw kasly rish kéeir liêy.

English: 15 My strength is dried up like a potsheard, & my tongue cleaveth to my gummes : and thou shalt bring mee into the dust of death.
Manx: 15. Ta my gniart chyrmẏt shúas mar [stẃckan] dy ghrackan[49], as ta my hiange lianaghtyn gys my grauntyn[50] : as ver us mish gys jan yn váys.

English: 16 For (many) dogs are come about me : and the counsell of the wicked layeth siege against me.
Manx: 16. Erson ta ymmydi madi er jít magíyrt ymmw̌ym : as ta kowrley y niawghráwi ern’ ẃne[51] m’ ýoi.

English: 17 They pearced my hands, and my feete; I may tell all my bones : they stand staring and looking upon me.
Manx: 17. Hoẃl ayd my lawyn as my ghassyn, fodym my ghnawyn wlly y éryf : t’ áyd shassw giyndys as jaghyn orryms.

English: 18 They part my garments among them : and cast lots upon my vesture.
Manx: 18. T’ ayd réyn m’ ydagh nan másky : as tilge kráňghryn er my ghómrey.

English: 19 But be not thou farre from me, O Lord : thou art my succour, haste thee to helpe me.
Manx: 19. Agh ná bí us fodey voyms, O Hiarn : she us m’ aski,[52] jean séir dy ghẃyney láỳm.

English: 20 Deliver my soule from the sword : my darling from the power of the dogge.
Manx: 20. Lifré m’ anym vei yn ghliěw : my gráyi vei pẃyr yn vǒaddy.

English: 21 Save me from the Lions mouth : thou hast heard me also from among the hornes of the Unicornes.
Manx: 21. Saw mi vei béal yn lěion : ghýyl us mish níist vei masky érikyn běiyn yn-erick.

English: 22 I will declare thy Name unto my brethren : in the middest of the Congregation will I praise thee.
Manx: 22. Ínsiym t’ enyms dy my vraeraghyn : ayns meyn ny heglwis mollyms us.

English: 23 O praise the Lord ye that feare him : magnifie him all ye of the seed of Jacob, and feare him all ye seed of Israel;
Manx: 23. O molligi yn Chiarn, shiusse ta goyl agyl réfsyn : glorigi gy mẃar é, shiusse wlly dy rass Iákob, as gowgi agil réfsyn, shiusse wlly rass israel.

English: 24 For he hath not despised nor abhorred the low estate of the poore; he hath not hid his face from him : but when he called unto him, he heard him.
Manx: 24. Erson gha vel e er seiaghe beg na er doyrt dwoi dy stáid ishill yn voght, gha dalli e y edyn vei : agh tra jei é er, ghýyl eshyn é.

English: 25 My praise is of thee in the great Congregation : my vowes will I performe in the sight of them that feare him.
Manx: 25. Ta my voley iíds ayns y chessiaght vẃar : my vríeraghyn niyms y ghwilíny nan veanish-syn ta goyl agyl refsyn.

English: 26 The poore shall eate and be satisfied : they that seeke after the Lord, shall praise him; your heart shall live for ever.
Manx: 26. Ni ny boghtyn íi, as bi ayd bwíagh : aydsyn ta shirre nyre yn Chiarn, moli áyd é; bi nan gri bió gybragh.

English: 27 All the ends of the world shall remember themselves, and be turned unto the Lord : and all the kinreds of the nations shall worship before him.
Manx: 27. Kwini kíin wlly yn týyl orw heyn, as bi ayd er nan jyndá gys y Chiarn : as ni kiynnaghyn wlly ny natiẃnyn ammys kiangóyrt rish-syn.

English: 28 For the kingdome is the Lords : and hee is the governour among the people.
Manx: 28. Sh’ lesh yn Chiarn yn riríyght : as shé eshyn kianẃrtys masky yn phobyl.

English: 29 All such as be fat upon earth : have eaten & worshipped.
Manx: 29. Yn leidsyn wlly ta ráwr er y talw : t’ áyd ern’ íì as ern’ ianw ammys.

English: 30 All they that go downe into the dust shall kneele before him : and no man hath quickened his owne soule.
Manx: 30. Aydsyn wlly ta dol shíis gys yn jan, níi ayd sliaghty[53] kiangóyrt rishsyn : as gha vel dẁyne erbi er mióghey y anym héyn.

English: 31 My seed shall serve him : they shall be counted unto the Lord for a generation.
Manx: 31. Ni my rass eshyn y hyrvées : bi ayd er nan érw d’ yn Chiarn erson shilogh.

English: 32 They shall come, and the heavens shall declare his righteousnesse : unto a people that shall be borne, whom the Lord hath made.
Manx: 32. Hig aydsyn, as insi ny neawaghyn yn gháyrys agge-syn : gys pobyl víis er an mré, ta yn Chiarn erna ianw.

English: Dominus regit me. Psal. 23.
Manx: Dominus regit me. psal. 23.

English: The Lord is my Shepheard : therefore can I lacke nothing.
Manx: 1. She yn Chiarn my voghily keragh : shenyfá gha vod feim ve aym er red erbi.

English: 2 He shall feed me in a greene pasture : and lead me forth beside the waters of comfort.
Manx: 2. Ni é my véaghey ayns pastyr glass : as liédji é mi magh rish liětty ny hwisskaghyn dy gyrjaghey.
my véaghey] ms. mi véaghey

English: 3 He shall convert my soule : and bring mee foorth in the paths of righteousnesse for his Names sake.
Manx: 3. Chyndai é m’ anym : as ver e magh mi ayns kassanyn ny káyrys, erson gráyi y enym.

English: 4 Yea though I walke thorow the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evill : for thou art with mee; thy rod and thy staffe comfort me.
Manx: 4. Gy jarw, ga ta mi gimíaght tryid kóyn dy ská yn váys, gha góym agil d’ olk erbi : erson ta us mârym, ta dthy ’latt as dthy loyrg dy my gyrjaghy.

English: 5 Thou shalt prepare a Table before mee against them that trouble mee : thou hast anointed my head with oile, and my cup shal be full.
Manx: 5. Ni us arlw boŷrd rẃỳms nan yoisyn ta dy my húa[54] : tóẁs ern’ ally[55] my ghian rish ẃil, as bi my ghapan láyn.

English: 6 But thy loving kindenesse and mercy shall follow mee all the dayes of my life : and I will dwell in the house of the Lord for ever.
Manx: 6. Agh êìri dthy gẃghys graigwill as dthy vyghin mish wlly lághyn my hýyl : as niym vághey ayns těi yn Chiarn erson gybragh.
êìri] ms. ni êìri; gẃghys] ms. ghẃghys

English: The v. day.
Manx: Yn v. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Aryn.

English: Domini est terra. Psal. 24.
Manx: Domini est terra. psal. 24.

English: The earth is the Lords, and all that therein is : the compasse of the world, and they that dwell therein.
Manx: 1. Sh’ lesh yn Chiarn yn talw, as wlly na ta ayn : kymshén yn týyl, as aydsyn ta vaghey aynsyn.

English: 2 For he hath founded it upon the Seas : and prepared it upon the floods.
Manx: 2. Erson hei eshyn é er ny farkaghyn : as ren é arlw é er ny twillaghyn.

English: 3 Who shall ascend into the hill of the Lord : or who shal rise up in his holy place?
Manx: 3. Quei héid shúas gys knock yn Chiarn : na quei irriys shuas ayns y ynyd-syn kasserick?

English: 4 Even he that hath cleane hands, and a pure heart : and that hath not lift up his minde unto vanitie, nor sworne to deceive his neighbour.
Manx: 4. Gy jarw eshynn ag vel lawyn glan, as krí gyn loght : as nagh vel er drogel shuas y agne gys fardálys, na er lẃ dy vàley y nábw.

English: 5 Hee shall receive the blessing from the Lord: and righteousnesse from the God of his salvation.
Manx: 5. Iew eshyn yn banaght vei yn Chiarn : as káyrys vei Jíh y hawálys.

English: 6 This is the generation of them that seeke him : even of them that seeke thy face, O Jacob.
Manx: 6. She sho y hilóỳgh acksyn ta dy hyrresyn : gy jarw jûsyn ta shyrre t’ edyns, O Iakob.

English: 7 Lift up your heads, O yee gates, and bee ye lift up yee everlasting doores : and the King of glory shall come in.
Manx: 7. Trogigi shúas nan gìín, O shiusse iattyn, as bigi trogit shuas, shiusse gorrysyn ta farraghtyn gybrágh : as hig ríi yn glóyr schiagh.

English: 8 Who is the King of glory : it is the Lord strong and mightie, even the Lord mighty in battell.
Manx: 8. Quei ta ríi yn gloyr ? she yn Chiarn laidjer as gniartoil, gy jarw yn Chiarn gniártoil ayns kagey.

English: 9 Lift up your heads, O yee gates, and be ye lift up yee everlasting doores : and the King of glory shall come in.
Manx: 9. Trogigi shuas nan gìín, O shiusse iattyn, as bigi trogit shuas, shiusse gorryssyn ta farraghtyn gybrágh : as hig ríi yn glóyr schiagh.

English: 10 Who is the King of glory : even the Lord of hostes, he is the King of glory.
Manx: 10. Quei ta ríi yn glóyr ? gy jarw Chiarn ny shessaghtyn ghagi, she eshyn ríi ny gloyr.
shessaghtyn] ms. shessaghyn

English: Ad te Domine. Psal. 25.
Manx: Ad te domine. psal. 25.

English: Unto thee, O Lord, will I lift up my soule; my God, I have put my trust in thee : O let mee not be confounded, neither let mine enemies triumph over me.
Manx: 1. Hwyds, O Hiarn, hrogym shúas m’ anym; my Iíh, ta mi er doyrt my hreistéel anyds : O na lig dow ve er my ghàl, namẃ lig dy my nóidjyn barriyght y góyl harrymm.

English: 2 For all they that hope in thee shal not be ashamed : but such as transgresse without a cause, shall be put to confusion.
Manx: 2. Erson áydsyn wlly ta treistéel anyd, gha bi áyd er ’an náraghy : agh yn leidsyn as ta janw peke gyn óeyr, bi ayd er nan gwrr moẃ.
’an náraghy] ms. an’ áraghy

English: 3 Shew mee thy wayes, O Lord : and teach mee thy paths.
Manx: 3. Jeagh dow dthy ráydjyn, O Hiarn : as ynsi dow dthy ghassanyn.

English: 4 Leade me forth in thy trueth, and learne me : for thou art the God of my salvation; in thee hath bene my hope all the day long.
Manx: 4. Líid mi magh ayns t’ irrinys, as ynsi mi : erson she us Jíh my hawálys; ányds va my hreistéel fei yn lá liáur.

English: 5 Call to remembrance, O Lord, thy tender mercies : and thy loving-kindnesse which hath been ever of old.
Manx: 5. Éi gys kwinaghtyn, O Hiarn, dthy vyghin mú[56] : as dthy gheindylys grayiwil va rîu ada yn chen iérish.

English: kindenesse which hath] 1662 kindnesses which have
6 Oh remember not the sinnes and offences of my youth : but according to thy mercie thinke thou upon mee, O Lord, for thy goodnesse.
Manx: 6. O na kwini er peke as loghtyn m’ ágid : agh nyre dthy hrokeryght smwni us oryms, O Hiarn, erson dthy veiys.
erson] ms. ersoy

English: 7 Gracious and righteous is the Lord : therefore wil he teach sinners in the way.
Manx: 7. Ta yn Chiarn grasóil as káyr : shenyfá ýnsiys [e] peki ayns y ráyd.

English: 8 Them that be meeke shal he guide in Judgement : and such as be gentle, them shall he learne his way.
Manx: 8. Aydsyn ta míin ni e líidjél ayns brẃinys : as yn léidsyn ta míin, dawsyn yinsi e y ráyd.

English: be meeke] 1662 are meek; be gentle] 1662 are gentle
9 All the pathes of the Lord are mercie and trueth : unto such as keepe his covenant and his testimonies.
Manx: 9. Ta wlly ráydjyn yn Chiarn myghin as firrinys : d’ an léidsyn ass ta frial y ghwnáynt as rikóyrtyn.

English: 10 For thy Names sake, O Lord : bee mercifull unto my sinne, for it is great.
Manx: 10. Erson grayi t’ enym, O Hiarn : bi myghinagh dy my pheky, erson t’ e mwar.

English: 11 What man is hee that feareth the Lord : him shall hee teach in the way that he shall choose.
Manx: 11. Quei yn dẃyne ta goyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn : eshyn ni é y ynsaghy ayns y ráyd ni é y ry̌ei.

English: 12 His soule shal dwel at ease : & his seed shall inherit the land.
Manx: 12. Ni y anym vaghey ag éish : as iew y rass eiryght áyns y tálw.
áyns] ms. áyn

English: 13 The secret of the Lord is among them that feare him : and he will shew them his Covenant.
