Manx: 13. Ta fálliyght yn Chiarn nan maskysyn ta goyl agyl réyf : as soilshi é dawsyn y ghẃnáynt.

English: 14 Mine eyes are ever looking unto the Lord : for he shall plucke my feet out of the net.
Manx: 14. Ta my hẃilyn gybrágh jeaghyn gys y Chiarn : erson tarni e my ghassyn magh ass y lién.

English: 15 Turne thee unto me, and have mercie upon me : for I am desolate and in miserie.
Manx: 15. Chyndá us hwyms, as jean myghin orym : erson ta mi trégit as ayns boghtanys.

English: 16 The sorrowes of my heart are enlarged : O bring thou me out of my troubles.
Manx: 16. [Ta] trimshẏ my ghri erna ligge magh : O toyr us mi magh ass my heaghyn.

English: 17 Looke upon mine adversitie and miserie : and forgive me all my sinne.
Manx: 17. Jeagh er my hýaghyn as er my voghtanyght : as ly̌oi daw my pheky wlly.

English: 18 Consider mine enemies how many they are : and they beare a tyrannous hate against me.
Manx: 18. Smwni er my nóidjyn kaẃod t’ ayd : as t’ ayd gymmyrke rẃn[57] tréyn[58] m’ ýoi.

English: 19 O keepe my soul, and deliver me : let mee not bee confounded, for I have put my trust in thee.
Manx: 19. O fríal my anym, as lifré mi : na lig dow ve er my ghwr mow, erson ta mi er doyrt my hreistéel ay̌nyds.

English: 20 Let perfectness and righteous dealing waite upon me : for my hope hath bene in thee.
Manx: 20. Ligg e fir̀rinys as déllel káyr farkiaght oryms : erson ta my hreistéel er mé ay̌nyds.

English: 21 Deliver Israel, O God : out of all his troubles.
Manx: 21. Lifré Israel, O Iíh : magh ass y hyaghyn wlly.

English: Iudica me Domine. Psal. 26.
Manx: Iudica me Domine. psal. 26.

English: Be thou my Judge, O Lord, for I have walked innocently : my trust hath bene also in the Lord, therfore shal I not fall.
Manx: 1. Bi us my vriẃ, O Hiarn, erson ta mi ern’ immiaght gyn loght : ta my hreistéel er mé níist ayns y Chiarn, shennyfá gha dwitchym.

English: 2 Examine me, O Lord, and proove mee : try out my reines and my heart.
Manx: 2. Feyst mi, O Hiarn, as ransi mi : shiyr magh m’ ayraghyn as my ghrí.

English: 3 For thy loving kindnesse is ever before mine eyes : and I wil walke in thy trueth.
Manx: 3. Erson ta dthy gheindylys grayigoil gybragh kiangoyrt rish my hwylyn : as niym immiaght ayns t’ ir̀rinys.

English: 4 I have not dwelt with vaine persons : neither wil I have fellowship with the deceitfull.
Manx: 4. Gha nel mi er me vaghey marish sly̌i fardalagh : ghamẃ víis shessaght aym rish yn klyei valtoil.

English: 5 I have hated the congregation of the wicked : and will not sit among the ungodly.
Manx: 5. Hwg mi fúa d’ yn chymsaghy kwijaght dy grogh hessiaght : as ghá jeanym sy̌i masky yn niawghráwi.

English: 6 I wil wash mine hands in innocencie, O Lord : and so will I goe to thine Altar;
Manx: 6. Níỳm my lawyn ayns glénid, O Hiarn : as marshen hiŷm gys t’ altyr;

English: 7 That I may shew the voyce of thankesgiving : and tell of all thy wonderous workes.
Manx: 7. Gy vodym y ghwrr magh korá dy hoyrt bẃias : as inss dy dthy obraghyn ientysagh wlly.

English: 8 Lord, I have loved the habitation of thy house : and the place where thine honour dwelleth.
Manx: 8. Hiarn, ta mi er doyrt gráyi [er ... ][59] dy hyěi : as d’ yn iynyd ta t’ onyr vaghey.

English: 9 O shut not up my soule with the sinners : nor my life with the bloodthirstie;
Manx: 9. O na jég shuas my anym márish ny peki : na my vé mariûsyn ta páagh nyrg fẁil;

English: 10 In whose hands is wickednes : and their right hands are full of gifts.
Manx: 10. Ayns ny lawyn acksyn ta olkys : as ta ny lawyn jésh acksyn layn dy hóyrtysyn.

English: 11 But as for mee, I will walke innocently : O Lord deliver me and be mercifull unto me.
Manx: 11. Agh er my hons, im̌miym gyn loght : O Hiarn, fýàskyl mi, as bi láyn vyghinagh dẃỳs.

English: 12 My foote standeth right : I wil praise the Lord in the Congregations.
Manx: 12. Ta my [ghass] shassw jíragh : mallym yn Chiarn ayns ny haglishyn.

English: The v. day.
Manx: Yn v. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Dominus illuminatio. Psal. 27.
Manx: Dominus illuminatio. psal. 27.

English: The Lord is my light & my salvation; whom then shal I feare : the Lord is the strength of my life; of whom then shall I be afraid?
Manx: 1. She yn Chiarn my hoilshe as my hawálys; quei réỳfs eish góỳms agyl ? she yn Chiarn gniart my vé; quei íè eish viyms aglagh?
réỳfs] ms. réỳss

English: 2 When the wicked (even mine enemies and my foes) came upon mee to eat up my flesh : they stumbled and fell.
Manx: 2. Nar háink yn niawghráwi, gy jarw, my noidjyn as my niawghárjyn orym dy íi shuas my éyl : skir áyd as hwitch áyd.

English: 3 Though an hoste of men were layd against me, yet shal not my heart bee afraide : and though there rose up war against me, yet wil I put my trust in him.
Manx: 3. Gy véagh sheshiaght ghagi sy̌it m’ ýoi, fóyst gha bi my ghri aglagh : as gy ’irriagh shuas kagey my ýoi, fóst verym my hreistéel aynsyn.

English: 4 One thing have I desired of the Lord, which I will require : even that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the dayes of my life, to beholde the faire beautie of the Lord, and to visit his Temple.
Manx: 4. Hyn ryd ta mi erna hy̌irre er y Chiarn niym y hyrre ríist : gy jarw gy vodym vaghey ayns ty̌ei yn Chiarn lághyn wlly my hýyl, dy iághyn er boíid alin yn Chiarn, as dy iághyn gy menick y hiampyl.

English: 5 For in the time of trouble he shal hide me in his Tabernacle : yea, in the secret place of his dwelling shall he hide me, and set me up upon a rocke of stone.
Manx: 5. Erson ayns iérish sýaghyn falli é mi ayns y ynyd vaghiys : gy jarw, ayns ynyd fallíit y vaghesyn ’alliys é mí, as sy̌ei e mi shuas er kreg ghlói.
y ynyd] ms. y t’ ynyd

English: 6 And now shall hee lift up mine head : above mine enemies round about me.
Manx: 6. As nish hrogys e shúas my ghian : erskyn my noidjyn krwin magiyrt ymmw̌m.

English: 7 Therefore wil I offer in his dwelling an oblation with great gladnes : I wil sing and speake praises unto the Lord.
Manx: 7. Shenyfá owrelyms ayns y enydsyn vaghey owrel rish bogey mẃar : góỳm oráyn as lóyrym molaghyn gys y Chiarn.

English: 8 Hearken unto my voyce, O Lord, when I cry unto thee : have mercy upon me, and heare me.
Manx: 8. Klast rish my ghórá, O Hiarn, tra ta mi gemagh hẃỳds : jean myghin ořym as klw̌yn mi.

English: 9 My heart hath talked of thee, seeke ye my face : thy face Lord will I seeke.
Manx: 9. Ta my ghri er loyrt ĵids; shyirrigi shius m’ edyns : t’ edyn, [Hiarn,] hẏrriyms.
my ghri] ms. mi ghri

English: 10 O hide not thou thy face from me : nor cast thy servant away in displeasure.
Manx: 10. O na falli us t’ edyn vóỳms : namẃ tilg dthy hyrváynt er shiul ayns jumwys.

English: 11 Thou hast bene my succour : leave mee not, neither forsake me, O God of my salvation.
Manx: 11. Tows er mé my ghomrićk : na fáag mi, namẃ treyg mi, O Iíh dy my hawalys.

English: 12 When my father and my mother forsake me : the Lord taketh me up.
Manx: 12. Trá ta m’ áer as my vêier dy my hregáel : ta yn Chiarn dy my góyl shuas.

English: 13 Teach me thy way, O Lord : and leade me in the right way, because of mine enemies.
Manx: 13. Ynsi dẃỳs dthy ráyd, O Hiarn : as líid mi ayns y ráyd gháyr erson my noidjyn.

English: 14 Deliver me not over into the wil of mine adversaries : for there are false witnesses risen up against mee, and such as speake wrong.
Manx: 14. Na lifré mi harrish gys agney my nóidjyn : erson ta feanish fallsy ern’ irri shuas m’ ýois, as leid ass ta loyrt agáyr.

English: 15 I should utterly have fainted : but that I beleeve verely to see the goodnesse of the Lord in the land of the living.
Manx: 15. Vêin er doyrt nardey glan : agh gy vel mi krediu gy firrinagh dy akin méìys yn Chiarn ayns talw ny miǒ.

English: 16 O tary thou the Lords leasure : be strong, and he shall comfort thine heart; and put thou thy trust in the Lord.
Manx: 16. O farki er eynchys[60] y Chiarn : [...][61] as gyrji é dthy ghrí, as toyr us dthy hreistéel ayns y Chiarn.

English: Ad te Domine. Psal. 28.
Manx: Ad te Domine. psal. 28.

English: Unto thee will I cry, O Lord, my strength : thinke no scorne of mee; lest if thou make as though thou hearest not, I become like them that goe downe into the pit.
Manx: 1. Hŵyds éìyms, O Hiarn my gniart : na smwni knáid ĵims, nagh my ni us mar ass nagh glwinaght ẃ, biyms kasly ríùsyn ta doll shíis ayns y lagg.

English: 2 Heare the voyce of my humble petitions when I cry unto thee : when I holde up my handes toward the Mercie seat of thy holy Temple.
Manx: 2. Klwin korá m’ agheinyn íshyl [...][62] : tra ta mi trogel shuas my láwyn gys ynyd sýi vyghin dy dthy hiampyls kasserick.

English: 3 O plucke mee not away (neither destroy mee) with the ungodly and wicked doers : which speake friendly to their neighbours, but imagine mischiefe in their hearts.
Manx: 3. O na tarn mi er shiul, namẃ strwi mí rish yn niawghráwi as aydsyn ta janẃ olk : ta loyrt gy mwinjeróil rish nan nabẃnyn, agh smẃnaghtyn olk ayns nan griaghyn.

English: 4 Reward them according to their deeds : and according to the wickednesse of their owne inventions.
Manx: 4. Íik áyd nyrg ’an ’altyn[63] : as nyrg olkys ’an gwmme héyn.

English: 5 Recompense them after the worke of their hands : pay them that they have deserved.
Manx: 5. Kwilin áyd nyrg obyr nan lawyn : íik daw shen t’ áyd erna holliẃ.

English: 6 For they regard not in their minde the workes of the Lord, nor the operation of his handes : therefore shall hee breake them downe, and not build them up.
Manx: 6. Erson kwmmy liôw ayns ’an agney obraghyn yn Chiarn, na janw y lawyn : shenyfá brishi é shíis áyd, as gha ni ’an drogell shuas áyd.

English: 7 Praised be the Lord : for he hath heard the voice of my humble petitions.
Manx: 7. Mólíit gy row yn Chiarn : erson te er glastcheyn korá m’ ágheinyn íshill.

English: 8 The Lord is my strength and my shield; my heart hath trusted in him, and I am helped : therefore my heart danceth for joy, and in my song will I praise him.
Manx: 8. She yn Chiarn my gniart as my ské, ta my ghrí er dreistéel aynsyn, as ta mi er geathin kwyne : shenyfá ta my ghrí dáynsyn erson boǵey, as ayns m’ oráyn volym é.

English: 9 The Lord is my strength : and he is the wholesome defence of his Anointed.
Manx: 9. She yn Chiarn my gniart : as she eshyn yn frial sláintoil y ghristsyn.

English: 10 O save thy people, and give thy blessing unto thine inheritance : feed them, and set them up for ever.
Manx: 10. O saw dthy phobyl, as tóyr dthy vánaght dy t’ éirys : biêg áyd as séi ayd shuas erson gybragh.

English: Afferte Domino. Psal. 29.
Manx: Aferte Domino. psal. 29.

English: Bring unto the Lord (O ye mightie) bring yong rammes unto the Lord : ascribe unto the Lord worship and strength.
Manx: 1. Tóergi gys yn Chiarn, O shiusse gniártoil, tóergi réaghyn ayg gys y Chiarn : kwrrigi d’ yn Chiarn ammys as gniart.

English: 2 Give the Lord the honour due unto his Name : worship the Lord with holy worship.
Manx: 2. Kwrrigi d’ yn Chiarn yn oneyr kwi dá enym : jeanji ammys d’ yn Chiarn rish ammys kasserick.

English: 3 It is the Lord that commandeth the waters : it is the glorious God that maketh the thunder.
Manx: 3. She yn Chiarn ta sáyry ny hwiskaghyn : she yn Jíh gloróil ta janw yn tarniagh.

English: 4 It is the Lord that ruleth the sea; the voice of the Lord is mightie in operation : the voice of the Lord is a glorious voice.
Manx: 4. She yn Chiarn ta réel yn fárgey; ta korá yn Chiarn gniártoil ayns obraghy : ta korá yn Chiarn na ghora gloróil.

English: 5 The voice of the Lord breaketh the Cedar trees : yea, the Lord breaketh the Cedars of Libanus.
Manx: 5. Ta korá yn Chiarn brishie ny bilchyn sédyr : gy jarw ta yn Chiarn brishie sedyryn dy Libanus.

English: 6 Hee made them also to skip like a calfe : Libanus also, and Syrion, like a yong Unicorne.
Manx: 6. Hwg e ořiusyn níist dy vrwiskynygh mar ly̌i : Libanus níist as Sirion mar béagh ayg ynn-érićk.

English: made] 1662 maketh
Manx: ořiusyn] ms. eřiusyn; vrwiskynygh] ms. vrwikynygh; béagh ayg ynn] ms. (altered)[64] béagh yn ynn.

English: 7 The voice of the Lord divideth the flames of fire; the voice of the Lord shaketh the wildernesse: yea, the Lord shaketh the wildernesse of Cades.
Manx: 7. Ta korá yn Chiarn reygn na lóssyryn angil; ta korá yn Chiarn krá yn faysyght : gy jarw ta yn Chiarn krá fasyght Ghades.
lóssyryn] ms. lóssyrynyn

English: 8 The voice of the Lord maketh the Hindes to bring forth yong, and discovereth the thicke bushes : in his Temple doeth every man speake of his honour.
Manx: 8. Ta korá yn Chiarn tóyrt er ny báa fei fielagh ay̌gy y hoyrt magh, as ligge rish ny twmagyn chiw : ayns y hiampyl ta dygh ynn ’ẁyne loyrt dy onersyn.

English: 9 The Lord sitteth above the water flood : and the Lord remaineth a King for ever.
Manx: 9. Ta yn Chiarn na hy̌i erskyn yn twilliw-ẃisky : as ta yn Chiarn faraghtyn na rii erson gybragh.

English: 10 The Lord shal give strength unto his people : the Lord shall give his people the blessing of peace.
Manx: 10. Ver yn Chiarn gniart dâ phobyl : ver yn Chiarn da phobyl banaght ny shíi.

English: The vi. day.
Manx: Yn vi. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Exaltabo te Domine. Psal. 30.
Manx: Exaltabo te Domine. psal. 30.

English: I will magnifie thee, O Lord, for thou hast set mee up : and not made my foes to triumph over me.
Manx: 1. Níỳms us y volley gy mẃar, O Hiarn, erson tow er my heiaghe shúas : as gha vel w er ligge dy my nóidjyn barriyght bogòyl y góỳl hařryms.

English: 2 O Lord my God, I cried unto thee : and thou hast healed me.
Manx: 2. O Hiarn my Iíh, jei mi hẃỳds : as ta us er my laynaghey.

English: 3 Thou Lord hast brought my soule out of hell : thou hast kept my life from them that goe downe to the pit.
Manx: 3. Ta us, Hiarn, er doyrt m’ anym magh ass nifrin : tóẁ er vríal my vé vousyn ta dol shíis gys yn làg.

English: 4 Sing praises unto the Lord (O ye saints of his) : and give thankes unto him for a remembrance of his holinesse.
Manx: 4. Gowigi oráyn dy vollaghyn gys y Chiarn, O shiusse nẃyn aggesyn : as kwrgi bwias dasyn erson kwine dâ ghassrikys.

English: 5 For his wrath endureth but the twinckling of an eye, and in his pleasure is life : heavinesse may endure for a night, but joy commeth in the morning.
Manx: 5. Erson ghá vel y ghorri farraghtyn agh migey ny swyly, as ayns y ’oer ta be : fodi trymshey faraghtyn erson y̌i, agh ta bogey chíit ayns y voghre.
farraghtyn] ms. farragtyn

English: 6 And in my prosperitie I said, I shal never be removed : thou Lord of thy goodnesse hadst made my hill so strong.
Manx: 6. As ayns iérish my rágh[65] dwyrt mi, gha bíỳm gybrágh er my skwghey : ta us Hiarn dy dthy vêiys ern’ ianw my ghnock gho laidjer.

English: 7 Thou didst turne thy face (fro me) : & I was troubled.
Manx: 7. Hyndá us t’ edyns vóỳms : as va mi er my húaghy.[66]

English: 8 Then cried I unto thee, O Lord : and gate mee unto my Lord right humbly.
Manx: 8. Eish jei mi hẃỳds, O Hiarn : as héyr[67] mi gys my Hiarn gy fiir arimagh.
jei mi] ms. jei my

English: 9 What profit is there in my blood : when I goe downe to the pit?
Manx: 9. Kré yn kosny ta ayns m’ wỳl : tra ta mi dol shíis gys y lagg?

English: 10 Shall the dust give thanks unto thee : or shall it declare thy trueth?
Manx: 10. Der yn ẃyr bẃias dwich : na soilshi é t’ eirinys ?

English: 11 Heare, O Lord, and have mercie upon mee : Lord be thou my helper.
Manx: 11. Klast, O Hiarn, as jean myghin ořym : Hiarn, bi us m’ er kwyney.

English: 12 Thou hast turned my heavinesse into joy : thou hast put off my sackcloth, and girded me with gladnesse.
Manx: 12. Tow er jyndá my hrimse gys bogey : tow er doyrt jéỳm my hack, as er my hiany rish gyrjaghy.

English: 13 Therefore shal every good man sing of thy praise without ceasing : O my God, I wil give thanks unto thee for ever.
Manx: 13. Shenyfá gowi dygh wlly gwyne mei oráyn dy dthy volley gyn skwyir : O my Iíh, verym bwias dwich erson gybrágh.

English: In te Domine speraui. Psal. 31.
Manx: In te Domine speraui. psal. 31.

English: In thee, O Lord, have I put my trust : let me never bee put to confusion, deliver me in thy righteousnesse.
Manx: 1. Anyds, O Hiarn, ta mi er doyrt my hreisteel : na lig dôw gybrágh ve er my hoyrt gys náre; lifré mi ayns dthy gháyrys.

English: 2 Bow down thine eare to me : make haste to deliver me.
Manx: 2. Krowm núas dthy ghlúesh hwyms : jean sêir dy my lifré.
my] ms. mi

English: 3 And be thou my strong rocke, and the house of defence : that thou mayest save me.
Manx: 3. As bi us my ghreg láidjer, as tyi yn gniart : gy vod us mish y hawáel.

English: and the house] 1662 and house
4 For thou art my strong rocke, and my castle : be thou also my guide, and leade me for thy Names sake.
Manx: 4. Erson she us my ghreg laidjer as my ghastyl : bi us níist my líidjér, as líidj mi erson grayi t’ enym.

English: 5 Draw mee out of the net that they have layd privily for me : for thou art my strength.
Manx: 5. Tarn mish magh as y liyn t’ ayd erna heiaghy gy fallit er my hons : erson she us my gniart.

English: 6 Into thy handes I commend my spirit : for thou hast redeemed me, O Lord, thou God of trueth.
Manx: 6. Ayns dthy lawyn ta mish chymney my spyryd : erson ta us er my lifre, O Hiarn, us Iíh d’ yn ieryn.[68]

English: 7 I have hated them that hold of superstitious vanities : and my trust hath bene in the Lord.
Manx: 7. Ta mi er doyrt fẃua dáẁsyn ta kwmmel er fardálys mi ghreidjóil : as ta my hreistéel er mé ayns y Chiarn.

English: 8 I wil be glad, & rejoyce in thy mercy : for thou hast considered my trouble, and hast knowen my soule in adversities.
Manx: 8. Biŷms ganoil as goym boggy ayns dthy vyghin : erson ta ẃ er smwnaghtyn er my hýaghyn, as hwg w en er m’ anym ayns boghtanys.

English: 9 Thou hast not shut me up into the hand of the enemie : but hast set my feet in a large roume.
Manx: 9. Gha vel us er my gẃny shúas gys law my nóid : agh tow er seiaghy my ghassyn ayns rẃy̆m lien.

English: 10 Have mercie upon mee, O Lord, for I am in trouble : and mine eye is consumed for very heavinesse; yea, my soule and my body.
Manx: 10. Jean myghin orym, O Hiarn, erson ta mi ayns syaghyn : as ta my hẃilyn lyěit erson fíir trimshey, gy jarw m’ anym as my ghorp.

English: 11 For my life is waxen olde with heavinesse : and my yeeres with mourning.
Manx: 11. Erson ta my ve ern’ ol shan rish trimshey : as my vléinchyn rish dobran.

English: 12 My strength faileth me, because of mine iniquitie : and my bones are consumed.
Manx: 12. Ta my gniart dy my hoyrt nayrdey kientagh rish my pheky : as ta my knawyn kéyss.[69]

English: 13 I became a reproofe among all mine enemies, but specially among my neighbors : and they of mine acquaintance were afraid of me; and they that did see mee without conveyed themselves from me.
Manx: 13. Va mi ghon nárey masky my nóidjyn, erskyn wlly masky my nabẃnyn : as gow áydsyn dy m’ aynchys agyl rǒym, as aydsyn ghonićk mi mwi dalli ayd, ayd héyn vóỳm.

English: 14 I am cleane forgotten, as a dead man out of minde : I am become like a broken vessell.
Manx: 14. Ta mi glan er my iarẃd, mar dẃyne marw ass kwyney : ta mi kasly rish séìagh brisht.

English: 15 For I have heard the blasphemie of the multitude : and feare is on every side, while they conspire together against me, and take their counsell to take away my life.
Manx: 15. Erson ghýyl mi taglw malaghtagh dy ymmydi : as ta agyl er gygh yn chéyf, ghowd as t’ ayd toyrt nan gíin kwjaght m’ yoiys, as góyl nan gowrlie dy goyl er shiul my anym.

English: 16 But my hope hath bene in thee, O Lord : I have said, Thou art my God.
Manx: 16. Agh ta my hreistéel er mé an̆yds, O Hiarn : dwyrt mi, she us my Iíh.

English: 17 My time is in thy hand; deliver mee from the hand of mine enemies : and from them that persecute me.
Manx: 17. Ta my iérish ayns dthy law; lifré mi vei law my noidjyn : as vowsyn ta janw trynláys ořym.

English: 18 Shew thy servant the light of thy countenance: and save me for thy mercies sake.
Manx: 18. Jeagh dy dthy hyrváynt soilshe dy gnẃys : as saw mi erson grayi dthy vyghin.

English: 19 Let mee not be confounded, O Lord, for I have called upon thee : let the ungodly be put to confusion, and bee put to silence in the grave.
Manx: 19. Na lig dow ve er my ghall, O Hiarn, erson ta mi ern’ emagh oyrts : ligg e yn niawghrawi ve ernan doyrt gys kàll, as er nan dóyrt [nan dost] ayns yn ýoi.

English: 20 Let the lying lips be put to silence : which cruelly, disdainefully, and despitefully speake against the righteous.
Manx: 20. Ligg e ny meliyn bregagh ve er nan dóyrt nan dost : ta gy dwrey[70], gy faghijagh, as gy gneyfnagh[71] loyrt noy ny káyrys.

English: 21 O how plentifull is thy goodnesse which thou hast laid up for them that feare thee : and that thou hast prepared for them that put their trust in thee, even before the sonnes of men.
Manx: 21. O gho palchy ass ta dthy véiys ta us erna haskey shúas dáùsyn ta goyl agyl royds : as tow erna ianw arlw dáùsyn ta toyrt nan dreistéel aňyds, gy jarw feanish meck geney.

English: 22 Thou shalt hide them privily by thine owne presence, from the provoking of all men : thou shalt keepe them secretly in thy Tabernacle from the strife of tongues.
Manx: 22. Fallíit us aydsyn gynnys, liorish t’ eanish heyn, vei moyrn[72] gygh wlly gwyne : frialit us ayd gy fallíit ayns t’iynyd vaghey vei ymmyr ny jangeghyn.

English: 23 Thankes be to the Lord : for he hath shewed me marveilous great kindnesse in a strong Citie.
Manx: 23. Bẃias d’ yn Chiarn : erson t’ e ern’ iághyn dwys keindylys vwar ientysagh ayns ayrd valley laidjer.

English: 24 And when I made haste, I said : I am cast out of the sight of thine eyes.
Manx: 24. As nar ren mi séìr, dwyrt mi : ta mi tilgit magh ass shilliy dthy hẃilliyns.

English: 25 Neverthelesse thou heardest the voice of my prayer : when I cried unto thee.
Manx: 25. Fóost ghýyl us korá my phadjer : tra jei my oyrts.
mi] ms. my

English: 26 O love the Lord all yee his Saints : for the Lord preserveth them that are faithfull, and plenteously rewardeth the proud doer.
Manx: 26. O ligg e gráyi ve agğwish er y Chiarn, wlly shiusse y nẃyn : erson ta yn Chiarn d’ an vríalsyn ta kredjoil, as gy palche gíik yn dwyne ta janw gy morniagh.

English: 27 Be strong, and he shall stablish your heart : all yee that put your trust in the Lord.
Manx: 27. Bigi láidjer as gniarti e nan gri : shiusse wlly ta toyrt nan dreistéel ayns y Chiarn.

English: The vi. day.
Manx: Yn vi. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Beati quorum. Psal. 32.
Manx: Beati quorum. psal. 32.

English: Blessed is hee whose unrighteousnesse is forgiven : and whose sinne is covered.
Manx: 1. Baníit ta eshyn ta yn niawgháyrys erna ly̌ei da : as ta y pheky kwdit.

English: 2 Blessed is the man unto whom the Lord imputeth no sinne : and in whose spirit there is no guile.
Manx: 2. Baníit ta yn dwyne nagh vel yn Chiarn tóyr peky erbí na leè : as ayns y spyryd aggesyn nagh vel kálg erbi.

English: 3 For while I held my tongue : my bones consumed away through my dayly complaining.
Manx: 3. Erson ghowd ass ghwm mi my hange : ghéf my ghnawyn er shiul tryid m’ akan gygh lá.

English: 4 For thy hand is heavie upon mee day and night : and my moisture is like the drought in Summer.
Manx: 4. Erson ta dthy law troym oryms lá as y̌i : as ta my lẃghid[73] kasly rish y chirmaghy ’sy toẃry.

English: 5 I will acknowledge my sinne unto thee : and mine unrighteousnesse have I not hid.
Manx: 5. Góỳm rish my pheky dwich : as my niawgháyrys gha vel mi ern’ álaghy.

English: 6 I said, I will confesse my sinnes unto the Lord : and so thou forgavest the wickedneses of my sinne.
Manx: 6. Dẃyrt mi, góỳm rish my phekaghyn d’ yn Chiarn : as marshen lyoig[74] us olkys my pheky.

English: 7 For this shall every one that is godly, make his prayer unto thee in a time when thou mayest bee found : but in the great water-floods they shall not come nigh him.
Manx: 7. Erson shó, ni gygh anáyn ta kráwi y phaidjer y ianw hẃỳds, ayns ierish nar ’odyst w ve er dy geathin : agh ayns twiliaghyn mẃar wysky gha jig ayd na áyrsyn.
’odyst w] ms. ’odyst ou

English: 8 Thou art a place to hide me in, thou shalt preserve mee from trouble : thou shalt compasse mee about with songs of deliverance.
Manx: 8. She ynyd us dy my ’allaghy ayn; fréylit us mish vei sýaghyn : ni us my hiǎny magiyrt rish oranyn fýàskyli.

English: 9 I will enforme thee, and teach thee in the way wherein thou shalt goe : and I will guide thee with mine eye.
Manx: 9. Veryms oyrt dy hwigel, as ynsiym us ayns yn ráyd ni w immiaght ayn : as líidjym us rish my hwil.

English: 10 Be ye not like to horse and mule, which have no understanding : whose mouthes must be holden with bit and bridle, lest they fall upon thee.
Manx: 10. Na bigi kasly rish kabyl as mẃyl, nagh vel twigel erbi aćk : segyn [dy] ny béal ack ve erna ghwmmel rish beal-raghan, as strian, nagh dwit ayd oyrts.

English: holden] 1662 held
11 Great plagues remaine for the ungodly : but who so putteth his trust in the Lord, mercy imbraceth him on every side.
Manx: 11. Ta patchyn mẃary faraghtyn erson yn niawghráwi : agh quei erbi ta tóyrt y hreistéel ayns y Chiarn, ta myghin dy góyl e ayns y riaghyn er gygh yn chéyf.

English: 12 Be glad, O ye righteous, and rejoyce in the Lord : and be joyfull, all ye that are true of heart.
Manx: 12. Bigi ganoil, O shiusse lyei kayragh, as gowgi bogey ayns y Chiarn : as bigi ganoil, shiusse wlly ta firrinagh dy ghrí.

English: Exultate iusti. Psal. 33.
Manx: Exultate iusti. psal. 33.

English: Rejoyce in the Lord, O yee righteous : for it becometh well the just to be thankefull.
Manx: 1. Gowgi bogey ayns y Chiarn, O shiusse lyei káyragh : erson t’ e chíit gy mei d’ yn klyei ghayragh dy ve bẃìasoil.

English: 2 Praise the Lord with harpe : sing Psalmes unto him with the Lute and instrument of ten strings.
Manx: 2. Moligi yn Chiarn rish krw̌it : gowgi shalmyn dâsyn rish yn liŵt as gry̌ei dy iei strengyn.

English: Psalmes] 1662 praises
3 Sing unto the Lord a newe Song : sing praises lustily (unto him) with a good courage.
Manx: 3. Gowgi orayn nóo d’ yn Chiarn : gowgi oraynyn moli gy ganoil huggesyn rish dánys mei.

English: 4 For the word of the Lord is true : and all his workes are faithfull.
Manx: 4. Erson ta gẃ yn Chiarn firrinagh : as ta y obraghyn wlly kredjoil.

English: 5 He loveth righteousnesse and Judgement : the earth is full of the goodnesse of the Lord.
Manx: 5. Sh’ yne lesh y Chiarn kayrys as brwinys : ta yn talẃ láyn dy veiys d’ yn Chiarn.

English: 6 By the word of the Lord were the heavens made: and all the hostes of them by the breath of his mouth.
Manx: 6. Liórish gẃ yn Chiarn va ny neaẃyn er nan ianw : as wlly ny shessaghtyn kagi acksyn rish anel y vealsyn.

English: 7 He gathereth the waters of the sea together, as it were upon an heape : and layeth up the deep as in a treasure house.
Manx: 7. T’ e chiaglym wyskaghyn ny fárkey kwjaght, mar veagh e ayns karnán : as kwr shúas yn deifnid mar ayns tei taski.

English: 8 Let all the earth feare the Lord : stand in awe of him, all ye that dwell in the world.
Manx: 8. Ligg e yn talw wlly agyl y góyl réỳfs y Chiarn : shassigi ayns óyn[75] jesyn, shiusse wlly ta vaghey ayns y týyl.
shassigi] ms. shassi

English: 9 For he spake, and it was done : hee commanded, and it stood fast.
Manx: 9. Erson lóeyr é, as ve jeant : hwg e sárey as hass e sićkyr.
ve] ms. va

English: 10 The Lord bringeth the counsell of the heathen to nought : and maketh the devises of the people to be of none effect, and casteth out the counsailes of Princes.
Manx: 10. Ta yn Chiarn toyrt kowrl yn angristi gys gyn veg : as janw saysyn y phobyl dy vé gyn veg y vri, as tilge magh kowrliaghyn riaghyn.

English: 11 The counsaile of the Lord shall endure for ever : and the thoughts of his heart from generation to generation.
Manx: 11. Ni kowrl yn Chiarn faraghtyn erson gybrágh : as smwnaghtyn y ghrí vei shilógh gys shilógh.

English: 12 Blessed are the people, whose God is the Lord Jehova : and blessed are the folke that he hath chosen to him to be his inheritance.
Manx: 12. Baníit ta yn pobyl ta yn Jih acksyn yn Chiarn Jehováh : as baníit ta yn slyei ta eshyn erna ryei dâ, dy vé na éìrys.

English: 13 The Lord looked downe from heaven, and beheld all the children of men : from the habitation of his dwelling hee considereth all them that dwell on the earth.
Manx: 13. Ta yn Chiarn ern’ iaghyn núas vei neaw, as ghonick e wlly klawn gene : vei ynyd y vághey te smẃnaghtyn orìúsyn wlly ta vaghey ayns y talw.
te] ms. ta

English: 14 He fashioneth all the hearts of them : and understandeth all their workes.
Manx: 14. Te kwm̀mey wlly ny kríaghyn acksyn : as twigel wlly nan obraghyn.

English: 15 There is no king that can be saved by the multitude of an host : neither is any mighty man delivered by much strength.
Manx: 15. Gha vel ríi erbi ’odys ve erna hawáyl liórish moráyn dy heshiaght ghagi : namẃ ta dwyne gniartoil erbi erna lifré liorish ymmydi gniart.

English: 16 A horse is counted but a vaine thing to save a man : neither shall he deliver any man by his great strength.
Manx: 16. Gha vel kabyl erna góyl agh red fardálagh dy hawáyl dwyne : ghamw lífréys e dwyne erbí liórish y gniart vwar.

English: 17 Beholde, the eye of the Lord is upon them that feare him : and upon them that put their trust in his mercy;
Manx: 17. Jeagh ta sẃil yn Chiarn oriǔsyn ta goyl agyl réyfsyn : as oriǔsyn ta tóyrt nan dreistéel ayns y vyghin;

English: 18 To deliver their soules from death : and to feede them in the time of dearth.
Manx: 18. Dy lifré nan anminiyn vei báys : as dy nan miêg[76] ayns iérish ny geǹnid.

English: 19 Our soule hath patiently taried for the Lord : for he is our helpe, and our shield.
Manx: 19. Ta nan anym gy míin er varkiaght er y Chiarn : erson she eshyn nan gẃney as nan ské.

English: 20 For our heart shall rejoyce in him : because wee have hoped in his holy Name.
Manx: 20. Erson gowi nan gríaghyn bogey aynsyn : erson gy hréìst shwin ayns y enymsyn kasserick.

English: 21 Let thy mercifull kindenesse (O Lord) bee upon us : like as we doe put our trust in thee.
Manx: 21. Ligg e dthy gwghys láyn dy vyghin, O Hiarn, ve orwiniyn : mar ta shwin toyrt nan dreistéel anyds.

English: Benedicam Domino. Psal. 34.
Manx: Benedicam Domino. psal. 34.

English: I will alway give thankes unto the Lord : his praise shall ever be in my mouth.
Manx: 1. Verrym goni bwías d’ yn Chiarn : bi y vólysyn gybrágh ayns my veal.

English: 2 My soule shall make her boast of the Lord : the humble shall heare thereof, and be glad.
Manx: 2. Ni my anym y bogyssi[77] d’ yn Chiarn : klwini yn slyei ishil je shen as bi ayd ganoil.

English: boast of] 1662 boast in
3 O praise the Lord with mee : and let us magnifie his Name together.
Manx: 3. O moligi yn Chiarn marŷms : as lig ’win y enymsyn y voley gy mwár kwjaght.

English: 4 I sought the Lord, and he heard me : yea, he delivered me out of all my feare.
Manx: 4. Héir mi yn Chiarn, as ghýl é mi : gy jarw dýaskyly eshyn mish magh ass my agyl wlly.
dýaskyly] ms. dy askyly

English: 5 They had an eye unto him, and were lightened: and their faces were not ashamed.
Manx: 5. Va swil ack er, as v’ áyd er nan soilsheghy : as gha row ny hedynyn acksyn naraghtagh.

English: 6 Lo, the poore crieth, and the Lord heareth him : yea, and saveth him out of all his troubles.
Manx: 6. Jeagh, ta yn boght gémagh, as ta yn Chiarn da ghlastchen : she gy jarw, as dâ hawayl-syn magh as y hyaghyn wlly.

English: 7 The Angel of the Lord tarieth round about them that feare him : and delivereth them.
Manx: 7. Ta ángyl yn Chiarn fẃraghtyn krw̌yn magíyrt ymbẃsyn ta góyl agyl réyfsyn : as d’ an vyaskyly áyd.

English: 8 O taste and see how gracious the Lord is : blessed is the man that trusteth in him.
Manx: 8. O blassigi, as jeaghigi ghó grasoil ass ta yn Chiarn : baníit ta yn dwyne ta treistéel aynsyn.

English: 9 O feare the Lord yee that are his Saints : for they that feare him, lacke nothing.
Manx: 9. O gowigi agyl réỳfs y Chiarn, shiusse ta ny nẃaghyn aggesyn : erson gha vel áydsyn ta góyl agyl rêyf-syn fegwish veg.

English: 10 The lions do lack, and suffer hunger : but they which seeke the Lord, shall want no maner of thing that is good.
Manx: 10. Ta féim ag ny léìonyn as t’ áyd fwllaghtyn akrys : agh áydsyn ta shiy̌re yn Chiarn, gha bi áyd fegẃish mòney dy red erbi ta mei.

English: which] 1662 who
11 Come ye children, and hearken unto mee : I will teach you the feare of the Lord.
Manx: 11. Tredigi,[78] shiusse ghlawn, as klastigi rẃỳms : as ýnsiym difs agyl yn Chiarn.

English: 12 What man is hee that lusteth to live, and would faine see good dayes : keepe thy tongue from evil, and thy lips that they speake no guile.
Manx: 12. Kre yn dwyne ta eshiyn salliesh bé, as by vei lesh laghyn mei y akin : kwmm dthy hiǎnge vei olk, as dthy veliyn nagh lóyr ayd malley erbi.

English: keepe, etc.] in 1662 becomes v. 13, with consequent numbering of the remaining verses moved on by one.
13 Eschew evil, and doe good : seeke peace, and ensue it.
Manx: 13. Trég olk, as jean mei : shy̌ir shíi [as] éigyr é.

English: 14 The eyes of the Lord are over the righteous : and his eares are open unto their prayers.
Manx: 14. Ta sẃilyn yn Chiarn harrish yn sly̌ei gháyragh : as ta y ghlýash-syn foskilt gys nan badjraghyn.

English: 15 The countenance of the Lord is against them that doe evil : to root out the remembrance of them from the earth.
Manx: 15. Ta edyn yn Chiarn nan yóìsyn ta janw olk : dy roẃry magh yn kwiny acksyn vei yn talw.

English: 16 The righteous cry, and the Lord heareth them: and delivereth them out of all their troubles.
Manx: 16. Ta yn slýèi káyragh gémagh, as ta yn Chiarn d’ an glastchen : as d’ an vyaskyly áyd magh as nan syaghyn.

English: 17 The Lord is nigh unto them that are of a contrite heart : and wil save such as be of an humble spirit.
Manx: 17. Ta yn Chiarn fàgys dâwsyn ta dy ghri brist : as sawi e leidsyn ass ta dy spyryd ishill.

English: 18 Great are the troubles of the righteous : but the Lord delivereth him out of all.
Manx: 18. Smẃar sýaghyn yn dwyne gháyragh : agh ta yn Chiarn dy ýaskyly-syn magh ass wlly.

English: 19 Hee keepeth all his bones : so that not one of them is broken.
Manx: 19. Te kwmmel y ghnawyn wlly : marshen nagh vel anayn jû brist.

English: 20 But misfortune shall slay the ungodly : and they that hate the righteous, shall be desolate.
Manx: 20. Agh marri niawghonagh[79] yn niawghráwi : as aydsyn ta dwôi ack er yn klei gháyragh, bi áyd er nan vagael fáys.[80]

English: 21 The Lord delivereth the soules of his servants : and all they that put their trust in him, shall not be destitute.
Manx: 21. Ta yn Chiarn fyaskyly anminiyn y herváyntyn : as aydsyn wlly ta toyrt nan dreistéel aynsyn, gha bi áyd er nan vagáel mw̌i.

English: The vii. day.
Manx: Yn vii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Iudica me Domine. Psal. 35.
Manx: Iudica me Domine. psal. 35.

English: Pleade thou my cause, O Lord, with them that strive with mee : and fight thou against them that fight against me.
Manx: 1. Gow my ghẃish ayns láw, O Hiarn, mariusyn ta janw ymmer vei[81] rwy̌ms : as kag us nan yoisyn ta kagey m’ ýoiys.

English: 2 Lay hand upon the shield and buckler : and stand up to helpe me.
Manx: 2. Kwr láw er y skae as éjy[82] : as shass shúas dy ghẃne láỳms.

English: 3 Bring foorth the speare, and stop the way against them that persecute mee : say unto my soule, I am thy salvation.
Manx: 3. Kwr magh yn tly̌ei, as jěy yn ráyd nan ýoisyn ta dy my êiyrts : abber rish m’ anym, she mish dthy hawálys.

English: 4 Let them be confounded and put to shame that seeke after my soule : let them bee turned backe, & brought to confusion, that imagine mischiefe for me.
Manx: 4. Lig ’aŵsyn ve er nan doyrt mow as gys náre ta shy̌irre nyre m’ anyms : lig ’awsyn ve er nan jyndá arràsh as er nan doyrt gys náre, ta smwnaghtyn skelle er my hons.

English: 5 Let them be as the dust before the winde : and the Angel of the Lord scattering them.
Manx: 5. Lig ’aw ve mar yn ẃeir réfs yn gúa : as áinnil yn Chiarn d’ an skeyly.
Chiarn] ms. charn

English: 6 Let their way be darke and slipperie : and let the Angel of the Lord persecute them.
Manx: 6. Ligg e nan ráyd ve dorghy as sleǎwn : as ligg e áinnil yn Chiarn aydsyn y éìyrts.
Chiarn] ms. charn

English: 7 For they have privily layd their net to destroy me without a cause : yea, even without a cause have they made a pit for my soule.
Manx: 7. Erson t’ ayd gy fallíit er séìaghy nan líyn dy my strwiel gyn óeyr : gy jarw gyn óeyr t’ ayd ern’ ianw lag ghon m’ anyms.

English: 8 Let a sudden destruction come upon him unawares, and his net that he hath layd privily catch himselfe : that hee may fall into his owne mischiefe.
Manx: 8. Ligg e strwiel dol tattym chíit ersyn gyn ’yss, as y líyn te erna hêiaghy gy fallíit y héyn y góyl : gy vod e twittym ayns y grogh red héyn.

English: 9 And my soule, bee joyfull in the Lord : it shall rejoyce in his salvation.
Manx: 9. As, m’ anym, bi us gannoil ayns y Chiarn : gowi é bogge ayns y hawálys.

English: 10 All my bones shall say, Lord, who is like unto thee, which deliverest the poore from him that is too strong for him : yea, the poore and him that is in miserie, from him that spoileth him?
Manx: 10. Jirr wlly my ghnawyn, Hiarn, quei ta kasly rw̌yts; ta lifré yn boght veisyn ta róo laidjer da : gy jarw yn boght as eshyn ta ayns tréanid, veisyn ta dâ rẃisk é?

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: quei ta] ms. quei te

English: 11 False witnesses did rise up : they laid to my charge things that I knew not.
Manx: 11. Jirri feanishyn fallsy shúas : hwg áydsyn my líè redyn nagh row fyss aym er.

English: witnesses] 1605 witnesse
12 They rewarded me evil for good : to the great discomfort of my soule.
Manx: 12. Jik áyd doŵ olk erson mei : gys niaw gyrjaghey vẃar dy m’ anym.

English: 13 Neverthelesse, when they were sicke, I put on sacke-cloth, and humbled my soule with fasting : and my prayer shall turne into mine owne bosome.
Manx: 13. Er y ghon sho wlly, nar va áyd chín, hwg mi ymmwm áynryt sack; as j́isli mi m’ anym rish trosky : as chyndái my phadjer gys m’ oghrys héyn.

English: 14 I behaved my selfe as though it had bene my friend, or my brother : I went heavily, as one that mourneth for his mother.
Manx: 14. Jimmark mi mi héyn mar ass gy beagh é my gene-mwinjer, na my vrayr : ghái mi gy troym, mar anáyn ta dobran erson y vwmmwg.
mi héyn] ms. my héyn

English: 15 But in mine adversitie they rejoyced, & gathered them together : yea, the very abjects came together against me unawares, making mowes at me, and ceased not.
Manx: 15. Agh ayns my hyaghyn gow ayd bogey, as hagyl áyd kwjaght : gy jarw haink [y] bownlygh[83] kwjaght m’ yois gyn yss knaid ymmwyms, as gha gow ayd fée.

English: them] 1662 themselves; mowes] 1662 mouthes
Manx: yss] ms. uss

English: 16 With the flatterers were busie mockers : which gnashed upon me with their teeth.
Manx: 16. Márish ny brynryn va knaidjeryn arlw : ren snaggerni orym rish nan veakylyn.

English: which] 1662 who
17 Lord, how long wilt thou looke upon this : O deliver my soule from the calamities which they bring on me, and my darling from the Lions.
Manx: 17. Hiarn, káid iághyst us er shó : O lifrae m’ anym véi ny syaghyn t’ ayd dy hóyrt ory̌m, as m’ yn anáyn[84] vei ny leionyn.

English: 18 So will I give thee thankes in the great Congregation : I will praise thee among much people.
Manx: 18. Marshen veřryms bwias dwich ayns y chessiaght vẃar : mollym us masky ymmydi pobyl.
bwias] ms. bwiaghs

English: 19 O let not them that are mine enemies triumph over mee ungodly : neither let them winke with their eyes that hate me without a cause.
Manx: 19. O na lig dawsyn ta my nóidjyn bogey y góyl hařrym gy niaw-ghráwi : namẃ lig dawsyn migy rish nan sẃilyn ta dwoi ack orrym gyn óyr.

English: 20 And why? their communing is not for peace : but they imagine deceitfull words against them that are quiet in the land.
Manx: 20. As kamma? gha vel yn taglw âcksyn erson shíi : agh t’ áyd smẃnaghtyn fokelyn kálgagh nan ýoi-syn ta feagh ayns y talw.

English: 21 They gaped on me with their mouthes, and said: Fie on thee, fie on thee, we saw it with our eyes.
Manx: 21. Doskẏl áyd nan méyl ořyms, as dwyrt áyd : fei oyrts, fei oy̆rts, ghonick [shwin] e rish nan sẃilyn.

English: gaped on] 1662 gaped upon
22 This thou hast seene, O Lord : holde not thy tongue then, goe not farre from me, O Lord.
Manx: 22. Shó ghonick us, O Hiarn : na kwm dthy hange éish, na immi fodey voyms, O Hiarn.

English: 23 Awake and stand up to judge my quarrel : avenge thou my cause, my God, and my Lord.
Manx: 23. Dẃisk as shass shuas dy hoyrt brẃinys er m’ óyr : kwilín us my ghẃysh, my Iíh, as my Hiarn.

English: 24 Judge mee, O Lord my God, according to thy righteousnes : and let them not triumph over mee.
Manx: 24. Tóer brwinys oryms, O Hiarn my Iíh, nýre dthy gháyrys : as na lig daw bogey y góyl harřyms.

English: 25 Let them not say in their hearts, There, there, so would we have it : neither let them say, Wee have devoured him.
Manx: 25. Na lig daw y grá ayns nan gríaghyn, shen, shen, bail liên marshen e : namw lig daw y grá, ta shwin ern’ y ghwr moẃ.

English: 26 Let them be put to confusion and shame together that rejoyce at my trouble : let them bee clothed with rebuke and dishonour that boast themselves against me.
Manx: 26. Lig daŵ ve er nan dóyrt mow as gys náre kwjaght, ta góyl bogey dy my hýaghyn : lig ’aw ve er nan gomrey rish náre as niaw onéyr ta d’ an mogyssy heyn m’ yois.

English: 27 Let them be glad and rejoyce that favour my righteous dealing : yea let them say alway, Blessed bee the Lord, which hath pleasure in the prosperitie of his servant.
Manx: 27. Lig ’aw ve gannoil as boggey y góyl ta foráel[85] my ianw káyragh : gy jarw lig ’aw y grá goni, baníit gy row yn Chiarn ag vel tatnys aýns rá y herváynt.

English: which] 1662 who
28 And as for my tongue, it shall be talking of thy righteousnes : and of thy praise all the day long.
Manx: 28. As erson my hiange, bi é taglw dy dthy gháyrys : as dy dthy volley fei yn lá.

English: Dixit iniustus. Psal. 36.
Manx: Dixit iniustus. psal. 36.

English: My heart sheweth me the wickednes of the ungodly : that there is no feare of God before his eyes.
Manx: 1. Ta my ghrí jaghyn dow peky y niaw-ghráwi : nagh vel agyl erbi dy Iíh feanish y hwilyn.

English: 2 For he flattereth himselfe in his owne sight : untill his abominable sinne be found out.
Manx: 2. Erson t’ e dy vrynryght héyn ayns y hilliy héyn : naggydere viís y pheky dẃiól erna geadthyn magh.

English: 3 The wordes of his mouth are unrighteous, and full of deceit : he hath left off to behave himselfe wisely, & to do good.
Manx: 3. Ta fokelyn y véyl niawgharagh, as láyn dy vally : t’ é er vagáel je dá ymmyrke heyn gy kríney as d’ ianw mei.

English: 4 He imagineth mischiefe upon his bed, and hath set himselfe in no good way : neither doth he abhorre any thing that is evill.
Manx: 4. Te smwnaghtyn skelley er y liabby, as gha vel é er y heiaghe héyn ayns ráyd erbí mei : ghamw t’ e toyrt dw̌oi dy red erbí ta olk.

English: 5 Thy mercy, O Lord, reacheth unto the heavens : and thy faithfulnesse unto the clouds.
Manx: 5. Ta dthy vyghin, O Hiarn, roschyn gys neawaghyn : as t’ eiryinys[86] gys ny bojelyn.

English: 6 Thy Righteousnesse standeth like the strong mountaines : thy Judgements are like the great deepe.
Manx: 6. Ta dthy gháyrys shassw mar ny knwick láidjer : as ta dthy vrwinys kasly rish yn dyifnid vẃar.

English: 7 Thou Lord shalt save both man and beast; How excellent is thy mercie, O God : and the children of men shall put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.
Manx: 7. Sáwíit us, Hiarn, dẃyne as béagh níist; ghó ýasyl ass ta dthy vyghin, O Iíh : as ver klawn déne nan dreistéel fwó ská dy skányns.

English: 8 They shall bee satisfied with the plenteousnesse of thy house : and thou shalt give them drinke of thy pleasures, as out of the river.
Manx: 8. Bi áyd er nan ianw bẃiagh rish palchy dy héìys : as ver us dáẁsyn jogh dy dthy voggys mar as y trẃan.
jogh] ms. iogh

English: 9 For with thee is the well of life : and in thy Light shall we see light.
Manx: 9. Erson mâyrts ta chibbyrt yn vé : as ayns dthy hoilshy hií meid soilshy.
soilshy] ms. shoilshy

English: 10 O continue foorth thy loving kindnesse unto them that know thee : and thy righteousnesse unto them that are true of heart.
Manx: 10. O ligg e dthy gheindylys grayiẃil faraghtyn fodey dawsyn sawn us : as dthy gháyrys dawsyn ta firrinagh dy ghrí.

English: 11 O let not the foote of pride come against me : and let not the hand of the ungodly cast me downe.
Manx: 11. O ná lig dy ghass yn voyrn chíit m’ yois : as na lig dy law y niawghráwi my hilge shíis.

English: 12 There are they fallen (all) that worke wickednes: they are cast downe, and shall not be able to stand.
Manx: 12. Aynshen t’ áyd er dwittym wlly ta gobraghy peky : t’ áyd er nan dilge shíis, as gha bi áyd fowndagh dy hassw.

English: The vii. day.
Manx: Yn vii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Noli æmulari. Psal. 37.
Manx: Noli emulari. psal. 37.

English: Fret not thy selfe, because of the ungodly : neither bee thou envious against the evill doers.
Manx: 1. Na tóeyr sonáys oyrt heyn erson y niaw ghráwi : namẃ bi us tnẃygh[87] nan-yoi-syn ta janw olk.

English: 2 For they shall soone bee cut downe like the grasse : and bee withered even as the greene herbe.
Manx: 2. Erson bi áyd gylie erna iáry shíis kasly rish [yn] ’eyr : as er nan fioghy gy jarw mar yn lwss glass.

English: 3 Put thou thy trust in the Lord, and be doing good : dwell in the land, & verily thou shalt be fed.
Manx: 3. Tóer dthy hreistéel ayns y Chiarn as bi janw mei : jean vághy ayns y talw as gy jarw bíit ẃ er dy vieg.

English: 4 Delight thou in the Lorde : and he shall give thee thy hearts desire.
Manx: 4. Kwr us dy hatnys ayns y Chiarn : as ver e dwit agne dthy ghrí.

English: 5 Commit thy way unto the Lorde, and put thy trust in him : and he shall bring it to passe.
Manx: 5. Tilg dthy ráyd er y Chiarn, as tóer dthy hreistéel aynsyn : as ver eshyn é gys kian.

English: 6 He shall make thy righteousnesse as cleare as the light : and thy just dealing as the noone day.
Manx: 6. Ni é dthy gháyrys ghó solys as y soilshe : as dthy ianw káyragh mar myn lá.

English: 7 Holde thee still in the Lord, and abide patiently upon him : but grieve not thy selfe at him whose way doth prosper, against the man that doeth after evill counsailes.
Manx: 7. Kwmm ẃ kínjagh ayns y Chiarn, as fan gy míin ersyn : agh na gow héyn korri rish-syn ta y ráyd dol er [y] hoshiagh, nyói yn dwyne ta janw nyre drogh ghórliaghyn.

English: 8 Leave off from wrath, and let goe displeasure : fret not thy selfe, else shalt thou be mooved to doe evill.
Manx: 8. Faygi ie vei farg, as ligg e jwmẃiys imíaght : na kwr sonás oyrt héyn, naníìo[88] bíit w er dy grenniaghy dy ianw olk.
naníìo] ms. naníìs

English: 9 Wicked doers shall bee rooted out : and they that patiently abide the Lord, those shall inherit the land.
Manx: 9. Bi áydsyn ta janw olk er nan rowry magh : as aydsyn ta gy míin farkiaght er y Chiarn, iew áyd eirys ayns y talw.

English: 10 Yet a little while, and the ungodly shal be cleane gone : thou shalt looke after his place, and he shall be away.
Manx: 10. Fóyst gar̀rid veg, as bi yn niawghráwi glan er shiẃl : jeaghyt us nýre y enyd, as bi eshyn er shiẃl.

English: 11 But the meeke spirited shal possesse the earth : and shal be refreshed in the multitude of peace.
Manx: 11. Agh aydsyn ta dy spyryd víin, iew áyd kwmmel ayns y talw : as bi áyd er nan ẃraghy ayns ymmydi shíi.

English: 12 The ungodly seeketh counsaile against the just: and gnasheth upon him with his teeth.
Manx: 12. Ta yn niaw ghráwi shyire kówrly nýoi yn dwyne gháyragh : as te snaggerni ersyn rish y ’eakylyn.

English: 13 The Lord shall laugh him to scorne : for he hath seene that his day is comming.
Manx: 13. Ni yn Chiarn góyl geraghti knáid ymmish-syn : erson t’ e ern akin gy vel y la chíit.

English: 14 The ungodly have drawen out the sword, and have bent their bow : to cast downe the poore and needy, and to slay such as be of a right conversation.
Manx: 14. Ta yn niawghráwi er dayrn magh yn kleiw, as er lwby nan mow : dy hilge shíis yn boght as ymmyrtsagh, as dy varrw léid-syn as ta dy ymmyrke káyr.

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
Manx: lwby] ms. lwbi

English: 15 Their sword shall goe through their owne heart: and their bow shall be broken.
Manx: 15. Heid nan gleiw tryid nan gri héyn : as bi nan moẃ erna vrishie.
Heid] ms. Heiryd

English: 16 A small thing that the righteous hath : is better then great riches of the ungodly.
Manx: 16. Red beg t’ ag yn dwyne gháyragh : t’ e na sháyr na berchys vwar yn niawghráwi.

English: 17 For the armes of the ungodly shall be broken : and the Lord upholdeth the righteous.
Manx: 17. Erson bi ríaghyn y niawghráwi erna vrishie : as ta yn Chiarn kwmmel shúas yn klyi gháyragh.

English: 18 The Lord knoweth the dayes of the godly : and their inheritance shall endure for ever.
Manx: 18. Sawn d’ yn Chiarn ny lághyn acksyn ta kraẃi : as farri nan eirys erson gybrágh.

English: 19 They shal not be confounded in the perilous time : and in the dayes of dearth they shall have ynough.
Manx: 19. Gha bi áyd er nan doyrt mow ayns yn ierish gawagh : as ayns lághyn ny genniy bi gallior ǎck.

English: 20 As for the ungodly they shall perish; and the enemies of the Lord shall consume as the fat of lambes : yea, even as the smoke shall they consume away.
Manx: 20. Ass erson y niawghráwi, héyd ayd mow̌; as ni nóidjyn yn Chiarn kéyf mar rowrid y̌en[89] : gy jarw mar yn jéagh ni áyd kieu er shiul.

English: 21 The ungodly borroweth, and payeth not againe : but the righteous is mercifull and liberall.
Manx: 21. Ta yn niaw ghráwi gesaght, as gha vel e gík ríist : agh ta yn dwyne káyragh trokroil as feilćhagh.

English: 22 Such as be blessed of God, shall possesse the land : and they that be cursed of him shal be rooted out.
Manx: 22. Léid-syn as ta baniit dy Iih, iew ayd yn talw : as aydsyn ta y vollaght ǒrẃ, bi áyd erna rowry magh.

English: Such as be] 1662 Such as are; they that be] 1662 they that are
23 The Lord ordereth a good mans going : and maketh his way acceptable to himselfe.
Manx: 23. Ta yn Chiarn réaghy immiaght yn dwyne věi : as t’ e janw y ráyd bwiasoil da héyn.

English: 24 Though he fall, he shal not be cast away : for the Lord upholdeth him with his hand.
Manx: 24. Ga hwitchys e, gha bi [e] erna hilge er shiúl : erson ta yn Chiarn dâ ghwmmel shúas rish y law.

English: 25 I have bene yong, and now am olde : and yet saw I never the righteous forsaken, nor his seede begging their bread.
Manx: 25. Va mi áyg, as nish ta mi shaǹn : as foyst gha nack mi riw yn dwyne káyragh erna hregéel, na y rass shyirre jérig.[90]

English: 26 The righteous is ever merciful, and lendeth : and his seede is blessed.
Manx: 26. Ta yn dwyne káyragh gygh wlly ẃyr myghinaght, as giésaght : as ta y rass baníit.

English: 27 Flee from evill, and doe the thing that is good : and dwell for evermore.
Manx: 27. Ché vei yn olk, as jean yn red ta mei : as jean vághe erson gybrágh.

English: 28 For the Lord loveth the thing that is right : hee forsaketh not his that be godly, but they are preserved for ever.
Manx: 28. Erson sh’ úney lesh yn Chiarn red ta káyragh : gha vel e tregáel y vẃìnjer héyn ta krawi, agh t’ ayd er nan vrial erson gybrágh.

English: 29 The righteous shall be punished : as for the seed of the ungodly, it shall be rooted out.
Manx: 29. Bi yn slŷi kayragh er nan geraghy : as erson rass y niaw ghráwi, bi e erna rowry magh.

English: The righteous (sic)] 1662 The unrighteous
30 The righteous shall inherit the land : and dwel therein for ever.
Manx: 30. Ni yn slŷi káyragh eiyrys y geadthyn ayns y talw : as vághe ayns shen erson gybrágh.

English: 31 The mouth of the righteous is exercised in wisedome : and his tongue will be talking of judgement.
Manx: 31. Ta béal ny néne káyragh klaghtíit ayns kiál : as bi y hiange taglw dy vrwinys.

English: 32 The Law of his God is in his heart : and his goings shall not slide.
Manx: 32. Ta ly̌ei y Iíh ayns y ghrí : as gha jean yn immíaght aggesyn skirrey.

English: 33 The ungodly seeth the righteous : and seeketh occasion to slay him.
Manx: 33. Híi yn niaw ghráwi yn dwyne káyragh : as t’ e shyirre óyr da varrw-syn.

English: 34 The Lord will not leave him in his hand : nor condemne him when he is judged.
Manx: 34. Gha váyg yn Chiarn eshyn ayns y láw : gha mẃ ni e eshyn y guere[91] tra víis brwinys erna hoyrt er.

English: 35 Hope thou in the Lord, and keepe his way, and he shal promote thee, that thou shalt possesse the land : when the ungodly shall perish, thou shalt see it.
Manx: 35. Tréist us ayns y Chiarn, as frial y ráyd, as trogi e shuas ẃ, gy vow ey̌irys ’sy talw : nar víis y niaw ghráwi erna ghwr mow, híi us é.

English: 36 I my selfe have seene the ungodly in great power: and flourishing like a greene Bay tree.
Manx: 36. Ghonićk mi héyn yn niaw ghráwi ayns pẃyr vẃar : as blághy mar bille bée glass.

English: 37 I went by, and loe he was gone : I sought him, but his place could no where be found.
Manx: 37. As ghai mi shaghy, as jeagh, ve er shiúl : heir mi e, agh gha dod yn ynyd aggesyn ve erna geadthyn ayns ynyd erbí.

English: 38 Keepe innocencie, and take heed unto the thing that is right : for that shall bring a man peace at the last.
Manx: 38. Bi gyn loght, as kwr tasky d’ yn ryd ta jiragh : erson ver shen shii gys dwyne ag y jere.

English: 39 As for the transgressors, they shall perish together : and the end of the ungodly is, They shal be rooted out at the last.
Manx: 39. As erson peki bíi áyd er nan doyrt mow kwjaght : as she jere yn niaw ghráwi, bíi ayd erna rowrey magh ag y jere.

English: 40 But the salvation of the righteous commeth of the Lord : which is also their strength in the time of trouble.
Manx: 40. Agh ta sawalys yn klyi ghráwi chíit dyn Chiarn : ta eshyn niist nan gniart ayns iérish sýaghyn.

English: which is] 1662 who is
41 And the Lord shall stand by them, and save them : hee shall deliver them from the ungodly, and shall save them, because they put their trust in him.
Manx: 41. As shassi yn Chiarn lioriusyn, as sawi é ayd : lifréi é áyd vei y niawghrawi as sawi é ayd, erson gy vel ayd toyrt nan dreistéel aynsyn.

English: The viii. day.
Manx: Yn viii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Domine ne in furore. Psal. 38.
Manx: Domine ne in furore. psal. 38.

English: Put me not to rebuke (O Lord) in thine anger : neither chasten me in thy heavie displeasure.
Manx: 1. Na tóyr mi gys náre, O Hiarn, ayns dthy ghòri : namw kw̌ysk mi ayns dthy iwmwiys vẃar.

English: 2 For thine arrows sticke fast in me : & thy hand presseth me sore.
Manx: 2. Erson ta dthy heidjyn sáitch[92] sickyr any̌ms : as ta dthy law dy my ghwmmel shiis gy tróym.

English: 3 There is no health in my flesh, because of thy displeasure : neither is there any rest in my bones, by reason of my sinne.
Manx: 3. Gha vel slaynt erbi ayns m’ éyl erson dthy iumwius : ghamẃ ta fe erbi ayns my ghnáwyn kientagh rish my pheky.

English: 4 For my wickednesses are gone over my head : and are like a sore burden too heavy for me to beare.
Manx: 4. Erson ta my grogh ianw er’ n’ol har̀rish my ghian : as t’ ayd kasly rish ere mẃar roo hroym dwys y ymmyrke.

English: 5 My wounds stink, & are corrupt : through my foolishnes.
Manx: 5. Ta my lottyn breyn as low : trýid m’ ámmyjys.

English: 6 I am brought into so great trouble and miserie : that I goe mourning all the day long.
Manx: 6. Ta mi er my hoyrt gys sýaghyn ghwish as trei : gy vel mi gimiaght keny fyei yn la.

English: 7 For my loynes are filled with a sore disease : and there is no whole part in my body.
Manx: 7. Erson ta my viaghyn liýnt rish drogh aslaint : as gha vel ayrn erbi sláyn ayns my ghorp.

English: 8 I am feeble and sore smitten : I have roared for the very disquietnesse of my heart.
Manx: 8. Ta mi anẃn as er my vóaly gy holk : ren mi bẃriẃgh erson yn ’íir anvé my ghri.

English: 9 Lord, thou knowest all my desire : and my groning is not hid from thee.
Manx: 9. Hiarn, sawn dw̌itch wlly my agney : as gha vel m’ akeǐn fallíit vǒid.

English: 10 My heart panteth, my strength hath failed mee : and the sight of mine eyes is gone from me.
Manx: 10. Ta my ghrí liěm,[93] ta my gniart er my hoyrt náyrdy : as ta shilliy my hẃilyn er nol vóỳm.

English: 11 My lovers and my neighbours did stand looking upon my trouble : and my kinsemen stood afarre off.
Manx: 11. Ren my gharjyn as my nabónyn shassw jághyn er my hýaghyn : as hass my gene mwinjer fodey voyms.

English: 12 They also that sought after my life, layd snares for me : and they that went about to doe mee evill talked of wickednesse, and imagined deceit all the day long.
Manx: 12. Aydsyn níist ren shyirře nyre my vé, hei áyd ribbaghyn er my hons : as áydsyn ghái magíỳrt dy ianw olk dwys, ren ayd taglw dy olkys, as smwni ayd maltéryght fei yn lá.

English: 13 As for me, I was like a deafe man, and heard not: and as one that is dumbe, which doeth not open his mouth.
Manx: 13. As er my hons va mi kasly rish dwyne boŵr, as gha gýyl mi : as mar anáyn ta bàllw, nagh vel foskyly y véal.

English: which doeth] 1662 who doth
14 I became even as a man that heareth not : and in whose mouth are no reproofes.
Manx: 14. Vá mi gy jarw mar dwyne nagh vel klastchen : as ayns y véal agǧesyn ghánel aghsan erbi.

English: 15 For in thee, O Lord, have I put my trust : thou shalt answere for me, O Lord my God.
Manx: 15. Erson aňyds, O Hiarn, ta mi er dóyrt my hreistéel : ní us fragyrt er my hons, O Hiarn my Iíh.

English: 16 I have required that they, even mine enemies, should not triumph over mee : for when my foot slipt, they rejoyced greatly against me.
Manx: 16. Ta mi er shy̌irre nagh jeanagh aydsyn, gy jarw my nóidjyn, bogey y góyl hařrym : erson tra ren my ghass skirr̀y, gow áyd bogey gy mẃar m’ ýoi.

English: 17 And I truely am set in the plague : and my heaviness is ever in my sight.
Manx: 17. As ta mish gy firrinagh seit ayns y phàtt : as ta my hrymsey gybrágh ayns my hilliy.

English: 18 For I wil confesse my wickednes : & be sory for my sinne.
Manx: 18. Erson goŵym rish m’ olkys : as bíỳm troym erson my pheky.

English: 19 But mine enemies live, and are mighty : and they that hate me wrongfully are many in number.
Manx: 19. Agh ta my nóidjyn bió, as t’ áyd gniartoil : as aydsyn ta dẃoi ack ořym gy hagáragh, t’ áyd ymmydi ayns erif.

English: 20 They also that reward evill for good, are against me : because I follow the thing that good is.
Manx: 20. Aydsyn níist ta kwilíny olk erson mei, t’ ayd m’ ýois : erson gy vel mi geiyrt er yn red ta mei.

English: 21 Forsake me not, O Lord my God : be not thou far from me.
Manx: 21. Na trég mi, O Hiarn, my Iíh : na bi us fodey vóỳms.

English: 22 Haste thee to helpe mee : O Lord God my salvation.
Manx: 22. Jean seir dy ghwyne laŷms : O Hiarn Jih my hawálys.

English: God my salvation, 1599] 1636, 1660 God of my salvation
Dixi, custodiam. Psal. 39.
Manx: Dixi cuﬆodiam. psal. 39.

English: I said, I will take heed to my wayes : that I offend not in my tongue.
Manx: 1. Dẃyrt mi, verrym tasky dy my ráydjyn : nagh jeanym foil ayns my hiangey.

English: 2 I will keepe my mouth, as it were with a bridle : while the ungodly is in my sight.
Manx: 2. Fríalym my véal, mar veagh e rish strýan : ghowd as ta yn niawghrawi ayns my hilliy.

English: 3 I helde my tongue, and spake nothing : I kept silence, yea, even from good words; but it was paine & griefe to me.
Manx: 3. Ghwmm mi my hiange, as gha lóyr mi veg : va mi [my] hòst, gy jarw, vei goyn mei, agh v’ e dokkyr as trymshey dwys.
hòst] ms. ghòst

English: 4 My heart was hotte within mee, and while I was thus musing, the fire kindled : and at the last I spake with my tongue;
Manx: 4. Va my ghrí che er lef stei jîm, as ghowd as va mi smwnaghtyn mar shó, ren yn aínnil lossy : as ag y jere lóyr mi rish my hiange.

English: 5 Lord, let me know mine ende, and the number of my dayes : that I may be certified how long I have to live.
Manx: 5. Hiarn, lig dow̌ fyss ve aŷm er my iere, as érif my lághyn : gy voddym ve sickyr káid ta áỳm dy ve bió.

English: 6 Behold, thou hast made my dayes as it were a spanne long : and mine age is even as nothing in respect of thee; and verily every man living is altogether vanity.
Manx: 6. Jeagh, tow ern’ ianw my lághyn mar véagh résh er líufrid : as gy jarw gha vel m’ ýesh veg dwich, as gy jarw ta dygh wlly gwyne bio wlly kwjaght fardálys.

English: 7 For man walketh in a vaine shadowe, and disquieteth himselfe in vaine : he heapeth up riches, and cannot tell who shall gather them.
Manx: 7. Erson ta dwyne gimmiaght ayns ska fardálagh,  as d’ ianw e héyn anvéagh ayns fardayl : te tórry shuas berchys as gha nell fyss agge quei haglys áyd.

English: 8 And now, Lord, what is my hope : truely my hope is even in thee.
Manx: 8. As nish, Hiarn, kre ta my hreistéel ? gy firrinagh ta my hreisteel gy jarw anyds.

English: 9 Deliver mee from all mine offences : and make mee not a rebuke unto the foolish.
Manx: 9. Lifrée mish vei my loghtyn wlly : as na jean náre jíỳms gys ny hammydanyn.

English: 10 I became dumbe, and opened not my mouth : for it was thy doing.
Manx: 10. Va mi ballw, as gha doskyl mi my véal : erson v’ e dthy iaǹwys.

English: 11 Take thy plague away from me : I am even consumed by the meanes of thy heavie hand.
Manx: 11. Gow dthy phatt as y ráyd voyms : ta mi gy jarw keyst[94] kientagh rish dthy law hróym.

English: 12 When thou with rebukes doest chasten man for sinne, thou makest his beauty to consume away like as it were a moth fretting a garment : every man therefore is but vanitie.
Manx: 12. Tra toŵs rish náreghyn kwsky gẁne erson peky, tow toyrt er y vóid kéyss er shiul, naght mar veagh liemyn gii ydagh : shenyfá gha vel gygh wlly gwyne agh fardálys.

English: 13 Heare my prayer, O Lord, and with thine eares consider my calling : hold not thy peace at my teares.
Manx: 13. Klast rish my phadjer, O Hiarn, as rish dthy ghléyshyn smẃni er m’ émagh : na kwmm dthy hiange ag my iéir.

English: 14 For I am a stranger with thee, and a sojourner : as all my fathers were.
Manx: 14. Erson she jóri mish mayrts, as fer-vághi : mar va m’ aeraghyn wlly.

English: 15 O spare mee a little, that I may recover my strength : before I goe hence, and be no more seene.
Manx: 15. O shaghan mi began beg, gy voddym my gniart y ghowrel : ma jéym as sho, as gyn ve er m’ akin nasmẃ.
jéym] ms. jénym

English: Expectans expectaui. Psal. 40.
Manx: Expectans expectaui psal. 40.

English: I waited patiently for the Lord : and hee enclined unto mee, and heard my calling.
Manx: 1. Darki mi gy míin er y Chiarn : as ghromm e hwym, as ghýyl é m’ émagh.

English: 2 He brought me also out of the horrible pit, out of the myre and clay : and set my feete upon the rocke, and ordered my goings.
Manx: 2. Hwgg é mish níist magh as yn lag aglagh, magh as yn laygh as ghré : as t’ e er seiaghe my ghassyn er yn ghreg, as ern’ ordráel my immiaghtyn.

English: 3 And hee hath put a newe song in my mouth : even a thankesgiving unto our God.
Manx: 3. As t’ e er doyrt oráyn nóo ayns my véal : gy jarw toyrt bwias dy nan Iíh.

English: 4 Many shall see it, and feare : and shall put their trust in the Lord.
Manx: 4. Híi ymmydi é, as gowi áyd agyl : as ver ayd nan dreistéel ayns y Chiarn.

English: 5 Blessed is the man that hath set his hope in the Lord : and turned not unto the proud, and to such as goe about with lies.
Manx: 5. Baníit ta yn dwỳne ta er doyrt y hreistéel ayns y Chiarn : as nagh hyndá gys yn klýèi vorniagh, as gys léid as ta doll magiyrt lesh brégyn.

English: 6 O Lord my God, great are thy wonderous workes which thou hast done : like as be also thy thoughts which are to us ward, and yet there is no man that ordereth them unto thee.
Manx: 6. O Hiarn my Iíh, sh’ mẃar t’ obbraghyn ientysagh tóẁs erna ianw : nash[95] mar ta tdy smwnaghtyn niist ta hwiniyn, as fóost gha vel dwyne erbi ta d’ an ordráel-syn dwitch.

English: 7 If I would declare them and speake of them : they should be mo then I am able to expresse.
Manx: 7. Gy níinshiyn áyd, as loyrt j́ù : véagh áyd nasmẃ na ta mish fowndagh dy hoyrt magh.

English: If I would] 1662 If I should; mo] 1660 more
8 Sacrifice and meate offering thou wouldest not have: but mine eares hast thou opened.
Manx: 8. Toyrtys kasserick as bí-óẁrel gha baylts y góyl : agh my ghlyeshyn ta us erna óskyly.

English: wouldest not have] 1662 wouldest not
9 Burnt offerings and sacrifice for sinne hast thou not required : then said I, Loe, I come,
Manx: 9. Owrelyn losk, as owrelyn erson peky gha hyirr us : éish dwyirt mish, jéagh, ta mi chíit.

English: 10 In the volume of the booke it is written of me, that I should fulfill thy will, O my God : I am content to do it; yea, thy Law is within my heart.
Manx: 10. Ayns korp yn liór té skriwt jiŷms, gy leishyns t’ agnys y liény, O my Iih : ta mi bẃiagh dy ianw é; gy jarw, ta dy ly̌ei er chew stei dy my ghrí.

English: 11 I have declared thy righteousnes in the great Congregation : loe, I will not refrane my lips, O Lord, and that thou knowest.
Manx: 11. Ta mi er soilsaghy dthy gháyrys ayns y chessiaght vẃar : jeagh, gha gwmmwm my veliyn, O Hiarn, as shen ta fyss áyds.

English: 12 I have not hid thy righteousnes within my heart : my talking hath beene of thy trueth and of thy salvation.
Manx: 12. Gha dalli mi dthy gháyrys er léf stei dy my ghrí : ta my haglw er mé dy t’ irrinys, as dy dthy hawálys.

English: my talking] 1662 my talk
13 I have not kept backe thy loving mercie and trueth : from the great Congregation.
Manx: 13. Gha ghwm mi er gẃl dthy vyghin grayiẃyl as t’ irrinys : vei yn chessiaght vẃar.

English: 14 Withdraw not thou thy mercie from mee, O Lorde: let thy loving kindenesse and thy trueth alway preserve mee.
Manx: 14. Na tarn us er shiul dthy vyghin vóỳms, O Hiarn : ligg e dthy gwghys grayiẃyl as t’ irrinys goni mish y ríal.

English: 15 For innumerable troubles are come about mee; my sinnes have taken such hold upon mee, that I am not able to looke up : yea, they are mo in number then the haires of mine head, and mine heart hath failed me.
Manx: 15. Erson ta syaghyn erskyn erif er jít magiyrt ymmw̌yms, ta my phekaghyn ern’ góyl leid y grým ořyms, nagh vel mi fowndagh dy iaghyn shuas : gy jarw, t’ áyd nasmẃ ayns eryf na fóolt my ghiin, as ta my ghri er my hóyrt nárdy.

English: 16 O Lord, let it be thy pleasure to deliver me : make haste (O Lord) to helpe me.
Manx: 16. O Hiarn, ligg e ve t’ agnys dy my lifrée : jean seir, O Hiarn, dy ghẃne liam.

English: 17 Let them bee ashamed and confounded together that seeke after my soule to destroy it : let them bee driven backward and put to rebuke that wish me evill.
Manx: 17. Lig gawsyn ve náríit, as ve er nan doyrt mow kwjaght, ta shiyrre nyre my anyms da strwiel é : lig gawsyn ve er nan iymman góeir nan drom̀my as er nan doyrt gys náre ta sowlaghy olk dwys.

English: 18 Let them be desolate and rewarded with shame, that say unto me: Fie upon thee, fie upon thee.
Manx: 18. Lig gawsyn ve er nan dregél as er nan íik rish náry : ta gra rŵyms, fúi oyrts, fúi oyrts.

English: 19 Let all those that seeke thee, be joyful, and glad in thee : and let such as love thy Salvation, say alway, The Lord be praised.
Manx: 19. Lig gawsyn wlly ta dy hiyrrys ve gannoil as bogóil ayňyds : as leid as shúney-lésh dthy hawálys, gra goni, molit gy row yn Chiarn.

English: 20 As for me, I am poore and needy : but the Lord careth for me.
Manx: 20. As er my hons, ta mi boght as árkysagh : agh ta yn Chiarn gimné er my honn.

English: 21 Thou art my helper and Redeemer : make no long tarying, O my God.
Manx: 21. She us m’ er kẃney as m’ er kani ríist : na jean fwrraghtyn foděy, O my Iíh.

English: The viii. day.
Manx: Yn viii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Beatus qui intelligit. Psal. 41.
Manx: Beatus qui intelligit. [psal. 41.]

English: Blessed is he that considereth the poore (and needy) : the Lord shall deliver him in the time of trouble.
Manx: 1. Baniit ta eshyn ta tóyrt tasky dyn voght as ymmyrtsagh : lifréi yn Chiarn eshyn ayns ierish syaghyn.

English: 2 The Lord preserve him and keep him alive, that hee may be blessed upon earth : and deliver not thou him into the will of his enemies.
Manx: 2. Yn Chiarn dâ ghawdesyn as dâ ghummel-syn bió, gy vod e vé baníit er y tallw : as na lifre us eshyn gys agney y noidjyn.

English: 3 The Lorde comfort him, when hee lyeth sicke upon his bedde : make thou all his bed in his sickenesse.
Manx: 3. Yn Chiarn dy gýrjaghy eshyn nar t’ e lyi chíin er y liabbi : jean us wlly y liabbi ayns y hinnys.

English: 4 I said, Lord be mercifull unto me : heale my soule, for I have sinned against thee.
Manx: 4. Dwyrt mi, O Hiarn, bi trokroil dwys : slani m’ anyms erson ta mi ern ianw peky t’ yois.

English: 5 Mine enemies speake evill of me : when shall he die, and his name perish?
Manx: 5. Ta my noidjyn loyrt olk jíms : kwyn víis e marw, as y enym-syn chereghtyn?

English: 6 And if he come to see me, he speaketh vanitie: and his heart conceiveth falshood within himselfe, and when he commeth, forth he telleth it.
Manx: 6. As ma higg e dy my iaghyn, t’ e lóyrt fardalys : as ta y ghri genaghtyn fallsyght er léyf stei je héyn, as nar te chiit magh [te] da insh é.
insh é] ms. inshé

English: 7 All mine enemies whisper together against me: even against me doe they imagine this evill.
Manx: 7. Ta my noidjyn wlly shansieryght kwjaght m’ yôis : gy jarw, m’ yôis t’ ayd smwnaghtyn yn olk shó.

English: 8 Let the sentence of guiltinesse proceed against him : and now that he lyeth, let him rise up no more.
Manx: 8. Ligg e brẃinys oẃlid[96] dol magh na ŷoi-syn : as nish tra t’ e na lyei, na lig gâ irri shúas aragh.

English: 9 Yea, even mine owne familiar friend whom I trusted : which did also eat of my bread, hath laid great wait for me.
Manx: 9. Shé, gy jarw, my gharry dwi héyn ren mish y hreistéel : jí níist dy m’ aran, t’ e ern’ ianw seiaghe mẃar er my ghon.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: er] ms. ar

English: 10 But be thou merciful unto me, O Lord : raise thou me up againe, and I shall reward them.
Manx: 10. Agh bi us myghinagh dwys, O Hiarn : trog us mish shuas ríist, as niyms aydsyn y ghwiliny.

English: 11 By this I know thou favourest me : that mine enemy doeth not triumph against me.
Manx: 11. Liorish shó sawn dẃỳs gy vel us dy m’ ’oráel : nagh vel my noidjyn goyl barriygh m’ ýoi.

English: 12 And when I am in my health, thou upholdest me : and shalt set me before thy face for ever.
Manx: 12. As nar ta mi ayns my láint tow dy my ghwmmel shuas : as sy̌it us mish kiangóyrt rish t’ edyn erson gybragh.

English: 13 Blessed bee the Lorde God of Israel : world without end. Amen.
Manx: 13. Baníit gy row yn Chiarn Jih Eisrael : sýyl gyn ghian. Amen, marshen-gy-row.[97]

English: Quemadmodum. Psal. 42.
Manx: Quemadmodum. psal. 42.

English: Like as the hart desireth the water brookes : so longeth my soule after thee, O God.
Manx: 1. Mar ta yn fúei[98] shyirre nyre ny strẃanyn wiskey : marshen ta m’ anym goyl fodiaght t’ ’yrus,[99] O Iíh.

English: 2 My soule is athirst for God, yea, even for the living God : when shall I come to appeare before the presence of God?
Manx: 2. Ta m’ anym páa erson Jih, she, gy jarw, erson yn Jih béoil : kwyn hiǧgyms dy my iaghyn heyn ayns feanish Iíh?

English: 3 My teares have bene my meate day and night : while they dayly say unto me, Where is now thy God?
Manx: 3. Ta my iěir er me my víi, lá as yí : ghowd as t’ áyd gygh wlly lá gra rẃms, kàj̀e[100] vel nish dthy Iíh ?

English: 4 Nowe when I thinke thereupon, I powre out my heart by my selfe : for I went with the multitude, & brought them forth into the house of God;
Manx: 4. Nish tra ta mi smẃnaghtyn er shen, ta mi duerty magh my ghri liôrym peyn : erson ghai mi marish yn chessiaght as hwgg mi magh ayd gys tei Iíh;

English: 5 In the voyce of praise and thankesgiving : among such as keepe holy day.
Manx: 5. Ayns korá moly as toyrt bwias : masky yn leid-syn as ta kwmmel lá feliy.

English: 6 Why art thou so full of heavinesse (O my soul) : and why art thou so disquieted within me?
Manx: 6. Kamma vel us gho láyn dy hrimse, O m’ anym : as kamma vel us gho anvéagh er lief stei jím?

English: 7 Put thy trust in God : for I will yet give him thankes for the helpe of his countenance.
Manx: 7. Tóer dthy ierkel ayns Jíh : erson veryms fóyst bẃias dasyn erson kẃne y éi.

English: 8 My God, my soul is vexed within mee : therefore will I remember thee, concerning the land of Jordane, and the little hill of Hermon.
Manx: 8. My Iih, ta m’ anym syit er lief stei ĵim : shenefa kwiniym oyrts benelt rish talw Iurynan, as knock beg Hermon.

English: 9 One deepe calleth another, because of the noyse of the water pipes : all thy waves and stormes are gone over me.
Manx: 9. Ta yn dyifnid gémagh er dyifnid elle, erson féìr ny pipanyn wyske : ta dy hoǹnyn wlly as dy gorrinyn ern’ ’oll harryms.
gorrinyn] ms. gonyn

English: 10 The Lord hath granted his loving kindnes on the day time : and in the night season did I sing of him, and made my prayer unto the God of my life.
Manx: 10. Ta yn Chiarn ern’ ialtyn y gwghys grayiwil ayns ierish y lá : as léas yi gow mish oráyn jeshyn, as ren mi my phajer gys Jíh my vé.

English: 11 I will say unto the God of my strength, Why hast thou forgotten me : why goe I thus heavily, while the enemie oppresseth me?
Manx: 11. Jirrym rish Jíh my gniárt, kamma vel us er my iarẃd : kamma vel mish gimiaght gho troym shó, ghowd as ta yn noid janw trynlás oryms?

English: 12 My bones are smitten asunder as with a sword : while mine enemies (that trouble me) cast me in the teeth;
Manx: 12. Ta my ghnáwyn er nan moaly as y ghielle mar rish kleiw : ghowd as ta my nóidjyn ta dy my hyaghy, dy my hilge ayns my feaklyn.

English: 13 Namely, while they say dayly unto me : Where is now thy God?
Manx: 13. [...][101] ghowd as t’ ayd grá gygh wlly lá rwyms : kaje vel nish dthy Iíh?

English: 14 Why art thou so vexed, O my soule : and why art thou so disquieted within me?
Manx: 14. Kamma vel us gho gonit, O m’ anym : as kamma vel us gho anvéagh er léif stei j́ìm?

English: 15 O put thy trust in GOD : for I will yet thanke him, which is the helpe of my countenance and my God.
Manx: 15. O toer dthy ierkel ayns Jíh : erson verym fóost bẃias dâsyn ta kwney my gnwish,[102] as my Iíh.

English: Iudica me Deus. Psal. 43.
Manx: Iudica me deus. psal. 43.

English: Give sentence with me, O God, and defend my cause against the ungodly people : O deliver me from the deceitfull and wicked man.
Manx: 1. Kur brwinys er my heyfs, O Iíh, as fríal my ghwsyn nýoi yn slyi niawghrawi : O lifré mish vei yn dwyne malteragh as olk.

English: 2 For thou art the God of my strength, why hast thou put mee from thee : and why goe I so heavily, while the enemie oppresseth me?
Manx: 2. Erson she us Jih my gniárt, kamma vel us er my hort void : as kamma vel mish gimíaght gho troym ghowd as ta yn noid janw trynlás orym.
ta] ms. te

English: 3 Oh sende out thy light and thy trueth, that they may leade me : and bring me unto thy holy hill, & to thy dwelling.
Manx: 3. O toer magh dthy hoilshe as t’ irrinys, gy vod ayd my lidjéel : as kwr mish gys dthy ghnock ghasserick, as gys dthy vaghey.

English: 4 And that I may goe unto the Altar of God, even unto the God of my joy and gladnesse : and upon the harpe will I give thanks unto thee, O God my God.
Manx: 4. As gy vodym dol gys alter Iih, gy jarw gys Jíh my voge as my ian[103] : as er yn krwitch verym bwias dwitch, O Iíh, my Iíh.

English: 5 Why art thou so heavie, O my soul : and why art thou so disquieted within me?
Manx: 5. Kamma vel us gho troym, O m’ anym : as kamma vel ẃ gho anvéagh er léif stei ĵiyms?

English: 6 O put thy trust in God : for I wil yet give him thanks, which is the helpe of my countenance, and my God.
Manx: 6. O toer dthy ierkel ayns Jíh : erson verym fóost bẃias dâsyn she ta kwney m’ ei, as my Iíh.

English: The ix. day.
Manx: Yn ix. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Deus auribus. Psal. 44
Manx: Deus auribus noﬆris. psal. 44.

English: We have heard with our eares, O God, our fathers have tolde us : what thou hast done in their time of olde;
Manx: 1. Ghýyl shwin rish nan glyasyn, O Iíh, jinsh nan áeraghyn dwiniyn : kre ren us ayns yn ierish acksyn ’sy chan amser;

English: 2 How thou hast driven out the Heathen with thy hand, and planted them in : how thou hast destroyed the nations and cast them out.
Manx: 2. Kyns ta us ern’ iímman magh ny hangristin rish dthy law, as er nan seiaghe-syn schiagh : kyns tow er doyrt mow ny natiẃnyn, as er nan dilge magh.

English: 3 For they gate not the land in possession through their owne sword : neither was it their owne arme that helped them;
Manx: 3. Erson gha dwóer áyd yn talw ayns êirys tryid nan gliew héyn : gha mw v’ e yn ryi ack héyn ren kwney liew.

English: 4 But thy right hand, and thine arme, and the light of thy countenance : because thou haddest a favour unto them.
Manx: 4. Agh dthy law iesh as dthy ry̆i, as soilshe dthy gnẃish : erson gy row fóer áyds dawsyn.

English: 5 Thou art my King (O God) : send helpe unto Jacob.
Manx: 5. Shé us my ríi, O Iíh : kwr kẃne gys Jakob.

English: 6 Through thee wil we overthrow our enemies : and in thy Name will we tread them under that rise up against us.
Manx: 6. Troyids hilg meid harrish nan noidjyn : as ayns t’ enyms stampi meid aydsyn fwo ta gire shúas nan yoi.

English: 7 For I wil not trust in my bow : it is not my sword that shall helpe me;
Manx: 7. Erson gha jerkyms ayns my vow : ghanié my ghleiw ghẃnys láyms.
ghanié] ms. ghani é

English: 8 But it is thou that savest us from our enemies : and puttest them to confusion that hate us.
Manx: 8. Agh she us ta d’ ’an sawáel shwin vei nan noidjyn : as d’ ’an dóyrt-syn moẃ ta dwoi ack orwiniyn.

English: 9 We make our boast of God all day long : and will praise thy Name for ever.
Manx: 9. Ta shwin janw nan mogyss dy Iih fei yn lá : as mol med t’ enyms erson gybragh.

English: 10 But now thou art farre off, and puttest us to confusion : and goest not foorth with our armies.
Manx: 10. Agh nish ta us fodey vóìn, as dan doyrt shwiniyn moẃ : as gha vel ẃ dol magh marish nan shessaghtyn ghagi.

English: 11 Thou makest us to turne our backs upon our enemies : so that they which hate us, spoile our goods.
Manx: 11. Tow toyrt orwiniyn nan rymmyn y hyndá er nan noidjyn : marshen gy vel áydsyn ta dwoi ack orwiniyn rwysky nan gwid.

English: 12 Thou lettest us be eaten up like sheep : and hast scattered us among the heathen.
Manx: 12. Tow ligge dwiniyn dy ve er nan ii shúas mar kirri : as er nan skyle masky ny hangristín.

English: 13 Thou sellest thy people for nought : and takest no money for them.
Manx: 13. Tow kreck dthy phobyl erson veg : as gha vel ẃ goyl veg yn argyd er-nan-son.

English: 14 Thou makest us to bee rebuked of our neighbours : to bee laughed to scorne and had in derision of them that are round about us.
Manx: 14. Tow toyrt orwiniyn dy ve er nan náraghy dy nan nabwnyn : dy ve er nan gáry gys knaid, as ayns faghid jusyn ta chymmylt magíyrt ymmw̌in.

English: 15 Thou makest us to be a by-word among the heathen : and that the people shake their heads at us.
Manx: 15. Tow toyrt orwin dy ve nan angóo[104] masky ny hangristín : as gy vel yn pobyl krá nan gíin orwiniyn.

English: 16 My confusion is daily before me : and the shame of my face hath covered me;
Manx: 16. Ta my náre gygh wlly lá m’ ’ienish : as ta náre my ydyn er my ghẃdaghy.

English: 17 For the voice of the slanderer and blasphemer: for the enemie and avenger.
Manx: 17. Erson korá yn fer líùn as yn dwyne ta lóyrt gy malaghtagh : erson y nóid, as yn fer ta kwiliny.

English: 18 And though all this be come upon us, yet do we not forget thee : nor behave our selves frowardly in thy Covenant.
