Manx: 18. As gy ta wlly sho er jit orwiniyn, foyst ghá vel shwin dy dthy iarẃd : na d’ an ymmyrke héyn gy frowyrtagh ayns dthy ghwnánts.

English: 19 Our heart is not turned back : neither our steps gone out of thy way;
Manx: 19. Gha vel nan grí er y hyndá er gẃl : gha mẃ ta nan gasmedjyn er nol as dy ráyds;

English: 20 No not when thou hast smitten us into the place of Dragons : and covered us with the shadow of death.
Manx: 20. Ghanel, nar tow er nan moally shwin ayns ynyd ny nrágwnyn : as er nan gwdaghy shwin rish ská yn váas.

English: 21 If we have forgotten the Name of our God, and holden up our hands to any strange god : shall not God search it out? for he knoweth the very secrets of the heart.
Manx: 21. My ta shwin ern’ iarẃd enym nan Iíh, as er drogel shúas nan lawyn gys Jih erbi jori : nagh ranshi Jih magh e? erson sawn da fíir alliaghtyn[105] yn ghri.
ranshi] ms. ranshigi

English: 22 For thy sake also are wee killed all the day long : and are counted as sheepe appointed to be slaine.
Manx: 22. Er dthy hons níist ta shwin er nan marw fei yn lá : as ta shwin er nan góyl mar kirri ordíit dy ve er nan marw.

English: 23 Up Lord, why sleepest thou : awake, and be not absent from us for ever.
Manx: 23. Shuas, Hiarn, kamma vel ẃ kadley : dwisk, as na bi as y ráyd voiniyn erson gybragh.

English: 24 Wherefore hidest thou thy face : and forgettest our miserie and trouble?
Manx: 24. Kamma vel us fallaghy t’ ydyn : as jarwd nan dreyid[106] as nan syaghyn.
jarwd] ms. jarwd y; dreyid] ms. tdreyid

English: 25 For our soule is brought low, even unto the dust : our belly cleaveth unto the ground.
Manx: 25. Erson ta nan anym erna hoyrt íshill, gy jarw gys yn ẃyer : as ta nan molg lienaghtyn gys y talw.

English: 26 Arise, and helpe us : and deliver us for thy mercies sake.
Manx: 26. Irri as kwin leniyn : as lifre shwin erson grayi dthy vyghin.

English: Eructauit cor meum. Psal 45.
Manx: Eructauit cor meum. psal. 45.

English: My heart is enditing of a good matter : I speake of the things which I have made unto the King.
Manx: 1. Ta my ghri toyrt magh red mei : loyrym dy ny redyn ta mi ern’ ianw gys y ríi.

English: 2 My tongue is the pen : of a readie writer.
Manx: 2. She my hiange fedjagh skriwi : dy skriwdêr arlẃ.
She] ms. Sshe

English: 3 Thou art fairer then the children of men : full of grace are thy lips, because God hath blessed thee for ever.
Manx: 3. Tow nas áliy na klawn déney : láyn dy gráys ta dy veliyn, erson gy vel Jih er dy vanaghe erson gybragh.

English: 4 Gird thee with thy sword upon thy thigh, O thou most mighty : according to thy worship and renowne.
Manx: 4. Chian w heyn rish tdy ghleiow er dy lieshid,[107] O us smẃ gniartoil : nyre t’ ammys as t’ ýasly.

English: 5 Good lucke have thou with thine honour : ride on, because of the word of trueth, of meekenesse, and righteousnes; and thy right hand shall teach thee terrible things.
Manx: 5. Ayí-mei gy row ayds lesh t’ oneyrs : marki er dy hoshiagh, erson gẃ ny firriny, dy vinid, as dy gháyrys, as ynsi dthy law iesh dwitch redyn aglagh.

English: 6 Thy arrowes are very sharpe, and the people shall be subdued unto thee : even in the middes among the Kings enemies.
Manx: 6. Ta dthy hédjyn fíir iér, as bi yn pobyl er an gwr shíis dwitch : gy jarw ayns [y] véyn masky nóidjyn yn ríi.

English: 7 Thy seate (O God) endureth for ever : the Scepter of thy kingdome is a right Scepter.
Manx: 7. Ta t’ enyds, O Iíh, faraghtyn erson gybragh : ta lorg[108] gniart dy ririyghts lorg gniart káyragh.
lorg ´2] ms. larg ´2

English: 8 Thou hast loved righteousnesse, and hated iniquitie : wherefore God (even thy God) hath anointed thee with the oyle of gladnesse above thy fellowes.
Manx: 8. Biíny lets kayrys, as va dwoi ayds er peky : shenyfá ta Jíh gy jarw dy Íihys er t’ wilus rish ẃil dy gannylys erskyn dthy heshaghyn.
t’ wilus] ms. twil vs; heshaghyn] ms. hesshaghyn

English: 9 All thy garments smell of Myrrhe, Aloes, and Cassia : out of the Ivory palaces, wherby they have made thee glad.
Manx: 9. Ta wlly t’ ydagh soary dy vyrr, aloes, as kássia : magh as ny plasyn iveri, liorish t’ áyd er d’ ianw̓s gannoil.
iveri] ms. jveri

English: 10 Kings daughters were among thy honourable women : upon thy right hand did stand the Queene in a vesture of gold (wrought about with divers colours).
Manx: 10. Va innínyn ríaghyn masky dy vynáyn ýasyl : er dthy law iěsh hass yn ven ríin ayns kómry áyr óbrit magiyrt rish kyghlághyn dâ.

English: 11 Hearken (O daughter) and consider, encline thine eare : forget also thine owne people, and thy fathers house.
Manx: 11. Klast, O inín, as smwni, krom dthy ghlúesh : jarẃd níist dthy phobyl héyn as ty̌i t’ aeyry.

English: 12 So shall the King have pleasure in thy beautie : for he is thy Lord (God) and worship thou him.
Manx: 12. Marshen víis agny ag y ríi ayns dthy vóiid : erson shé eshyn dthy Hiarn Jíh, as jean ammys dá.

English: 13 And the daughter of Tyre shal be there with a gift : like as the rich also among the people shall make their supplication before thee.
Manx: 13. As bíi inín Teir aynshen lesh toyrtys : margedyn ni yn slyei berchiagh masky yn phobyl nan akan kiangóyrt rwyts.
berchiagh] ms. berchigh

English: 14 The Kings daughter is all glorious within : her clothing is of wrought gold.
Manx: 14. Ta inín yn ríi wlly gloróil er liêf stei : ta y ydagh dy áyr óbrit.

English: 15 Shee shal be brought unto the King in raiment of needle worke : the Virgins that be her fellowes shall beare her company, and shall be brought unto thee.
Manx: 15. Bi [i] erna tóyrt gys yn ríi ayns komry dy obyr snaidje : ny méidjynyn ta y shessaghyn, kwmmi áyd shessaght rí, as bi áyd er nan doyrt hŵyds.

English: 16 With joy and gladnesse shall they be brought : and shall enter into the Kings palace.
Manx: 16. Rish bogey as gàn víis áyd er nan dóyrt : as hèdj áyd schiagh ayns plás y ríi.
schiagh] ms. chiagh

English: 17 In stead of thy fathers thou shalt have children: whom thou mayest make princes in all lands.
Manx: 17. Ayns ynyd t’ aeraghyn, iew us klawn : ’odyst ẃ y ianw nan brynsyn ayns gygh wlly hàllw.

English: 18 I wil remember thy Name from one generation to another : therefore shall the people give thankes unto thee world without end.
Manx: 18. Kwiniym er t’ enyms vei yn shilógh gys shilógh elle : shennyfá ver yn pobyl bwias dwich sýyl gyn ghian.

English: Deus noster refugium. Psal. 46.
Manx: Deus noﬆer refugium. psal. 46.

English: God is our hope and strength : a very present helpe in trouble.
Manx: 1. She Jíh nan dreistéel as gniárt : kẃney fir ’aggys ayns sýaghyn.

English: 2 Therefore will wee not feare though the earth be mooved : and though the hilles bee caried into the middes of the Sea.
Manx: 2. Shenyfá gha gow meid agyl, ga víis yn talw erna ghrá : as ga víis ny knwick er nan iymmyrke gys méan yn arge;

English: 3 Though the waters thereof rage & swell : and though the mountaines shake at the tempest of the same.
Manx: 3. Gá víis ny hwiskaghyn agge kýei as gatt : as gy ni ny knwick krá ag [y] dorryn aggesyn.

English: 4 The rivers of the flood thereof shall make glad the Citie of God : the holy place of the Tabernacle of the most Highest.
Manx: 4. Nii strẃanyn yn twlliy aggesyn ganoil ard valle Iíh : ynyd kassarick kabán aglish d’ yn yrje smẃ.

English: 5 God is in the middest of her, therefore shall shee not be remooved : God shall helpe her, and that right earely.
Manx: 5. Ta Jíh ayns y véyn ack, shenyfá ghá bí hí erna skwghey : kwni Jih lei, as shen gy fíir voghey.

English: 6 The heathen make much ado, and the kingdomes are moved : but God hath shewed his voyce, and the earth shall melt away.
Manx: 6. Ta ny hangristín janw fy̌eir mẃar, as ta ny ríriaghtyn er nan skwghey : agh ta Jih ern’ iaghyn y ghorá, as lyegi yn talw er shiul.
ríriaghtyn] ms. ríriaghyn

English: 7 The Lord of hostes is with us : the God of Jacob is our refuge.
Manx: 7. Ta Chiarn ny hói[109] marwin : she Jíh Jakob nan gemmirk.

English: 8 O come hither, and behold the workes of the Lord : what destruction he hath brought upon the earth.
Manx: 8. O targi aynsho, as jeaghi[110] er obraghyn y Chiarn : kre yn kwr moŭ te er y hoyrt er y talẃ.

English: 9 He maketh warres to cease in all the world : he breaketh the bow, and knappeth the speare in sunder, and burneth the chariots in the fire.
Manx: 9. Te tóyrt er kagaghyn dy skwir ayns y týyl wlly : t’ e brishie yn vow, as ráby yn tly̌ei as y ghielle, as losky ny siaredyn ayns yn aínnil.

English: 10 Be still then, and know that I am God : I will be exalted among the heathen, and I will be exalted in the earth.
Manx: 10. Bi kíẁn êish, as twigigi gy ní mish Jíh : bíìms er my hrogel shuas masky ny hangristín, as bíìm er my hrogel shuas ayns y tálw.

English: 11 The Lord of hostes is with us : the God of Jacob is our refuge.
Manx: 11. Ta Chiarn ny hói marwiniyn : she Jíh Jakob nan gemmirk.

English: The ix. day.
Manx: Yn ix. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Omnes gentes plaudite. Psal. 47.
Manx: Omnes gentes plaudite. psal. 47.

English: O clap your hands together, (all ye people :) O Sing unto God with the voyce of melodie,
Manx: 1. O bóaligi nan lawyn kwjaght, wlly shiusse phobyl : O gowigi oráyn gys Jíh rish korá bín.

English: 2 For the Lord is high, and to be feared : hee is the great King upon all the earth.
Manx: 2. Er son ta yn Chiarn árd, as agyl dy vé erná góyl rêyfs : she eshyn yn ríi mẃar er yn talw wlly.
rêyfs] ms. rêyss

English: 3 Hee shall subdue the people under us : and the nations under our feet.
Manx: 3. Ver e shíis yn phobyl fwoniyn, as ny hatíwnyn fẃo nan gassyn.

English: 4 He shall chuse out an heritage for us : even the worship of Jacob whom he loved.
Manx: 4. Réigi[111] e magh éirys dwiniyn : gy jarw ammys Jakob býny lesh-syn.

English: 5 God is gone up with a mery noise : and the Lord with the sound of the Trumpe.
Manx: 5. Ta Jih er nol shúas rish korá[112] gannoil : as yn Chiarn rish fy̌eir y gharn prass.

English: 6 O sing praises, sing praises unto (our) God : O sing praises, sing praises unto our King.
Manx: 6. O gowgi orányn moli, gowgi orányn moli gys nan Iíh : O gowgi oráynyn moli gys nan ríi.

English: 7 For God is the King of all the earth : sing yee praises with understanding.
Manx: 7. Erson she Jíh ríi yn talw wlly : gowigi orányn moli rish twigel.

English: 8 God reigneth over the heathen : God sitteth upon his Holy seat.
Manx: 8. Ta Jih réel harrish ny hatiẃni : ta Jíh sei er y ynyd ghasserićk.
hatiẃni] ms. héthni

English: 9 The princes of the people are joyned unto the people of the God of Abraham : for God (which is very high exalted) doeth defend the Earth as it were with a shield.
Manx: 9. Ta prinsaghyn yn phobyl er ’an dóyrt kẃjaght gys pobyl Iíh Abraham : erson ta Jíh, ta gy fír áyrd erna hrogel shúas, fríal yn talw, mar véagh e rish ské.

English: Magnus Dominus. Psal. 48.
Manx: Magnus Dominus. psal. 48.

English: Great is the Lord, and highly to be praised : in the Citie of our God, even upon his Holy hill.
Manx: 1. Ta yn Chiarn mẃar, as gy hard dy vé erna voley : ayns áyrd valle nan Iíh, gy jarw er y ghnock ghasserick.

English: 2 The hill of Sion is a faire place, and the joy of the whole earth : upon the Northside lieth the Citie of the great King; God is well knowen in her palaces, as a sure refuge.
Manx: 2. Ta knock Seion ynyd alin, as bogey yn týyl wlly : er yn chef twoi ta lyi ayrd valle yn ríi vẃar; sawn daw gy mei Jih ayns ny plasyn ěcks mar kémrick síćkkyr.

English: 3 For loe, the Kings of the earth : are gathered and gone by together.
Manx: 3. Erson jéagh, ta riaghyn yn talẃin : chiaglit as er nol shaghe kwjaght.

English: 4 They marveiled to see such things : they were astonied, and suddenly cast downe.
Manx: 4. Gow ayd ientyss d’ akin leid ny redyn shen : va áyd achẏmagh, as dol tattym er nan dilge shíis.

English: 5 Feare came there upon them, and sorrow : as upon a woman in her travaile.
Manx: 5. Haink agyl ořw aynshen, as trimshe : mar er ben er trawelt.

English: 6 Thou shalt breake the ships of the Sea : through the East winde.
Manx: 6. Brishit ẃ longyn na mǎrry : tryid yn gýa niěr.

English: 7 Like as we have heard, so have we seene in the City of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God : God upholdeth the same for ever.
Manx: 7. Nash mar ghýyl shwin, margedyn ghonick shwin ayns ayrd valle yn Chiarn ny hoi, [ayns ayrd valle] nan Iíh : ta Jih dy ghwmmel shen shuas erson gybragh.

English: 8 We wait for thy loving kindnesse (O God :) in the mids of thy Temple.
Manx: 8. Ta shwin farkiaght er dthy gwghys grayiẃyl, O Iíh : ayns méyn dthy hambyl.

English: 9 O God, according unto thy Name, so is thy praise unto the worlds end : thy right hand is full of righteousnesse.
Manx: 9. O Iíh, mar ta t’ enyms, margedyn ta dthy vòlley gys kián yn týyl : ta dthy láw iésh layn dy ghárys.

English: 10 Let the mount Sion rejoyce, and the daughters of Juda be glad : because of thy Judgements.
Manx: 10. Ligg e knock Seion bogey y góyl, as iníyn Juda ve gannoil : erson dthy vrẃinys.

English: 11 Walke about Sion, and go round about her : and tel the towres thereof.
Manx: 11. Immigi magiyrt Seion, as shiuligi krwn magiyrt ymbí : as eryfgi ny tẃryn eck.

English: 12 Marke well her bulwarks, set up her houses : that ye may tell them that come after.
Manx: 12. Kwrrigi taske mei dy ny volaghyn ěck, síǵgi[113] shuas y těiyn ěck : gy vod shiu insh gawsyn higg nan iěi.

English: 13 For this God is our God for ever and ever : he shall be our guide unto death.
Manx: 13. Erson she yn Jíh shó yn Jih áìniyn erson gybrágh : bi e nan lidjér gys báas.

English: Audite hæc omnes. Psal. 49
Manx: Audite hec omnes. psal. 49.

English: O Heare yee this all ye people : ponder it with your eares, all ye that dwell in the world;
Manx: 1. O klastigi rish shó, wlly shiusse phobyl : smwnigi er rish nan glyasyn, shiusse wlly ta vaghey ayns y týyl;
shiusse phobyl] ms. shiuss y phobyl

English: 2 High and low, rich and poore : one with another.
Manx: 2. Árd as íshil, boght as bertchiagh : gygh anáyn ra ghiělle.

English: 3 My mouth shall speake of Wisedome : and my heart shall muse of understanding.
Manx: 3. Loyri my véal dy ghrínyght : as smẃni my ghri er twigel.

English: 4 I will incline mine eare to the parable : and shewe my darke speech upon the harpe.
Manx: 4. Króymmym my ghlýesh gys y ghóra dorghy : as soilshiym my glayr dorghy er y ghrw̌it.

English: 5 Wherefore should I feare in the days of wickednes : and when the wickednes of my heeles compasseth me round about?
Manx: 5. Krefá goinsh agyl ayns lághyn yn olkys : as nar ta olkys my vǒynyn seiaghy orym krw̌in magiyrt?

English: 6 There bee some that put their trust in their goods : and boast themselves in the multitude of their riches.
Manx: 6. Ta payrt ta toyrt nan dreistéel ayns nan gwidj : as d’ an mogassi héyn ayns ymmydi ’an merchys.

English: 7 But no man may deliver his brother : nor make agreement unto God for him;
Manx: 7. Agh gha vod dwyne erbi y vráer y lifré : na kordáil y ianw rish Jih er y-hon.

English: 8 For it cost more to redeeme their soules : so that he must let that alone for ever;
Manx: 8. Erson ghost e nasmẃ dy ghiánaghy nan anminiyn : marshen gy nagyn dâ ligge dâ shen vei gybragh;

English: 9 Yea, though he live long : and see not the grave.
Manx: 9. Gy jarw, ga víis e bio fodey : as gyn ýei y ákin.

English: 10 For he seeth that wise men also die, & perish together : as wel as the ignorant & foolish, and leave their riches for other.
Manx: 10. Erson híi e gy vel déne kriny níist fyethyn báys, as cheraghtyn kẃjaght : ghomma as yn slyei niawghriny as ammyjagh, as fagáel nan merchys d’ ’ielagh elle.

English: 11 And yet they thinke that their houses shall continue for ever : and that their dwelling places shall endure from one generation to another; and call their landes after their owne names.
Manx: 11. As fóost t’ ayd smwnaghtyn gy var nan déìyn erson gybrágh : as gy var nan enydyn vaghey vei yn shilógh gys shilógh elle, as génmys ny talẃiniyn nýre nan enmyn héyn.
enmyn] ms. enmys

English: 12 Neverthelesse, man wil not abide in honour : seeing he may be compared unto the beasts that perish; this is the way of them.
Manx: 12. Na iei, gha van dwyne ayns onèyr : fackin gy vod e ve erna hoylaghy rish ny běiyn ta cheraghtyn; she sho yn rayd ack.

English: 13 This is their foolishnesse : and their posteritie praise their saying.
Manx: 13. She sho nan ammyjys : as ta ’an slwght moley ’an rá.

English: 14 They lie in the hell like sheepe, death gnaweth upon them, and the righteous shall have domination of them in the morning : their beautie shall consume in the sepulchre out of their dwelling.
Manx: 14. T’ ayd ly̌i ayns nifrin kasly rish kirri, ta yn báys kagne orw̌, as iew yn slyei kayragh réel jusyn ayns y voghre : ni yn moidj[114] kéyf ayns yn yei magh as an vághey.

English: 15 But God hath delivered my soule from the place of hell : for he shall receive me.
Manx: 15. Agh ta Jih er lifre m’ anym vei ynyd ’ifrin : erson gowi e mi.

English: 16 Be not thou afraid though one bee made rich : or if the glory of his house be increased;
Manx: 16. Na bi us aglagh ga víis anayn erna ianw berchiagh : na ga víis glóer y hěi erna vishaghy;

English: 17 For hee shall cary nothing away with him when he dieth : neither shall his pompe follow him.
Manx: 17. Erson gha níimyrk e red erbi er shiul lesh nar víis e marw : ghamw éìgyrys y vorálys e.

English: 18 For while he lived, he counted himselfe an happy man : and so long as thou doest well unto thy selfe, men will speake good of thee.
Manx: 18. Erson ghowd as v’ é bio, gow e e héyn na gwney baníit : as ghowd as tow janw gy mei dw̌it héyn, loyri dene gy mei jids.
gwney] ms. dwney; janw gy] ms. janw gym

English: 19 He shal follow the generation of his fathers : and shall never see light.
Manx: 19. Eigyri e shilóghyn y aeraghyn : as gha vack e gybragh soilshe.

English: 20 Man being in honour, hath no understanding: but is compared unto the beasts that perish.
Manx: 20. Dwyne ayns oneyr, gha vel twigel erbi agge : agh te sóliit rish ny baiyn ta dol mow.

English: The x. day.
Manx: Yn x. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Deus deorum. Psal. 50.
Manx: Deus deorum. psal. 50.

English: The Lord, even the most mightie God hath spoken : and called the world, from the rising up of the Sunne, unto the going downe thereof.
Manx: 1. Ta yn Chiarn, gy jarw yn Jih smẃ gniártoil, er lóyrt : as ern’ iemaght er y týyl vei irri shúas ny greny gys y gol shíis eck.

English: 2 Out of Sion hath God appeared : in perfect beautie.
Manx: 2. Magh as Seion ta Jih erna iaghyn héyn : boíìdj firrinagh.

English: 3 Our God shall come, and shall not keepe silence: there shall goe before him a consuming fire, and a mightie tempest shall bee stirred up round about him.
Manx: 3. Hig nan Iíh, as gha gwmm e y hiange : heyd réfsyn ainnil strẃil, as bi dorrin mwar erna glýasyght shuas krwin magiyrt ymmish.

English: 4 He shal call the heaven from above : and the earth, that he may judge his people.
Manx: 4. Ei [é] er y neáw vei húas : as y talw, gy vod e y phobyl y vrẃinys.

English: 5 Gather my Saints together unto me : those that have made a covenant with me with sacrifice.
Manx: 5. Chagẏlgi my nwyn kwjaght hẃyms : aydsyn ta ern’ ianw kwnánt rẃyms rish ówrel.

English: 6 And the heavens shall declare his righteousnesse : for God is judge himselfe.
Manx: 6. As ni ny néawaghyn yn gharys aggesyn y hoilsaghy : erson ta Jih na vriẃ e héyn.
vriẃ] ms. vrwiẃ

English: 7 Heare, O my people, and I wil speake : I myselfe will testifie against thee, O Israel; for I am God, even thy God.
Manx: 7. Klastigi, O my phobyl, as lióryms : níims mi héyn féanish y ymmyrke t’ ýỳis, O Israel, erson she mish [Jih,] gy jarw dthy Iíhys.

English: 8 I will not reproove thee because of the sacrifices, or for thy burnt offerings : because they were not alway before mee.
Manx: 8. Gha derryms aghsan dwit erson t’ owrelyns, na erson t’ owrelyn losk : erson nagh row áyd goni kiangoyrt rẃỳms.

English: the sacrifices] thy sacrifices 1581, 1636, 1660, 1662
9 I wil take no bullocke out of thy house : nor hee goats out of thy folds.
Manx: 9. Gha goẃỳms gown erbi magh as dthy hei : na goer fyrryn magh as dthy voilchyn.

English: 10 For all the beasts of the forest are mine : and so are the cattels upon a thousand hils.
Manx: 10. Erson she layms beiyn wlly yn ’ásygh : as margedyn ta yn alagh er twsayn dy ghnwick.

English: 11 I know all the foules upon the mountaines : and the wilde beasts of the field are in my sight.
Manx: 11. Sawn dwys yn énli wlly er ny sléchyn : as ta béiyn kýei yn vagher ayns my hilliys.

English: 12 If I be hungry, I wil not tel thee : for the whole world is mine, and all that is therein.
Manx: 12. Ma viyms gackrys, gha ninshiym dwit : erson she láỳms yn sýyl wlly, as wlly na ta áyn.
ninshiym] ms. niymshiym

English: 13 Thinkest thou that I will eate buls flesh : and drinke the blood of Goates?
Manx: 13. Vel ẃ smwnaghtyn gy niiyms feyl terriu : as gy nifym fwil góer?
niiyms] ms. niiys

English: 14 Offer unto God thankesgiving : and pay thy vowes unto the most Highest.
Manx: 14. Jean owrel dy Iíh toyrt bwias : as íik dthy vriaryghin gys yn ýrje smẃ.

English: 15 And call upon me in the time of trouble : so wil I heare thee, and thou shalt praise me.
Manx: 15. As éi ořryms ayns ierish sýaghyn : shen mar ghlẃinyms us as moliit us mish.

English: 16 But unto the ungodly said God : Why doest thou preach my Lawes, and takest my Covenant in thy mouth?
Manx: 16. Agh rish yn niawghráwi dẃyrt Jih : kamma vel us prechéel my lyóìyns, as góyl my ghwnaynt ayns dthy véal?

English: 17 Whereas thou hatest to be reformed : and hast cast my wordes behind thee.
Manx: 17. Fackin gy vel dẃòi ayd dy vé er dy líàssaghy : as gy vel ẃ er dilge m’ okelyns er dthy ghwlẃ.

English: 18 When thou sawest a thiefe, thou consentedst unto him : and hast bene partaker with the adulterers.
Manx: 18. Nar ghonick ẃ merliagh, ren ẃ t’ agne méi gâ : as tóẁ er mé góyl ayrn maríùsyn ta brissie pwsey.

English: 19 Thou hast let thy mouth speake wickednes : and with thy tongue thou hast set forth deceit.
Manx: 19. Tôw er ligge dy dthy véal [olkys] y lóyrt : as rish dthy hiange tóẁ er seiaghe magh maltáryght.

English: 20 Thou satest and spakest against thy brother : yea, and hast slandered thine owne mothers sonne.
Manx: 20. Hĕi ẃ as loyr ẃ nyoi dthy vráer : gy jarw, as tôw er gwr líùn er mack dthy váyre héyn.

English: 21 These things hast thou done, and I held my tongue, and thou thoughtest wickedly, that I am even such a one as thy selfe : but I wil reproove thee, and set before thee the things that thou hast done.
Manx: 21. Shó ny redyn ta us erna ianw, as ghwmm mi my hange, as smwni us gy holk, gy vel mish leid yn anáyn as ta ẃ heyn : agh veřrym aghsan dwit, as seíỳm kiangoyrt rwyts ny rédyn ta us erna ianw.
erna ianw, as ghwmm] ms. er y ianw, as ghwmm

English: 22 O consider this, ye that forget God : lest I plucke you away, and there be none to deliver you.
Manx: 22. O smẃnigi er sho, shiusse ta jarwd Iih : nagh dârniym shiuss er shiul, as nagh bi veg d’ an lifré.

English: 23 Who so offereth me thankes and praise, he honoureth mee : and to him that ordereth his conversation right, will I shew the salvation of God.
Manx: 23. Quei erbi ta gowrel hwyms bwias as mòle, t’ e toyrt oneyr dwys : as dâsyn ta réel y ymmyrke gy káyr, jaghyms sawalys Iíh.

English: Miserere mei Deus. Psal. 51.
Manx: Miserere mei Deus. 51.

English: Have mercie upon me, O God, after thy great goodnesse : according to the multitude of thy mercies do away mine offences.
Manx: 1. Jean myghyn orrym, O Iíh, nyrg dthy vêiys mẃar : nyrg ymmydi dy hrokeryght kwr er shiul my loghtyn.

English: 2 Wash me throughly from my wickednesse : and cleanse me from my sinne.
Manx: 2. Ní mish gy tryid vei m’ olkys : as glan mi vei my pheky.

English: 3 For I knowledge my faults : & my sin is ever before me.
Manx: 3. Erson ta mi góyl rish m’ óilchyn : as ta my pheky gybrágh m’ iénish.

English: 4 Against thee onely have I sinned, and done this evil in thy sight : that thou mightest bee justified in thy saying, and cleare when thou art judged.
Manx: 4. T’ ýeis d’ ’olymarkan ta mi ern’ ianw peky, as ern’ ianw yn olk shó ayns t’ ienish : gy vodagh us ve sýyr ayns dy rá, as glan nar tǒw brwinyssyt.
T’ ýeis] ms. T’ý éish; ern’ ianw yn olk] ms. er’n’ ianw yn olk

English: 5 Beholde, I was shapen in wickednesse : and in sinne hath my mother conceived me.
Manx: 5. Jeagh, ta mi er my ghwr[115] ayns olkys : as ayns peky ren my vwmmwg my iénaghtyn.

English: 6 But loe, thou requirest trueth in the inward parts: and shalt make me to understand wisedome secretly.
Manx: 6. Agh jeagh, tow us shyirre firrinys ayns ny hárnyn sty̆i : as ver us ořryms kiál y hwigel gy fallíit.

English: 7 Thou shalt purge me with Hysope, & I shal be cleane : thou shalt wash me, and I shal be whiter then snow.
Manx: 7. Glanit us mish [rish] hisop, as bíim glan : níyt us mish, as bíym nash kille na snaghty.

English: 8 Thou shalt make me heare of joy and gladnesse : that the bones which thou hast broken may rejoyce.
Manx: 8. Ver us orryms dy ghlastchen dy vogey as gann : gy vod ny knawyn ta us erna vrishie bogey y góyl.

English: 9 Turne thy face from my sinnes : and put out all my misdeeds.
Manx: 9. Chyndá t’ edyn vei my pheky : as kwr magh wlly my grogh ianw.

English: 10 Make me a cleane heart, O God : and renew a right spirit within me.
Manx: 10. Jean kri glan anyms, O Iíh : as jean nóo ríist spyryd káyragh aňyms.

English: 11 Cast mee not away from thy presence : and take not thy holy Spirit from me.
Manx: 11. Na tilg mish er shiul vei t’ éanish : as na gow dthy spyryd kasserick vóỳm.

English: 12 O give me the comfort of thy helpe againe : and stablish me with thy free spirit.
Manx: 12. O kwr dwys gyrjaghe dy dthy ghẃne ríist : as gniarti mish rish dthy spyryd sýyr.

English: 13 Then shall I teach thy wayes unto the wicked : and sinners shal be converted unto thee.
Manx: 13. Eísh ynsiyms dthy raydjyns d’ yn niawghrawi : as bi peki er nan jyndá hwyds.

English: 14 Deliver me from bloodguiltines, O God, thou that art the God of my health : & my tongue shal sing of thy righteousnes.
Manx: 14. Lifré mi vei fwil ghientagh, O Iih, us ta Jíh my láìnts : as gowi my hiange oráyn dy dthy gháyrys.

English: 15 Thou shalt open my lips (O Lord :) and my mouth shall shew thy praise.
Manx: 15. Foskilẏt us my veliyn, O Hiarn : as soilshi my véal dthy volle.

English: 16 For thou desirest no sacrifice, els would I give it thee : but thou delightest not in burnt offerings.
Manx: 16. Erson gha vel us shyirre veg yn owrel, naníò[116] vêin er dóyrt dwit é : agh gha vel tatnys ayds ayns owrelyn loisk.

English: 17 The sacrifice of God is a troubled spirit : a broken and contrite heart (O God) shalt thou not despise.
Manx: 17. She owrel Iíh spyryd sy̌it : kri brist as arẏsagh, O Iíh, gha sei us beg j́è.

English: 18 O be favourable and gracious unto Sion : build thou the walles of Hierusalem.
Manx: 18. O bi fóroil as grásoil dy Hêion : trog shuas ballaghyn Jerusalem.

English: 19 Then shalt thou be pleased with the sacrifice of righteousnesse, with the burnt offerings and oblations : then shall they offer yong bullocks upon thine Altar.
Manx: 19. Eish bíit ẃ bwiagh rish owrelyn dy gháyrys, rish owrélyn loisk as tóyrtyssyn : éish owri áyd gowny ayg er t’ altyrs.

English: Quid gloriaris? Psal. 52.
Manx: Quid gloriaris? psal. 52.

English: Why boastest thou thy selfe, thou tyrant : that thou canst doe mischiefe?
Manx: 1. Kamma vel us dy dthy voggassygh héyn, us hrénydyr : gy vod ẃ olk y ianw;

English: 2 Whereas the goodnesse of God : endureth yet dayly?
Manx: 2. Fackin gy vel meiys Iíh : farraghtyn fóyst gygh lá?

English: 3 Thy tongue imagineth wickednes : and with lies thou cuttest like a sharpe rasor.
Manx: 3. Ta dthy hiange smwnaghtyn olkys : as rish bregyn tow gàry kasly rish skíyn var[117] íer.

English: 4 Thou hast loved unrighteousnes more then goodnes : and to talke of lies more then righteousnes.
Manx: 4. Bíyny lǎts niawghayrys na smw na meiys : as dy haglw dy vregyn na smẃ na káyrys.

English: 5 Thou hast loved to speake all words that may do hurt : O thou false tongue.
Manx: 5. Bíyny lǎts dy loyrt gygh wlly okyl odys górtaghy y ianw : O us hiange fálsy.

English: 6 Therefore shall God destroy thee for ever : he shall take thee, and plucke thee out of thy dwelling, and roote thee out of the land of the living.
Manx: 6. Shenyfá strwi Jih us erson gybragh : gowi e us, as tarni e ẃ magh as dthy vaghey, as rowri e ẃ magh as talw yn klyěi vío.

English: 7 The righteous also shall see this, and feare : and shall laugh him to scorne;
Manx: 7. Híi yn sly̌ei káyragh sho níist, as gowi ayd agyl : as ni ayd knáid ymmíshyn geraghti:

English: 8 Lo, this is the man that tooke not God for his strength : but trusted unto the multitude of his riches, & strengthened himselfe in his wickednesse.
Manx: 8. Jeagh, shé shó yn dwyne nagh gow Jih ghon y gniart : agh ren treisteel ayns y verchys vẃar, as ládjeri e héyn ayns y olkys.

English: 9 As for me, I am like a greene Olive tree in the house of God : my trust is in the tender mercie of God for ever & ever.
Manx: 9. As er my hons, ta mi kasly rish bille glass ẃil ayns těi Iíh : tá my hreistéel ayns myghin víin Iíh erson gybrágh as gybrágh.

English: 10 I wil alwaies give thanks unto thee for that thou hast done : & I wil hope in thy Name, for thy Saints like it well.
Manx: 10. Verryms bwias dwich góni erson na tow̌ erna ianw : as treistchyms ayns t’ enyms, erson statchyn lesh dy nẃyn shen gy mei.

English: The x. day.
Manx: Yn x. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Dixit insipiens. Psal. 53.
Manx: Dixit insipiens. psal. 53.

English: The foolish body hath saide in his heart : There is no God.
Manx: 1. Dẃyrt yn ammydan ayns y ghrí : ghá vel Jih erbí ayn.

English: 2 Corrupt are they, and become abominable in their wickednes : there is none that doeth good.
Manx: 2. T’ aydsyn low as dwoióel ayns nan olkys : ghanel veg ta janw mei.

English: 3 God looked downe from heaven upon the children of men : to see if there were any that would understand, and seeke after God.
Manx: 3. Iagh Jíh núas vei neaw er klawn géne : dy iághyn ma vá anayn baillesh twigel, as shyirre nýre Iíh.
Iagh] ms. jeagh

English: 4 But they are all gone out of the way, they are altogether become abominable : there is also none that doeth good, no not one.
Manx: 4. Agh ta áyd wlly er nol as y ráyd; t’ ayd wlly kẃjaght dwoióel : gha vel níist veg ta janw mei, gha vel anayn.

English: 5 Are not they without understanding that worke wickednesse : eating up my people as if they would eate bread? they have not called upon God.
Manx: 5. Nagh vel áydsyn gyn twigel ta janw olkys : gí shúas my phobyl mar assagh[118] áyd aran? gha vel ayd ern’ iémagh er Jíh.

English: 6 They were afraid where no feare was : for God hath broken the bones of him that besieged thee; thou hast put them to confusion, because God hath despised them.
Manx: 6. Va áydsyn aglagh yn iynyd nagh row agyl erbi : erson ta Jíh er mrishie ny knawyn acksyn dríal us schiagh; tow er nan dóyrt-syn gys náre, erson ta Jíh er seiaghe beg jusyn.

English: 7 Oh that the Salvation were given unto Israel out of Sion : Oh that the Lord would deliver his people out of captivitie.
Manx: 7. O gy beagh yn sawálys erna hoyrt dy Eisrael magh as Seion : O gy lifréagh yn Chiarn y phobyl magh as kapy.

English: 8 Then should Jacob rejoyce : and Israel should bee right glad.
Manx: 8. Éish véagh Jakob bógoil : as véagh Eisrael fíir ganóel.

English: Deus in Nomine. Psal. 54.
Manx: Deus in nomine tuo. psal. 54.

English: Save me, O God, for thy Names sake : and avenge mee in thy strength.
Manx: 1. Saw mi, O Iíh, erson grayi t’ enym : as kwilín mish ayns dthy gniart.

English: 2 Heare my prayer, O God : and hearken unto the wordes of my mouth.
Manx: 2. Eist my phaidjer, O Iíh : as klast rish fokelyn my véal.

English: 3 For strangers are risen up against mee : and tyrants (which have not God before their eyes) seeke after my soule.
Manx: 3. Erson ta joriyn ern’ irri shuas m’ ýeis : as tréni nagh vel Jíh ǎck réfs nan swilyn shyirre nyre m’ anym.
joriyn] ms. jorẏn

English: 4 Beholde, God is my helper : the Lord is with them that uphold my soule.
Manx: 4. Jeagh, she Jíh m’ ’er kẃney : ta yn Chiarn mariusyn ta kwmmel shuas m’ anym.

English: 5 He shall reward evil unto mine enemies : destroy thou them in thy trueth.
Manx: 5. Iki é riist olk dy my noidjyns : strẃi us aydsyn ayns t’ eirrinys.

English: 6 An offering of a free heart will I give thee, and praise thy Name, O Lord : because it is so comfortable.
Manx: 6. Owrel dy ghri feilchagh verryms dwit, as molym t’ enyms, O Hiarn : erson gy vel e ghó gyrjẃil.

English: 7 For he hath delivered me out of all my trouble : & mine eye hath seene his desire upon mine enemies.
Manx: 7. Erson t’ é er my lifré as my hyaghyn wlly : as ta my hẃil er vakin y agne er my noidjyn.

English: Exaudi Deus. Psal. 55.
Manx: Exaudi deus. psal. 55.

English: Heare my prayer, O God : and hide not thy selfe from my petition.
Manx: 1. Klast rish my phadjer, O Iíh : as na falli ẃ héyn vei m’ aghin.

English: 2 Take heed unto me, & heare me : how I mourne in my prayer, and am vexed.
Manx: 2. Kwrr taskey dwys, as klast rŵyms : kyns ta mi dobran ayns my phadjer, as ta mi dy my hyaghyn.

English: 3 The enemie crieth so, and the ungodly commeth on so fast : for they are minded to doe me some mischiefe, so maliciously are they set against me.
Manx: 3. Ta yn noidj gémagh marshen, as ta yn niawghrawi chíit ořrym gho chiàn : erson t’ ayd smwnaghtyn dy ianw drogh red egnagh dẃỳs, t’ ayd gho ganlysagh shen syěit m’ ýois.

English: 4 My heart is disquieted within mee : and the feare of death is fallen upon me.
Manx: 4. Ta my ghrí anvéagh er léyfs stei jíim : as ta agyl yn váys er dwitchym ořym.

English: 5 Fearfulnesse and trembling are come upon mee : and an horrible dread hath overwhelmed mee.
Manx: 5. Ta agyl as kréàw er jít orryms : as ta agyl aglagh er my hilge harrish.

English: 6 And I saide, Oh that I had wings like a Dove : for then would I flee away, and be at rest.
Manx: 6. As dwyrt mi, O gy béagh skéanyn ayms kasly rish kalmáyn : erson eis atlieing er shiúl, as veing ag fé.

English: 7 Lo, then would I get me away far off : and remaine in the wildernesse.
Manx: 7. Jeagh, eis raǧhein er shiúl fodey as y rayd : as ’ẃrring ayns yn aisnaght.

English: 8 I would make haste to escape : because of the stormie winde and tempest.
Manx: 8. Ienin seir dy haghne : erson yn gýe styrrẏmagh as dor̀rin.

English: 9 Destroy their tongues, O Lord, and divide them : for I have spied unrighteousnesse and strife in the Citie.
Manx: 9. Strẃi nan jangaghan, O Hiarn, as rěing áyd : erson ta mi er vackin niawgháyrys, as strýìf ayns y valley.

English: 10 Day and night they go about within the walles thereof : mischiefe also and sorrow are in the mids of it.
Manx: 10. Lá as ýì t’ áyd dòl magiyrt er léf stěi ny vollaghyn agge : ta olkys níist as trimshe ayns y véyn agge.

English: 11 Wickednesse is therein : deceit and guile goe not out of their streets.
Manx: 11. Ta niaw ghráwiys aynshen : gha nel mally as kalg dòll magh as nan strádjyn.

English: 12 For it is not an open enemie that hath done me this dishonour : for then I could have borne it.
Manx: 12. Erson ghanié nóid foskilt ren yn niaw oǹeyr sho dẃỳs : erson eis ’odin y ymmyrke é.

English: 13 Neither was it mine adversary that did magnifie himselfe against me : for then (peradventure) I would have hid my selfe from him.
Manx: 13. Ghamẃ she my nóid ren e héyn y ianw mẃar m’ ýei : erson eis higge[119] vein er m’ alaghy héyn výèi.

English: 14 But it was even thou my companion : my guide, and mine owne familiar friend.
Manx: 14. Agh v’ é gy jarw us my heshy : my líidjér, as my gharry anchysagh héyn.

English: 15 We took sweete counsell together : and walked in the house of God as friends.
Manx: 15. Gow shinin korliy vilish kwjaght : as jimmi shwin ayns těi Iíh mar karjyn.

English: 16 Let death come hastily upon them, and let them goe downe quicke into hell : for wickednesse is in their dwellings, and among them.
Manx: 16. Ligg e báas chíit gy séìragh orriusyn, as lig aw̌ doll shíis bió gys nifrin : erson ta olkys ayns nan yinydyn vaghey, as nan masky-syn.

English: 17 As for mee, I will call upon God : and the Lord shall save me.
Manx: 17. As er my hons, eiyms er Jíh : as sáwi yn Chiarn mi.

English: 18 In the evening and morning, and at noone day wil I pray, and that instantly : and he shall heare my voyce.
Manx: 18. Ayns yn ’áskyr, as y voghre, as ag mynn lá, niym padier y góyl, as shen ry ierw[120] : as klwini é my ghorá.

English: 19 It is he that hath delivered my soule in peace, from the battel that was against me : for there were many with me.
Manx: 19. She eshyn ta er lifré m’ anym ayns shíi vei yn ghagey ta m’ yei : erson va ymmydi maŕỳms.

English: 20 Yea, even God that endureth for ever shall heare me, and bring them downe : for they wil not turne, nor feare God.
Manx: 20. Shé, gy jarw Jíh ta faraghtyn erson gybrágh klwini mish, as ver é aydsyn núas : erson gha jyndá áyd, na agyl y góyl dy Iíh.

English: 21 He layde his hands upon such as be at peace with him : and he brake his covenant.
Manx: 21. Ghwr é y lawyn er leid as ta ag shíi rishsyn : as vrissi e y ghẃnaynt.

English: 22 The words of his mouth were softer then butter, having warre in his heart : his wordes are smoother then oile, and yet be they very swords.
Manx: 22. Vá fokelyn y véal nasbwggy na imm, ag vel kagey ayns y ghri : vá y ’ókelyn nasmíny[121] na ẃil, as foyst she kleiwnyn áyd.

English: are smoother] 1581, 1636, 1660, 1662 were smoother
23 O cast thy burden upon the Lord, and he shall nourish thee : and shall not suffer the righteous to fall for ever.
Manx: 23. O tilg dthy vert[122] er y Chiarn, as kwmmi é shúas ẃ : as gha vwlli e yn sly̌i ghrawi dy hwytchym erson gybrágh.
vwlli] ms. vwlly

English: 24 And as for them : thou, O God, shalt bring them into the pit of destruction.
Manx: 24. As er nan-son-syn : ver us aydsyn, O Iíh, ayns wig yn strwi.

English: 25 The bloodthirstie and deceitfull men shall not live out halfe their dayes : neverthelesse, my trust shall be in thee, O Lord.
Manx: 25. Gha bi ny déne páygh d’ ’wǐl as maltoil bío yn darre lé dy nan lághyn : na iei, bi my hreistéel anyds, O Hiarn.

English: The xi. day.
Manx: Yn xi. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Miserere mei Deus. Psal. 56.
Manx: Miserere mei deus. psal. 56.

English: Be mercifull unto mee, O God, for man goeth about to devour me : he is dayly fighting, and troubling me.
Manx: 1. Bi trokroil dẃỳs, O Iih, erson ta dwyne dol magiyrt dy my ghwr mow̌ : t’ é gygh wlly lá kage as dy my hyaghyn.

English: 2 Mine enemies are dayly in hand to swallow mee up : for they bee many that fight against mee, O thou most Highest.
Manx: 2. Ta my nóidjyn gygh la ayns law dy my lwggy shúas : erson t’ aydsyn ymmydi ta kage m’ ýòis, O us smw swyrje.

English: 3 Neverthelesse, though I am sometime afraide : yet put I my trust in thee.
Manx: 3. Er-y-hon shó wlly, gy ta mi nagerẃn[123] aglagh : fóyst ta mi toyrt my hreistéel anyds.

English: 4 I will praise God, because of his word : I have put my trust in God, and will not feare what flesh can do unto me.
Manx: 4. Molyms Jih erson y ’okyl : ta mi er dóyrt my hreistéel ayns Jíh, as gha goym agyl kre ’odys feyl y ianw rwyms.

English: 5 They dayly mistake my words : all that they imagine, is to doe me evil.
Manx: 5. T’ ayd gygh lá góyl m’ okylyns gy hagáragh : ta wlly na t’ ayd dy smwnaghtyn dy ianw olk dẃỳs.

English: 6 They holde all together, and keepe themselves close : and marke my steps, when they lay wait for my soule.
Manx: 6. T’ ayd kwmmel wlly kwjaght, as d’ an vríal ayd héyn gyn ’ys : as krannaghe my ghassmeidjyn, nar t’ ayd lyi farkiaght erson m’ anym.

English: 7 Shall they escape for their wickednesse : thou, O God, in thy displeasure shalt cast them downe.
Manx: 7. An[124] jean aydsyn shaghne erson nan olkys : tílgit us, O Iíh, núas aydsyn ayns dthy iŵmẃiys.

English: 8 Thou tellest my flittings; put my teares into thy bottel : are not these things noted in thy Booke?
Manx: 8. Tow gériw[125] m’ araghe, kwr my iêir ayns dthy vottél : nagh vel ny rédyn sho skriw̌it ayns dthy lior?

English: 9 Whensoever I call upon thee, then shall mine enemies be put to flight : this I know; for God is on my side.
Manx: 9. Kre yn trá erbí ta mi gemagh oy̌rts, éis bi my noidjyn er ’an gwr dy hée : shó sáwn dwys, erson ta Jih er my héyfs.

English: 10 In Gods word wil I rejoyce : in the Lords word will I comfort me.
Manx: 10. Ayns gẃ Iíh niyms bógey y góyl : ayns gẃ yn Chiarn niŷm my gyrjaghy.

English: 11 Yea, in God have I put my trust : I will not be afraid what man can doe unto me.
Manx: 11. Gy jarw, ayns Jíh ta mi er dóyrt my hreistéel : ghá góym agyl kré ’odys dẃyne y ianw rwyms.

English: 12 Unto thee, O God, will I pay my vowes : unto thee will I give thankes.
Manx: 12. Dwitch, O Iíh, ikym my vríaraghyn : dwich veřrym bŵias.

English: 13 For thou hast delivered my soul from death, and my feete from falling : that I may walke before God in the light of the living.
Manx: 13. Erson ta [us] er lifre m’ anym vei báas, as my ghassyn vei twittym : gy vodym gimmíaght feanish Jih ayns soilshe yn kly̌ei vio.

English: Miserere mei Deus. Psal. 57.
Manx: Miserere mei Deus. psa1. 57.

English: Be mercifull unto me, O God, be mercifull unto me, for my soule trusteth in thee : and under the shadow of thy wings shall be my refuge, untill this tyrannie be overpast.
Manx: 1. Bi myghinagh dwys, O Iíh, bi myghinagh dẃỳs, erson ta m’ anym treistéel anyds : as fwó ská dy skányns víis my ghómmirk, naggedere viis yn trényght sho ern’ ’oll shaghey.

English: 2 I will call unto the most High God : even unto the God that shall performe the cause which I have in hand.
Manx: 2. Éìym gys yn Jíh smẃ sýyrje : gy jarw gys yn Jíh ghwilínys y ghẃish ta áỳms áyns láw.

English: 3 He shall send from heaven : and save mee from the reproofe of him that would eate me up.
Manx: 3. Ver e vei neaw : as sawi e mi vei yn nare aggesyn bail lesh m’ íi shúas.

English: 4 God shall send foorth his mercie and trueth : my soule is among Lions.
Manx: 4. Ver Jih magh y hrokeryght as y irrinys : ta m’ anym masky lêionyn.

English: 5 And I lie even among the children of men (that are set on fire :) whose teeth are speares and arrowes, and their tongue a sharpe sword.
Manx: 5. As ta mi ly̌ei gy jarw masky kláwn géne ta syit er aínnil : ta ny fiekylyn ack sleǐn as séìjyn, as nan jange klèiw géyr.

English: 6 Set up thy selfe, O God, above the heavens : and thy glory above all the earth.
Manx: 6. Sěi shúas ẃ héyn, O Iíh, erskyn ny néawaghyn : as dthy glóyr erskyn yn talw wlly.

English: 7 They have layde a net for my feete, and pressed downe my soule : they have digged a pit before me, and are fallen into the mids of it themselves.
Manx: 7. Ta áyd er seiaghy liŷn ghon my ghassyn, as ern’ iǹny[126] shíis m’ anym : t’ ayd er rawry lag róỳms, as t’ áyd héyn er dwichym ayns y véyn agge.

English: 8 My heart is fixed, O God, my heart is fixed : I will sing and give praise.
Manx: 8. Ta my ghri sy̌it, O Iíh, ta my ghri sy̌it : góym oráyn as verrym moley.

English: 9 Awake up my glory; awake Lute and Harp : I my selfe will awake right earely.
Manx: 9. Dẃysk shúas, my glóyr, dẃysk, líùt as krw̌it : dẃyskym mi héyn gy fiir voghey.

English: 10 I wil give thanks unto thee, O Lord, among the people : and I wil sing unto thee among the Nations.
Manx: 10. Verrym bwias dwich, O Hiarn, masky yn phobyl : as góỳm orayn dwich masky ny natiownyn.

English: 11 For the greatnesse of thy Mercy reacheth unto the heavens : and thy Trueth unto the cloudes.
Manx: 11. Erson ta móyrid dy vyghin roschyn gys ny neawaghyn : as t’ y̌irinys gys ny bojelyn.

English: 12 Set up thy selfe, O God, above the heavens : and thy glory above all the earth.
Manx: 12. Sei shúas ẃ héyn, O Iíh, erskyn ny neawaghyn : as dthy glóyr erskyn yn talw wlly.

English: Si verè vtique.Psal. 58.
Manx: Si vere vtique. psal. 58.

English: Are your minds set upon righteousnesse, O yee Congregation : and doe yee judge the thing that is right, O yee sonnes of men?
Manx: 1. Vel nan agnaghyn sy̌it er káyrys, O shiusse áglish : as vel shiu brwinys yn red ta káyr, O shiusse ghláwn géne?

English: 2 Yea, ye imagine mischiefe in your heart upon the earth : and your hands deale with wickednesse.
Manx: 2. Gy jarw, ta shiu smwnaghtyn olkys ayns nan grí er y talw : as ta nan lawyn àgwish kwr rish olkys.

English: 3 The ungodly are froward even from their mothers wombe : assoone as they be borne, they go astray & speake lies.
Manx: 3. Ta yn niawghráwi freawrtagh gy jarw vei bolg nan mayry : gho lýe as t’ áyd er nan mre, t’ áyd dol er shaghran as lóyrt bregyn.

English: be borne] 1662 are born
4 They are as venemous as the poyson of a Serpent : even like the deafe Adder that stoppeth her eares;
Manx: 4. T’ áyd gho pwishẃnagh as pwishẃn yn arneyf : gy jarw kasly rish yn addyr bowr ta dwiny y klyeshyn;

English: 5 Which refuseth to heare the voyce of the charmer : charme he never so wisely.
Manx: 5. Ta gobel dy ghlastchen korá yn fer obi : kadje[127] ghriney ni e obi.

English: 6 Breake their teeth (O God) in their mouthes; smite the jaw bones of the Lions, O Lord : let them fall away like water that runneth apace; and when they shoote their arrowes, let them be rooted out.
Manx: 6. Briss nan vieklyn, O Iíh, ayns nan meyl; boyl knáwyn kíil ny leionyn : lig gáw twitchym er shiúl mar ẃisky ta ryi gy biew, as trá hilgys ayd nan seijyn, ligg aw ve er nan rowry magh.

English: 7 Let them consume away like a snaile, and bee like the untimely fruit of a woman : and let them not see the Sunne.
Manx: 7. Ligg ’aw liéỳ er shíul mar shellíit,[128] as ve kasly rish meass nagh bi anẃgh[129] dy ven : as na lig dáẁ yn grien y akin.

English: 8 Or ever your pots be made hot with thornes : so let indignation vexe him, even as a thing that is raw.
Manx: 8. Ma bi gybrágh nan bẃit[130] er nan ianw che rish drěin : marshen ligg e korri eshyn y hyaghyn, gy jarw mar red ta aów.

English: 9 The righteous shall rejoyce when he seeth the vengeance : he shall wash his footsteps in the blood of the ungodly.
Manx: 9. Bíi yn dwyne káyragh gannoil nar híi e yn kerygh : níi e y ghasmedjyn ghosse ayns fwil yn niawghráwi.

English: 10 So that a man shal say, Verily there is a reward for the righteous : doubtlesse there is a God that judgeth the earth.
Manx: 10. Marshen gy nabber dwyne, gy jarw ta lúagh ghon y dwyne ghayragh : gyn ymné ta Jih ta toyrt brwinys er y talw.

English: The xi. day.
Manx: Yn xi. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Eripe me de inimicis. Psal. 59.
Manx: Eripe me Deus de inimicis.[131] psal. 59.

English: Deliver me from mine enemies (O God :) defend me from them that rise up against me.
Manx: 1. Lifré mi vei my nóidjyn, O Iíh : fríal mi vôusyn ta girri shuas m’ yeiys.

English: 2 O deliver me from the wicked doers : and save mee from the bloodthirstie men.
Manx: 2. O lifré mish vôusyn ta janw olk : as saw mi vei ny déne ta páa nýre fwil.

English: 3 For loe, they lie waiting for my soule : the mightie men are gathered against mee, without any offence or fault of me, O Lord.
Manx: 3. Erson jeagh, t’ áyd lyi farkiaght er m’ anym : ta ny déne láidjer er jaglym m’ yoiys, gyn loght na fòil erbi jeyms, O Hiarn.

English: 4 They runne and prepare themselves without my fault : arise thou therefore to helpe me, and behold.
Manx: 4. T’ ayd ry̌ei as d’ an ianw héyn arlw gyn m’ ’oil : shenyfá irri us dy ghẃne layms, as jéagh.

English: 5 Stand up (O Lord God of hosts) thou God of Israel, to visite all the heathen : and be not mercifull unto them that offend of malicious wickednesse.
Manx: 5. Shass shúas, O Hiarn Iíh ny shessaghtyn, us Iíh Israel, dy iaghyn ny hangristín wlly : as na bi trokróil dawsyn ta janw peky d’ olk ganlysagh.

English: 6 They goe to and fro in the evening : they grinne like a dogge, and runne about through the Citie.
Manx: 6. T’ áyd dol hwgge as vei ayns yn íàskyr : t’ ayd grynli[132] kasly rish mody, as ry̌ei magiyrt tryid yn ayrd valley.

English: 7 Behold, they speake with their mouth, and swords are in their lips : for who doeth hear?
Manx: 7. Jeagh, t’ áyd lóyrt rish nan méal, as ta kleiwnyn ayns nan meliynyn : erson quei ta klastchen?

English: 8 But thou, O Lord, shalt have them in derision : and thou shalt laugh all the heathen to scorne.
Manx: 8. Bi ayd, O Hiarn, ayns faghid ayds : as níi us geraghti ny hangristín wlly ayns knaid.

English: 9 My strength will I ascribe unto thee : for thou art the God of my refuge.
Manx: 9. My gniart verym dwich : erson she us Jíh my ghemmirk.

English: 10 God sheweth me his goodnesse plenteously : and God shall let me see my desire upon mine enemies.
Manx: 10. Ta Jíh jeaghyn dôw y véiys gy palchey : as liggi Jíh dow m’ agney y akin er my noidjyn.

English: 11 Slay them not, lest my people forget it : but scatter them abroad among the people, and put them downe, O Lord, our defence.
Manx: 11. Na marrw áyd, nagh jarwd my phobyl é : agh skýyl ayd gy liên masky yn phobyl, as kwr shíis áyd, O Hiarn, nan vríaly.

English: 12 For the sinne of their mouth, and for the words of their lips, they shall be taken in their pride : and why? their preaching is of cursing and lies.
Manx: 12. Erson pecky nan méal, as erson fokelyn nan méliyn; bi áyd er nan góyl ayns nan moyrn : as kamma? ta nan brechél dy gwiaghyn as vréagyn.

English: 13 Consume them in thy wrath, consume them, that they may perish : and know that it is God which ruleth in Jacob, and unto the ends of the world.
Manx: 13. Kwr mow áyd ayns tdy ghorri, kwr mǒw áyd, gy bi áyd er an gall : as gy vod fyss vé ack gy ne Jíh ta réel ayns Jakob, as gys kíin yn týyl.

English: which ruleth] 1662 that ruleth
14 And in the evening they will returne : grinne like a dogge, and will goe about the Citie.
Manx: 14. As ayns yn iáskyr ni áyd chyndá ríist : as grynli kasly rish mody as héd áyd magiyrt yn ard valley.

English: 15 They wil runne here and there for meate : and grudge if they be not satisfied.
Manx: 15. Rii áyd aynshó as aynshen, erson bíi : as gowi ayd gy holk rish managh bí ayd er nan lieny.

English: 16 As for me, I will sing of thy power, and will praise thy mercy betimes in the morning : for thou hast bene my defence and refuge in the day of my trouble.
Manx: 16. As er my hons, góym oráyn dy tdy phẃers, as molym tdy vyghin gy lié ayns y voghre : erson tóẁ er me my rialy as my ghemmirk ayns lá my hyaghyn.

English: 17 Unto thee (O my strength) will I sing : for thou, O God, art my refuge, and my mercifull God.
Manx: 17. Dẃìch, O my gniart, goyms oráyn : erson she us, O Iíh, my ghemmirk as my Iíh hrokroil.

English: Deus repulisti nos. Psal. 60.
Manx: Deus repuliﬆi nos. psal. 60.

English: O God, thou hast cast us out, & scattered us abroad : thou hast also bene displeased; O turne thee unto us againe.
Manx: 1. Ó Iíh, ta us er nan dilge magh, as er nan skýlé gy liên : tow níist er me jumwgh; Ó chyndá us hẃìniyn ríist.

English: 2 Thou hast mooved the land, and divided it : heale the sores thereof, for it shaketh.
Manx: 2. Tow er skwghey yn talw, as reyn ẃ é : slani ny chinniyn agge, erson t’ é krá.

English: 3 Thou hast shewed thy people heavy things : thou hast given us a drinke of deadly wine.
Manx: 3. Ta us ern’ iághyn dy tdy phobyl redyn trommy : ta us er doyrt dwin jogh d’ ’íen varrw.

English: 4 Thou hast given a token for such as feare thee : that they may triumph because of the Trueth.
Manx: 4. Tow er doyrt kowry dy leid as ta góyl agyl róỳds : gy vod áyd bogey dy várriyght [y goyl] erson yn ieryny.

English: 5 Therefore were thy beloved delivered : helpe me with thy right hand, and heare me.
Manx: 5. Shennyfá va tdy gharjyn er nan lifrée : kẃỳn liǎm rish tdy law iesh, as klwìín mi.

English: 6 God hath spoken in his Holinesse, I will rejoyce and divide Sichem : and mete out the valley of Succoth.
Manx: 6. Ta Jíh er lóyrt ayns y ghassrikys : góỳms bogey as renniym Seichem : as tow̌ys magh kóỳn Sukoth.

English: 7 Gilead is mine, and Manasses is mine : Ephraim also is the strength of my head; Juda is my Lawgiver;
Manx: 7. She láỳms Gilead as sh’ láỳms Manasses : shé Ephrain níist gniart my ghíin, she Juda ta toyrt my lýoi.

English: 8 Moab is my washpot; over Edom will I cast out my shooe : Philistia be thou glad of me.
Manx: 8. Shé Moab my ghrákkan níighan; harrish Edom hilgym magh my vráyg : Philistia, bii us gannoil jíims.

English: 9 Who will leade me into the strong Citie : who wil bring me into Edom?
Manx: 9. Quei líidys mish gys yn árd valley laidjer : quei ver mish gys Edom?
líidys] ms. líid us

English: 10 Hast not thou cast us out, O God : wilt not thou, O God, goe out with our hostes?
Manx: 10. Nagh vel us er nan dilge magh, O Iíh : nagh jedj us, O Iih, shiul magh marish nan shessaghtyn kagi?

English: 11 O bee thou our helpe in trouble : for vaine is the helpe of man.
Manx: 11. O bí us nan kwny áyns syaghyn : erson she fardalagh kwyne gwyney.

English: 12 Through God will wee do great actes : for it is hee that shall tread downe our enemies.
Manx: 12. Tryid Jih ni měid obraghyn mwǎry : erson she eshyn stampys shíis nan nóidjyn.

English: Exaudi Deus. Psal. 61.
Manx: Exaudi Deus. psal. 61.

English: Heare my crying, O God : give eare unto my prayer.
Manx: 1. Klast rish m’ ’émagh, O Iih : as kwr klúash dy my phadjer.

English: 2 From the ends of the earth will I call unto thee: when my heart is in heavinesse.
Manx: 2. Vei kíin yn talw éiym oŷrts : nar ta my ghrí ayns trimshey.

English: unto thee] 1662 upon thee
3 Oh set me up upon the rocke that is higher then I: for thou hast bene my hope, and a strong tower for mee against the enemie.
Manx: 3. O sei mish shuas er y ghreg tá nás ýrje na mi : erson ta us er mé my hreistéel, as tẃỳr láidjer dẃỳs nýoi yn noidj.

English: 4 I will dwell in thy Tabernacle for ever : and my trust shall be under the covering of thy wings.
Manx: 4. Níìms vaghey ayns t’ ynyd kasserick erson gybrágh : as bíi my hreisteel fwo kẃdaghy tdy skányns.

English: 5 For thou, O Lord, hast heard my desires : and hast given an heritage unto those that feare thy Name.
Manx: 5. Erson ta us, O Hiarn, er glastchen m’ agny : as er doyrt eirys dawsyn ta góyl agyl dy t’ enyms.
agyl dy] ms. agyl tdy

English: 6 Thou shalt grant the King a long life : that his yeeres may endure throughout all generations.
Manx: 6. Gallíit us d’ yn Ríi sýyl fodey : gy vod y vléinchyn faraghtyn tryid magh gygh wlly hilógh.

English: 7 Hee shall dwell before God for ever : O prepare thy loving mercie and faithfulnesse, that they may preserve him.
Manx: 7. Ni e vaghe fenish Iíh erson gybragh : O jean arlw tdy vyghin graiẃill, as t’ irinys, gy vod ayd eshyn y ghaẃdy.

English: 8 So will I alwayes sing praise unto thy Name : that I may dayly performe my vowes.
Manx: 8. Shen mar níìms oráyn y góyl gygh wlly hrá dy t’ enyms : gy vodym gygh lá my vríaraghyn y ghwiliny.

English: The xii. day.
Manx: Yn xii.la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Nonne Deo. Psal. 62.
Manx: Nonne deo? psal. 62.

English: My soul truely waiteth still upon God : for of him commeth my salvation.
Manx: 1. Ta m’ anym gy jarw farkiaght góni er Jíh : erson je eshyn ta my hawalys chíit.

English: 2 He verily is my strength and my salvation : hee is my defence, so that I shall not greatly fall.
Manx: 2. She eshyn gy jarw my gniart, as my hawálys : she eshyn m’ ’er ríal, marshen nagh dwitchym gy mẃar.

English: 3 How long will yee imagine mischiefe against every man : ye shall bee slaine all the sort of you; yea as a tottering wall shall ye be, and like a broken hedge.
Manx: 3. Káid smẃiniys shiu drogh red nýei gygh wlly gwyney : bi shiu er nan marrw wlly yn gry̌ei[133] aggw, gy jarw mar báll low[134] víis shiu, as kasly rish klei brist.

English: 4 Their device is onely how to put him out whom God will exalt : their delight is in lies; they give good words with their mouth, but curse with their heart.
Manx: 4. Ta yn kwmme ack nalymarkan kyns ni ayd eshyn y hoyrt magh, níi Jíh y hrogel shúas : ta an mien ayns bregyn; t’ áyd toyrt fokelyn mei rish nan méal, agh gwiaghyn rish nan gri.

English: 5 Neverthelesse, my soule wait thou still upon God : for my hope is in him.
Manx: 5. Er-y-hon-sho wlly, m’ anyms, fark us goni er Jíh : erson ta my hreistéel áynsyn.

English: 6 Hee truely is my strength and my salvation : he is my defence, so that I shall not fall.
Manx: 6. She eshyn gy firrinagh my gniart as my hawálys : she eshyn my ríaly marshen nagh dwitchym.

English: 7 In God is my health and my glory : the rocke of my might, and in God is my trust.
Manx: 7. Ayns Jíh ta my láint as [my] glóyr : kreg my gniart, as ayns Jih ta my hreistéel.

English: 8 O put your trust in him alway (yee people :) powre out your hearts before him, for God is our hope.
Manx: 8. O kwrrigi nan dreistéel aynsyn góni, shiusse phobyl : diertigi magh nan griaghyn refsyn, erson she Jih nan dreistéel.

English: 9 As for the children of men, they are but vaine: the children of men are deceitful upon the weights, they are altogether lighter then vanitie it selfe.
Manx: 9. As erson klawn géne, gha vel áyd agh fardáil : ta klawn gene maltóil er ny méìaghyn, t’ ayd wlly kwjaght nas édrymmy na fardalys heyn.

English: vaine] 1662 vanity
10 O trust not in wrong and robbery, give not your selves unto vanitie : if riches increase, set not your heart upon them.
Manx: 10. O na treistigi ayns agáyr as rwyskryght; na kwrgi shiu heyn gys fardálys : my ta berchys goyl bishagh, na seigi nan gri orrw.

English: 11 God spake once and twise : I have also heard the same, that power belongeth unto God;
Manx: 11. Lóyr Jih yn ghýyrt as jís : ghýyl mi níist yn red kedyn, gy vel pẃer benelt gys Jih;

English: once and twise : I have] 1662 once : and twice I have
Manx: Loyr] ms. Loyrt; mi] ms. my

English: 12 And that thou Lord art mercifull : for thou rewardest every man according to his worke.
Manx: 12. As gy vel us, Hiarn, trokroil : erson tow gíik gygh wlly gwyne nýre y obyr.

English: Deus Deus meus. Psal. 63.
Manx: Deus deus meus. psal. 63.

English: O God, thou art my God : earely will I seeke thee.
Manx: 1. O Iíh, she us my Iíh : gy moghy heirrym us.

English: 2 My soule thirsteth for thee, my flesh also longeth after thee : in a barren and dry land, where no water is.
Manx: 2. Ta m’ anym páa er tdy hons, ta m’ éyl níist góyl fodiaght tdy iěiys : ayns talw pháys as chirym, yn iy̌nyd nagh vel veg yn wisky.

English: 3 Thus have I looked for thee in holinesse : that I might behold thy power and glory.
Manx: 3. Marshó ta mi ern’ iaghyn er tdy hons ayns kasserikys : gy voddin tdy phẃer as tdy glóyr y ’akin.

English: 4 For thy loving kindnesse is better then the life it selfe : my lips shall praise thee.
Manx: 4. Erson ta tdy gheindylys [grayigóil] na sháyr na yn be e héyn : molli my véliyn us.

English: 5 As long as I live, wil I magnifie thee on this manner : and lift up my hands in thy Name.
Manx: 5. Ghowd as víỳms bió, molliym us gy mẃar er yn aght shó : as trogym shúas my lawyn ayns t’ ényms.

English: 6 My soule shall be satisfied even as it were with marow and fatnesse : when my mouth praiseth thee with joyfull lips.
Manx: 6. Bi m’ anym erna lieny, gy jarw mar véagh é rish smyrr as míàlys : [nar] vollys my veal us rish méliyn ganoil.

English: 7 Have I not remembred thee in my bed : and thought upon thee when I was waking?
Manx: 7. Nagh ghwini mi oy̌rts ayns my labbi : as smẃni mi oy̌rts nar va mi dẃysk?

English: 8 Because thou hast bene my helper : therefore under the shadow of thy wings will I rejoyce.
Manx: 8. Erson gy vel us er me m’ er kwyne : shenifa fwo ská tdy skanyns goyms bogey.

English: 9 My soule hangeth upon thee : thy right hand hath upholden me.
Manx: 9. Ta m’ anyms kroghey oy̌rts : ta tdy law iesh er my ghwmmel sýas.

English: 10 These also that seeke the hurt of my soule : they shall goe under the earth.
Manx: 10. Áydshó níist ta shyre gortaghy m’ anym : heid áyd fwó yn talw.

English: 11 Let them fall upon the edge of the sword : that they may be a portion for Foxes.
Manx: 11. Lig ’áẁ twitchym er fóèr y ghleiw : gy vod áyd ve earn ghon shinney.

English: 12 But the King shall rejoyce in God; all they also that sweare by him, shall bee commended : for the mouth of them that speak lies, shall be stopped.
Manx: 12. Agh níi yn ríi bogey y goyl ayns Jíh, wlly aydsyn níist ta lw liorishyn, bi ayd er nan molléỳ : erson bi yn beal acksyn ta lóyrt bregyn erna iei.

English: Exaudi Deus. Psal. 64.
Manx: Exaudi deus psal. 64.

English: Hear my voyce, O God, in my prayer : preserve my life from feare of the enemie.
Manx: 1. Klast rish my ghorá, O Iíh, ayns my phadjer : frial m’ anym vei agyl yn noid.

English: 2 Hide mee from the gathering together of the froward : and from the insurrection of wicked doers;
Manx: 2. Falli mi vei chiaglym kwjaght ny néne olk : as vei irri sýas yn slyi ta janw olk;
vei irri] ms. va irri

English: 3 Which have whet their tongue like a sword : and shoot out their arrowes, even bitter words;
Manx: 3. Ta er sliw ’an jange kasly rish kleiw : as tilge magh nan seijyn, gy jarw fokelyn shiarw;

English: Which have] 1662 Who have
4 That they may privily shoote at him that is perfect : suddenly doe they hit him, and feare not.
Manx: 4. Gy vod áyd gyn ’yss saijéraght ersyn ta firrinagh : doll tattym t’ áyd dy voaly é gyn agyl y góyl.

English: 5 They courage themselves in mischiefe : and commune among themselves how they may lay snares; and say that no man shall see them.
Manx: 5. T’ áyd d’ an ianw héyn dány ayns olkys : as taglw nan masky heyn, kyns odys áyd kalgyn y heiaghy; as grá, nagh vǎck dwyne erbí áyd.

English: courage] 1662 incourage
6 They imagine wickednesse and practise it : that they keepe secret among themselves, every man in the deepe of his heart.
Manx: 6. Tá áyd smwnaghtyn olkys, as dy ghlághty e : shen t’ áyd dy rial fallíit nan masky héyn, gygh wlly dwyne ayns dýfnid y ghri.

English: 7 But God shall suddenly shoot at them with a swift arrow : that they shall be wounded.
Manx: 7. Agh níi Jíh doll tattym sáìjéragh oriǔsyn rish séid lýa : gy bíi ayd kortíit.[135]

English: 8 Yea their owne tongues shall make them fall : in so much that who so seeth them, shall laugh them to scorne.
Manx: 8. Gy jarw ver nan jangaghyn héyn orw twitchym : er ghwis quei erbi híi áyd, níi áyd geraghti ymbẃsyn ayns faghid.

English: 9 And all men that see it, shall say, This hath God done : for they shall perceive that it is his worke.
Manx: 9. As gygh wlly gwyne híi é, jirr áyd, shó ta Jih erna ianw : erson enni áyd gy níi y obersyn.

English: 10 The righteous shall rejoyce in the Lord, and put his trust in him : and all they that are true of heart, shall be glad.
Manx: 10. Gowi yn dwyney kayragh boggey ayns y Chiarn, as ver e y hreistéel ayns-syn : as bi aydsyn wlly ta firrinagh dy ghrí gannoil.

English: The xii. day.
Manx: Yn xii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Te decet hymnus. Psal. 65.
Manx: Te decet hymnus. psal. 65.

English: Thou, O God, art praised in Sion : and unto thee shall the vowe bee performed in Hierusalem.
Manx: 1. Ta us, O Iíh, mollít ayns Seion : as dwitch víis yn briyry erna ghwiliny ayns Jeriusalem.

English: 2 Thou that hearest the prayer : unto thee shall all flesh come.
Manx: 2. Us ta klastchen yn phaidjer : hẃỳds hig gygh wlly éyl.

English: 3 My misdeedes prevaile against me : oh be thou mercifull unto our sinnes.
Manx: 3. Ta my grogh ianw góyl barriyght m’ ýòis : Ó bi us trokroil dys nan bekaghyn.

English: 4 Blessed is the man whom thou choosest and receivest unto thee : hee shall dwell in thy Court, and shall bee satisfied with the pleasures of thy house, even of thy holy Temple.
Manx: 4. Báníit ta yn dwyne ta us dy ryi, as dy góyl hẃỳds : níi e vaghey ayns tdy ghẃyrt, as bíi é erna liény rish éunys dy tdy hei, gy jarw dy tdy hiampyl kasserićk.

English: 5 Thou shalt shewe us wonderfull things in thy righteousnesse, O God of our salvation : thou that art the hope of all the ends of the earth, and of them that remaine in the broad sea.
Manx: 5. Jeaghit us redyn ientysagh dẃìniyn ayns dy ghayrys, O Iíh dy nan sawálys : us ta treistéel dy kíin wlly yn talw, as jusyn ta farraghtyn ayns yn ’arky lien.
jeaghit] ms. jeaghiy

English: 6 Which in his strength setteth fast the mountaines: and is girded about with power.
Manx: 6. Ta ayns y gniart seiaghy ny slechyn síćkyr : as ta chaynchy[136] magiyrt rish pwer.

English: Which] 1662 Who
7 Who stilleth the raging of the sea : and the noyse of his waves, and the madnesse of his people.
Manx: 7. Ta kiúnaghy bẃriwgh yn árky : as shiǎn y honnyn, [as] kýeid y phobyl.

English: Which] 1662 Who; his people] 1662 the people
8 They also that dwell in the uttermost partes of the earth, shall be afraid at thy tokens : thou that makest the outgoings of the morning and evening to praise thee.
Manx: 8. Aydsyn níist ta vaghey ayns ny harnyn soje magh d’ yn talw, bíi áyd aglagh dy tdy ghóraghyn : us ta tóyrt er gymiaght magh yn voghrey as yn ’askyr dy tdy voll’us.
ny harnyn] ms. y harnyn

English: 9 Thou visitest the earth, and blessest it : thou makest it very plenteous.
Manx: 9. Tóẁ jaghyn yn talw, as dy vanaghy é : tóẁ dy ianw é fíir palchey.

English: 10 The river of God is full of water : thou preparest their corne, for so thou providest for the earth.
Manx: 10. Ta strẃan Iíh láyn d’ wyskey : tóẁ janw arlw nan arẁ, erson marshen tóẁ góyl yimne ghon y talw.

English: 11 Thou waterest her furrowes, thou sendest raine into the little valleyes thereof : thou makest it soft with the drops of raine, and blessest the increase of it.
Manx: 11. Tóẁ gwyskaghe y kríghyn, tow toyrt flaghy ayns ny kónyn begy acks : tow d’ ianw bog [ee] rish banniyn[137] flaghi, as bannaghy yn bishagh agge.

English: 12 Thou crownest the yeere with thy goodnes : and thy cloudes drop fatnesse.
Manx: 12. Tow karghey[138] yn vléyn rish tdy veiys : as ta tdy vojelyn shilliey méalys.
vojelyn] ms. vojelynyn

English: 13 They shall droppe upon the dwellings of the wildernesse : and the little hilles shall rejoyce on every side.
Manx: 13. Ni ayd shilliy er ny hynydyn vághey d’ yn áysyght : as gowi ny knwick begy boggy er gygh wn chéyf.

English: 14 The folds shall be full of sheepe : the valleys also shall stand so thicke with corne, that they shall laugh and sing.
Manx: 14. Bii ny boilchyn layn dy ghirri : shassi ny glantínyn niist gho chew rish arrw, gy jean ayd gery as oráyn y góyl.

English: Iubilate Deo. Psal. 66.
Manx: Jubilate deo. psal. 66.

English: O be joyfull in God all ye lands : sing praises unto the honour of his Name, make his praise to be glorious.
Manx: 1. O bigi ganoil ayns Jih, wlly shiùsse hallwiniyn : molligi rish oráyn oneyr y enymsyn; kwrrigi er y volley dy vé gloroil.

English: 2 Say unto God, O how wonderful art thou in thy workes : through the greatnes of thy power shall thine enemies be found lyars unto thee.
Manx: 2. Abergi rish Jih, O ghó iéntyssagh as ta us ayns t’ obraghyn : treyfd móarid dy tdy phwer víis tdy noidjyn er nan géàdthyn nan mregyryn dwich.

English: 3 For all the world shall worship thee : sing to thee, and praise thy Name.
Manx: 3. Erson níi yn sýyl wlly ammys y hoyrt dwich : oráyn y góyl jíds, as t’ enym y volley.

English: sing to thee] 1581, 1636, 1660, 1662 sing of thee
4 O come hither, and behold the workes of God : how wonderfull he is in his doing toward the children of men.
Manx: 4. O tredigi aynshó, as jeaghigi er obraghyn Iíh : ghó ientysagh as t’ é ayns y ianw gys klawn géne.

English: 5 He turned the sea into drie land : so that they went thorow the water on foote; there did we rejoyce thereof.
Manx: 5. Hyndá é yn farkey ayns talw chirỳm : marshen gy jagh áyd tryid yn ẃisky rǎnn gosh, aynshen gow shwiniyn bogey jé.
jagh] ms. jeagh; gosh] ms. ghosh

English: 6 He ruleth with his power for ever; his eyes behold the people : and such as will not beleeve, shall not be able to exalt themselves.
Manx: 6. T’ é réel rish y phẃyr erson gybragh; ta y hẃilyn jaghyn er y phobyl : as leid ass nagh gred, gha bi áyd abyl d’ an drogel héyn sýas.

English: 7 O praise our God (ye people :) and make the voyce of his praise to be heard;
Manx: 7. O molligi nan Iih, shiusse phobyl : as kwrrigi er korá y voley-syn dy vé erna ghlastchen;

English: 8 Which holdeth our soule in life : and suffereth not our feete to slip.
Manx: 8. Ta kwmmel nan anym ayns bé : as nagh vel syrrel nan gassyn dy skyr̀re.

English: Which] 1662 Who
9 For thou (O God) hast proved us : thou also hast tried us, like as silver is tried.
Manx: 9. Erson ta us, O Iíh, er nan shir̀re magh : tóẁ níist er nan [..........,][139] kasly rish argyd ta erna hyrre magh.

English: 10 Thou broughtest us into the snare : and layedst trouble upon our loynes.
Manx: 10. Tow̌ er nan dóyrt shwin ayns y ribby : as er sěiaghy syaghyn er nan míaghyn.

English: 11 Thou sufferedst men to ride over our heads : we went through fire and water, and thou broughtest us out into a wealthy place.
Manx: 11. Hwr us dene dy varkiaght har̀rish nan gin : ghái shwin tryid aínil as wysky, as hwgg us [liatt] shwinyn [magh] gys ynyd berchiagh.

English: 12 I wil go into thy house with burnt offrings: and wil pay thee my vowes which I promised with my lips, & spake with my mouth when I was in trouble.
Manx: 12. Híem schiagh ayns tdy heiys lesh owrelyn loisk : as íikym dwich my vriaraghyn ta mi erna iáltyn rish my veliyn, as lóyr mi rish my véal, nar vá mi ayns sýaghyn.

English: 13 I wil offer unto thee fat burnt sacrifices, with the incense of rammes : I will offer bullocks and goats.
Manx: 13. Oŵryms oŵrelyn loisk ráwr dwich, lesh sóyr mei dy reaghyn : oŵryms gowne as góeir.

English: 14 O come hither, and hearken all ye that feare God : and I wil tell you what he hath done for my soule.
Manx: 14. O trédigi aynshó, as klastigi, wlly shiusse ta goyl agyl réyfs Jíh : as inshiym díifs kre t’ é erna ianw ersonn m’ anym.

English: 15 I called unto him with my mouth : and gave him praises with my tongue.
Manx: 15. Jei mi ersyn rish my véal : as hwgg mi mollaghyn dâ rish my hiange.

English: 16 If I incline unto wickednes with my heart : the Lord will not heare me.
Manx: 16. Ma verryms my hatnys er olk rish my ghri : gha glwn yn Chiarn mi.

English: 17 But God hath heard mee : and considered the voyce of my prayer.
Manx: 17. Agh ta Jíh er my ghlastchen : as er smwnaghtyn er korá my phadjer.

English: 18 Praised bee God, which hath not cast out my prayer : nor turned his mercie from me.
Manx: 18. Mollíit gy row Jih, nagh vel er dilge magh my phadjer : na er jyndá y vyghin voym.

English: which] 1662 who
Deus misereatur. Psal. 67.
Manx: Deus misereatur. psal. 67.

English: God be mercifull unto us, and blesse us : and shew us the light of his countenance, and be mercifull unto us:
Manx: 1. Gy row Jíh myghinagh dẃìn, as d’ an managhy shwin : as dy hoilsaghey gẃìn sóilshe y ýei, as dy vé myghinagh dwin.

English: 2 That thy way may be knowen upon earth : thy saving health among all nations.
Manx: 2. Gy vod tdy ráỳds ve er fyss er y talw : tdy laint sawáyl masky ny natiẃnyn wlly.

English: 3 Let the people praise thee, O God : yea, let all the people praise thee.
Manx: 3. Ligg e yn pobyl us y volly, O Iíh : gy jarw, ligg e yn pobyl wlly us y volley.

English: 4 O let the nations rejoyce & be glad, for thou shalt judge the folke righteously : and governe the nations upon earth.
Manx: 4. O ligg dy ny hatiẃnyn bogey y goyl as vé gannòil : erson ni us yn slyei y vrẃinys gy káyr, as ny hatiẃnyn y réyl er y talw.

English: be glad, ... righteously : and] 1636, 1660, 1662 be glad : ... righteously, and
5 Let the people praise thee, O God : let all the people praise thee.
Manx: 5. Ligg e yn pobyl us y volley, O Iíh : ligg e yn pobyl wlly us y volley.

English: 6 Then shall the earth bring foorth her increase : and God, even our owne God, shall give us his blessing.
Manx: 6. Eish níi yn talw y hóyrt magh y bishagh héyn : as ver Jíh, gy jarw yn Jih ain héyn, gẃiniyn y vanaght.

English: 7 God shall blesse us : and all the ends of the world shall feare him.
Manx: 7. Níi Jih shwiniyn y vánaghy : as gowi kíin yn týyl wlly agyl roi-syn.
gowi] ms. gowgi

English: The xiii. day.
Manx: Yn xiii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Aryn.

English: Exurgat Deus. Psal. 68.
Manx: Exvrgat Deus. psal. 68.

English: Let God arise, and let his enemies bee scattered : let them also that hate him, flee before him.
Manx: 1. Ligg e Jíh girri, as ligg e y noidjyn vé er nan skéyly : ligg awsyn níist ta dẃoi àck ersyn ’etlagh roisyn.

English: 2 Like as the smoke vanisheth, so shalt thou drive them away : and like as waxe melteth at the fire, so let the ungodly perish at the presence of God.
Manx: 2. Mar ta yn jéagh kéyf, marshen ymmanyt us áydsyn er shíẁl : as mar ta kéyr liey ag yn aínil, marshen ligg e yn niaw ghrawi vé er nan gwr mów ayns fénish Iíh.
ligg e] ms. lig

English: 3 But let the righteous be glad and rejoyce before God : let them also be merie and joyfull.
Manx: 3. As ligg e yn slyei kayragh ve gannoil as bogey y goyl feanish Jíh : ligg ’awsyn níist vé gannoil as bogyl.

English: 4 O sing unto God, and sing praises unto his Name : magnifie him that rideth upon the heavens as it were upon an horse; praise him in his Name, yea, and rejoyce before him.
Manx: 4. O gowigi oráyn dy Iíh, as molligi y enym rish oráyn : gloŕigi eshyin gy mẃar ta márkiaght er ny neawaghyn, mar veagh é er kapyl; molligi eshyn ayns y enym, gy jarw, as gowigi bogey na ’iénishyn.

English: Name, yea,] 1703 Name, Jah
5 He is a father of the fatherlesse, and defendeth the cause of the widowes : even God in his holy habitation.
Manx: 5. T’ é na áer d’ yn ghlawn gyn áer : as t’ e fríal kẃishyn ny mẏnáyn tréagh, gy jarw Jíh ayns y ynyd vághe kasserick.

English: 6 He is the God that maketh men to bee of one minde in an house, and bringeth the prisoners out of captivitie : but letteth the runnagates continue in scarcenesse.
Manx: 6. She eshyn yn Jíh ta toyrt er déne dy vé d’ yn agney ayns těi, as tóyrt ny kapi magh as kapy : agh ligg e ny siẃlaghanyn fannaghtyn ayns genid.

English: 7 O God, when thou wentest foorth before the people : when thou wentest thorow the wildernesse;
Manx: 7. O Iíh, nar ghái us magh réỳfs yn phobyl : nar ghái us tréỳfd yn ’ásygh;

English: 8 The earth shooke, and the heavens dropped at the presence of God : even as Sinai also was mooved at the presence of God, which is the God of Israel.
Manx: 8. Ghrei yn talẃ, as hill ny neawaghyn ag fénish Iíh : gy jarw mar vá Seinái níist er glýasagh ag feanish Iíh, she ta Jih Eisrael.

English: which is] 1662 who is
9 Thou, O God, sentest a gracious raine upon thine inheritance : and refreshedst it when it was wearie.
Manx: 9. Tá us, O Iíh, toyrt flaghey grasóil er t’ éirys : as dwrri ẃ é nar v’ é skíe.

English: 10 Thy Congregation shall dwell therein : for thou, O God, hast of thy goodnesse prepared for the poore.
Manx: 10. Níi tdy heshiaght vaghey aynshen : erson ta us, O Iíh, dy tdy véìys ern’ arlaghy é ghon ny moght.

English: 11 The Lord gave the word : great was the company of the Preachers.
Manx: 11. Hwgg yn Chiarn yn gẃ : smẃar va shessaght ny bréchéryn.

English: 12 Kings with their armies did flee and were discomfited : and they of the houshold divided the spoile.
Manx: 12. Ren Riaghyn rish nan shessaghtyn kagoil ché, as v’ áyd er [nan] gwrr ergẃl : as aydsyn d’ yn teíus,[140] ren áyd y ghréagh.

English: 13 Though ye have lien among the pots, yet shall ye bee as the wings of a Dove : that is covered with silver wings, and her feathers like gold.
Manx: 13. Gy ta shiu er ly̌i masky ny pwitch, fóyst bíi shiu mar skeányn kalmáyn : ta kẃdit rish skeányn argid, as y feadjaghyn kasly rish áyr.

English: 14 When the Almightie scattered Kings for their sake : then were they as white as snow in Salmon.
Manx: 14. Trá skýyl yn wlly gniartoil ríaghyn er-nan-son-syn : eis v’ áyd ghó gìál as snaghty ayns Salmon.

English: 15 As the hill of Basan, so is Gods hill : even an high hill, as the hill of Basan.
Manx: 15. Mar knock Vasan, marshen ta knock Iíh : gy jarw knock ard, mar knock Vasan.

English: 16 Why hop ye so ye high hils? this is Gods hill, in the which it pleaseth him to dwell : yea, the Lord will abide in it for ever.
Manx: 16. Kamma vel shiu liem marshen, shiusse ghnwick ardy? she sho knock Iíh, aynshen va eshyn bwiagh dy vaghy : gy jarw, fwrri yn Chiarn áyn erson gybrágh.
va] ms. ve

English: 17 The charets of God are twenty thousand, even thousands of Angels : and the Lord is among them, as in the holy place of Sinai.
Manx: 17. Ta fiéninyn[141] kage Iíh fíid twsányn, gy jarw twsányn d’ aínilyn : ta yn Chiarn nan masky-syn, mar ayns yn ynyd kasserick dy Heinai.
yn ynyd] ms. ym ynyd

English: 18 Thou art gone up on high, thou hast led captivitie captive, and received gifts for men : yea, even for thine enemies, that the Lord God might dwell among them.
Manx: 18. Tow er nol sýas gy hárd, tow er lidjéel kapy na ghimmi, as ern góyl giwtyn erson déne : she, gy jarw erson tdy nóidjyn, gy vodagh yn Chiarn Jih vaghey nan masky-syn.
er nol] ms. er’ nol

English: 19 Praised bee the Lord dayly : even the God which helpeth us, and powreth his benefits upon us.
Manx: 19. Mollit gy row yn Chiarn gygh lá : gy jarw Jíh ta kwney leiniyn, as dýyrty y hórtyssyn mei orwiniyn.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: hórtyssyn] ms. hórtyffyn

English: 20 He is our God, even the God of whom commeth salvation : God is the Lord, by whom we escape death.
Manx: 20. Shé eshyn nan Iíh, gy jarw yn Jíh iê ta sawálys chíit : she Jih yn Chiarn, liórish ta shwin shaghnéy báas.

English: 21 God shall wound the head of his enemies : and the hairie scalpe of such a one as goeth on still in his wickednesse.
Manx: 21. Lotti Jíh kian y nóidjyn : as mwlagh fwilt kian léid yn anáyn as ta shíir gimmiáght ayns y pheky.

English: 22 The Lord hath said, I will bring my people againe, as I did from Basan : mine owne will I bring againe, as I did sometime from the deepe of the Sea.
Manx: 22. Ta yn Chiarn ern’ rá, verrym my phobyl ríist, mar ren mi vei Basan : my lyei héyn verrym riist, mar ren mi kýyrt dy row vei diyfnid yn ’argey.

English: 23 That thy foot may be dipped in the blood of thine enemies : and that the tongue of thy dogs may bee red through the same.
Manx: 23. Gy vod tdy ghass ve erna hẃmmy ayns fwil tdy nóidjyn : as gy vod chiange dy vodi vé jarge[142] tryid shen.

English: 24 It is well seene, O God, how thou goest : how thou my God and King goest in the Sanctuary.
Manx: 24. S’ mei t’ é erna ackyn, O Iíh, kyns ta us gimiaght : kyns ta us, my Íih as ríi, gimiaght ayns yn ynyd ghasserićk.

English: 25 The singers goe before, the minstrels follow after : in the middest are the damosels playing with the timbrels.
Manx: 25. Ta ny fy̌ir oráyn gol roi, ny mynstrélyn géìyrts na yre : ayns yn véan ta ny mynáyn aǵy klwi rish ny teimpanyn.

English: 26 Give thankes, O Israel, unto God the Lord in the Congregations : from the ground of the heart.
Manx: 26. Kwr bwias, O Eisrael, dy Iíh yn Chiarn ayns ny shessaghtyn : vei diyfnid yn ghri.

English: 27 There is little Benjamin their ruler, and the princes of Juda their counsaile : the princes of Zabulon, & the princes of Nephthali.
Manx: 27. Aynshen ta Benjamyn beg nan fer réel, as ríiaghyn Juda nan gowrle : kanẃrti Zabulon, as kanwrti Nepthali.

English: 28 Thy God hath sent foorth strength for thee : stablish the thing, O God, that thou hast wrought in us,
Manx: 28. Ta dy Iíh er doyrt magh gniart dwitch : gniarti yn red, O Iíh, ta us erna obraghy aynnyniyn,

English: 29 For thy Temples sake at Hierusalem : so shall Kings bring presents unto thee.
Manx: 29. Erson grayi tdy hampyl ag Jeriusalem : marshen ver ríaghyn toyrtyssyn dwitch.
