English: 30 When the company of the spearemen, and multitude of the mighty are scattered abroad among the beastes of the people (so that they humbly bring pieces of silver :) and when he hath scattered the people that delight in warre;
Manx: 30. Tra ta shessaght ny déne sléy, as ymmydi dy geney láidjer er nan skély er lied masky běin yn phobyl, marshen gy vel ayd gy hishyil toyrt liéw pisyn d’ argyd : as nar t’ e er skely yn slyei ta agne ack ayns kagey;

English: 31 Then shall the princes come out of Egypt : the Morians land shall soone stretch out her hands unto God.
Manx: 31. Eish higg ny kianẃrtyn magh as Éjipt : shini gy lýe talw Vorian y lawyn magh gys Jíh.

English: 32 Sing unto God, O ye kingdomes of the earth : O sing praises unto the Lord;
Manx: 32. Gowji orayn gys Jih, O shiuss ririaghtin yn tallw : O gowji orayn dy voallaghin gys yn Chiarn;[143]
chiarn] ms. chairn

English: 33 Which sitteth in the heavens over all from the beginning : lo, he doth send out his voice, yea, & that a mighty voice.
Manx: 33. Ta sy̌ei ayns ny neawaghyn harrish wlly vei yn toshiagh : jéagh, t’ é tóyrt magh y ghorá, gy jarw, as shen korá gníartoil.

English: Which] 1662 Who
34 Ascribe ye the power to God over Israel : his worship and strength is in the cloudes.
Manx: 34. Kwrrigi pẃer dy Iíh harrish Éisrael : ta y ammys as y gniart ayns ny bojalyn.

English: 35 O God, wonderfull art thou in thy holy places : even the God of Israel, hee wil give strength and power unto his people; blessed be God.
Manx: 35. O Iíh, toẃs layn iéntysagh ayns t’ yn̄yd kasserick : gy jarw Jíh Eisrael, ver eshyn gniart as pẃer da phobyl. Báníit gy row Jíh.

English: The xiii. day.
Manx: Yn xiii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Saluum me fac. Psal. 69.
Manx: Saluum me fac. psal. 69.

English: Save mee, O God : for the waters are come in, even unto my soule.
Manx: 1. Sáw mi, O Iíh : erson ta ny hwyskaghyn er jíit schiagh, gy jarw gys my anym.

English: 2 I sticke fast in the deepe myre, where no ground is : I am come into deepe waters, so that the floods runne over me.
Manx: 2. Ta mi sy̌it sickyr ayns y láygh dow̌in, yn ynyd nagh vel veg y talw : ta mi er jít ayns wiskaghyn dowin, marshen gy vel [ny] twyllaghyn ry̌i harrym.

English: 3 I am weary of crying; my throat is dry : my sight faileth mee for waiting so long upon my God.
Manx: 3. Ta mi skíi d’ émaght, ta my skorniagh chirym : ta my hilliy dy my hoyrt nayrde erson farkiaght ghowd er my Iíh.
my skorniagh] ms. mi skorniagh; my hilliy] ms. mi hilliy

English: 4 They that hate mee without a cause, are moe then the haires of my head : they that are mine enemies, and would destroy me guiltlesse, are mighty.
Manx: 4. Aydsyn ta dẃoi ack ořryms gyn óyr, t’ ayd naslí na renagyn my ghinn : ta aydsyn ta my nóidjyn, as balliesh my strẃiěl niawghientagh, gniartoil.

English: 5 I payd them the things that I never tooke : God, thou knowest my simplenes, and my faults are not hid from thee.
Manx: 5. Jík mi daw ny rydyn nagh gow mi riǔ : Iíh, sáwn dwich my iírid[144] gyn loght, as gha vel m’ ’óilchyn fallíit voidj.

English: 6 Let not them that trust in thee, O Lord God of hosts, be ashamed for my cause : let not those that seeke thee be confounded through me, O Lord God of Israel.
Manx: 6. Na ligg dáw ta treistéel ǎnyds, O Hiarn Jíh ny shessaghtyn, ve nayragh erson my ghwisys : na ligg dawsyn ta dy tdy hyrrys vé er nan nayraghy troyms, O Hiarn Iíh Eisrael.
ghwisys] ms. ghwisyns

English: 7 And why? for thy sake have I suffred reproofe : shame hath covered my face.
Manx: 7. As kamma? er tdy hons ta mi er vwllaghtyn aghsyn : ta nayre er gwdaghy m’ edyn.

English: 8 I am become a stranger unto my brethren : even an aliant unto my mothers children.
Manx: 8. Ta mi mar dwyney jori dy my vraeraghyn : gy jarw, mar dwyney qwéagh dy ghlawn my váyry.
dwyney jori] ms. dyney jori

English: 9 For the zeale of thy house hath even eaten me: and the rebukes of them that rebuked thee, are fallen upon me.
Manx: 9. Erson ta grayi che dy tdy hei gy jarw er m’ íi : as ta [ny] haghsanyn acksyn hwg aghsyn dw̌ich er dwitchym orryms.
dy tdy hei] ms. y dy hei

English: 10 I wept, and chastened my selfe with fasting : and that was turned to my reproofe.
Manx: 10. Ren mi kwo as smaghti mi mi héyn rish trosky : as va shenn erna hyndá gys m’ ághsan.

English: 11 I put on a sackcloth also : and they jested upon me.
Manx: 11. Hwg mi aynrit sack ymmẃm níist : as ren ayd knaid ymmẃm.
sack ymmẃm] ms. sack ymmẃn

English: 12 They that sit in the gate speake against mee : and the drunkards make songs upon me.
Manx: 12. Ta aydsyn ta sěi ayns y iat lóyrt m’ ýois : as ta ny déne meskoil janw oranyn orryms.

English: 13 But Lord, I make my prayer unto thee : in an acceptable time.
Manx: 13. Agh, Hiarn, ta mi janw my phaidjer hẃỳds : ayns ierish bẃiasoil.

English: 14 Heare me, O God, in the multitude of thy mercie : even in the trueth of thy salvation.
Manx: 14. Klwyn mi, O Iíh, ayns ymmydi dy tdy vyghin : gy jarw ayns firrinys tdy hawálys.

English: 15 Take me out of the myre, that I sinke not : O let me bee delivered from them that hate mee, and out of the deepe waters.
Manx: 15. Gow mi magh as y láygh, nagh biym er my váyg[145] : O Iíh, lig dow ve er my lifré vowsyn ta dwoi ack orrym, as ass ny hwyskaghyn dowin.
váyg] ms. váyr

English: 16 Let not the water flood drowne mee, neither let the deepe swallow me up : and let not the pit shut her mouth upon me.
Manx: 16. Na ligg d’ yn twilliw wysky mish y váyg, namẃ ligg d’ yn díyfnid my lwgge sýas : as na lig d’ yn lagg y béal y iei orryms.

English: 17 Heare me, O Lord, for thy loving kindnesse is comfortable : turne thee unto mee, according to the multitude of thy mercies.
Manx: 17. Ést rwyms, O Hiarn, erson ta tdy gheindylys grayióil gyrjwill : chyndá us hwyms nyre ymmydi dy tdy hrokeryn.

English: 18 And hide not thy face from thy servant, for I am in trouble : Oh haste thee, and heare me.
Manx: 18. As na falli t’ edyn vei tdy hyrváynt, erson ta mi ayns syaghyn : O jean seir as klwyn mí.

English: 19 Draw nigh unto my soule, and save it : Oh deliver me, because of mine enemies.
Manx: 19. Tarn argere [dy] m’ anym, as saw e : ó lifrée mish erson my nóidjyn.

English: 20 Thou hast knowen my reproofe, my shame, and my dishonour : mine adversaries are all in thy sight.
Manx: 20. Bawn dwit m’ aghsan, my náyre, as my niaw onéyr : ta my noidjyn wlly ayns tdy hilliy.

English: 21 Thy rebuke hath broken my heart; I am full of heavinesse : I looked for some to have pitie on me, but there was no man, neither found I any to comfort me.
Manx: 21. Ta tdy náyre er mrishie my ghri, ta mi layn dy hrimshey : iagh mi erson anáyn egnagh dy goyl tréyi jíim, agh gha row dwney erbi, ghamẃ fóyr mi anáyn dy my gyrjaghy.
tréyi] ms. tréy

English: 22 They gave me gall to eate : and when I was thirstie, they gave me vineger to drinke.
Manx: 22. Hwgg áyd dǒw gàll dy íi : as trá va mi páa, hwgg ayd dow phien gér dy íif.

English: 23 Let their table bee made a snare to take themselves withall : and let the things, that should have bene for their wealth, be unto them an occasion of falling.
Manx: 23. Ligg e nan moỳrd ve erna ianw na rìbbey dan góyl heyn rish : as ligg e ny redyn leshaght y ve ghon nan mei, ve dawsyn ǒyr dy hwitchym.

English: 24 Let their eyes bee blinded that they see not : and ever bow downe their backs.
Manx: 24. Ligg e nan sẃilyn ve er nan ’ally, nagh vaick áyd : as gybragh krẃmm us[146] shiis nan ’rymmyn.

English: bow downe] 1562, 1662 bow thou down
25 Powre out thine indignation upon them : and let thy wrathfull displeasure take hold of them.
Manx: 25. Dýart magh tdy iẃmẃiys orǐusyn : as ligg e tdy ghorri jumẃìsagh gryem y góyl orrǐusyn.

English: 26 Let their habitation be voyd : and no man to dwell in their tents.
Manx: 26. Ligg e nan ienyd vaghi ve pháys : as gyn dẃney erbi dy vaghey ayns nan gábanan.

English: 27 For they persecute him whom thou hast smitten : and they talke how they may vexe them whom thou hast wounded.
Manx: 27. Erson t’ ayd dy eiỳert-syn gy rẃnagh ta us erna voally : as t’ áyd taglw kyns ’odys áyd aydsyn y hyaghy ta us erna lotty.

English: 28 Let them fall from one wickednesse to another: and not come into thy righteousnesse.
Manx: 28. Ligg ’áẁ twitchym vei yn pheky gys peky elley : as na chíit gys dy ghayrys.

English: 29 Let them be wiped out of the booke of the living : and not be written among the righteous.
Manx: 29. Ligg ’aŵ ve er nan glanny magh as liór yn klěi víò : as gyn ve er nan skriw masky yn klyěi ghayragh.

English: 30 As for mee, when I am poore and in heavinesse : thy helpe, O God, shall lift me up.
Manx: 30. As er my hons, nar ta mi boght as ayns trimshey : trogi tdy ghẃynys, O Iih, mish sýas.

English: 31 I will praise the Name of God with a song : and magnifie it with thankesgiving.
Manx: 31. Mollym enym Iíh rish oráyn : as níìms e gy mẃar y glóyraghy rish toyrt bẃias.

English: 32 This also shall please the Lord : better then a bullocke, that hath hornes and hoofes.
Manx: 32. Níi shó níist yn Chiarn y vẃias : na sháyr na gaẃn[147] ag vel eyrkyn as íngnyn.

English: 33 The humble shall consider this, and be glad : seeke yee after God, and your soule shall live.
Manx: 33. Ni ny déne míin smẃnaghtyn er shó, as bi áyd gannoil : shyrrigi nyre Iíh, as bíi nan anym bíò.

English: 34 For the Lord heareth the poore : and despiseth not his prisoners.
Manx: 34. Erson ta yn Chiarn klastchen ny moght : as gha vel é seiaghy begg da ghimmi.

English: 35 Let heaven and earth praise him : the sea and all that mooveth therein.
Manx: 35. Ligg e neaw as talw eshyn y volley : yn fargy as wlly ta glyasaght aynshen.

English: 36 For God will save Sion, and build the cities of Juda : that men may dwell there, and have it in possession.
Manx: 36. Erson sawi Jih Seion, as trogi é ballaghyn Iuda : gy vod déney vaghey ayn shen, as y geadthyn ghon eíỳrys é.

English: 37 The posteritie also of his servants shall inherit it : and they that love his Name shall dwell therein.
Manx: 37. Bíi e na éìrus ag slwght dy herváyntyn níist : as ní aydsyn shyney lesh y enymsyn vaghey aynshen.

English: Deus in adiutorium. Psal. 70.
Manx: Deus in adiutorium. psal. 70.

English: Haste thee, O God, to deliver me : make haste to helpe me, O Lord.
Manx: 1. Jean us séìr, O Iíh, dy mi lifré : jean séìr dy ghẃney láym, O Hiarn.
my] ms. mi

English: 2 Let them be ashamed and confounded that seeke after my soule : let them bee turned backward and put to confusion that wish me evill.
Manx: 2. Ligg ’awsyn vé er ’an náyraghy as er nan gwrr mow ta shyirre nyre m’ anym : ligg ’awsyn ve er nan jyndá góyr ’an rommy, as er nan doyrt gys náyre ta sowlaghy olk dwys.
gwrr] ms. ghwrr

English: 3 Let them for their reward be soone brought to shame : that cry over me, There, there.
Manx: 3. Ligg ’awsyn erson nan lúagh vé gy lúa er nan doyrt gys nare : ta gemagh harryms, shen, shen.

English: 4 But let those that seeke thee, be joyful and glad in thee : and let all such as delight in thy Salvation, say alway, The Lord be praised.
Manx: 4. Agh ligg ’awsyn wlly ta dy [tdy] hyiřrys vé bogoil as ganoil ay̌nyds : as ligg e wlly leidj as ta agney ack ayns tdy hawálys, y grá gybragh, molley d’ yn Chiarn.

English: 5 As for mee, I am poore and in miserie : haste thee unto me, O God.
Manx: 5. As er my hons, ta mi boght, as ayns trýei : jean us seir hwyms, O Iíh.

English: 6 Thou art my helper and my Redeemer : O Lord, make no long tarying.
Manx: 6. She us m’ er kẃni, as m’ er kani ríist : O Hiarn, na jean vegg y fwrriagh fodey.
ríist] ms. níist

English: The xiiii. day.
Manx: Yn xiiii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: In te, Domine, speraui. Psal. 71.
Manx: In te Domine speraui. psal. 71.

English: In thee, O Lorde, have I put my trust, let mee never be put to confusion : but rid me, and deliver mee in thy righteousnesse, encline thine eare unto mee, and save me.
Manx: 1. Ǎnyds, O Hiarn, ta mi er doyrt my hreistéel, na ligg doŵ gybragh ve er my hóyrt náyre : agh rei[148] mí, as lifré mí ayns tdy ghayrys; krom tdy ghlúesh hẃỳms, as saw mí.

English: 2 Be thou my strong hold, whereunto I may alway resort : thou hast promised to helpe mee, for thou art my house of defence, and my castle.
Manx: 2. Bíi us m’ ynyd laidjer, gys ’odym goni gól : tow ern’ gnialtyn dy ghwyney láỳm, erson she us my hy̌i friali as my ghastyl.

English: 3 Deliver mee, O my God, out of the hande of the ungodly : out of the hand of the unrighteous and cruel man.
Manx: 3. Lifré mi, O my Iíh, magh as láw yn niawghrawi : as law yn dwyney niawghayragh as dew̌il.
dwyney] ms. dyney

English: 4 For thou, O Lord God, art the thing that I long for : thou art my hope, even from my youth.
Manx: 4. Erson she us, O Hiarn Jíh, yn red ta mi góyl fódiaght er y hon : she us my hreistéel, gy jarw vei my ágid.

English: 5 Through thee have I bene holden up ever since I was borne : thou art hee that tooke me out of my mothers wombe; my praise shal be alway of thee.
Manx: 5. Trowyds vá mi er my ghwmmell shúas ríù ada rwgg mi : she us eshyn gow mi magh as bren my váyre; bíi my volly gybragh j́ids.

English: alway] 1636 alwayes
6 I am become as it were a monster unto many : but my sure trust is in thee.
Manx: 6. Ta mi er jít mar veagh e ientyss dy ymmydi : agh ta my hreisteel ay̌nyds.

English: 7 O let my mouth be filled with thy praise : that I may sing of thy glory and honour, all the day long.
Manx: 7. O ligg e my véal vé erna liány rish tdy volly : gy voddym oráyn y góyl dy tdy glóyr as óneyr fei yn lá.

English: 8 Cast mee not away in the time of age : forsake me not when my strength faileth me.
Manx: 8. Na tilg mi er shiul ayns iérish my yesh : ná tréyg mi nar ta my gniart dy my hoyrt náyrdé.

English: 9 For mine enemies speake against me, & they that lay waite for my soule, take their counsell together, saying : God hath forsaken him; persecute him, and take him, for there is none to deliver him.
Manx: 9. Erson ta my noidjyn lóyrt m’ ýoi, as aydsyn ta farkiaght er m’ anym, góyl an gowrley kẃjaght, grá : ta Jih erna hregael-syn, eigyrgi gy holk é, as gowigi é, erson gha vel anáyn da lifrée.

English: 10 Go not farre from me, O God : my God, haste thee to helpe me.
Manx: 10. Na gow fodey vóỳm, O Iíh : my Iíh, jean us séir dy ghwyney láym.

English: 11 Let them bee confounded and perish, that are against my soule : let them bee covered with shame and dishonour, that seeke to doe me evil.
Manx: 11. Ligg ’awsyn vé er ’an doyrt gys náyre as er an gwr moẃ, ta nýei m’ anym : ligg ’aw ve er ’an gwdaghy rish náyre as niaw onyr ta shyr̀re dy ianw olk dẃys.

English: 12 As for mee, I will patiently abide alway : and will praise thee more and more.
Manx: 12. As er my hons, níìm farkiaght gy míin gybrágh : as mollym us nasmw as nasmw.

English: 13 My mouth shall dayly speak of thy righteousnes and salvation : for I know no ende thereof.
Manx: 13. Lóyri my véal gygh lá dy tdy gháyrys as hawálys : erson gha náùn dow kian erbi j́è.

English: 14 I will goe forth in the strength of the Lord God: and wil make mention of thy righteousnesse onely.
Manx: 14. Hiêms magh ayns gniart yn Chiarn Jih : as lóyryms dy tdy gháyrys nolymarkan.

English: 15 Thou, O God, hast taught mee from my youth up untill now : therefore will I tell of thy wonderous workes.
Manx: 15. Ta us, O Iíh, er my ynsaghey vei m’ ágid shuas naggedere nish : shennyfá iínshiym dy t’ obraghyn ientysagh.

English: 16 Forsake me not, O God, in mine old age, when I am gray headed : until I have shewed thy strength unto this generation, and thy power to all them that are yet for to come.
Manx: 16. Na tréyg mi, O Iíh, ayns my henn ýesh, nar ta my ghian liêy[149] : naggydere víim ern’ iághyn tdy gniart d’ yn shilógh shó, as tdy phwer dáẁsyn wlly ta fóyst rá híìt.

English: 17 Thy righteousnesse, O God, is very high : and great things are they that thou hast done, O God, who is like unto thee?
Manx: 17. Ta tdy gháyrys, O íih, fíir áyrd : as smẃar ny redyn shen ta us erna ianw, O Iíh; quei ta kasly rẃỳts?

English: 18 O what great troubles and adversities hast thou shewed me, and yet diddest thou turne & refresh me : yea, and broughtest me from the deepe of the earth againe.
Manx: 18. O kré ny sýaghyn mẃary, as boghtanys ta us erna iághyn dẃỳs? as fóost ren ẃ chyndá, as dẃri ẃ mi : as hwgg ẃ mi vei dẏfnid yn talw ríist.
ny sýaghyn] ms. yn sýaghyn; dẃri ẃ] ms. dẃriw ẃ

English: 19 Thou hast brought me to great honour : and comforted me on every side.
Manx: 19. Ta us er my hoyrt gys oneyr vẃar : as er my gyrjaghey er gygh wn cheyf.

English: 20 Therefore will I praise thee and thy faithfulnes, O God, playing upon an instrument of musicke : unto thee will I sing upon the harpe, O thou holy one of Israel.
Manx: 20. Shennyfá vollym us as t’ irrinys, O Iíh, klw̌i er grei dy vínníys : hẃỳds goym oráyn er y krwit, ó, us anáyn ghasserićk dy Eisrael.

English: 21 My lips will be faine when I sing unto thee : and so wil my soule whom thou hast delivered.
Manx: 21. Bíi my veliyn gannoil tra góym oráyn dwich : as marshen víis m’ anym ta us erna lifré.

English: 22 My tongue also shall talke of thy righteousnes all the day long : for they are confounded and brought unto shame that seeke to do me evill.
Manx: 22. Nii my hiange níist taglw dy tdy gháyrys féi yn lá liáur : erson ta áydsyn er an gwrr mow as er nan doyrt gys náyre, ta sheirre dy ianw olk dŵys.

English: Deus, iudicium. Psal. 72.
Manx: Deus judicium. psal. 72.

English: Give the King thy judgements, O God : and thy righteousnesse unto the Kings sonne.
Manx: 1. Kwrr tdy vrẃynys d’ yn ríi, O Iíh : as tdy gháyrys dy vack yn ríi.

English: 2 Then shall he judge the people according unto right : and defend the poore.
Manx: 2. Eish níi eshyn yn pobyl y vrẃinys nýre káyr : as yn boght y ríal.

English: the people] 1662 thy people
3 The mountaines also shall bring peace : and the litle hilles righteousnes unto the people.
Manx: 3. Ver ny knwick níist shí : as ny knwick begy káyrys gys y phobyl.

English: 4 He shall keepe the simple folke by their right : defende the children of the poore, and punish the wrong doer.
Manx: 4. Friáli é yn sly̌i gyn loght liórish ’an gáyr : friali é klawn ny moght, as níi e yn dwyne ta janw agáyr y gheraghy.
klawn] ms. ghlawn; y gheraghy] ms. é gheraghy

English: 5 They shall feare thee, as long as the Sunne and Moone endureth : from one generation to another.
Manx: 5. Gowi áyd agyl j́ìds, ghowd as níi yn grían as yn éask farraghtyn : vei yn shilógh gys shilógh elle.
Gowi] ms. Gowigi

English: 6 He shall come downe like the raine into a fleece of wooll : even as the drops that water the earth.
Manx: 6. Higg é núas mar yn flaghy ayns lomry ólly : gy jarw mar ny báìnyn ta gwiskaghy yn talw.
flaghy] ms. slaghy

English: 7 In his time shall the righteous flourish : yea, and abundance of peace, so long as the Moone endureth.
Manx: 7. Ayns y iérishyn níi yn slyei kayragh bláy : gy jarw, as ymmydi dy híi, ghowd as níi yn éask faraghtyn.

English: 8 His dominion shal be also from the one sea to the other : and from the flood unto the worlds ende.
Manx: 8. Bíi y réelsyn níist vei yn argey gys fargey elle : as vei yn twylly gys kian yn týyl.

English: 9 They that dwell in the wildernesse shall kneele before him : his enemies shall licke the dust.
Manx: 9. Níi áydsyn ta vaghey ayns yn aysnyght sliaghty réefsyn : líi y nóidjyn yn ẃeir.

English: 10 The Kings of Tharsis and of the Iles shall give presents : the Kings of Arabia and Saba shall bring gifts.
Manx: 10. Ver ríiaghyn ’Harsys as nyn Ellanyn giwtyn : ver riaghyn Arabia as Saba owrelyn.

English: 11 All Kings shall fall downe before him : all nations shall doe him service.
Manx: 11. Twitchi gygh wlly ríi shíis na ienyssyn : nii gygh wlly atiẃyn shyrvéès dasyn.

English: 12 For he shal deliver the poore when he crieth : the needie also, and him that hath no helper.
Manx: 12. Erson lifréi e yn boght nar tê gémagh : yn fer ymmyrtsagh níist, as eshyn nagh vel fer kwney erbí agge.

English: 13 He shall bee favourable to the simple and needie : and shall preserve the soules of the poore.
Manx: 13. Bii é foróil dyn sly̌ei gyn loght as ymmyrtsagh : as friali e anmyniyn ny moght.

English: 14 He shall deliver their soules from falshood and wrong : and deare shall their blood be in his sight.
Manx: 14. Lifréi é nan anmyniyn vei falsyght as agáyr : as bíi nan vwil dyar ayns y hilliy.

English: 15 He shall live, and unto him shall be given of the gold of Arabia : prayer shall be made ever unto him, and dayly shall he be praised.
Manx: 15. Bíi e bíò, as dásyn víis erna hoyrt dy áyr Arabia : bii paidjer erna ianw gybragh dâsyn, as gygh lá viis eshyn erna volly.

English: 16 There shall bee an heape of corne in the earth, high upon the hils : his fruit shall shake like Libanus, and shall bee greene in the Citie, like grasse upon the earth.
Manx: 16. Bíi dash d’ ařrw ayns y talw, ayrd er ny knwick : níi y veass krá mar Libanys, as bii e úỳne[150] ayns yn ayrd valley, mar féyr er y talw.

English: 17 His Name shall endure for ever; his Name shall remaine under the Sunne among the posterities : which shall be blessed through him; and all the heathen shall praise him.
Manx: 17. Níi y ’enym farraghtyn erson gybrágh, bíi y enym er mayrn fẃo yn grían masky ny shiloghyn : víis er nan managhy tréyfd-syn, as níi wlly ny hangristíin eshyn y volly.

English: 18 Blessed bee the Lord God, even the God of Israel : which onely doeth wonderous things;
Manx: 18. Baníit gy row yn Chiarn Jíh, [gy jarw Jih] Eisrael : ta nolymarkan janw redyn ientysagh.

English: 19 And blessed be the Name of his Majestie for ever : and all the earth shall be filled with his Majestie. Amen, Amen.
Manx: 19. As baníit gy row enym y ardýesly erson gybragh : as bíi yn talw wlly erna liény rish y ayrd yesly. Amen, Amen.

English: The xiiii. day.
Manx: Yn xiiii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Quàm bonus Israel. Psal. 73.
Manx: Quam bonus Israel. psal. 73

English: Truely God is loving unto Israel : even unto such as are of a cleane heart.
Manx: 1. Gy jarw ta Jih grayiẃyl dy Eisrael : gy jarw dy leid as ta [dy] ghri glan.

English: 2 Neverthelesse, my feete were almost gone : my treadings had welnigh slipt.
Manx: 2. Na iêi va my ghassyn fag̀gys er shiŵl : va my ghasmedjyn er gere dy skyrraghtyn.
skyrraghtyn] ms. kyrraghtyn

English: 3 And why? I was grieved at the wicked : I doe also see the ungodly in such prosperitie.
Manx: 3. As kamma? Va mi jwmẃygh rish yn drogh lyěi : híym níist yn niawghráwi ayns léid y rǎh.

English: 4 For they are in no perill of death : but are lustie and strong.
Manx: 4. Erson gha vel áyd ayns gaw erbí dy váys : agh t’ áyd reagh as láidjer.

English: 5 They come in no misfortune like other folke : neither are they plagued like other men.
Manx: 5. Gha vell áyd chíit ayns drogh ghonagh[151] erbí mar sly̌ei elle : ghamw t’ áyd phlogit kassly-rish deney elle.

English: 6 And this is the cause that they be so holden with pride : and overwhelmed with crueltie.
Manx: 6. As she shó yn óyr gy vel áyd marshen er ’an gwmmel rish mǒyrn : as er nan dilge harrish rish díèwlys.

English: be so holden] 1662 are so holden
7 Their eies swel with fatnes : & they do even what they lust.
Manx: 7. Ta nan sẃìlyn gàtt rish rífrid : as t’ ayd janw gy jarw na salǐeu.

English: 8 They corrupt other, and speake of wicked blasphemie : their talking is against the most highest.
Manx: 8. T’ áyd milliy sly̌ei elle, as loyrt dy haglw molaghtóil : ta nan daglw nyoi yn ýrje smẃ;

English: most highest] 1662 most High
9 For they stretch foorth their mouth unto the heaven : and their tongue goeth through the world.
Manx: 9. Erson t’ áyd shíny magh nan méal gys neaw : as ta nan jange dol treyfd yn týyl.

English: 10 Therefore fall the people unto them : and thereout sucke they no small advantage.
Manx: 10. Shennyfá ta yn sly̌ei twitchym hwcksyn : as magh ass shen ghanii beggan kosny t’ ayd dy ióyl.

English: 11 Tush (say they) how should God perceive it : is there knowledge in the most highest?
Manx: 11. Twish, t’ aydsyn grá, kyns odagh Jih enaghtyn e : vel fysseri ayns yn’ ýrje smẃ?

English: most Highest] 1662 most High
12 Lo, these are the ungodly, these prosper in the world, and these have riches in possession : & I said, Then have I cleansed my heart in vaine, and washed mine hands in innocencie.
Manx: 12. Jeagh, she sho yn niawghrawi, t’ áyd shó doll er nan doshagh ayns y týyl, as ta berchys ack sho ayns kwmmel : as dẃyrt mi, éish ta mi [er] glanny my ghri ayns fardáil, as er ní my lawyn ayns glenẏd.

English: 13 All the day long have I bene punished : and chastened every morning.
Manx: 13. Fei yn lá liáur va mi er my gheraghy : as er my ghwsky dygh yn voghre.

English: 14 Yea, and I had almost said even as they : but loe, then should I have condemned the generation of thy children.
Manx: 14. Gy jarw, va mi fagys er’ rá, gy jarw mar áyd : agh jeagh, éis véìn ern’ ýre[152] shilógh dy ghlaẃnys.

English: then should I] 1662 then I should
15 Then thought I to understand this : but it was too hard of me,
Manx: 15. Eish smwni mi dy hwigel shó : agh ve róo ghřei dow,

English: hard of me] 1599, 1636, 1660 hard for me
16 Untill I went into the Sanctuarie of God : then understood I the end of these men;
Manx: 16. Naggedere ghái mi gys ynyd ghasserick Iih : eish hwig mi jere ny néne shó:

English: 17 Namely how thou doest set them in slipperie places : and castest them downe, and destroyest them.
Manx: 17. Gy vel us d’ an seiaghy-syn ayns ynydyn sliawn : as d’ an dilge shíis, as d’ an strẃiel-syn.

English: 18 Oh how suddenly doe they consume : perish, and come to a fearefull end!
Manx: 18. O gho doltattym as t’ ayd lýei : kéyf, as chíit gys jere aglagh!

English: 19 Yea, even like as a dreame when one awaketh : so shalt thou make their image to vanish out of the Citie.
Manx: 19. She, gy jarw kasly-rish brynládi mar ta anáyn dwysky : marshen ver us er ’an jalw kéyf magh as yn árd-valley.

English: 20 Thus my heart was grieved : and it went even through my reines.
Manx: 20. Shó mar va my ghrí trwm : as ghai e gy jarw tréyfd m’ áraghyn.

English: 21 So foolish was I and ignorant : even as it were a beast before thee.
Manx: 21. Ghó ammyjagh shen va mish as gyn twisky : gy jarw mar veagh e béagh t’ eanishus.
t’ eanishus] ms. t’ e enish us

English: 22 Neverthelesse, I am alway by thee : for thou hast holden me by my right hand.
Manx: 22. Na iêi, ta mi gygh iérish líòrts : erson ta us [er] my ghwmmel rish my law iesh.

English: 23 Thou shalt guide me with thy counsaile : and after that receive me with glory.
Manx: 23. Níi us mish y lídjél rish tdy ghowrley : as ná ýre shen, gowyt w mish rish tdy glóyr.

English: 24 Whom have I in heaven but thee : and there is none upon earth that I desire in comparison of thee.
Manx: 24. Quei ta áỳm ayns neaw agh us ? as gha vel anáyn er y talw ta mi dy hyrre shaǧhyds.

English: 25 My flesh and my heart faileth : but God is the strength of my heart, and my portion for ever.
Manx: 25. Ta m’ éyl as my ghrí toyrt nárdy : agh shé Jih gniart my ghri, as my árn erson gybragh.

English: 26 For loe, they that forsake thee shall perish : thou hast destroyed all them that commit fornication against thee.
Manx: 26. Erson jeagh, bi aydsyn ta dy hregáyls er nan gwrr mow : ta us er nan strẃiel-syn wlly ta janw mardrys t’ yeis.

English: 27 But it is good for me to holde mee fast by God, to put my trust in the Lord God : and to speake of all thy works (in the gates of the daughter of Sion.)
Manx: 27. Agh té méi dẃỳs dy my ghwmmel sićkyr liórish Iíh, dy hoyrt my hreistéel ayns yn Chiarn Jíh : as dy lóyrt dy wlly t’ obraghyns ayns dorsyn iníin Heion.

English: Vt quid Deus. Psal. 74.
Manx: Vt quid deus. psal. 74.

English: O God, wherefore art thou absent from us so long : why is thy wrath so hote against the sheepe of thy pasture?
Manx: 1. O Iih, kamma [vel] us as y ráyd voníỳn ghówd : kamma vel tdy iẃmẃiys gho ché nýoi kirri dy tdy phastyr?

English: 2 O thinke upon thy Congregation : whom thou hast purchased and redeemed of old.
Manx: 2. O smwni er t’ aglys : ta us erna ghosny, as erna ghianaghy ríist ada yn chenn ierish.

English: 3 Thinke upon the tribe of thine inheritance : and mount Sion wherein thou hast dwelt.
Manx: 3. Smwni er kǐyny t’ éirys : as knock Séion, ayns ren ẃ vaghey.

English: 4 Lift up thy feet, that thou maiest utterly destroy every enemie : which hath done evill in thy Sanctuary.
Manx: 4. Trog shúas tdy ghassyn, gy vod us y strwiel gy glan gygh wlly noidj : ta erna ianw olk ayns t’ ynyd kasserick.

English: 5 Thine adversaries roar in the middes of thy Congregations : and set up their banners for tokens.
Manx: 5. Ta tdy nóidjyn bwriẃght ayns méyn t’ aglishyn : as toyrt shúas nan merjaghyn[153] ghon kowraghyn.

English: 6 Hee that hewed timber afore out of the thicke trees : was knowen to bring it to an excellent worke.
Manx: 6. Éshyn iár feig[154] rói magh as ny bilchyn chiw : ve er fyss dy hoyrt e gys obyr ýasyl.

English: 7 But now they breake downe all the carved worke thereof : with axes and hammers.
Manx: 7. Agh nish t’ ayd brishie shíis ny obraghyn wlly granit : rish téigyn as ordyn.

English: 8 They have set fire upon thy Holy places : and have defiled the dwelling place of thy Name, even unto the ground.
Manx: 8. T’ ayd er dóyrt aínil er t’ ynydyns kasserick : as t’ áyd er salghy ynyd vaghey t’ enyms, gy jarw gys y talw.

English: 9 Yea, they said in their hearts, Let us make havocke of them altogether : thus have they burnt up all the houses of God in the land.
Manx: 9. Gy jarw, dẃyrt áyd ayns nan griághyn, lig win aydsyn y strwiel wlly kwjaght : sho mar t’ ayd er losky shúas wlly têiyn [Iih] ayns y talw.
ayns y talw] ms. ayn y talw

English: 10 We see not our tokens, there is not one Prophet more : no, not one is there among us, that understandeth any more.
Manx: 10. Gha vaick meid nan goraghyn; gha vel yn ’ádéyr smw : ghá vell anáyn nan masky ta twigel áragh.

English: 11 O God, how long shal the adversary do this dishonour : how long shall the enemie blaspheme thy Name for ever?
Manx: 11. O Iíh, káid níi yn ferr ta nýoi shwin yn niawonyr sho : káid níi yn nóid lóyrt gy molaghtagh dy t’ enyms gybragh?
dy] ms. tdy

English: 12 Why withdrawest thou thy hand : why pluckest not thou thy right hand out of thy bosome to consume the enemie?
Manx: 12. Kamma vel us tayrn er shiul tdy láw : kamma nagh vel us y hayrn tdy láw iesh magh [ass] t’ oghrish dy ghwr mow y nóid?

English: pluckest not thou] 1662 pluckest thou not
13 For God is my King of olde : the helpe that is done upon earth, he doeth it himselfe.
Manx: 13. Erson she Jíh my ríi ada yn chenn iérish : yn kwney ta jant er y talw, t’ e dy ianw e heyn.

English: 14 Thou diddest divide the sea through thy power : thou brakest the heads of the Dragons in the waters.
Manx: 14. Réyn us yn argey tréyfd tdy phweyr : vrish w kíinn ny nrágonyn ayns ny hwiskaghyn.

English: 15 Thou smotest the heads of Leviathan in pieces: and gavest him to be meat for the people in the wildernesse.
Manx: 15. Vǒayl ẃ kíinn yn Leviathan ayns stwćkanyn : as hwgg ẃ é dy ve bíi d’ yn phobyl ayns yn ’aýsyght.

English: 16 Thou broughtest out fountaines and waters out of the hard rocks : thou driedst up mighty waters.
Manx: 16. Hwgg us magh chibbwrtyn as ẃyskaghyn as ny kregyn kryoi : hyrmi us shuas ẃyskaghyn gniártoil.

English: 17 The day is thine, and the night is thine : thou hast prepared the light and the Sunne.
Manx: 17. Sh’ lǎts yn lá, as sh’ lǎts yn ýi : tow ern ianw arlw yn soilshe as yn grían.

English: 18 Thou hast set all the borders of the earth : thou hast made Summer and Winter.
Manx: 18. Tóẁ er seiaghy kaglaghyn wlly yn talẃin : tow ern’ ianw sóẁry as geifry.

English: 19 Remember this, O Lord, how the enemie hath rebuked : and how the foolish people hath blasphemed thy Name.
Manx: 19. Kwini er shó, O Hiarn, kyns ta yn nóid er nayraghy : as kyns ta yn slyei ammyjagh er lóyrt gy molaghtagh dy t’ enyms.
dy] ms. tdy

English: 20 O deliver not the soule of thy Turtle Dove unto the multitude of the enemies : and forget not the Congregation of the poore for ever.
Manx: 20. O na lifrée anym dy ghalmáyn míin gys ymmydi ny nóidjyn : as na jarwd shessaght yn voght erson gebrágh.

English: 21 Looke upon the Covenant : for all the earth is full of darkenesse and cruell habitations.
Manx: 21. Jéagh er yn ghẃnaynt : er son ta yn talw wlly láyn dy gorghy̌s as ynydyn vaghey diěwil.

English: 22 Oh let not the simple goe away ashamed : but let the poore and needy give praise unto thy Name.
Manx: 22. O na ligg d’ yn dwyne gyn loght doll er shíul naríit : agh ligg e yn boght as ymmyrtsagh t’ ényms y volley.

English: 23 Arise, O God, maintaine thine owne cause : remember how the foolish man blasphemeth thee dayly.
Manx: 23. Irri, O Iíh; kwmm shúas tdy ghẃish héyn : kẃini kyns ta yn dwyne ammyjagh loyrt gy mólaghtagh jids gygh lá.

English: 24 Forget not the voice of thine enemies : the presumption of them that hate thee, increaseth ever more and more.
Manx: 24. Na jarẃd korá dy tdy nóidjyn : ta yn danys mórniagh ǎcksyn ta dwói ack oyrts, gáas gybragh nasmẃ as nasmẃ.
tdy nóidjyn] ms. t’ nóidjyn

English: The xv. day.
Manx: Yn xv. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Confitebimur tibi. Psal. 75.
Manx: Confitebimur tibi. psal. 75.

English: Unto thee, O God, do we give thankes : yea, unto thee doe we give thanks.
Manx: 1. Dẃìtch, O Iíh, ta shwin toyrt bwias : gy jarw, dẃìtch ta shwin toyrt bwias.

English: 2 Thy Name also is so nigh : and that do thy wonderous works declare.
Manx: 2. Ta t’ enym níist ghó fagys : as shen ta t’ obraghyn iéntysagh y insh.

English: 3 When I receive the Congregation : I shall judge according unto right.
Manx: 3. Nar goym yn shessaght : verrym brwinys nýre káyr.

English: 4 The earth is weake, and all the inhabiters thereof : I beare up the pillars of it.
Manx: 4. Ta yn talw anẃn, as aydsyn wlly ta vaghey ayn : ta mi kẃmmell shúas ny gowlyn[156] agge.

English: 5 I said unto the fooles, Deale not so madly : and to the ungodly, Set not up your horne.
Manx: 5. Dẃyrt mi rish ny hammydanyn, na jeanji gho kýei : as rish yn niawghráwi, na seigi shúas nan erick.

English: 6 Set not up your horne on high : and speake not with a stiffe necke.
Manx: 6. Na seigi shúas nan erick er eýrdje : as na lóyrigi rish mwynal krýei.

English: 7 For promotion commeth neither from the East, nor from the West : nor yet from the South.
Manx: 7. Erson gha nel ýasly chíit vei yn gniarr, na vei yn gniér : na fóyst vei yn jass.

English: 8 And why? God is the Judge : he putteth downe one, and setteth up another.
Manx: 8. As kamma? she Jíh yn briw̌ : ta kwrr shíis anáyn, as seiaghy shúas anàn elle.

English: 9 For in the hand of the Lord there is a cup, and the wine is red : it is full mixt, and he powreth out the same.
Manx: 9. Erson ta kappan ayns láw yn Chiarn, as ta yn phiyn jarg : t’ e láyn maskit, as t’ é dýart é magh jé-shen.

English: out the same 1599, 1605] out of the same 1581, 1636, 1660
10 As for the dregs thereof : all the ungodly of the earth shall drinke them, and sucke them out.
Manx: 10. As erson yn lái[157] agge : ívi wlly yn niawghrawi d’ yn talw áyd, as jowli ayd magh.

English: 11 But I will talke of the God of Jacob : and praise him for ever.
Manx: 11. Agh lóyrym dy Iíh Iakob : as mollym e erson gybrágh.

English: 12 All the hornes of the ungodly also will I breake : and the horns of the righteous shall be exalted.
Manx: 12. Brishiym wlly eírkyn yn niawghráwi níist : as bíi éirkyn yn kly̆ei gháy̌ragh er nan drogel.

English: Notus in Iudæa. Psal. 76.
Manx: Notus in Judéa. psal. 76.

English: In Jury is God knowen : his Name is great in Israel.
Manx: 1. Ayns Juda ta enn er Jih : ta y enym mẃar ayns Eisrael.

English: 2 At Salem is his tabernacle : and his dwelling in Sion.
Manx: 2. Agg Salem ta y ghaban aglish : as y vaghey ayns Seion.

English: 3 There brake hee the arrowes of the bow : the shield, the sword and the battaile.
Manx: 3. Aynshen vrish e seijyn yn voẃ : yn skéy, yn kléiw, as yn kagey.

English: 4 Thou art of more honour and might : then the hilles of the robbers.
Manx: 4. Ta us dy oneyr smw as gniart : na knwick ny rwyskyderyn.

English: 5 The proud are robbed, they have slept their sleepe : and all the men whose hands were mighty, have found nothing.
Manx: 5. Ta yn sly̌ei morniagh er nan rwysky, t’ áyd er gadly ’an gadly : as gha dẃèyr wlly ny déney va ny lawyn ǎćk gniártoil vegg.

English: 6 At thy rebuke, O God of Jacob : both the charet and horse are fallen.
Manx: 6. Ag t’ aghsan, O Iíh Iacob : ta yn chiared as yn kabyl er dwittym níist.

English: 7 Thou, even thou art to bee feared : and who may stand in thy sight when thou art angrie?
Manx: 7. Us, gy jarw us ta agyl dy ve erna góyl rôyds : as quei odys shassw ayns tdy hilliys nar tow korri?

English: 8 Thou diddest cause thy Judgement to bee heard from heaven : the earth trembled, and was still;
Manx: 8. Hwgg us er tdy vrwinys dy ve erna ghlastchen vei néàw : ren yn talw krá as v’ é kíẁn;

English: 9 When God arose to judgement : and to helpe all the meeke upon earth.
Manx: 9. Nar jirri Jíh gys brẃinys : as dy ghẃney lesh wlly yn slyei míin er y talw.

English: 10 The fiercenesse of man shal turne to thy praise : and the fiercenesse of them shalt thou refraine.
Manx: 10. Bii kýeidj gwney erna hyndá gys tdy vollys : as kwmmyt us er gẃl yn kýeidj acksyn.

English: 11 Promise unto the Lord your God, and keepe it, all yee that be round about him : bring presents unto him that ought to be feared.
Manx: 11. Gialligi d’ yn Chiarn nan Iíh, as frialigi e, wlly shiusse ta krẃnn magíỳrt ymmish : kwrrigi toyrtyssyn hwggesyn leshaght agyl ve erna góyl róì.

English: be round] 1662 are round
12 He shall refraine the spirit of princes : and is wonderfull among the Kings of the earth.
Manx: 12. Kwmmi eshyn shíis spyryd riaghyn : as t’ é ientysagh masky riaghyn yn talw.

English: Voce mea ad Dominum. Psal. 77.
Manx: Voce mea ad Dominum. psal. 77.

English: I will cry unto God with my voyce : even unto God will I cry with my voyce, and he shall hearken unto me.
Manx: 1. Éìm gys Jíh rish my ghorá : gy jarw gys Jíh éìym rish my ghorá, as klasti e rẃỳms.

English: 2 In the time of my trouble I sought the Lord : my sore ranne and ceased not, in the night-season my soule refused comfort.
Manx: 2. Ayns ierish my hýaghyn heir mi yn Chiarn : ren my hínn rýei as gha gow e fée; er léash yíi dob m’ anym gyrjaghy.

English: 3 When I am in heavinesse, I will thinke upon God: when my heart is vexed, I will complaine.
Manx: 3. Nar ta mi ayns trimshey, smwniym er Jíh : nar ta my ghrí ayns syaghyn, niym akkann.

English: 4 Thou holdest mine eyes waking : I am so feeble that I cannot speake.
Manx: 4. Tow kwmmel my hẃilyn dwýsk : ta mi gho anẃn nagh vodym lóyrt.

English: 5 I have considered the dayes of old : and the yeeres that are past.
Manx: 5. Smẃni mi er lághyn yn chenn iérish : as ny bléyňchyn ta ern’ ’oll shaghey.

English: 6 I call to remembrance my song : and in the night I commune with mine owne heart, and search out my spirits.
Manx: 6. Ta mi gémaght gys kwinaghtyn my oráyn : as ayns yn ýì ta mi taglw rish my ghri héyn, as shyrre magh my spyrydyn.

English: 7 Will the Lord absent himselfe for ever : and will he be no more intreated?
Manx: 7. Gwmm yn Chiarn e héyn as y ráyd erson gybrágh : as nagh bíi e erna hóyrt magiyrt áragh?

English: 8 Is his mercie cleane gone for ever : and is his promise come utterly to an end for evermore?
Manx: 8. Vell y vyghin er shiul glan erson gybragh : as y ’ialtyn er jít glan gys kian erson gybrágh?

English: 9 Hath God forgotten to be gracious : and wil he shut up his loving kindenesse in displeasure?
Manx: 9. Vel Jíh ern’ iarẃd dy ve grasóil : as jéig e shúas y gheindylys graygoil ayns jumwiys?

English: 10 And I said, It is mine owne infirmitie : but I wil remember the yeeres of the right hand of the most Highest.
Manx: 10. As dẃyrt mi, she m’ ěnẃnid héyn e : agh kẃiníỳm er bleynchyn law iesh yn ýrje smẃ.

English: 11 I will remember the workes of the Lord : and call to minde thy wonders of old time.
Manx: 11. Kwiniym er obraghyn yn Chiarn : as smẃiniym er ientyssyn yn chenn amser.[158]

English: 12 I will thinke also of all thy workes : and my talking shall be of thy doings.
Manx: 12. Smwiniym níist er wlly t’ obbraghyns : as bíi my haglw dy tdy ianws.

English: 13 Thy way, O God, is holy : who is so great a God (as our God?)
Manx: 13. Ta dy ráyd, O Íih, kasserick : quei ta na Iih gho mẃar as yn Jíh áìniyn?
na Iih] ms. na Jih

English: 14 Thou art the God that doeth wonders : and hast declared thy power among the people.
Manx: 14. She us yn Jíh ta janw iéntyssyn : as tow ern’ iaghyn tdy phwer masky yn sly̌ei.

English: 15 Thou hast mightily delivered thy people : even the sonnes of Jacob and Joseph.
Manx: 15. Tow gy gniartoil er lifrée tdy phobyl : gy jarw meck Iacob as Ióseph.
Tow gy] ms. Tow er

English: 16 The waters saw thee, O God, the waters saw thee, and were afraid : the depths also were troubled.
Manx: 16. Ghonick ny hwiskaghyn us, O Iíh, ghonick ny hwiskaghyn us, as v’ áyd aglagh : va ny hynydyn down níist er ’an sěyi.

English: 17 The cloudes powred out water, the aire thundered : and thine arrowes went abroad.
Manx: 17. Gýyrt ny bojelyn magh ẃysky, ren yn áyr tarnaghy : as ghái tdy heyjyn er liéd.[159]
tarnaghy] ms. t’arnaghy

English: 18 The voyce of thy thunder was heard round about : the lightnings shone upon the ground; the earth was mooved, and shooke withall.
Manx: 18. Va korá dy tdy harniagh erna ghlastchen krwnn magiyrt : ren ny háinilyn tarniagh soilshen er y talw; va yn talw erna glýasaght, as ghrai e níist.

English: 19 Thy way is in the sea, and thy pathes in the great waters : and thy footsteps are not knowen.
Manx: 19. Ta tdy ráyd ayns yn ’argey, as tdy ghassanyn ayns ny hwiskaghyn mẃary : as gha vel fyss er kasmedjyn dy ghossey.

English: 20 Thou leddest thy people like sheepe : by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
Manx: 20. Líid us tdy phobyl kasly-rish kirri : rish law Moises as Aáron.

English: The xv. day.
Manx: Yn xv. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Attendite popule. Psal. 78.
Manx: Attendite popule. psal. 78.

English: Heare my law, O my people : encline your eares unto the words of my mouth.
Manx: 1. Klastigi rish my lýey, O my phobyl : krwmmigi nan glýassyn gys góyn my veal.

English: 2 I will open my mouth in a parable : I will declare hard sentences of old;
Manx: 2. Fóskylym my véal ayns korá dorghy : íinshiym glayr kréi d’ yn chen iérish.

English: 3 Which wee have heard and knowen : and such as our fathers have told us;
Manx: 3. Ta shwin erna ghlastchen as bawn dwin : as leid ass jinsh nan áeraghyn dwin;

English: 4 That we should not hide them from the children of the generations to come : but to shewe the honour of the Lord, his mightie and wonderfull workes that he hath done.
Manx: 4. Nagh valliygh shwin áyd věi klawn yn shilógh ta ra híit : agh dy iaghyn onéyr yn Chiarn, y obraghyn gniártoil as ientyssagh ta eshyn erna ianw.

English: 5 Hee made a covenant with Jacob, and gave Israel a Law : which he commaunded our forefathers to teach their children;
Manx: 5. Ren e kwnáynt rish Iákob, as hwgg e lýei dy Eisrael : ren é háyre dy nan shan áeryn dy ynsaghy nan glawn;
Ren e] ms. Ren y

English: 6 That their posteritie might know it : and the children which were yet unborne;
Manx: 6. Gy voddagh fyss vé ag nan shilógh err : as yn ghlawn va foyst gyn vre.

English: 7 To the intent that when they came up : they might shew their children the same;
Manx: 7. Erson nar horragh ayd shúas : gy voddagh áyd y iaghyn dy nan glawn é;
nar] ms. na; glawn] ms. ghlawn

English: 8 That they might put their trust in God : and not to forget the workes of God, but to keepe his Commandements;
Manx: 8. Gy vodagh áyd nan dreistéel y hóyrt ayns Jíh : as gyn obraghyn Iíh y iarwd, agh dy ríall y abertsyn;

English: 9 And not to be as their forefathers, a faithlesse and stubburne generation : a generation that set not their heart aright, and whose spirit cleaveth not stedfastly unto God;
Manx: 9. As gyn ve mar nan shan áeraghyn, shilógh niaw ghredjoil as mi ammysagh : shilógh nagh vel seiaghe nan gri gy káyr, as nagh vell yn spyryd lientyn gy sickyr gys Jih.

English: 10 Like as the children of Ephraim : which being harnessed, and carrying bows, turned themselves backe in the day of battaile.
Manx: 10. Kasly rish klawn Ephraim : vá éjit[160] as gymmarky bowghyn, hyndá áyd héyn góyr ’an ’rommey ayns lá yn ghagi.

English: which being] 1662 who being
Manx: gymmarky bowghyn] ms. bowghyn gymmarky

English: 11 They kept not the Covenant of God : and would not walk in his Law;
Manx: 11. Ghá drial áyd kẃnaynt Iíh : as gha balliêu gymmiaght ayns y lýei-syn;

English: 12 But forgate what hee had done : and the wonderfull worke that he had shewed for them.
Manx: 12. Agh iarwd áyd shen ren é : as yn obyr ientyssagh ren e y iaghyn er nan-son-syn.

English: worke] 1662 works
13 Marveilous things did hee in the sight of our forefathers, in the land of Egypt : even in the field of Zoan.
Manx: 13. Redyn ientyssagh ren e ayns shilliy nan shan aeraghyn ayns tallw Egipt : gy jarw ayns maghyr Zoan.

English: 14 He divided the sea, and let them goe through : he made the waters to stand on an heape.
Manx: 14. Réyng e yn fargey, as ligg e daw doll tréyfd : hwgg e er ny hwiskaghyn shassw shúas ayns tòrr.
ligg e] ms. ligge e

English: 15 In the day time also hee led them with a cloud : and all the night through with a light of fire.
Manx: 15. Ayns yn lá níist líid e ayd rish bojal : as fwy̌d ny hy̌i tryefd rish soilshe áinil.

English: 16 He clave the hard rocks in the wildernesse : and gave them drinke thereof, as it had bene out of the great depth.
Manx: 16. Skáilt e ny kregyn krýoi ayns yn ’ásyght : as hwgg e jogh daw iê shen, mar veagh é magh as yn dyfnid vẃar.

English: 17 Hee brought waters out of the stonie rocke : so that it gushed out like the Rivers.
Manx: 17. Hwgg e wiskaghyn magh as yn ghregg ghlaghi : marshen gy vrish e magh mar strẃányn.

English: 18 Yet for all this they sinned more against him : and provoked the most Highest in the wildernesse.
Manx: 18. Fóyst er y hon-shó wlly ren ayd twlliw pecky na yoi-syn : as vrosni áyd yn yrje smw ayns yn ’aysyght.

English: 19 They tempted God in their hearts : and required meat for their lust.
Manx: 19. Vióẁli áyd Jíh ayns nan gríaghyn : as héyr ayd bí ghon nan agney.

English: 20 They spake against God also, saying : Shall God prepare a table in the Wildernesse?
Manx: 20. Loyr ayd nyoi Jíh níist, grá : jean Jíh bord arlw ayns yn aysyght?

English: 21 He smote the stonie rock in deed, that the waters gushed out, and the streames flowed withall : but can hee give bread also, or provide flesh for his people?
Manx: 21. Voil e yn ghrèg ghlagh gy jarw, gy rýi yn wisky magh, as ren yn strw lieny harrish : agh vod e aran y hóyrt níist, na feyl y ianw arlw ghon y phobyl?

English: 22 When the Lord heard this, hee was wroth : so the fire was kindled in Jacob, and there came up heavie displeasure against Israel;
Manx: 22. Nar ghýyl yn Chiarn sho, v’ é korri : marshen va yn ainill erna addy ayns Jakob, as haink jumwiys hroym shúas nyoi Eisrael;

English: 23 Because they beleeved not in God : and put not their trust in his helpe.
Manx: 23. Erson nagh ghred ayd ayns Jíh : as nagh dwgg ayd nan dreistýyl ayns y ghwne-syn.

English: 24 So he commanded the cloudes above : and opened the doores of heaven.
Manx: 24. Marshen hwgg e sayry dy ny bojelyn húas : as doskyl e dorryssyn neaw.

English: 25 He rained downe Manna also upon them for to eate : and gave them food from heaven.
Manx: 25. Ren e flaghe manna núas oriusyn níist ghon dy íi : as hwgg e dáẁ bíi vei néaw.

English: 26 So man did eate Angels food : for hee sent them meate ynough.
Manx: 26. Marshen jí dwyne bii ainilyn : erson hwgg é hwck bíi gyllior.

English: 27 He caused the East wind to blow under heaven : and through his power he brought in the South west winde.
Manx: 27. Hwgg e er yn gye niar séje fwo néaw : as tréyd y phẃer hwgg e schiagh yn gyé niér ’ass.

English: 28 He rained flesh upon them as thicke as dust : and feathered foules like as the sand of the sea.
Manx: 28. Ren e flaghe féyl oríùsyn gho chiw as ẃir : as éynli fejaghagh kasly rish génagh ny fargey.

English: 29 He let it fall among their tents : even round about their habitation.
Manx: 29. Ligg e da twitchym masky nan gabbanyn : krwn magiyrt nan ynyd vâghe.

English: 30 So they did eate and were wel filled, for he gave them their owne desire : they were not disappointed of their lust.
Manx: 30. Marshen jí áyd, as v’ ayd liynt galliór, erson hwgg e daw nan agney héyn : gha row ayd er nan gwrr shaghy nan agney.

English: 31 But while the meat was yet in their mouthes, the heavy wrath of God came upon them, & slue the wealthiest of them : yea, and smote downe the chosen men that were in Israel.
Manx: 31. Agh ghowd as va yn bíi ayns nan meal, haink korri hromm Iíh ořrw, as varŕ e ny déne by verchi jû : gy jarw, as voall é shíis ny déney ry̌it va ayns Eisrael.

English: 32 But for all this they sinned yet more : and beleeved not his wonderous workes.
Manx: 32. Agh er y hon sho wlly, ren áyd twlliw peky fóost : as gha ghred áyd ny obraghyn iéntyssagh aggesyn.

English: 33 Therefore their dayes did he consume in vanitie: and their yeeres in trouble.
Manx: 33. Shennyfá ghéyf e nan lághyn ayns fardalys : as nan mléinchyn ayns sýaghyn.

English: 34 When he slew them, they sought him : and turned them early, and enquired after God.
Manx: 34. Nar varrw e áyd, hyrr áyd é : as hyndá áyd gy moghey, as hýrr ayd nýre Jih.

English: 35 And they remembred that God was their strength : and that the high God was their Redeemer.
Manx: 35. As ghwini áyd gy níi e Jih va nan gniart : as gy ni e yn Jíh áyrd vá nan ferr kani ríist.
kani] ms. gani

English: 36 Neverthelesse, they did but flatter him with their mouth : and dissembled with him in their tongue.
Manx: 36. Er y hon sho wlly, gha ren áyd agh brynryght rish-syn rish nan méal : as bregyn y insh dâ rish nan jangey.

English: 37 For their heart was not whole with him : neither continued they stedfast in his Covenant.
Manx: 37. Erson gha row ’an grí slayn leshyn : ghamw dwrri ayd sickyr ayns y ghẃnayntsyn.

English: 38 But hee was so mercifull that hee forgave their misdeeds : and destroyed them not.
Manx: 38. Agh ve gho trokróil, gy lyoi e nan ’rogh ianw : as gha strwi e ayd.

English: 39 Yea many a time turned hee his wrath away : and would not suffer his whole displeasure to arise.
Manx: 39. Gy jarw, ymmydi dy ierishsyn hyndá e y ghorri er shiúl : as gha balliesh y iwmẃiys slayn dy irri.

English: 40 For he considered that they were but flesh : and that they were even a winde that passeth away, and commeth not againe.
Manx: 40. Erson ghwini e nagh row áyd agh feyl : as gy row ayd gy jarw gýa ta dol er shiúl, as nagh vell chíit ríist.

English: 41 Many a time did they provoke him in the wildernesse : and grieved him in the desert.
Manx: 41. Shymmy kiyrt grenni ayd eshyn ayns yn ’aysyght : as ren ayd eshyn troymm ayns yn ynyd pháys.
grenni] ms. gremi

English: 42 They turned backe, and tempted God : and mooved the Holy one in Israel.
Manx: 42. Hynda ayd er gẃll, as viowli ayd Jih : as vrosni áyd yn anáyn kasserick ayns Eisrael.

English: 43 They thought not of his hand : and of the day when he delivered them from the hand of the enemie;
Manx: 43. Ghá smwni áyd er y lawynsyn : as er yn lá nar lifre eshyn áyd vei law yn nóid;

English: 44 How he had wrought his miracles in Egypt : and his wonders in the field of Zoan.
Manx: 44. Kyns ren e y ghóraghyn[161] ayns Ejipt : as y iéntyssyn ayns magher Zoan.

English: 45 He turned their waters into blood : so that they might not drinke of the Rivers.
Manx: 45. Hyndá e nan wiskaghyn gys fẁill : marshen nagh vodagh ayd íif dy ny strwanyn.

English: 46 He sent lice among them, and devoured them up : and frogs to destroy them.
Manx: 46. Hwgg e mielyn nan maskysyn, as ghwrr e mow ayd shúas : as froggyn dan strwiel syn.

English: 47 He gave their fruit unto the Caterpiller : and their labour unto the Grashopper.
Manx: 47. Hwgg e nan měass d’ yn brattágan[162] : as nan ober d’ yn ghellagh renni.

English: 48 He destroyed their Vines with hailestones : and their Mulberie trees with the frost.
Manx: 48. Strwi e nan milchyn phíyn rish klaghyn snaghti : as nan milchyn mwllberi rish rió.

English: 49 He smote their cattell also with hailestones : and their flocks with hot thunderbolts.
Manx: 49. Vǒal e nan allagh níist rish klaghyn snaghtẏ : as nan sheluánan[163] rish klaghyn tarni ché.

English: 50 He cast upon them the furiousnes of his wrath, anger, displeasure, and trouble : and sent evil angels among them.
Manx: 50. Hilgg é kéiys y ghorri oriǔsyn, fárg, jumẃys, as syaghyn : as hwgg e drogh ainilyn nan maskysyn.

English: 51 Hee made a way to his indignation, & spared not their soule from death : but gave their life over to the pestilence;
Manx: 51. Ren é ráyd gys y ’arg, as gha haghni é nan anym vei báas : agh hwgg é nan me harrish d’ yn ghnàp;
haghni] ms. haghny

English: 52 And smote all the first borne in Egypt : the most principall and mightiest in the dwellings of Ham.
Manx: 52. As vǒall e wlly bý lýèi[164] ayns Ejipt : shen b’ ýrje as by gniártoil ayns ynydyn vaghey Ham.
shen] ms. shon

English: 53 But as for his owne people, hee ledde them foorth like sheepe : and caried them in the wildernesse like a flocke.
Manx: 53. Agh erson y phobyl héyn, líid é magh ayd kasly ry kirri : as jymmyrk e ayd ayns yn ’aysyght kasly rish shellíẁ.[165]

English: 54 He brought them out safely that they should not feare : and overwhelmed their enemies with the Sea.
Manx: 54. Hwgg e magh ayd gy sawchy nagh góagh áyd agyl : as vág é nan nóidjyn rish yn argey.

English: 55 And brought them within the borders of his Sanctuarie : even to his mountaine which hee purchased with his right hand.
Manx: 55. As hwgg é áyd er chew stêi dy ghadlaghyn y ynyd ghasserick : gy jarw gys y ghnocksyn ghiani e rish y law iesh.
dy ghadlaghyn] ms. y ghadlaghyn

English: 56 Hee cast out the heathen also before them : caused their land to be divided among them for an heritage, and made the tribes of Israel to dwel in their tents.
Manx: 56. Hilg é magh ny hangristíin níist nan véanishyn : hwg e er nan dallw dy ve erna réyn nan maskysyn ghon eirys, as hwgg e er shilógh Eisrael vaghey ayns nan gabanyn.

English: 57 So they tempted and displeased the most high God : and kept not his Testimonies;
Manx: 57. Marshen viowli áyd as ren ayd jwmẃygh yn Jíh smẃ syrje : as gha drial ayd y rikortyn;

English: 58 But turned their backes, and fell away like their forefathers : starting aside like a broken bow.
Manx: 58. Agh hynda áyd nan rimmyn, as hwitch áyd er shiul kasly rish nan shan aéraghyn : liěm er lietty mar bow brist.

English: 59 For they grieved him with their hill altars : and provoked him to displeasure with their images.
Manx: 59. Erson ren áyd eshyn troym rish nan alteryn knwick : as vrosni ayd eshyn gys jwmẃiys rish nan jallwnyn.

English: 60 When God heard this, he was wroth : and tooke sore displeasure at Israel.
Manx: 60. Nar ghýyl Jíh shó, v’ e korri : as gow e jwmẃiys vẃar dy Eisrael.

English: 61 So that hee forsooke the Tabernacle in Silo : even the tent that he had pitched among men.
Manx: 61. Marshen gy hréyg e yn kaban aglwish ayns Séìlo : gy jarw yn kaban ve erna héiaghy nan masky-syn.

English: 62 He delivered their power into captivitie : and their beautie into the enemies hand.
Manx: 62. Lifrée eshyn nan bẃer gys kapi : as nan móid gys law yn nóid.

English: 63 He gave his people over also unto the sword : and was wroth with his inheritance.
Manx: 63. Hwgg e [y] phobyl harrish níist gys yn ghléìw : as ve korri rish y eirys.

English: 64 The fire consumed their yong men : and their maidens were not given to mariage.
Manx: 64. Strwi yn aínil nan ’éney ágy : as gha row nan móidjynyn er nan doyrt dy phẃsey.

English: 65 Their Priestes were slaine with the sword : and there were no widowes to make lamentation.
Manx: 65. Va nan sagartyn er ’an márw rish y ghléìw : as gha row veg ny mynáyn tréogh dy ianw dobran.

English: 66 So the Lord awaked as one out of sleepe : and like a Giant refreshed with wine.
Manx: 66. Marshen ẃisk yn Chiarn mar anayn as kadly : as kasly rish fowyr erna ẃraghy ríist rish phiyn.

English: 67 He smote his enemies in the hinder parts : and put them to a perpetuall shame.
Manx: 67. Vóal e y nóidjyn ayns ny harnyn jere : as hwgg e ayd gys nayre gybragh.

English: 68 He refused the Tabernacle of Joseph : and chose not the tribe of Ephraim;
Manx: 68. Dobb e kaban aglwish Ióseph : as gha rýei e kyne Ephraim.

English: 69 But chose the tribe of Juda : even the hill of Sion, which he loved.
Manx: 69. Agh rýei e kyney Iúda : gy jarw knock Hêion bueny lesh.

English: 70 And there he builded his temple on high : & laid the foundation of it like the ground which he hath made continually.
Manx: 70. As aynshen hrogg e y hiampyl er ýrje : as hêi e yn bwnn aggy kasly rish yn tallw te erna ianw gy kínjagh.

English: 71 He chose David also his servant : and tooke him away from the sheepe folds.
Manx: 71. Rýei e David y herváynt níist : as gow e er shíul e vei boilchyn ny gyrragh;.

English: 72 As hee was following the Ewes great with yong ones, he tooke him : that he might feed Jacob his people, and Israel his inheritance.
Manx: 72. Mar v’ e géiyrt ny kirri trómm rish y̌en, gow éshyn e : gy vodagh e Jakob y phobyl y víèg, as Eisrael y eirys.

English: 73 So he fed them with a faithfull and true heart : and ruled them prudently with all his power.
Manx: 73. Marshen víèg e ayd rish kri kredjoil as firrinagh : as réel e áyd gy kriney rish y phwer wlly.

English: The xvi. day.
Manx: Yn xvi. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Deus, venerunt. Psal. 79.
Manx: Deus, venerunt. psal. 79.

English: O God, the heathen are come into thine inheritance : thy holy Temple have they defiled, and made Hierusalem an heape of stones.
Manx: 1. O Iíh, ta ny hangristínyn er jit schagh gys t’ êirys : tdy hampyls kasserick t’ áyd erna halghy, as ern’ ianw karnán klagh dy Jeriusalem.

English: 2 The dead bodies of thy servants have they given to bee meate unto the foules of the aire : and the flesh of thy Saints unto the beasts of the land.
Manx: 2. T’ áyd er doyrt kirp marrw tdy hervayntyns dy vé bíi dy eynli yn áer : as feyl dy nwghyn gys béìyn yn talẃin.
hervayntyns] ms. hervayntys

English: 3 Their blood have they shed like water on every side of Hierusalem : and there was no man to burie them.
Manx: 3. T’ ayd ern iêrty nan vwil acksyn mar ẃisky er gygh yn cheyf dy Jeriusalem : as gha row dwyne erbi d’ ǎn anlyky.

English: 4 Wee are become an open shame to our enemies : a very scorne and derision unto them that are round about us.
Manx: 4. Ta shwin er jít náyre foskylt dys nar[166] nóidjyn : gy jarw knáid as faghid dawsyn ta chimmyl magiyrt ymmw̌in.

English: 5 Lord, how long wilt thou bee angrie : shall thy jelousie burne like fire for ever?
Manx: 5. Hiarn, káid víist us korri : jean t’ etaghy[167] losky kasly rish aingil erson gybrágh?

English: 6 Powre out thine indignation upon the heathen that have not knowen thee : and upon the kingdomes that have not called upon thy Name.
Manx: 6. Dýart magh tdy ghorri er ny hangristínyn, nagh vel er dóyrt enn ǒyrts : as er ny ririoghtyn nagh jéi er t’ enyms.

English: 7 For they have devoured Jacob : and layde waste his dwelling place.
Manx: 7. Erson t’ áyd ern’ íi súas Jakob : as ern ianw yn enyd vaghey aggesyn fáys.

English: 8 O remember not our old sinnes, but have mercy upon us, and that soone : for we are come to great misery.
Manx: 8. O na kwini er nan shan pekaghyn, agh jean myghin orw̌in, as shen gy lýe : erson ta shwin er jít gys try̌ei vwar.

English: 9 Helpe us, O God of our salvation, for the glory of thy Name : O deliver us, and be merciful unto our sinnes for thy Names sake.
Manx: 9. Kwin léìnwin, O Iíh nan sawálys, erson glóyr t’ ényms : O lifré shwin, as bi trokróil dy nan bekaghyn erson grayi t’ ényms.

English: 10 Wherefore doe the heathen say : Where is now their God?
Manx: 10. Kréfa ta ny hangristín gra : kaje[168] vel yn Jih ačksyn nish?

English: 11 O let the vengeance of thy servants blood that is shed : be openly shewed upon the heathen in our sight.
Manx: 11. O ligg e kwilíny fwill dy tdy herváyntyns ta erna gyarty : vé gy foskilt erna ’akin er ny hangristíin ayns yn shilliy áìniyn.

English: 12 O let the sorowful sighing of the prisoners come before thee : according to the greatnesse of thy power preserve thou those that are appointed to die.
Manx: 12. O ligg e osny tróymm ny gimmín[169] chíit t’ énishus : nyrg módiyght[170] tdy phẃer, fríal us aydsyn ta erna ordyghey gys báys.
t’ enishus] ms. t’enish us

English: 13 And for the blasphemie wherewith our neighbors have blasphemed thee : reward thou them, O Lord, seven fold into their bosome.
Manx: 13. As erson yn ayrd volaght lesh ta nar nabẃnyn er lóyrt gy molaghtagh iíd : íik us aydsyn, O Hiarn, shaght fílliy schiagh ayns nan oghrys.

English: 14 So wee that bee thy people and sheepe of thy pasture, shall give thee thankes for ever : and will alway be shewing foorth thy praise from generation to generation.
Manx: 14. Marshen ver meid ta tdy phobyls as kirri tdy phastyr, bẃias dwitch erson gybrágh : as bíi meid gybrágh soilsaghy magh tdy volleys vei shilógh gys shilogh.

English: wee that bee] 1662 we that are
Qui regis Israel. Psal. 80.
Manx: Qui regis Israel. psal. 80.

English: Heare, O thou Shepheard of Israel, thou that leadest Joseph like a sheepe : shew thy selfe also thou that sittest upon the Cherubims.
Manx: 1. Klast, O us boghily keragh Israel, us ta liídjél Joseph kasly rish kyrry : soilshi ẃ héyn margedyn níist, us ta sei er ny cherwbynyn.

English: 2 Before Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasses : stirre up thy strength, and come, and helpe us.
Manx: 2. Féanish Ephraim, Benjamin, as Manasses : trog shúas tdy gniart, as tréyd as kẃin leniyn.

English: 3 Turne us againe, O God : shew the light of thy countenance, and we shall be whole.
Manx: 3. Chyndá shwiniyn ríst, O Iíh : jeagh soílshey t’ edyn, as bíi meid sláyn.

English: 4 O Lord God of hostes : how long wilt thou be angrie with thy people that prayeth?
Manx: 4. O Hiarn Iíh ny hói : kaid víist ẃ korri rish tdy phobyl ta goyl paidjer?

English: 5 Thou feedest them with the bread of teares : and givest them plenteousnesse of teares to drinke.
Manx: 5. Tow d’ an méyg shwin[171] rish aran dy iêyr : as tow̌ tóyrt palchey dy ióeryn dy íif.

English: 6 Thou hast made us a very strife unto our neighbours : and our enemies laugh us to scorne.
Manx: 6. T’ ow ern ianw gy jarw stryif júìniyn dy nan nabẃnyn : as ta nan noidjyn geraghti gy knaidjoil ymmŵin.
nan nabẃnyn] ms. ny nabẃnyn

English: 7 Turne us againe, thou God of hostes : shew the light of thy countenance, and we shal be whole.
Manx: 7. Chynda shwin ríist us, O Iíh dy ny hói : jeagh soilshey dy gnẃish, as bíi meid sláyn.

English: 8 Thou hast brought a Vine out of Egypt : thou hast cast out the heathen, and planted it.
Manx: 8. T’ ow er dóyrt billey phiýn as Ejipt : tow er dilge magh ny hangristinyn, as erna heiaghe é.

English: 9 Thou madest roome for it : and when it had taken root, it filled the land.
Manx: 9. Ren ẃ ynyd dá : as nar vê er góyl fréàw, lien e yn talw.

English: 10 The hils were covered with the shadow of it : and the boughes thereof were like the goodly Cedar trees.
Manx: 10. Va ny knwick er nan gwdaghy rish y ská agge : as va ny banglányn agge kasly rish ny bilchyn Cedar alyn.

English: 11 She stretched out her branches unto the Sea : and her boughes unto the river.
Manx: 11. Híin i magh y banglányn[172] gys yn argey : as y banglányn gys y trwan.
as y banglányn] ms. as y banglányn aggy

English: 12 Why hast thou then broken downe her hedge : that all they that goe by plucke off her grapes?
Manx: 12. Kamma vel us er mrishie shíis y klyei : gy vel áydsyn wlly ta doll shàghy ráby ĵi y meass?

English: 13 The wilde Bore out of the wood doeth root it up: and the wilde beasts of the field devoure it.
Manx: 13. Ta yn kollagh kýei magh as y ghéil da rowrey shúas : as ta bein kýei yn vagher dâ híi shuas.

English: 14 Turne thee againe, thou God of hostes, look down from heaven : behold, and visit this Vine;
Manx: 14. Chyndá ẃ héyn ríist, us O Iíh dy ny hói; jeagh núas vei neaw : jeagh, as kwrr mẏnier d’ yn ville phiyn shó.

English: 15 And the place of the vineyard, that thy right hand hath planted : & the branch that thou madest so strong for thy selfe.
Manx: 15. As yn ýnyd d’ yn gar phýìn ta tdy law iesh erna heiaghy : as yn bangláyn ren ẃ gho laidjer dwitt héyn.

English: 16 It is burnt with fire, and cut downe : and they shall perish at the rebuke of thy countenance.
Manx: 16. T’ e loiskt rish aínill, as giarit shíis : as héad aydsyn moẃ ag aghsyn tdy gnẃys.
giarit] ms. giarti

English: 17 Let thy hand be upon the man of thy right hand : and upon the sonne of man whom thou madest so strong for thine owne selfe.
Manx: 17. Ligg e tdy law ve er dwyne dy tdy law ièsh : as er mack dwyne tow erna ianw ghó laidjer dẃitt héyn.

English: 18 And so will not we goe backe from thee : O let us live, and we shall call upon thy Name.
Manx: 18. As shen mar nagh jed měid er gẃl void : O lig ẃìn vé bio, as ei meid er t’ enym.

English: 19 Turne us againe, O Lord God of hosts : shew the light of thy countenance, and we shall be whole.
Manx: 19. Chyndá shẃìniyn ríist, O Hiarn Jíh ny hói : jéagh soilshe t’ edyn, as bíi meid sláyn.

English: Exultate Deo. Psal. 81.
Manx: Exvltate Déo : psal. 81.

English: Sing we merily unto God our strength : make a cheereful noyse unto the God of Jacob.
Manx: 1. Ligg ’ẃìn oráyn y góyl gy gannoil gys Jíh nan gniart : jeanji kióyl gannoil gys Jíh Jakob.

English: 2 Take the Psalme, bring hither the Tabret : the merrie Harpe, with the Lute.
Manx: 2. Gowigi yn psialm,[173] kwrrigi léyf aynshó yn tabwrd : yn ghrwit ienoil, márish y ghlásagh.

English: 3 Blow up the Trumpet in the new Moone : even in the time appointed, and upon our solemne feast day.
Manx: 3. Sejigi shuas yn trwmpéỳt ayns yn iask nóo : gy jarw ayns y trá erna ordyghey, as yn lá fiely ýasyl áin.

English: 4 For this was made a statute for Israel : and a Law of the God of Jacob.
Manx: 4. Erson va shó erna ianw na slattys ghon Eisrael : as na lyóèi dy Iíh Iacob.

English: 5 This he ordained in Joseph for a testimonie : when he came out of the land of Egypt, and had heard a strange language.
Manx: 5. Ren e shó y ordyghy ayns Joseph ghon féanish : nar haink e magh as talw Ejipt, as ve er glastchen gláyr ióri.

English: 6 I eased his shoulder from the burden : and his handes were delivered from making the pots.
Manx: 6. Hwgg mi áas dâ gýalyn vei yn erry : as va y lawyn er nan lifré vei janw ny bott.

English: 7 Thou calledst upon mee in troubles, and I delivered thee : and heard thee what time as the storme fell upon thee.
Manx: 7. Jei w ořrẃms ayns sýaghyn, as lifré mi ẃ : as ghýyl mi ẃ, nar hwitt yn dorrym[174] oyrt.

English: 8 I prooved thee also : at the waters of strife.
Manx: 8. Jidyr[175] mi us magh níist : ag ny hwiskaghyn dy ymmervái.[176]
dy ymmervái] ms. ny hymmer vái

English: 9 Heare, O my people, and I wil assure thee, O Israel : if thou wilt hearken unto me,
Manx: 9. Klast, O my phobyl, as níims y ierw[177] dw̌it, O Eisrael : ma ghlastchist us rẃỳms;

English: 10 There shall no strange god bee in thee : neither shalt thou worship any other God.
Manx: 10. Gha bíi jih jori erbi aynyds : gha níi ẃ ammys dy iih erbi elle.
níi] ms. bíi níi

English: 11 I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt : open thy mouth wide, and I shal fil it.
Manx: 11. She mish yn Chiarn tdy Iíh, hwgg us magh ass talw Ejypt : foskyl tdy véal liân, as liényms é.

English: 12 But my people would not heare my voice : and Israel would not obey me.
Manx: 12. Agh ghá balliesh my phobyl my ghoráys y ghlastchen : as gha balliesh Eisrael arym y hóyrt dẃỳs.

English: 13 So I gave them up unto their owne hearts lusts: and let them follow their owne imaginations.
Manx: 13. Shennyfá hwgg mi shúas aydsyn dy agney nan griaghyn héyn : as ligg mi dâw nan smwnaghtyn héyn y eigyrt.

English: 14 O that my people would have hearkened unto mee : for if Israel had walked in my wayes,
Manx: 14. O gy béagh my phobyl er glastchen rẃỳms : erson gy béagh Eisrael ern’ immiaght ayns my rádjyns,

English: 15 I should soone have put downe their enemies : and turned my hand against their adversaries.
Manx: 15. Sh’ lyei vêinsh er doyrt shíis ny noidjyn acksyn : as er jyndá my lawyn nyéi ny dene ta nan nýoisyn.

English: 16 The haters of the Lord should have bene found lyars : but their time should have endured for ever.
Manx: 16. Veagh aydsyn ta dẃòi ack er y Chiarn er nan geadthen nan mrágeryn : agh veagh yn iérish acksyn er faraghtyn erson gybrágh.

English: 17 Hee should have fed them also with the finest wheate flowre : and with honie out of the stonie rocke should I have satisfied thee.
Manx: 17. Véagh é er nan míeg aydsyn níist rish yn flẃyr kwrnaght sklene : as véynsh er dy vẃiys rish mill as y ghregg ghloi.

English: The xvi. day.
Manx: Yn xvi. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Deus stetit. Psal. 82.
Manx: Devs stetit. psal. 82.

English: God standeth in the Congregation of princes : he is a Judge among gods.
Manx: Ta Jih shassw ayns shessaght prinsaghyn : she bríw é masky nan iíaghyn.

English: 2 How long will yee give wrong judgement : and accept the persons of the ungodly?
Manx: 2. Kaid ver shiu briwnys agáyragh : as góys shiu lesh y niawghrawi?

English: 3 Defend the poore and fatherlesse : see that such as bee in need and necessitie, have right.
Manx: 3. Frialigi yn boght as yn lianẃ gyn áer : jeaghigi gy vow aydsyn káyr ta ayns feim as ymmyrts.

English: such as bee] 1662 such as are
4 Deliver the outcast and poore : save them from the hand of the ungodly.
Manx: 4. Lifréegi eshyn ta tilgit er shiúl as boght : sáwigi áyd vei láw yn niawghrawi.

English: 5 They will not bee learned, nor understand, but walke on still in darkenesse : all the foundations of the earth be out of course.
Manx: 5. Gha n’ ’alliew ve ynsíit, na twigel, agh gimmiáght er nan dossiagh goni ayns dorghys : ta wlly bwnyn yn talw magh as [kwys].[178]

English: bee out] 1662 are out
Manx: [kwys] ms. dorghys

English: 6 I have said, Ye are gods : and ye all are children of the most Highest.
Manx: 6. Dwyrt mi, she jíaghyn shiu : as ta shiu wlly nan glawn yn yrje smẃ.

English: ye all are] 1662 ye are all the
7 But ye shall die like men : and fall like one of the princes.
Manx: 7. Agh iêw shiu báas mar déne : as twitti shiu mar anayn dy ny prynsaghyn.

English: 8 Arise, O God, and judge thou the earth : for thou shalt take all heathen to thine inheritance.
Manx: 8. Irri, O Iíh, as toyr brẃinys er y tallw : erson goẃy̌t us ny hangristínyn wlly ghon t’ eirys.

English: Deus quis similis? Psal. 83.
Manx: Devs quis similis? psal. 83.

English: Holde not thy tongue, O God, keepe not still silence : refraine not thy selfe, O God.
Manx: 1. Na kwmm tdy hange, O Iíh, na bi dy host : namw gow fée, O Iih.

English: 2 For loe, thine enemies make a murmuring : and they that hate thee, have lift up their head.
Manx: 2. Erson jeagh, ta tdy noidjyn janw jwmẃys : as ta áydsyn ta dwoi ack oyrts er drogel shýas nan gian.

English: 3 They have imagined craftily against thy people: and taken counsaile against thy secret ones.
Manx: 3. T’ ayd er smwnaghtyn gy krowtagh nyói tdy phobyls : as ern’ góyl kowrley nyoi t’ anánys fallíit.

English: 4 They have said, Come, and let us roote them out, that they bee no more a people : and that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance.
Manx: 4. Dwyrt áyd, tryedigi, as ligg win nan roawry magh, nagh bii áyd aragh nan bobyl : as nagh bii ényms Eisrael aragh ayns kwiney.

English: 5 For they have cast their heads together with one consent : and are confederate against thee;
Manx: 5. Erson t’ áyd er dilge nan ginn kwjaght rish yn agney : as ern’ góyl an gowrley t’ ýèis;

English: 6 The tabernacles of the Edomites and the Ismaelites : the Moabites and Hagarenes;
Manx: 6. Kabanyn ny Hedomeityn as ny Heismaelityn : ny Moabityn as ny Hagarenyn;

English: 7 Gebal and Ammon, and Amalech : the Philistines, with them that dwel at Tyre.
Manx: 7. Gebal, as Ammon, as Amaleck : ny Philistini, mariusyn ta vaghey ag Téìr.

English: 8 Assur also is joyned unto them : and have holpen the children of Lot.
Manx: 8. Ta Assur níist er shassw hẃcsyn : as er gwne lesh klawn Lott.

English: joyned unto] 1662 joined with
Manx: klawn] ms. klawnt

English: 9 But doe thou to them as unto the Madianites : unto Sisera, and unto Jabin, at the brooke of Kison;
Manx: 9. Agh jean ríùsyn mar rish ny Madianiti : rish Sisera, as rish Jabin ag strwan Ghison;

English: 10 Which perished at Endor : and became as the dung of the earth.
Manx: 10. Va erna strẃiel ag Endor : as haink ayd dy ve mar ýyle[179] ’yn tallw.

English: Which perished] 1662 Who perished
11 Make them and their princes like Oreb and Zeb : yea, make all their princes like as Zeba and Salmana;
Manx: 11. Jean riusyn as nan riiaghyn mar Oreb as Zheb : gy jarw jean wlly nan ríaghyn kasly rish Zheba as Salmána;

English: 12 Which say, Let us take to our selves : the houses of God in possession.
Manx: 12. Ta grá, ligg win góyl dwin heyn : téiyn Iíh ghon éirys.

English: Which say] 1662 Who say
13 O my God, make them like unto a wheele : and as the stubble before the winde;
Manx: 13. O my Iíh, jean aydsyn kasly rish quíil : as mar yn iar ghwnlygh réfs yn gýe;

English: 14 Like as the fire that burneth up the wood : and as the flame that consumeth the mountaines.
Manx: 14. Kasly rish yn áinil ta losky shyas yn ghelliy : as mar yn lossyr ta kwrr mow ny slechyn.

English: 15 Persecute them even so with thy tempest : & make them afraid with thy storme.
Manx: 15. Eigyr aydsyn gy tréan, gy jarw marshen rish tdy gorrym[180] : as jean ayd aglagh rish tdy styrrym.

English: 16 Make their faces ashamed, O Lord : that they may seeke thy Name.
Manx: 16. Jean ny hedynyn acksyn naýragh, O Hiarn : gy vod ayd t’ enym y hyrre.
naýragh] ms. aýragh

English: 17 Let them be confounded and vexed ever more & more : let them be put to shame and perish.
Manx: 17. Ligg ’aw ve er nan dóyrt gys náre as er nan syaghyn gybragh nasmẃ as nasmẃ : ligg ’aw ve er nan dort gys náyre, as er nan gwrr moẃ.

English: 18 And they shall know that thou, whose name is Jehovah : art onely the most Highest over all the earth.
Manx: 18. As bíi fyss ack gy nê us ta t’ énym Jehova : dy lymarkan yn yrje smw harrish yn tállw wlly.
gy] ms. gi

English: Quàm dilecta. Psal. 84.
Manx: Quam dilecta. psal. 84.

English: O how amiable are thy dwellings : thou Lord of hostes!
Manx: 1. O gho grayigoyl as ta t’ ynydyns vaghey : us Hiarn dy ny shessaghtyn!

English: 2 My soule hath a desire and longing to enter into the Courts of the Lord : my heart and my flesh rejoyce in the living God.
Manx: 2. Ta m’ anym shyirre as góyl fodiagh dy goll schiagh ayns kẃy̌rtyn yn Chiarn : ta my ghrí as m’ éyl goyl boge ayns y Jíh véoil.

English: 3 Yea, the sparow hath found her an house, and the swallow a nest, where she may lay her yong : even thy Altars, O Lord of hostes, my King and my God.
Manx: 3. Gy jarẃ, ta jallyn[181] er veatdhin těi jíh,[182] as yn golangei edd, yn ynyd odys i y heyn y hóyrt : gy jarw t’ altaryns, O Hiarn dy ny hói, my ríi as my Iíh.

English: 4 Blessed are they that dwell in thy house : they will bee alway praising thee.
Manx: 4. Baníit ta aydsyn ta vaghey ayns tdy hěiys : bíi áyd gybragh dy tdy vollěys.

English: 5 Blessed is the man whose strength is in thee : in whose heart are thy wayes.
Manx: 5. Baníit ta yn dwyne ta y gniart anyds : ayns y ghri ta tdy ráydjyns;

English: 6 Who going thorow the vale of misery, use it for a well : and the pooles are filled with water.
Manx: 6. Ta doll tryeid kóyn yn trýèi, ta dy ghlaghtey e ghon chibbyrt : as ta ny pwill lient rish wiskey.

English: 7 The will goe from strength to strength : and unto the God of gods appeareth every one of them in Sion.
Manx: 7. Heid áyd vei gniart gys gniart : as ta dygh anáyn acksyn dy iaghen héyn dy Iíh nyn iieghyn ayns Seion.

English: The will] 1599, 1636, etc. They will
8 O Lord God of hostes, heare my prayer : hearken, O God of Jacob.
Manx: 8. O Hiarn Iíh ny hói, klwin my phadjer : klast, O Iíh Iacob.

English: 9 Behold, O God our defender : and looke upon the face of thine Anointed.
Manx: 9. Jeagh, O Iíh nan ferr riall : as jeágh er ydyn tdy ghríst.
ydyn] ms. ynyd

English: 10 For one day in thy Courts : is better then a thousand.
Manx: 10. Erson sháyr yn la ayns tdy ghwrtyn : na twsáyn.

English: 11 I had rather bee a doore-keeper in the house of my God : then to dwell in the tents of ungodlinesse.
Manx: 11. B’ ’áyr láỳm ve m’ ’er fríal dorrys ayns tei my Iíh : na dy vaghey ayns kábanyn yn niaw-ghráwiys.

English: 12 For the Lord God is a light and defence : the Lord wil give grace and worship, and no good thing shall he withhold from them that live a godly life.
Manx: 12. Erson ta yn Chiarn Jíh na hoilshey as n’ ’endéel : ver yn Chiarn grays as ammys, as gha bí ryd erbí mei erna ghwmmel vowsyn ta líidjéel bée ghráwi.
n’ ’endéel] ms. m’ ’endéel

English: 13 O Lord God of hostes : blessed is the man that putteth his trust in thee.
Manx: 13. O Hiarn Iíh ny shessaghtyn hói : baníit ta yn dwyne ta toyrt y hreistéel anyds.

English: Benedixisti Domine. Psal. 85.
Manx: Benedixisti domine. psal. 85.
Benedixisti] ms. Benedixiﬆ

English: Lord, thou art become gracious unto thy land: thou hast turned away the captivitie of Jacob.
Manx: 1. Hiarn, tóẁ erna me grasóil dy tdy hallw : tow er jynda er shiul kapy Iacob.

English: 2 Thou hast forgiven the offence of thy people : and covered all their sinnes.
Manx: 2. Tóẁ er lyoi olkys dy tdy phobyl : as er gẃdaghey nan bekaghyn wlly.

English: 3 Thou hast taken away all thy displeasure : and turned thy selfe from thy wrathfull indignation.
Manx: 3. Tow ern’ ’óyl as y ráyd tdy iẃmẃiys wlly : as er dy hynda héyn vei chiass tdy ghorri.

English: 4 Turne us then, O God our Saviour : and let thine anger cease from us.
Manx: 4. Chyndá shwin éish, O Iíh nan sawálys : as ligg e tdy ghorri skwy̌irr voiniyn.

English: 5 Wilt thou bee displeased at us for ever : and wilt thou stretch out thy wrath from one generation to another?
Manx: 5. Bíi us jumẃiagh rwiniyn erson gybrágh : as shíin w magh tdy ghorri vei yn shilogh gys shilogh elle?

English: 6 Wilt thou not turne againe, and quicken us : that thy people may rejoyce in thee?
Manx: 6. Nagh jyndá us ríist as shwiniyn y víòghy : gy vod tdy phobyl ve gannoil anyds?

English: 7 Shew us thy mercy, O Lord : & grant us thy salvation.
Manx: 7. Jéagh dwiniyn tdy vyghin, O Hiarn : as jall dwin tdy hawalys.

English: 8 I wil hearken what the Lord God will say concerning me : for he shall speake peace unto his people, & to his Saints that they turne not againe.
Manx: 8. Klastchíỳms kre jir yn Chiarn Jíh my my ghians : erson lóyri é shíi da phobyl as da nẃghy,n nagh jyndá ayd ríist.

English: 9 For his salvation is nigh them that feare him : that glorie may dwell in our land.
Manx: 9. Erson ta yn sawálys aggesyn fagys dawsyn ta góyl agyl reyf : gy vod glóyr vaghey ayns nan dallw.

English: 10 Mercy and trueth are met together : righteousnes and peace have kissed each other.
Manx: 10. Ta myghin as firrinys er doyrt quayltys kwjaght : ta káyrys as shíi er bágy dâ ghielle.

English: 11 Trueth shall flourish out of the earth : and righteousnesse hath looked downe from heaven.
Manx: 11. Níi firrinys blághy magh as y tallw : as ta káyrys ern iághyn núas vei néaw.

English: 12 Yea, the Lord shal shew loving kindnesse : and our land shall give her increase.
