Manx: 12. Gy jarw, jághi yn Chiarn kéindylys graigóil : as verr yn talw ainyn y měass.

English: 13 Righteousnesse shall goe before him : and he shall direct his going in the way.
Manx: 13. Heid káyrys réyfsyn : as líidji e y immiaght ayns y ráyd.

English: The xvii. day.
Manx: Yn xvii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.
Ayryn] ms. Arryn

English: Inclina Domine. Psal. 86.
Manx: Inclina Domine aurem. psal. 86.

English: Bow downe thine eare, O Lord, and heare me : for I am poore, and in miserie.
Manx: 1. Krẃmm núas tdy ghlyesh, O Hiarn, as klwy̌n mi : erson ta mi boght as ayns ymmyrts.

English: 2 Preserve thou my soule, for I am holy : my God save thy servant that putteth his trust in thee.
Manx: 2. Friel us m’ anym, erson ta mi kasserick : my Iíh, saw tdy herváynt ta tóyrt y hreistéel anyds.

English: 3 Be merciful unto me, O Lord : for I wil call dayly upon thee.
Manx: 3. Bí trokróil dẃys, O Hiarn : erson éìym oyrts gygh lá.

English: 4 Comfort the soule of thy servant : for unto thee, O Lord doe I lift up my soule.
Manx: 4. Jean anym tdy herváynt y gyrjaghy : erson hẃyds, O Hiarn, ta mi trogel shuas m’ anym.

English: 5 For thou Lord art good and gracious : and of great mercie unto all them that call upon thee.
Manx: 5. Erson ta us, Hiarn, mei as grasóil : as dy vyghin vwar dawsyn wlly ta gémagh óỳrts.

English: 6 Give eare Lord unto my prayer : and ponder the voyce of mine humble desires.
Manx: 6. Kwr klýash, Hiarn, gys my phadjer : as smwni er kórá m’ aghinyns ishil.

English: 7 In the time of my trouble I will call upon thee : for thou hearest me.
Manx: 7. Ayns iérish my hyaghyns éìym óỳrts : erson ta us dy my ghlastchen.

English: 8 Among the gods there is none like unto thee, O Lord : there is not one that can doe as thou hast done.
Manx: 8. Masky nyn iíaghyn[183] gha vel veg kasly rw̌yts, O Hiarn : as gha vell anayn odys y ianw mar ta us janw.

English: as thou hast done] 1599, 1636, 1660, 1662 as thou do(e)st
9 All nations whom thou hast made, shal come and worship thee, O Lord : and shall glorifie thy Name.
Manx: 9. Higg wlly ny hatiẃni ta us erna ianw, as ver áyd ammys dwitch, O Hiarn : as níi áyd t’ enym y gloyraghey.

English: 10 For thou art great, and doest wonderous things : thou art God alone.
Manx: 10. Erson ta us mẃar, as janw redyn ientyssagh : she us Jih dy lymarkan.

English: 11 Teach me thy way, O Lord, and I will walke in thy trueth : O knit my heart unto thee, that I may feare thy Name.
Manx: 11. Ýnsi dow tdy ráyd, O Hiarn, as immiym ayns t’ irrinys : O sněym my ghri hẃỳds, gy vodym agyl y góyl dy t’ enyms.
dy t’ enyms] ms. tdy t’ enyms

English: 12 I wil thanke thee, O Lord my God, with al my heart : and wil praise thy Name for evermore.
Manx: 12. Verrym bẃias dwitch, O Hiarn my Iíh, rish my ghri wlly : as mollym t’ enyms erson gybrágh.

English: 13 For great is thy mercy toward me : and thou hast delivered my soule from the nethermost hell.
Manx: 13. Erson sh’ mẃar tdy vyghin dẃys : as tow er lifrée m’ anym vei yn iurin sh’ isley.

English: 14 O God, the proud are risen against mee : and the Congregations of naughtie men have sought after my soule, and have not set thee before their eyes.
Manx: 14. O Iih, ta yn slyěi morniagh ern’ irri m’ ýeis : as ta shessaghtyn klyei olk er shyirre nýre my anyms, as ghanel ayd er dy heiaghe feanish nan swilyn.

English: 15 But thou (O Lord God) art full of compassion and mercie : long suffering, plenteous in goodnesse and trueth.
Manx: 15. Agh ta us, [O] Hiarn Iíh, layn dy hréi as myghin : surrel fodey, palchey ayns mêiys as firrinys.
Hiarn] ms. Chiarn

English: 16 O turne thee then unto me, and have mercy upon me : give thy strength unto thy servant, and helpe the sonne of thine handmayd.
Manx: 16. O chyndá us eish hwyms, as jean myghin orym : kwrr tdy gniart dy tdy hervaynt, as kwyn lesh mack t’ innivýyl.

English: 17 Shew some good token upon mee for good, that they which hate mee, may see it, and bee ashamed : because thou Lord hast holpen me, and comforted me.
Manx: 17. Jeagh kóỳry egnagh[184] mei oryms ghon mei; gy vod aydsyn ta dwoi ack orryms y akin e, as ve nárie : erson gy vel us, Hiarn, er gẃyne layms, as er my gyrjaghey.

English: good token] 1662 token; they which hate] 1662 they who hate
Fundamenta eius. Psal. 87.
Manx: Fvndamenta eius. psal. 87.

English: Her foundations are upon the holy hils : the Lord loveth the gates of Sion, more then all the dwellings of Jacob.
Manx: 1. Ta ny bẃnnyn ecks er ny knwick kasserick : sh’ ýne lesh yn Chiarn dorsyn Seion, nasmẃ na ynyd vaghey wlly Iácob.

English: 2 Very excellent things are spoken of thee : thou city of God.
Manx: 2. Ta redyn fíir ýasyl d’ an loyrt[185] jíids : us áyrd valley Iíh.

English: 3 I will thinke upon Rahab and Babylon : with them that know me.
Manx: 3. Smẃniym er Rahab as Babilon : maríùsyn sáẁn mish.

English: 4 Behold ye the Philistines also : and they of Tyre, with the Morians; loe, there was he borne.
Manx: 4. Jéaghigi ny Pheilistini níist : as aydsyn dy Heir, marish ny Moriani; jeagh, aynshen rwgg e.
Jéaghigi] ms. Jéagh

English: 5 And of Sion it shall bee reported, that he was borne in her : and the most High shall stablish her.
Manx: 5. As dy Seion víis e erna grá, gy rwgg e aŷnjish : as níi yn ýrje smẃ ish y hickraghy.

English: 6 The Lord shall rehearse it when he writeth up the people : that he was borne there.
Manx: 6. Inshíi yn Chiarn ríist é nar skriẃiys é shúas yn pobyl : gy rwgg é aynshen.

English: 7 The singers also and trumpetters shal he rehearse : All my fresh springs shall be in thee.
Manx: 7. Inshíi é níist ny fyirr oráyn as ny trẃmpeteryn : bíi wlly my wyskaghyn gell ẃeir anyds.

English: Domine Deus. Psal. 88.
Manx: Domine Deus. psal. 88.

English: O Lord God of my salvation, I have cried day and night before thee : O let my prayer enter into thy presence, encline thine eare unto my calling.
Manx: 1. O Hiarn Iíh dy my hawálys, jei mi lá as ŷi kiangoyrt rwy̌ts : O ligg e my phadjer goll schiagh ayns t’ éanish; krómm tdy ghlýesh gys m’ emagh.

English: 2 For my soule is ful of trouble : and my life draweth nigh unto hell.
Manx: 2. Erson ta m’ anym láyn dy hyaghyn : as ta my vé tarn argere d’ yn ’iûrin.

English: 3 I am counted as one of them that goe downe into the pit : and I have bene even as a man that hath no strength.
Manx: 3. Ta mi er m’ erif mar anáyn jusyn ta doll shíis gys yn lagg : as ta mi er me gy jarw mar dwyne nagh vel veg yn gniart agge.

English: 4 Free among the dead, like unto them that be wounded and lie in the grave : which be out of remembrance, and are cut away from thy hand.
Manx: 4. Sýyr masky ny marrw, kásly ríusyn ta lottit as lyei ayns yn ýoi : ta as kwine, as garchy as y ráyd vei tdy láw.

English: be wounded] 1662 are wounded; which be out] 1662 who are out
5 Thou hast laid me in the lowest pit : in a place of darknesse, and in the deepe.
Manx: 5. Tóẁ er my hóyrt my lyei ayns y lagg íisly : ayns ynyd dy gorghys, as ayns y deifnid.

English: 6 Thine indignation lyeth hard upon mee : and thou hast vexed me with all thy stormes.
Manx: 6. Ta tdy ghořri lyi gy kroi orryms : as tow er my hýaghyn rish tdy gorrinyn wlly.
gorrinyn] ms. gorrin

English: 7 Thou hast put away mine acquaintance farre from me : and made me to be abhorred of them.
Manx: 7. Tow er doyrt er shiul m’ áynchys fodey vóỳms : as ern’ ianw dŵoi jiyms dâwsyn.

English: 8 I am so fast in prison : that I cannot get foorth.
Manx: 8. Ta mi gho sickyr ayns kappy : nagh voddym geadthyn magh.

English: 9 My sight faileth for very trouble : Lord, I have called dayly upon thee, I have stretched out mine hands unto thee.
Manx: 9. Ta my hilliy toyrt nayrdy erson syaghyn : Hiarn, ta mi ern émagh gygh lá óỳrts, ta mi er shíine magh my lawyn hẃỳds.

English: stretched out] 1662 stretched forth
10 Doest thou shew wonders among the dead : or shal the dead rise up againe, and praise thee?
Manx: 10. Vel us jaghyn iéntyssyn masky ny marrw : na nirri ny meriu shýas níist, as us y volley?
iéntyssyn] ms. iéntysagh

English: 11 Shall thy loving kindnesse be shewed in the grave : or thy faithfulnesse in destruction?
Manx: 11. An bíi tdy gheindylys grayigoyl erna iaghyn ayns yn yoi : as t’ irrinys ayns y gháll?

English: 12 Shall thy wonderous works be knowen in the darke : and thy righteousnesse in the land where all things are forgotten?
Manx: 12. An bíi fyss er t’ obraghyns iéantyssagh ayns y dorghys : as tdy ghayrys ayns y talw yn ienyd ta dygh wlly redd jarrẃdit?

English: 13 Unto thee have I cried, O Lord : and earely shall my prayer come before thee.
Manx: 13. Hẃỳds ta mi ern emagh, O Hiarn : as gy moghey higg my phadjer t’ énishus.
t’ énishus] ms. t’ énish us

English: 14 Lord, why abhorrest thou my soule : and hidest thou thy face from me?
Manx: 14. Hiarn, kamma vel dẃòi ayds er m’ anym : as vel us fallaghy t’ edyn vóỳms?

English: 15 I am in misery, and like unto him that is at the point to die : (even from my youth up) thy terrours have I suffered with a troubled minde.
Manx: 15. Ta mi ayns boghtynys, as kasly rishyn ta argere dy váys : gy jarw vei m’ agidj shyas, ta mi surráil t’ aglaghyns rish agney syitt.

English: 16 Thy wrathful displeasure goeth over me : and the fear of thee hath undone me.
Manx: 16. Ta tdy iumẃiys layn dy ghorri doll hařryms : as ta aggyl [jíds][186] er my ghraghey.

English: 17 They came round about mee dayly like water : and compassed me together on every side.
Manx: 17. Haink áyd krwnn magiyrt ymmwmm gygh lá kasly rish wisky : as haink ayd magiyrt ymmwmm kwjaght er gygh ẃnn cheyf.

English: 18 My lovers and friends hast thou put away from mee : and hid mine acquaintance out of my sight.
Manx: 18. Tow er dóyrt my gharjyn as my géne mẃnjer er shiul voyms : as er vallaghey m’ aynchys magh as my hilliy.

English: The xvii. day.
Manx: Yn xvii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Misericordias Domini. Psal. 89.
Manx: Misericordias Domini. psal. 89.

English: My song shall bee alway of the loving kindenesse of the Lord : with my mouth will I ever be shewing thy trueth, from one generation to another.
Manx: 1. Bíi m’ oráyn gybragh dy gheindylys grayigóil yn Chiarn : rish my véayl víim gybragh soilsaghy t’ irrinys vei yn shilogh gys shilogh elle.

English: 2 For I have said, Mercie shal be set up for ever : thy trueth shalt thou stablish in the heavens.
Manx: 2. Erson dwyrt mi, bíi myghin erna heiaghe sýas erson gybragh : t’ irrinys níi us y laidjraghy ayns ny neawghyn.
neawghyn] ms. neawhyn

English: 3 I have made a covenant with my chosen : I have sworne unto David my servant;
Manx: 3. Ta mi ern’ ianw kẃnaynt rish m’ er ryit : ta mi er lẃ dy Gavid my herváynt.

English: 4 Thy seede will I stablish for ever : and set up thy throne from one generation to another.
Manx: 4. Tdy rassys níiyms y gniartaghy erson gybragh : as seiym sýas tdy throyn vei yn shilogh gys shilogh elle.

English: 5 O Lord, the very heavens shall praise thy wonderous workes : and thy trueth in the Congregation of the Saints.
Manx: 5. O Hiarn, molli ny neawaghyn héyn t’ obraghyn ientyssagh : as t’ irrinys ayns shessaght ny nẃghyn.

English: 6 For who is he among the cloudes : that shal be compared unto the Lord?
Manx: 6. Erson quei eshyn masky ny bojalyn : víis erna howlaghy rish y Chiarn?

English: 7 And what is he among the gods : that shal be like unto the Lord?
Manx: 7. As kre ta eshyn masky nyn íìaghyn[188] : víis kasly rish y Chiarn?
eshyn] ms. ashyn

English: 8 God is very greatly to bee feared in the counsel of the saints : & to be had in reverence of al them that are about him.
Manx: 8. Ta agyl fíir vẃar dy vé erna góyl dy Iíh, ayns kowrley ny nẃyn : as dy vé ayns ammys vẃar jusyn wlly ta magiyrt ymmishyn.

English: about] 1662 round about
9 O Lord God of hosts, who is like unto thee : thy trueth (most mighty Lord) is on every side.
Manx: 9. O Hiarn Iíh ny hói, quei ta kasly rwyts ? ta t’ irrinus, Hiarn smẃ gniártoil, er gygh wnn chéỳf.

English: 10 Thou rulest the raging of the sea : thou stillest the waves thereof when they arise.
Manx: 10. Tow réel keidj yn argey : tow kwinaghy ny tonnyn ack nar t’ ayd girri.

English: 11 Thou hast subdued Egypt, and destroyed it : thou hast scattered thine enemies abroad with thy mighty arme.
Manx: 11. Tow er doyrt núas Egipt, as erna strẃi [e] : tóẁ er skýale tdy nóidjyn gy lien rish tdy rií gniartoil.

English: 12 The heavens are thine, the earth also is thine : thou hast layde the foundation of the round world, & all that therein is.
Manx: 12. Sh’ liatt ny neawaghyn, sh’liatt yn talw níist : tow er seiaghe bẃnn y týyl krwnn, as wlly na ta ayn.

English: 13 Thou hast made the North and the South : Tabor and Hermon shal rejoyce in thy Name.
Manx: 13. Tow ern ianw yn tẃòi as y jass : gowi Tabor as Hermon bogey ayns t’ enyms.

English: 14 Thou hast a mighty arme : strong is thy hand, & high is thy right hand.
Manx: 14. Ta ríi gniártoil ayds : sh’ laidjer tdy law, as sh’ áyrd tdy law iésh.

English: 15 Righteousnes and equitie is the habitation of thy seat : mercy and trueth shal goe before thy face.
Manx: 15. She káyrys as kiǎrt enyd vághey t’ enyd sy̌ei : héyd myghin as firrinys feanish t’ edyns.

English: equitie is] 1662 equity are
16 Blessed is the people (O Lord) that can rejoyce in thee : they shal walke in the light of thy countenance.
Manx: 16. Banniit ta yn pobyl, O Hiarn, ’odys bogey y góyl aynyds : immi áyd ayns soilshe t’ eiys.

English: 17 Their delight shall bee dayly in thy Name : and in thy righteousnesse shall they make their boast.
Manx: 17. Bíi yn dattnys acksyn[189] gygh lá ayns t’ enyms : as ayns tdy gháyrys níi aydsyn nan mogassi.

English: 18 For thou art the glory of their strength : and in thy loving kindnesse thou shalt lift up our hornes.
Manx: 18. Erson she us gloyr yn gniart acksyn : as ayns tdy gheindylys gráyigóyl hrogit us shúas ny herkyn ainiyn.
gloyr yn gniart] ms. yn gniart yn gniart

English: 19 For the Lord is our defence : the Holy-one of Israel is our King.
Manx: 19. Erson she yn Chiarn nan vrialy : she anáyn ghasserick Eisrael nan ríi.

English: 20 Thou spakest sometime in visions unto thy Saints, and saydest : I have layde helpe upon one that is mightie; I have exalted one chosen out of the people.
Manx: 20. Lóyr us na erẃn[190] ayns shilliaghyn rish tdy nẃaghyn, as dẃyrt ẃ : ta mi er dóyrt kẃney er anáyn ta gniártoil; ta mi er drogel shýas anáyn ry̌it magh d’ yn phobyl.

English: 21 I have found David my servant : with my holy oyle have I anoynted him.
Manx: 21. Ta mi er veadthy̌n David my herváynt : rish my aly kasserick ta mi er y alysyn.
er y alysyn] ms. er alysyn

English: 22 My hand shal holde him fast : and my arme shall strengthen him.
Manx: 22. Kwmmi my law eshyn sickyr : as gniarti my ríi eshyn.

English: 23 The enemie shall not be able to doe him violence: the sonne of wickednesse shall not hurt him.
Manx: 23. Ghá bíi yn nóid abyl dy iánw trynlás er : gha gorti mack yn olkys é.

English: 24 I shall smite downe his foes before his face : & plague them that hate him.
Manx: 24. Boilym shíis y nóidjyn na iénishyn : as kerriym aydsyn ta dwoi ack ersyn.

English: shall smite] 1662 will smite
25 My trueth also and my mercy shall be with him: and in my Name shall his horne be exalted.
Manx: 25. Bíi m’ irirnys níist as my vyghin marishsyn : as ayns m’ enyms víis yn erick aggesyn erna hrogel shýas.

English: 26 I will set his dominion also in the sea : and his right hand in the floods.
Manx: 26. Séìym y reelsyn níist ayns yn ’argey : as y láw iésh ayns ny twyllaghyn.
Séìym] ms. S’éìym

English: 27 He shall call mee, Thou art my Father : my God, and my strong salvation.
Manx: 27. Níi eshyn gemagh ořryms, she us m’ áer : my Iíh, as my hawalys laidjer.

English: 28 And I will make him my first borne : higher then the Kings of the earth.
Manx: 28. As níiyms eshyn my gheid vack : nas-sýrje na riyghyn yn talẃin.

English: 29 My mercy will I keepe for him for evermore : and my Covenant shall stand fast with him.
Manx: 29. Frialym my vyghin dâsyn erson gybragh : as shassi my ghwnáynt sickyr marishsyn.
marishsyn] ms. mariusyn

English: 30 His seed also will I make to endure for ever : and his throne as the dayes of heaven.
Manx: 30. Verryms er y rassyn dy araghtyn erson gybrágh : as y ényd sei mar laghyn yn neáw.

English: 31 But if his children forsake my Law : and walke not in my Judgements;
Manx: 31. Agh my hrégys y ghláwnsyn my lýèis : as nagh nimmi áyd ayns my vrẃinyssyns;

English: 32 If they breake my Statutes, and keepe not my Commandements : I will visite their offences with the rod, and their sinne with scourges.
Manx: 32. My vrishíis áyd my lattyssyns, as nagh vríal áyd m’ abertsyn : kẃistym nan loghtyn rish y tlatt, as nan beky rish kippyn.
loghtyn] ms. lottyn

English: 33 Neverthelesse, my loving kindnesse will I not utterly take from him : nor suffer my trueth to faile.
Manx: 33. Na iêi, ghá gôyms my gheindylys-grayigóyl gy-glan veisyn : ghamw hwrrym m’ irrinys dy hoyrt nayrdy.

English: 34 My Covenant will I not breake, nor alter the thing that is gone out of my lips : I have sworne once by my Holiness, that I wil not faile David.
Manx: 34. Gha brîshiym my ghẃnáynt, ghamẃ ghyghláym yn red ta er noll magh er my veliyn : ta mi er lẃ y̓n gheiyrt liórish my ghasserikys nagh valiyms David.

English: 35 His seed shall endure for ever : and his seate is like as the Sunne before me.
Manx: 35. Farri yn rass aggesyn erson gybragh : as ta y ririoghtyn kasly rish yn grién m’ eenishys.

English: 36 He shall stand fast for evermore as the Moone : and as the faithfull witnesse in heaven.
Manx: 36. Shassi e síćkyr erson gybrágh mar yn éask : as mar yn rikóyrt firrinagh ayns neaw.

English: 37 But thou hast abhorred and forsaken thine Anointed : and art displeased at him.
Manx: 37. Agh tow er dilge er shíul as er dregáel tdy ghríist : as tow jumẃiagh rishyn.

English: 38 Thou hast broken the covenant of thy servant: and cast his Crowne to the ground.
Manx: 38. Tow er mrishie kẃnáynt dy herváynt : as er dilge y attaghyn gys y talw.

English: 39 Thou hast overthrowen all his hedges : and broken downe his strong holds.
Manx: 39. Tow er dilge harrish wlly ny klêy aggesyn : as er mrishie nuas y hẃryn laidjer.

English: 40 All they that goe by, spoile him : and he is become a rebuke to his neighbours.
Manx: 40. Ta áydsyn wlly ta dol shaghe dâ ghreghe-syn : as te er jíit mar náyre da nabonyn.

English: rebuke] 1662 reproach
41 Thou hast set up the right hand of his enemies : and made all his adversaries to rejoyce.
Manx: 41. Tow er seiaghe shýàs law iesh y noidjynsyn : as hwgg w oriusyn wlly ta na ýoi bogey y góyl.

English: 42 Thou hast taken away the edge of his sword : and givest him not victorie in the battaile.
Manx: 42. Tow ern’ góyl er shiúl fŷiór y ghliew : as gha dwgg ẃ dásyn barriyght ayns y ghaggey.

English: 43 Thou hast put out his glory : and cast his throne downe to the ground.
Manx: 43. Tow er doyrt magh y glóyrsyn : as er dilge y hróyn shiis gys y talw.

English: 44 The dayes of his youth hast thou shortened : and covered him with dishonour.
Manx: 44. Tow ern’ iarraghey laghyn yn ágid aggesyn : as ghwrr ẃ eshyn rish niaw onéyr.
aggesyn] ms. aggesn

English: 45 Lord, how long wilt thou hide thy selfe, for ever: and shall thy wrath burne like fire?
Manx: 45. Hiarn, káid ’álliyst us ẃ héyn, erson gybrágh : as jean tdy ghorri lossy mar ainil?

English: 46 O remember how short my time is : wherefore hast thou made all men, for nought?
Manx: 46. O kẃyni gho giarr as ta my iérish : kamma vel us ern’ ianw dygh wlly gẃyne erson gyn veg?

English: 47 What man is he that liveth, and shall not see death : and shall he deliver his soule from the hand of hell?
Manx: 47. Quei yn dwyne ta bio as nagh vaick báys : as lifréi eshyn y anym héyn vei law ifrin?

English: 48 Lord, where are thy old loving kindnesses : which thou swarest unto David in thy trueth?
Manx: 48. Hiarn, kaje vel tdy hann gheindylyssyn grayigóyl : ren us y lẃ dy gavid ayns t’ irrinys?

English: 49 Remember, Lord, the rebuke that thy servants have : and how I doe beare in my bosome the rebukes of many people;
Manx: 49. Hiarn, kẃini er yn náyre t’ ag tdy herváyntyns : as kyns ta mi giymmyrky ayns m’ oghrys aghsanyn ymmydi slyěi;

English: 50 Wherewith thine enemies have blasphemed thee, and slandered the footsteps of thine anointed : praised bee the Lord for evermore. Amen, Amen.
Manx: 50. Rish shen ta tdy nóidjyn er lóyrt gy molaghtóil jíds, as er liún kasmedjyn kossey tdy ghríist : baníit gy row yn Chiarn erson gybragh. Amen, amen.

English: Amen, Amen.] 1662 Amen, and Amen.
The xviii. day.
Manx: Yn xviii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Domine, refugium. Psal. 90.
Manx: Domine refugium. psal. 90.

English: Lord, thou hast bene our refuge : from one generation to another.
Manx: 1. Hiarn, tow er mé nan gymmirk : vei yn shilogh gys shilógh elle.

English: 2 Before the mountaines were brought foorth, or ever the earth and the world were made : thou art God from everlasting, and world without end.
Manx: 2. My row ny knwickyn mẃar er nan dóyrt magh, my row riu yn talw as yn sýyl er nan ianw : she us Jíh vei gybrágh as syyl gyn ghiann.

English: 3 Thou turnest man to destruction : againe thou sayest, Come againe ye children of men.
Manx: 3. Tow chyndá dwyne gys doll mow : ríist tóẁ grá, targi ríist, shíus klawn ny néne.

English: 4 For a thousand yeres in thy sight, are but as yesterday : seeing that is past as a watch in the night.
Manx: 4. Erson ghá vel míley bléyn ayns tdy hilliys agh mar jé : fackyn gy vel shen ern ’oll shaghey mar are ayns yn yěi.

English: 5 Assoone as thou scatterest them, they are even as a sleepe : and fade away suddenly like the grasse.
Manx: 5. Gho lýe as toŵ d’ an skéley áyd, t’ áyd gy jarw mar kadly : as fióghy er shiúl doll tattiym mar y féyr.

English: 6 In the morning it is greene, and groweth up : but in the evening it is cut downe, dried up, and withered.
Manx: 6. Ayns y voghre t’ e ieny, as gáas shuas : agh ayns yn iaskyr t’ e garchit shiis, chermit shýas, as fiǒit.

English: 7 For wee consume away in thy displeasure : and are afraid at thy wrathfull indignation.
Manx: 7. Erson ta shwin kéyf er shiúl ayns tdy iẃmẃiys : as ta shwin aglagh ag tdy ghorri layn dy farg.

English: 8 Thou hast set our misdeedes before thee : and our secret sinnes in the light of thy countenance.
Manx: 8. Tow er doyrt nan drogh ianw t’ énishus : as nan beky fallíit ayns shilliy t’ edyns.
t’ énishus] ms. t’ énish us; shilliy] ms. silliy

English: 9 For when thou art angrie, all our dayes are gone : wee bring our yeeres to an end, as it were a tale that is told.
Manx: 9. Erson nar ta us korri, ta wlly nan laghyn er shíul : ta shwin tóyrt nan mliényn gys kian, mar veagh e skiál ta erna inshi.

English: 10 The dayes of our age are threescore yeres and ten; and though men be so strong that they come to foursecore yeeres : yet is their strength then but labour and sorrow; so soone passeth it away, and we are gone.
Manx: 10. Ta laghyn nan ýesh tri fíid bléyn as jei, as gy ta déney gho láidjer shen gy vel áyd chíit gys kéyr fíid bléyn : fóost gha vel ’an gniart acksyn éish agh dockyr as trimshey; gho lýe shen t’ e dol shaghey, as ta shwin er shiúl.

English: 11 But who regardeth the power of thy wrath : for even thereafter as a man feareth, so is thy displeasure.
Manx: 11. Agh quei ta tóyrt taskey dy phẃer tdy ghorris ? erson mar ta dwyne góyl agyl, shen mar ta tdy iumẃiys.

English: 12 O teach us to number our dayes : that wee may apply our hearts unto Wisedome.
Manx: 12. O ynsi dwin dy éryif nan lághyn : gy vod meid nan gríaghyn y hóyrt gys krinyght.

English: O teach] 1662 So teach
13 Turne thee againe (O Lord) at the last : and be gracious unto thy servants.
Manx: 13. Chyndá us ríist, O Hiarn, agg y jere : as bíi grasoil dy tdy herváyntyns.

English: 14 O satisfie us with thy mercie, and that soone : so shall we rejoyce and be glad all the dayes of our life.
Manx: 14. O lién shwin rish tdy vyghin hrókyrygh, as shen gy lýe : shen mar gow meid bogey, as vi meid gannoil laghyn nan sýyl wlly.
hrókyrygh] ms. ghrókyrygh

English: 15 Comfort us againe now after the time that thou hast plagued us : & for the yeres wherein we have suffered adversitie.
Manx: 15. Toer gyrjaghe win ríist, nish nýre yn iérish tow er nan geraghy : as erson ny bléinyn ayns ta shwin er vwlliaghtyn sýaghyn.

English: 16 Shew thy servants thy worke : and their children thy glory.
Manx: 16. Soilshi t’ obyr dy tdy hervayntyns : as tdy gloyr dy nan glawn.

English: 17 And the glorious Majestie of the Lord our God be upon us : prosper thou the worke of our hands upon us, O prosper thou our handy worke.
Manx: 17. As ligg e ayrd ýasly gloróil yn Chiarn nan Iíh ve orwin : toyr bishagh er obyr nan lawyn orwiniyn; O tóer us bishagh er nan obyr lawygh.

English: Qui habitat. Psal. 91.
Manx: Qui habitat. psal. 91.

English: Who so dwelleth under the defence of the most High : shall abide under the shadow of the Almightie.
Manx: 1. Quei ta vaghey fwo frialy yn ýrje smẃ : fwrri e fwo ská yn wlly gniartoil.

English: 2 I wil say unto the Lord, Thou art my hope and my strong hold : my God, in him wil I trust.
Manx: 2. Jirriyms rish y Chiarn, she us my hreistéel as my hẃwr laidjer : my Iíh, ayns-syn níyms treistéel.

English: 3 For he shall deliver thee from the snare of the Hunter : and from the noysome pestilence.
Manx: 3. Erson lifréei [é] us vei ribbey yn chelgéyr : as vei yn phatt skailtchagh.[191]

English: 4 Hee shall defend thee under his wings, and thou shalt be safe under his feathers : his faithfulnesse and trueth shall be thy shield and buckler.
Manx: 4. Friali é us fwó y skéanyn, as bíit ẃ sawchey fẃo y edjaghyn : bíi yn ’íir firrinys aggesyn tdy ské as tdy vwckler.
y skéanyn] ms. yn skéanyn

English: 5 Thou shalt not be afraid for any terrour by night: nor for the arrow that flyeth by day;
Manx: 5. Gha gow agyl dy agyl erbi ’syn ýei : na d’ yn teíidj ta getlagh ayns y lá;
’syn] ms. ’sy’n; teíidj] ms. t’eíidj

English: 6 For the pestilence that walketh in darknesse : nor for the sicknesse that destroyeth in the noone day.
Manx: 6. D’ yn ghnapp ta gimiaght ayns y dorghys : na d’ yn chinnys ta strwiel ag myn lá.

English: 7 A thousand shall fall beside thee, and ten thousand at thy right hand : but it shall not come nigh thee.
Manx: 7. Twitchi tẃsáyn lǒyrts, as jei tẃsányn ag tdy law iesh : agh gha jigg e argere gwitch.

English: 8 Yea, with thine eyes shalt thou behold : and see the reward of the ungodly.
Manx: 8. Gy jarw, rish tdy hwilyn iághyst us : as híi us lúagh yn niawghráwi.

English: 9 For thou Lord art my hope : thou hast set thine house of defence very high.
Manx: 9. Erson she us, Hiarn, my hreistéel : tow er seiaghe tdy hei friali fíir ayrd.

English: 10 There shall no evill happen unto thee : neither shall any plague come nigh thy dwelling.
Manx: 10. Gha daghyr skelly erbi dwitch : ghamẃ higg phlóg erbi farr tdy vaghey.

English: 11 For he shall give his Angels charge over thee : to keepe thee in all thy wayes.
Manx: 11. Erson ver e sayre dâ ainilyn harryds : dy tdy rial ayns tdy ráidjyns wlly.

English: 12 They shall beare thee in their handes : that thou hurt not thy foot against a stone.
Manx: 12. Ymmyrki ayd us ayns nan láwyn : na gorti ẃ tdy ghoss nyoi klagh.
Ymmyrki] ms. Ymmyrti

English: 13 Thou shalt goe upon the Lion and Adder : the yong Lion and the Dragon shalt thou tread under thy feet.
Manx: 13. Immiyt ẃ er y léìon as yn néìdyr : yn leion áyg as yn drakwn stampíit us fwo tdy ghassyn.
ghassyn] ms. ghasswn

English: 14 Because he hath set his love upon me, therefore shall I deliver him : I shall set him up, because hee hath knowen my Name.
Manx: 14. Erson gy row grayi agge orryms; shennyfá lifreyms eshyn : seíims shúas é erson gy bawn da m’ enyms.

English: therefore shall I] 1662 therefore will I; I shall set] 1662 I will set
Manx: bawn da] ms. bawn daw

English: 15 He shal cal upon me, & I wil heare him : yea, I am with him in trouble; I wil deliver him, and bring him to honour.
Manx: 15. Eíi eshyn ořryms, as klwinym e : gy jarw, ta mish marishyn ayns sýaghyn; lifréym e, as verrym e gys oneyr.

English: 16 With long life will I satisfie him : and shewe him my salvation.
Manx: 16. Rish sýyl fodey lienym e : as jághym dâ my hawalys.

English: Bonum est confiteri. Psal. 92.
Manx: Bonum est confiteri. psal: 92.

English: It is a good thing to give thankes unto the Lord : and to sing praises unto thy Name, O most Highest;
Manx: 1. She red mei dy hoyrt bẃias dyn Chiarn : as ayns y oráyn dy volley t’ enyms, O us yrje smẃ;

English: 2 To tell of thy loving kindenesse early in the morning : and of thy trueth in the night season;
Manx: 2. Dy insh dy tdy ghéindylys grayiẃil gy moghey ayns y voghre : as dy t’ irrinys er léash ŷi.

English: 3 Upon an instrument of ten strings, and upon the Lute : upon a lowd instrument, and upon the Harpe.
Manx: 3. Er ynstriument dy iêi strengyn, er yn líùt : er ynstriument ayrd, as er y krwitt.

English: 4 For thou Lord hast made me glad through thy works : and I will rejoyce in giving praise for the operations of thy hands.
Manx: 4. Erson tow us, Hiarn, er my ianw gaǹoil tréyfd t’ obraghyns : as goyms boggey ayns toyrt bwias, as erson obraghyn tdy láẁyns.

English: 5 O Lord, how glorious are thy works : & thy thoughts are very deepe.
Manx: 5. O Hiarn, gho gloróil as ta t’ obraghyns : as ta tdy smwnaghtyn fíir dow̌in.

English: & thy thoughts] 1662 thy thoughts
6 An unwise man doth not wel consider this : and a foole doeth not understand it.
Manx: 6. Ghá smẃni dwyne niawghríney gy méi er shó : as gha vel amydan da hwigel.
niawghríney] ms. niawghráwi

English: 7 When the ungodly are greene as the grasse, & when all the workers of wickednesse doe flourish : then shall they bee destroyed for ever; but thou Lord art the most highest for evermore.
Manx: 7. Nar ta yn niawghrawi glass mar yn féyr, as nar ta aydsyn wlly ta nan fyǐir obri d’ olkys gáas shýas : eish víis áyd er nan strẃiel erson gybrágh, agh she us, Hiarn, yn yrje smw erson gybragh.

English: 8 For loe, thine enemies (O Lord) loe thine enemies shall perish : and all the workers of wickednesse shall bee destroyed.
Manx: 8. Erson jeagh, bíi tdy nóidjyn, O Hiarn, jeagh, bíi tdy nóidjyn er ’an gwrr mow : as bíi ny hobríyn wlly d’ olk er ’an strwi.
hobríyn] ms. t’obríin

English: 9 But my horne shal be exalted like the horne of an Unicorn : for I am anoynted with fresh oyle.
Manx: 9. Agh bíi m’ érick erna hrogel shýas kasly rish érick yn beagh yn-erick : erson ta mi ẃlit rish ẃil ẃir.

English: 10 Mine eye also shall see his lust of his enemies : and mine eare shall heare his desire of the wicked that arise up against me.
Manx: 10. Híi my hwilyn níist y hagney[192] er my noidjyn : as klwini my ghlýesh y haghyn d’ yn drogh lyěi ta girri shúas m’ yeis.

English: his enemies] 1599, 1636, 1660 mine enemies
11 The righteous shal flourish like a palme tree : and shall spread abroad like a Cedar in Libanus.
Manx: 11. Níi yn dwyne kayragh bláe mar yn bille paylm : as skeli er lien kasly rish cedar ayns Libanys.

English: 12 Such as are planted in the house of the Lord : shall flourish in the Courts (of the house) of our God.
Manx: 12. Ni leid as ta syit ayns tei yn Chiarn : blaghý ayns kwrtyn dy hei yn Jíh ainiyn.

English: Such as be] 1662 Such as are
13 They also shall bring foorth more fruite in their age : and shal be fat and well liking.
Manx: 13. Ver ayd níist magh twilliw meass ayns nan yésh : as bii ayd rawr as jaghyn gy mei;

English: 14 That they may shew how true the Lord my strength is : and that there is no unrighteousnesse in him.
Manx: 14. Gy vod ayd y iaghyn gho firrinagh as ta yn Chiarn my gniarts : as nagh vel veg yn niaw gháyrys aynsyn.

English: The xviii. day.
Manx: Yn xviii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Dominus regnauit. Psal. 93
Manx: Dominus regnavit. psal. 93.

English: The Lord is King, and hath put on glorious apparel : the Lord hath put on his apparell, and girded himselfe with strength.
Manx: 1. Ta yn Chiarn na ríi, as er gwrr er ydagh glóróil : ta yn Chiarn er gwrr er y ydagh, as er y hany heyn rish gniart.

English: 2 He hath made the round world so sure : that it cannot be mooved.
Manx: 2. T’ e ern’ ianw yn sýyl krwnn gho sickyr : nagh vod e ve erna skwghey.

English: 3 Ever since the world beganne hath thy seate been prepared : thou art from everlasting.
Manx: 3. Ríù ada tossiagh yn týyl ta t’ ynyds erna ianw arlw : ta us víis vei gybragh.

English: 4 The floods are risen (O Lord) the floods have lift up their voyce : the floods lift up their waves.
Manx: 4. Ta ny twillaghyn ern’ irri, O Hiarn, ta ny twillaghyn er drogel sýas nan gorá : ta ny twillaghyn trogel sýas ’an donnyn.

English: 5 The waves of the sea are mightie, and rage horribly : but yet the Lord that dwelleth on high, is mightier.
Manx: 5. Ta tonnyn ny farkey gniartoil, as janw shian gy haglagh : agh fóyst ta yn Chiarn ta vaghey er yn yrje nas gniartoil.

English: that dwelleth] 1662 who dwelleth
6 Thy Testimonies, O Lord, are very sure : holinesse becommeth thine house for ever.
Manx: 6. Ta tdy rikórtyn, O Hiarn, fíir sickyr : ta kassrikys chíit gy mei tdy héìys erson gybragh.

English: Deus vltionum. Psal. 94.
Manx: Deus vltionum. psal. 94.

English: O Lord God, to whom vengeance belongeth: thou God to whom vengeance belongeth, shew thy selfe.
Manx: 1. O Hiarn Iíh, gys ta kwilíny benelt : us Iíh, gys ta kwilíny benelt, jeagh ẃ héyn.

English: 2 Arise thou Judge of the world : and reward the proud after their deserving.
Manx: 2. Irri, us briu yn týyl : as íik yn slyei morniagh nyre nan doilchyn.

English: 3 Lord, how long shall the ungodly : how long shall the ungodly triumph?
Manx: 3. Hiarn, káid níi yn niawghrawi : kaid níi yn niawghrawi yn bogey barriyght y geadthyn?

English: 4 How long shall all wicked doers speake so disdainefully : and make such proud boasting?
Manx: 4. Kaid níi aydsyn wlly ta janw olk lóyrt gho knaidjoil : as léid y vogassi morniagh y ianw?

English: 5 They smite downe thy people, O Lord : and trouble thine heritage.
Manx: 5. T’ áyd bwǒaly núas tdy phobyl, O Hiarn : as syei t’ eirys.

English: 6 They murther the widow and the stranger : and put the fatherlesse to death.
Manx: 6. T’ áyd dynvarrys yn ven tréogh as yn dwyne jori : as toyrt yn ghlawn gyn aer gys báas.

English: 7 And yet they say, Tush, the Lord shall not see : neither shall the God of Jacob regard it.
Manx: 7. Agh fóost t’ áyd grá, tysh, gha vack yn Chiarn : ghamẃ ver yn Jih Iacob tasky dâ.

English: 8 Take heed ye unwise among the people : O yee fooles, when will ye understand?
Manx: 8. Gowigi taskey, shiusse niawghriney masky yn pobyl : O shiusse ammydanyn, kwin níi shiu twigel?

English: 9 He that planted the eare, shall he not heare : or hee that made the eye, shall he not see?
Manx: 9. Eshyn hy̌ei yn ghlýesh, nagh glwin é : na éshyn ren yn twil, nagh vaick é?

English: 10 Or he that nurtureth the heathen : it is hee that teacheth man knowledge, shall not he punish?
Manx: 10. Na eshyn ta gynsaghey ny hatiẃni : she eshyn ta gynsaghey dy gwiney twigel, nagh jean eshyn keragh?

English: 11 The Lord knoweth the thoughts of man : that they are but vaine.
Manx: 11. Tá fyss ag y Chiarn er smẃnaghtyn y dwyney : nagh vell ayd agh fardáyl.

English: 12 Blessed is the man whom thou chastenest (O Lord :) and teachest him in thy Law;
Manx: 12. Baníit ta yn dwyne ta us dy ghwýskey, O Hiarn : as dy ynsaghey ayns tdy lyéìs;

English: 13 That thou mayest give him patience in time of adversitie : untill the pit be digged up for the ungodly.
Manx: 13. Gy vod us hyrráns y hóyrt dâsyn ayns ierish syaghyn : naggydere víis yn lagg erna roẃrey sýas d’ yn niawghrawi.

English: 14 For the Lord will not faile his people : neither will hee forsake his inheritance;
Manx: 14. Erson gha der yn Chiarn y phobyl náỳrdy : ghamẃ hréyg e y eirys.

English: 15 Untill righteousnes turne againe unto Judgement : all such as be true in heart shall follow it.
Manx: 15. Naggydere chyndáys káyrys ríist gys brẃinys : eigyrr an léid-syn wlly as ta firrinagh ayns krí e.

English: be true] 1662 are true
16 Who will rise up with me against the wicked : or who will take my part against the evill doers?
Manx: 16. Quei írriys shúas mâryms nýoi yn niawghráwi : na quei goys liams nan ýoisyn ta janw olk?

English: 17 If the Lord had not helped mee : it had not failed but my soule had bene put to silence.
Manx: 17. Managh beagh y Chiarn er gẃine láỳms : gha vodagh e ve nagh beagh m’ anym erna hóyrt na hóyst.
erna] ms. ern

English: 18 But when I said, My foote hath slipt : thy mercie (O Lord) held me up.
Manx: 18. Agh nar dwyrt mi, ta my ghass er skirraghtyn : [she] tdy vyghin, O Hiarn, ghẃmm shúas mi.

English: 19 In the multitude of the sorrowes that I had in my heart : thy comforts have refreshed my soule.
Manx: 19. Ayns ymmydi ny tryimshey va áỳms ayns my ghrí : ta tdy gyrjaghy ern’ ẃraghý m’ anyms.

English: 20 Wilt thou have any thing to do with the stoole of wickednesse : which imagineth mischiefe as a law?
Manx: 20. Bíi red erbi áyds d’ ianw rish stóyl yn niawghráwiys : ta smwnaghtyn skeley mar lýèi?

English: 21 They gather them together against the soule of the righteous : and condemne the innocent blood.
Manx: 21. T’ ayd d’ an jaglym kẃjaght nyoi anym yn dwyne ghayragh : as dýre yn ẃil gyn loght.

English: 22 But the Lord is my refuge : & my God is the strength of my confidence.
Manx: 22. Agh she yn Chiarn my ghemmirk : as she my Iíh gniart my hreistéel.

English: 23 He shall recompense them their wickednesse, and destroy them in their owne malice : yea, the Lord our God shall destroy them.
Manx: 23. Iíki e dawsyn nan beky, as strẃi e áyd ayns nan ganlys héyn : gy jarw, strẃi nan Jarn Jíh aydsyn.

English: The xix. day.
Manx: Yn xix. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Aryn.

English: Venite exultemus. Psal. 95.
Manx: Venite exultemus. psal. 95.

English: O come, let us sing unto the Lord : let us heartily rejoyce in the strength of our Salvation.
Manx: 1. O tredi, ligg win orayn y góyl gys y Chiarn : ligg ẃin gy krioil bogey y góyl ayns gniart nan sawálys.

English: 2 Let us come before his presence with thankesgiving : and shew our selves glad in him with Psalmes.
Manx: 2. Ligg win chíit na ienissyn rish toyrt bwias : as shwin héyn y hoilsaghy gyrjẃil aynsyn rish psalmyn.

English: 3 For the Lord is a great God : and a great King above all Gods.
Manx: 3. Erson ta yn Chiarn na Iíh vẃar : as na ríi vwar erskyn gygh wlly iíh.

English: 4 In his hand are all the corners of the earth : and the strength of the hils is his also.
Manx: 4. Ayns y lawynsyn ta wlly kwiltchyn y tallẃin : as [she] leshẏn gniart ny gnockanyn níist.

English: 5 The sea is his, and he made it : and his hands prepared the dry land.
Manx: 5. Shé leshsyn y farkey, as she ren é : as ren e láwynsyn arlw yn talw chiřrym.

English: 6 O Come, let us worship and fall downe : and kneele before the Lord our Maker.
Manx: 6. O tredi, lig win ammys y hóyrt as twitchym shíis : as slíaghti kian goyrt rish y Chiarn yn fér ghrẃ shwin.

English: 7 For he is (the Lord) our God : and we are the people of his pasture, and the sheepe of his hand.
Manx: 7. Erson she eshyn yn Chiarn nan Iíh : as she shwiniyn pobyl y phastyrsyn, as kirri y lawynsyn.

English: 8 To day if yee will heare his voyce, harden not your hearts : as in the provocation, and as in the day of temptation in the wildernesse;
Manx: 8. Ju ma níi shiu klastchen rish y ghorásyn, na kreigi nan gríaghyn : mar ayns y vrosnaghy, as mar ayns la y viǒwlaghy ayns yn ’asyght;

English: 9 When your fathers tempted me : prooved me, and saw my workes.
Manx: 9. Nar viowli ny háeraghyn aggw mish : héyr ayd magh mi, as ghonick áyd my obraghyn.

English: 10 Fortie yeeres long was I grieved with this generation, and said : It is a people that doe erre in their hearts, for they have not knowen my wayes;
Manx: 10. Rŷ dâ ’íid bléyn liaur va mish korri rish y chilogh shanoni, as dwyrt mi : she phobyl ta góyl as y ráyd ayns ’an griaghyn, erson ghanell ayd er doyrt enn er my ráydjyns;

English: 11 Unto whom I sware in my wrath : that they should not enter into my rest.
Manx: 11. Gawsyn ren mish lẃ ayns my ghorri : nagh jeanagh ayd goyl schiagh ayns my e.

English: Cantate Domino. Psal. 96.
Manx: Cantate domino. psal. 96.

English: O sing unto the Lord a new Song : sing unto the Lord all the whole earth.
Manx: 1. O gowgi d’ yn Chiarn oráyn nóo : gowigi orayn d’ yn Chiarn, wlly yn tallw sláyn.

English: 2 Sing unto the Lord, and praise his Name : be telling of his salvation from day to day.
Manx: 2. Gowigi oráyn d’ yn Chiarn, as molligi y enymsyn : bigi jinsh da hawálys-syn a[193] lá gy lá

English: 3 Declare his honour unto the heathen : and his wonders unto all people.
Manx: 3. Insigi y oneyrsyn dy ny hangristin : as y ientyssyn dy dygh wlly phobyl.

English: 4 For the Lord is great, and cannot worthily be praised : he is more to be feared then all gods.
Manx: 4. Erson sh’ mẃyr yn Chiarn, as gha vod e gy fiw ve erna volley : té nasmẃ dy góyl agyl róish na ny jighyn wlly.

English: 5 As for all the gods of the heathen, they bee but idoles : but it is the Lord that made the heavens.
Manx: 5. As erson jighyn wlly ny hangristín, gha vel áyd agh jallẃnyn : agh she yn Chiarn ren ny neawghyn.

English: they bee] 1662 they are
6 Glory and worship are before him : power and honour are in his Sanctuary.
Manx: 6. Ta glóyr as ammys na ienishyn : ta pẃeyr as oneyr ayns y heisyn kasserićk.

English: 7 Ascribe unto the Lord (O yee kinreds of the people :) ascribe unto the Lord worship and power.
Manx: 7. Toergi d’ yn Chiarn, Ó shiusse kínaghyn dyn phobyl : toergi dyn Chiarn ammys as pẃer.

English: 8 Ascribe unto the Lord the honour due unto his Name : bring presents, and come into his Courts.
Manx: 8. Toergi d’ yn Chiarn yn onéyr ta káyr dâ enym : toergi leyf giutyn, as targi schiagh ayns ny kwrtyn aggesyn.

English: 9 O worship the Lord in the beautie of holinesse : let the whole earth stand in awe of him.
Manx: 9. O jeanigi ammys d’ yn Chiarn ayns boíidj ghassrikys : ligg e yn talw wlly agyl y góyl jeshyn.

English: 10 Tell it out among the heathen, that the Lord is King : and that it is hee which hath made the round world so fast that it cannot bee mooved; and how that hee shall judge the people righteously.
Manx: 10. Iínsigi magh e másky ny hangristin, gy ne yn Chiarn sh’ Rii : as gy ne eshyn ren yn sýyl krwin gho sickyr nagh vod e ve erna skwghey, as kyns ni e yn phobyl y vrwinys gy káyr.

English: hee which] 1662 he who
11 Let the heavens rejoyce, and let the earth bee glad : let the sea make a noise, and all that therein is.
Manx: 11. Ligg e ny neawaghyn bogey y goyl, as ligg e yn tallw ve gannoil : ligg e yn farkey shían y ianw, as wlly na ta áyn.

English: 12 Let the field bee joyfull, and all that is in it : then shall all the trees of the wood rejoyce before the Lord.
Manx: 12. Ligg e yn magheyr be[194] gannoil ás wlly na ta ayn : eis gowi wlly bilchyn yn ghelliy bogey reyfs yn Chiarn.

English: 13 For he commeth, for hee commeth to judge the earth : and with righteousnesse to judge the world, and the people with his trueth.
Manx: 13. Erson t’ e chíit, erson t’ e chíit dy hóyrt brwinys er y tallw : as rish káyrys dy hoyrt brẃinys er y týyl as yn pobyl rish y irrinys.
t’ e chíit ´2] ms. t’ chíit ´2

English: Dominus regnauit. Psal. 97.
Manx: Dominus regnavit. [psal.] 97.

English: The Lord is King, the earth may be glad thereof : yea, the multitude of the Isles may be glad thereof.
Manx: 1. She yn Chiarn sh’ Ríi; fody yn talw ve gannoil je shen : gy jarw, foddi ymmydi ny’n ellanyn ve gannoil je.

English: 2 Cloudes and darkenesse are round about him : righteousnesse and judgement are the habitation of his seat.
Manx: 2. Ta bojalyn as dorghys krwnn magiyrt ymmishsyn : she káyrys as brwinys yn ynyd vaghey aggesyn.
ymmishsyn] ms. ymmshsyn

English: 3 There shall go a fire before him : and burne up his enemies on every side.
Manx: 3. Heid aínil reyfsyn : as loski e shúas y noidjyn er gygh ẃn cheyf.
loski] ms. loske

English: 4 His lightnings gave shine unto the world : the earth saw it and was afraid.
Manx: 4. Hwgg y ainilyn tarniagh soilshy d’ yn týyl : ghonick yn tallw e as ve aglagh.

English: 5 The hils melted like waxe at the presence of the Lord : at the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.
Manx: 5. Ren ny knwick liey kasly rish kéir ag feanish yn Chiarn : ag féanish Chiarn y týyl wlly.

English: 6 The heavens have declared his righteousnesse : and all the people have seene his glory.
Manx: 6. Ta ny neawaghyn ern’ insh y gháyrys : as ghonick wlly yn pobyl y glóyr.

English: 7 Confounded bee all they that worship carved images, and that delight in vaine gods : worship him all ye gods.
Manx: 7. Er an gwrr mow gy row aydsyn wlly ta janw ammys dy jallwnyn graynt, as ta agne ack ayns jiaghyn fardalagh : kwrgi ammys dasyn, shiusse iíaghyn wlly.

English: 8 Sion heard of it, and rejoyced : and the daughters of Juda were glad, because of thy Judgements, O Lord.
Manx: 8. Ghýyl Seion jê as gow e bogey : as va inínyn Iuda ganoil erson tdy vrẃinyssyn, O Hiarn.

English: 9 For thou Lord art higher then al that are in the earth : thou art exalted farre above all gods.
Manx: 9. Erson tow us, Hiarn, na sýrje na wlly na ta ayns y tallw : tow us trógit shýas fody erskyn ny jíaghyn wlly.

English: 10 O yee that love the Lord, see that yee hate the thing which is evill : the Lord preserveth the soules of his Saints; he shall deliver them from the hand of the ungodly.
Manx: 10. O shiusse ta grayi aggw er y Chiarn, jeaghigi gy bi dwoi aggw er yn red ta olk : ta yn Chiarn fríall anminiyn y nẃyn; lifréi e áyd vei law yn niawghrawi.
lifréi e] ms. lifréii

English: 11 There is sprung up a light for the righteous : and joyful gladnesse for such as be true hearted.
Manx: 11. Ta soilshe ern gáas[195] sýas d’ yn klyei ghayragh : as bogey gannoil dy léid as ta dy ghri firrinagh.

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
12 Rejoyce in the Lord ye righteous : and give thanks for a remembrance of his holinesse.
Manx: 12. Goẃigi bogey ayns y Chiarn, shiusse lýei kayragh : as toergi bwias erson kwine dyn ghasserick aggesyn.

English: The xix. day.
Manx: Yn xix.la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Cantate Domino. Psal. 98.
Manx: Cantate Domino. psal. 98.

English: O sing unto the Lord a new song : for hee hath done marveilous things.
Manx: 1. O gowigi oráyn nóo gys y Chiarn : erson te ern’ ianw redyn ientyssagh.

English: 2 With his owne right hand, and with his holy arme : hath he gotten himselfe the victory.
Manx: 2. Rish y law iesh héyn, as rish y rii ghasserick : te er veadthẏn ga héyn y varriyght.

English: 3 The Lord declared his salvation : his righteousnesse hath hee openly shewed in the sight of the heathen.
Manx: 3. Ta yn Chiarn er soilsaghy y hawálys : y ghayrys te erna hoilsaghey gy foskilt ayns silliy ny hangristín.

English: 4 He hath remembered his mercy and trueth toward the house of Israel : and all the ends of the world have seene the salvation of our God.
Manx: 4. T’ e er gwinaghtyn er y vyghin as yirriny gys tei Israel : as ta wlly kíinn y týyl er vackin sawálys nan Iíh.

English: 5 Shew your selves joyfull unto the Lord, all ye lands : sing, rejoyce, and give thankes.
Manx: 5. Soilshi shiu heyn gannoil gys y Chiarn, shiusse hallwnyn wlly : gowigi oráyn, gowji boge, as toergi bwias.

English: 6 Praise the Lord upon the Harpe : sing to the Harpe with a Psalme of thankesgiving.
Manx: 6. Mollígi yn Chiarn er y ghrw̌it : gowigi oráyn gys y ghrwit rish psalm dy vẃias y hoyrt.

English: 7 With trumpets also & shawmes : O shew your selves joyfull before the Lord the King.
Manx: 7. Rish trwmpetyn níist as psalmyn[196] : O soilshigi shiu héyn gyrjwil kiangoyrt rish y Chiarn yn ríi.

English: 8 Let the Sea make a noise, and all that therein is: the round world, and they that dwell therein.
Manx: 8. Ligg e yn farkey tyrmáyn[197] y ianw, as wlly na ta aynshen : yn sýyl krwin, as aydsyn ta vaghey áyn.

English: 9 Let the floods clap their hands, & let the hils be joyfull together before the Lord : for he is come to judge the earth.
Manx: 9. Ligg e ny lieanaghyn[198] ’an lawyn [y] voǎlley, as ligg e ny knwick ve gyrjẃil kẃjaght kiangoyrt rish y Chiarn : erson te er jít dy vrwinys y talw.

English: 10 With righteousnesse shall he judge the world : and the people with equitie.
Manx: 10. Rish káyrys níi e yn sýyl y vrwinys : as y pobyl rish korrymys.

English: Dominus regnauit. Psal. 99.
Manx: Dominus regnavit. psal. 99.

English: The Lord is King, be the people never so unpatient : hee sitteth betweene the Cherubims, bee the earth never so unquiet.
Manx: 1. She yn Chiarn y ríi gada[199] voyd anvé yn pobyl : tê sěi edyr ny cherẃbyn, kada voyd anve yn talw.
anvé yn pobyl] ms. an vé yn pobyl

English: 2 The Lord is great in Sion : and high above all people.
Manx: 2. Ta yn Chiarn mẃar ayns Seion : as ayrd erskin y pobyl wlly.

English: 3 They shall give thankes unto thy Name : which is Great, Wonderfull, and Holy.
Manx: 3. Ver ayd bwias dy t’ enyms : ta mwar, ientyssagh, as kasserick.

English: 4 The Kings power loveth Judgement; thou hast prepared equitie : thou hast executed Judgement, and righteousnesse in Jacob.
Manx: 4. Sh’ úney lesh pẃeyr yn ríi brwinys; tow ern’ ianw arlw káyr : as ern’ ianw brwinys as káyrys ayns Jakob.

English: 5 O magnifie the Lord our God : and fall downe before his footestoole, for he is Holy.
Manx: 5. O moligi gy hárd yn Chiarn nan Iíh : as twitchigi feanish stóyl y ghassyn, erson te kasserick.

English: 6 Moses and Aaron among his Priests, and Samuel among such as call upon his Name : these called upon the Lord, and he heard them.
Manx: 6. Moises as Aaron masky y hagartyn, as Samuel masky léid as ta gemagh er y enymsyn : jei áyd shó er y Chiarn, as ghýyl e áyd.

English: 7 He spake unto them out of the cloudy pillar : for they kept his Testimonies, and the Law that he gave them.
Manx: 7. Lóyr e riu magh as yn philler vójelagh : erson dríal ayd ny fenishyn aggesyn, as yn lýèi hwgg e daw.

English: 8 Thou heardest them (O Lord our God :) thou forgavest them, O God, and punishedst their owne inventions.
Manx: 8. Ghýyl ẃ áyd, O Hiarn nan Iíh : lyóig w daw, O Iíh, as tow er geraghy ny kwmmaghyn ack héyn.

English: 9 O magnifie the Lord our God, and worship him upon his Holy hill : for the Lord our God is Holy.
Manx: 9. O gloyrigi gy mẃar yn Chiarn nan Iíh, as kwrgi ammys gasyn er y ghnocksyn ghasserick : erson ta yn Chiarn nan Iíh kasserick.

English: Iubilate Deo. Psal. 100.
Manx: Jubilate deo. psal. 100.

English: O be joyfull in the Lord all ye lands : serve the Lord with gladnesse, and come before his presence with a Song.
Manx: 1. O bigi ganoil ayns y Chiarn, wlly shiusse hallwynyn : shervésigi yn Chiarn rish gian, as targi fenish y edynsyn lésh oráyn.

English: 2 Bee ye sure that the Lord he is God; it is he that hath made us, and not we our selves : we are his people, and the sheepe of his pasture.
Manx: 2. Bigi sickyr gy ré yn Chiarn Jih : she eshyn ren shwin as ghanie shwin héyn, she shwiniyn y phobylsyn, as kirri y phastyr.

English: 3 O goe your way into his Gates with thankesgiving, and into his Courts with praise : be thankefull unto him, and speake good of his Name.
Manx: 3. O shiuligi nan ráyd gys ny dorsyn aggesyn lesh bwias y hoyrt, as schiagh ayns y ghwrtynsyn rŷ moly : bigi bẃiasoil dasyn, as loyrgi gy mei da enymsyn.
loyrgi gy mei] ms. loyr gi mei

English: 4 For the Lord is gracious, his Mercie is everlasting : and his Trueth endureth from generation to generation.
Manx: 4. Erson ta yn Chiarn grasẃyl, ta y vyghin farraghtyn gybrágh : as ta [y] irrinys cheraghtyn[200] vei shilogh gys shilogh.

English: Misericordiam & iudicium. Psal. 101.
Manx: Misericordiam et iudicium. psal. 101.

English: My song shall bee of mercie and Judgement : unto thee, O Lord, will I sing.
Manx: 1. Bií m’ oráyn dy vyghin as brwinys : dwitch, O Hiarn, goyms oráyn.

English: 2 O let me have understanding : in the way of godlines.
Manx: 2. O ligg dow twiggel y geadthyn : ayns ráyd niaw ghrawiyght.[201]

English: 3 When wilt thou come unto mee : I will walke in my house with a perfect heart.
Manx: 3. Kẃin higg us hẃyms : immiyms ayns my hei rish kri jiragh.

English: 4 I will take no wicked thing in hand; I hate the sinnes of unfaithfulnesse : there shall no such cleave unto me.
Manx: 4. Ghá goym drogh red erbí ayns law; ta dwoi áỳm er pekaghyn yn niaw irrinys : gha jean veg léid shen liennaghtyn dẃỳs.

English: 5 A froward heart shal depart from me : I wil not know a wicked person.
Manx: 5. Héid kri frawyrtagh voyms : ghá derrym enn er drogh ẃney.

English: 6 Who so privily slandereth his neighbour : him will I destroy.
Manx: 6. Quei erbí ta kwrr liún er y nabẃ gynnys : strwiŷms é.

English: 7 Who so hath also a proud looke and high stomacke : I will not suffer him.
Manx: 7. Quei erbi níist ta shilliy morniagh agge as kri ayrd : gha syrryms é.

English: 8 Mine eyes looke upon such as be faithfull in the land : that they may dwell with me.
Manx: 8. Jeaghi my hwilyn er ’an léidsyn as ta firrinagh ayns y tallw : gy vod áyd vaghey maryms.

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
9 Who so leadeth a godly life : he shal be my servant.
Manx: 9. Quei erbi ta liidjéel bé ghráwi : bíi eshyn my hervaynts.

English: 10 There shall no deceitfull person dwell in my house : he that telleth lies shall not tary in my sight.
Manx: 10. Gha jean dwyne erbi maltóil vaghey ayns my hy̌ei : gha vwrri eshyn ta ginns bregyn ayns my hilliy.
maltoil] ms. m’ altoil

English: 11 I shall soone destroy all the ungodly that are in the land : that I may roote out all wicked doers from the Citie of the Lord.
Manx: 11. Strwiyms gy lýe wlly yn niawghrawi ta ayns y tallw : gy voddym wlly ta janw gy holk y rowry magh vei ayrd valley yn Chiarn.

English: The xx. day.
Manx: Yn xx. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Aryn.

English: Domine exaudi. Psal. 102.
Manx: Domine exaudi. psal. 102.

English: Heare my prayer, O Lord : and let my crying come unto thee.
Manx: 1. Klẁin my phaidjer, O Hiarn : as ligg e m’ emaght chíit hwyds.

English: 2 Hide not thy face from me in the time of my trouble : encline thine eares unto mee when I cal, O hear me, & that right soon.
Manx: 2. Na falli t’ edyns voyms ayns iérish my hyaghyn : krwmm tdy ghlýeshyn hwyms nar ta mi gemagh; O klẃin mi, as shen gy lýè.

English: thine eares] 1662 thine ear
3 For my dayes are consumed away like smoke : and my bones are burnt up as it were a firebrand.
Manx: 3. Erson ta my laghyn kéyst er shiul mar jeagh : as ta my ghnawyn loisk sýas, mar veagh e grísi.[202]

English: 4 My heart is smitten downe, and withered like grasse : so that I forget to eat my bread.
Manx: 4. Ta my ghri boiltch shíis as fióitch kasly rish féyr : marshen gy vel mish jarẃd dy íi m’ aran.

English: 5 For the voice of my groning : my bones wil scarse cleave to my flesh.
Manx: 5. Erson korá m’ akann : skawn ni my ghnawyn lianaghtyn rish m’ ’eyl.

English: 6 I am become like a Pelicane in the wildernesse : and like an Owle that is in the desert.
Manx: 6. Ta mish kasly rish pellikan ayns yn ’asygh : as mar én ny hyi ayns yn ynyd pháas.

English: 7 I have watched, and am even as it were a sparrow : that sitteth alone upon the house top.
Manx: 7. Ta mi ern’ arrey as ta mi gy jarrw mar véagh e jallwn : ta sěi nalymarkan er mwlagh yn ty̌i.
jallwn] ms. jallw

English: 8 Mine enemies revile me all the day long : and they that are mad upon me, are sworne together against me.
Manx: 8. Ta my nóidjyn lóyrt gy holk jîms fei yn lá : as ta aydsyn tá kyei orryms lẃitt kẃjaght m’ ýei.

English: 9 For I have eaten ashes as it were bread : and mingled my drinke with weeping;
Manx: 9. Erson ta mi ern’ íi ly̌éi mar aran : as er masky my iogh rish kẃo.

English: 10 And that because of thine indignation and wrath : for thou hast taken me up, and cast me downe.
Manx: 10. As shen erson tdy iwmẃiys as t’ ’arg : erson ta us er my góyl sýas, as er my hilge shíis.

English: 11 My dayes are gone like a shadow : and I am withered like grasse.
Manx: 11 Ta my lághyn ern’ ’oll er shiul mar skáa : as ta mi fiǒit mar féyr.

English: 12 But thou (O Lord) shalt endure for ever : and thy remembrance throughout all generations.
Manx: 12. Agh farríit us, O Hiarn, erson gybragh : as tdy ghwiney trýid magh gygh wlly hilógh.

English: 13 Thou shalt arise and have mercy upon Sion : for it is time that thou have mercy upon her, yea, the time is come.
Manx: 13. Irríit us as níi us myghin er Seion : erson sh’ mí[203] gy jean w myghin ẃřri, gy jarw ta yn ierish er jít.

English: 14 And why? thy servants thinke upon her stones: and it pitieth them to see her in the dust.
Manx: 14. As kamma? ta tdy herváyntyns smẃnaghtyn er ny klaghyn ecks : as s’ tréig lieu ish y akin ayns y jann.
s’ tréig] ms. tréig

English: 15 The heathen shall feare thy Name, O Lord : and all the Kings of the earth thy Majestie;
Manx: 15. Gowi ny hangristíin agyl dy t’ enyms, O Hiarn : as wlly riiyghyn d’ yn tállw t’ áyrd ýeslid;

English: 16 When the Lord shall builde up Sion : and when his glory shall appeare;
Manx: 16. Nar hrogys yn Chiarn syas Seion : as nar víis y gloyr erna akin;

English: 17 When hee turneth him unto the prayer of the poore destitute : and despiseth not their desire.
Manx: 17. Nar tê chyndá [e] gys padjer yn voght trégit : as gyn seiaghe beg d’ ’an aghin.

English: 18 This shal be written for those that come after: and the people which shal be borne shall praise the Lord.
Manx: 18. Bíi shó erna skriw dawsyn ta chíit na ýre : as molli yn sly̌ei víis er nan mré yn Chiarn.

English: 19 For hee hath looked downe from his Sanctuarie : out of the heaven did the Lord behold the earth;
Manx: 19. Erson íagh é núas vei y ynyd kasserićk : magh as neaw iagh yn Chiarn er y tallw;

English: 20 That hee might heare the mournings of such as be in captivitie : and deliver the children appointed unto death;
Manx: 20. Gy vodagh é yn dobran leidsyn ta ayns kapy y ghlastchyn : as dy lifré yn ghlawn ta er nan ordyghy gys báas;

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
21 That they may declare the Name of the Lord in Sion : and his worship at Hierusalem;
Manx: 21. Gy vod ayd enym y Chiarn y insh ayns Seion : as y ammys ag Jeriusalem;

English: 22 When the people are gathered together : and the kingdomes also, to serve the Lord.
Manx: 22. Nar ta yn pobyl chiaglit
kẃjaght : as ny ririaghtyn níist dy hyrvés yn Chiarn.

English: 23 Hee brought downe my strength in my journey: and shortened my dayes.
Manx: 23. Hwgg e núas my gniart ayns my iwrné : as iarr e my laghyn.

English: 24 But I said, O my God, take me not away in the middest of mine age : as for thy yeeres, they endure throughout all generations.
Manx: 24. Agh dwyrt mi, O my Iíh, na gow mi er shiul ayns méyn m’ ýesh : as erson tdy vleinchyn, t’ ayd farraghtyn trýid gygh wlly hilógh.

English: 25 Thou Lord in the beginning hast layd the foundation of the earth : and the heavens are the worke of thy hands.
Manx: 25. Ta us, O Hiarn, ayns y tossiagh er seiaghe bẃnn y tallwin : as she ny niawghyn ober tdy lawyn.

English: 26 They shall perish, but thou shalt endure : they all shall waxe old as doeth a garment;
Manx: 26. Heid aydsyn mow, agh farri us : níi aydsyn wlly goyl shentiyght mar ta komry.

English: 27 And as a vesture shalt thou change them, & they shal be changed : but thou art the same, and thy yeeres shall not faile.
Manx: 27. As mar ydagh ni us áydsyn y ghyghlá, as bi ayd kyghlit : agh she us anáyn kedyn, as ghá dèr tdy vleinchyn nárdy.

English: 28 The children of thy servants shall continue : and their seed shall stand fast in thy sight.
Manx: 28. Níi klawn tdy hervayntyn tynnaghtyn : as shassi e sliwght sickyr ayns tdy hilliys.
e sliwght] ms. i Sliwght

English: Benedic anima. Psal. 103.
Manx: Benedic anima. psal. 103.

English: Praise the Lord, O my soule : and all that is within mee, praise his holy Name.
Manx: 1. Moll yn Chiarn, O my anym : as wlly ta er léf stei jims, moligi y enymsyn kasserick.

English: 2 Praise the Lord, O my soule : and forget not all his benefits;
Manx: 2. Mol yn Chiarn, O my anym : as na jarẃd wlly ny toyrtyssyn aggesyn;

English: 3 Which forgiveth all thy sinne : and healeth all thine infirmities;
Manx: 3. Ta lyǒi wlly tdy pheky : as slaynaghy wlly t’ anẃniys;

English: Which] 1662 Who
4 Which saveth thy life from destruction : and crowneth thee with mercie and loving kindnesse;
Manx: 4. Ta sawáyl tdy vée vei kall : as ta kwrr attaghan oy̌rt rish myghin as dwghys grayigẃil.

English: Which] 1662 Who
Manx: dwghys] ms. dwiys

English: 5 Which satisfieth thy mouth with good things : making thee young and lustie as an Eagle.
Manx: 5. Ta liény tdy véal rish redyn mei : ta dy ianw áag as lẃr mar ýlrey.[204]

English: Which] 1662 Who
6 The Lord executeth righteousnesse and Judgement : for all them that are oppressed with wrong.
Manx: 6. Ta yn Chiarn janw káyrys as bríunys : daŵsyn wlly ta kwmmit shíis ry agáyr.

English: 7 Hee shewed his wayes unto Moses : his workes unto the children of Israel.
Manx: 7. Iágh e y rádjyn dy Vóyses : y obraghyn dy ghlawn Israel.

English: 8 The Lord is full of compassion and mercy : long suffering and of great goodnesse.
Manx: 8. Ta yn Chiarn láyn dy hrei as dy vyghin : syrrel fodey, as dy véìys mẃar.

English: 9 He will not alway be chiding : neither keepeth hee his anger for ever.
Manx: 9. Gha bíi e goni tródje : ghamẃ t’ e kwmmel y ghorri erson gybragh.

English: 10 He hath not dealt with us after our sinnes : nor rewarded us according to our wickednesse.
Manx: 10. Gha ren e rwiniyn nyre nan beky : ghamẃ jík e shwin nyre nan olkys.

English: wickednesse] 1662 wickednesses
11 For looke how high the heaven is in comparison of the earth : so great is his mercy also toward them that feare him.
Manx: 11. Erson jeagh ghó áyrd as ta yn neaw shaghey yn tallw : gho mẃar ta y vyghin-syn níist dawsyn ta goyl agyl reyf.

English: 12 Looke how wide also the East is from the West : so farre hath he set our sinnes from us.
Manx: 12. Jeagh gho líèn níist as ta yn iàrr vei yn ièrr : ghowd shen te er dóyrt nan bekaghyn voiniyn.
ghowd] ms. ghow

English: 13 Yea, like as a father pitieth his owne children : even so is the Lord mercifull unto them that feare him.
Manx: 13. Gy jarw, mar ta áer góyl treyi er y ghlawn héyn : gy jarw marshen ta yn Chiarn trokroil dáẁsyn ta goyl agyl je-shyn.

English: 14 For he knoweth whereof we be made : he remembereth that we are but dust.
Manx: 14. Erson sáẁn dasyn kre ié ta shwin jant : te kẃìnaghy nagh vell shwin ag jann.

English: be made] 1662 are made
15 The dayes of man are but as grasse : for he flourisheth as a flower of the field.
Manx: 15. Gha vel laghyn gwyne agh mar féyr : erson te gáas mar losserinyn yn vagheir.

English: 16 For assoone as the winde goeth over it, it is gone: and the place thereof shall know it no more.
Manx: 16. Erson gho lye as ta yn gýa ern oll harrish, te er shiul : as gha náwn d’ yn ynyd agge e áragh.

English: 17 But the mercifull goodnesse of the Lord endureth for ever and ever, upon them that feare him: and his righteousnesse upon childrens children;
Manx: 17. Agh ta méiys hrokroil yn Chiarn farraghtyn erson gybrágh as gybrágh, oriǔsyn ta goyl agyl jê : as y gháyrys er klaẃn ghlenniy.

English: 18 Even upon such as keepe his Covenant : and thinke upon his Commandements to doe them.
Manx: 18. Gy jarw er léid as ta frial y ghẃnayntsyn : as smwnaghtyn er y abertsyn [...].

English: 19 The Lord hath prepared his seate in heaven : and his kingdome ruleth over all.
Manx: 19. Ta yn Chiarn ern’ ianw arlw y ynyd ayns néaw : as ta yn ririyght aggesyn réel harrish wlly.

English: 20 O praise the Lord, ye Angels of his, yee that excell in strength : yee that fulfill his Commandement, and hearken unto the voyce of his words.
Manx: 20. O moligi yn Chiarn, shiusse aínilyn aggesyn, [shiusse] smw ayns gniart : shiusse ta kwiliny y abertsyn, as klastchen rish kóra y góyn.

English: 21 O praise the Lord all ye his hostes : yee servants of his that doe his pleasure.
Manx: 21. O moligi yn Chiarn, shiusse wlly y heshaghtyn ghagi-syn : shiusse ny sherváyntyn aggesyn ta janw y agney.

English: 22 O speake good of the Lord all ye workes of his, in all places of his dominion : Praise thou the Lord, O my soule.
Manx: 22. O lóyrigi mei d’ yn Chiarn, shiusse wlly ny hobraghyn aggesyn, ayns gygh wlly ynyd dâ réelsyn : mol us yn Chiarn, O m’ anym.

English: The xx. day.
Manx: Yn xx. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Benedic anima mea. Psal.104.
Manx: Benedic anima mea. psal. 104.

English: Praise the Lord, O my soule : O Lord my God, thou art become exceeding glorious; thou art clothed with Majestie and honour.
Manx: 1. Moll yn Chiarn, O m’ anym : O Hiarn my Iíh, ta us fíir gloróil; tow komrit rish ayrd ýaslid as oneyr.

English: 2 Thou deckest thy selfe with light as it were with a garment : and spreadest out the heavens like a curtaine.
Manx: 2. Toŵ dy tdy ghayraghy[205] héyn rish soilshey, mar véagh e ry ydagh : as skyley magh ny neawghyn mar kwrtayn;

English: 3 Which layeth the beames of his chamber in the waters : and maketh the cloudes his charet, and walketh upon the wings of the winde.
Manx: 3. Ta toyrt showtyn[206] y hiámbyr ayns ny hẃiskaghyn : as janw charedyn dâ dy ny bojalyn, as gimmiaght er skanyn yn gýei.

English: Which] 1662 Who; chamber, 1599, 1636] 1660, 1662 chambers
4 He maketh his Angels spirits : and his ministers a flaming fire.
Manx: 4. Te janw y áinilyn nan spyrydyn : as y hervési nan ainilyn lossy.
Te] ms. Ta

English: 5 Hee layde the foundations of the earth : that it never should moove at any time.
Manx: 5. Hy̌ei e shíis chymsym[207] yn tallwin : nagh beágh é erna skwghey ag iérish erbi.
beagh é] ms. beágé

English: 6 Thou coveredst it with the deepe like as with a garment : the waters stand in the hilles.
Manx: 6. Ghwr[208] us é rish y déifnid nash mar rish ydagh : ta ny hwiskaghyn shassẃ ayns ny knwick.
Ghwr us] ms. Ghwrys

English: 7 At thy rebuke they flee : at the voyce of thy thunder they are afraid.
Manx: 7. Ag t’ aghsan t’ áyd ché : agg kora dy hárniaghs t’ ayd agylagh.

English: 8 They goe up as high as the hilles, and downe to the valleys beneath : even unto the place which thou hast appointed for them.
Manx: 8. T’ áyd doll sýas gho ayrd as ny knwick, as shíis gys ny kónyn híis : gy jarw gys yn ýnyd tow us erna ordyghe dawsyn.

English: 9 Thou hast set them their bounds which they shall not passe : neither turne againe to cover the earth.
Manx: 9. Tow er seiaghe daw ’an gadlaghyn[209] nagh jed áyd shaghey : na chyndá ríist dy ghẃdaghy yn tallw.

English: 10 He sendeth the springs into the rivers : which runne among the hilles.
Manx: 10. Te toyrt ny chibbraghyn gys ny strẃanyn : ta rýi masky ny knwick.
Te] ms. Ta

English: 11 All beasts of the field drinke thereof : and the wilde asses quench their thirst.
Manx: 11. Ta wlly alagh yn vagheir gíf jé : as ny hassylyn kyêi kwir nan báa.

English: 12 Besides them shall the foules of the aire have their habitation : and sing among the branches.
Manx: 12. Liorish-syn ag éynli yn áeyr bii ynyd vaghey : as níi ayd bínnys masky ny banglanyn.

English: Besides, 1636] 1599, 1660 Beside
13 Hee watereth the hilles from above : the earth is filled with the fruit of thy workes.
Manx: 13. Te gwiskaghy ny knwick vei núas : ta yn tallẃ lienitch rish méas t’ obraghyns.
Te] ms. Ta

English: 14 Hee bringeth foorth grasse for the cattell : and greene herbe for the service of men;
Manx: 14. Tê toyrt magh féir d’ yn allagh : as luss glass dy hervées geney;

English: 15 That hee may bring food out of the earth, & wine that maketh glad the heart of man : and oile to make him a cheerefull countenance, and bread to strengthen mans heart.
Manx: 15. Gy vod e bi y hoyrt as y tallw, as phíyn ta janẃ ganoil krí yn dwyne : as ẃil dy ianw dâ éi ganoil, as aran dy gniartaghy kri gwyney.

English: 16 The trees of the Lord also are full of sap : even the Cedars of Libanus, which he hath planted;
Manx: 16. Ta bilćhyn yn Chiarn láyn dy happ : gy jarw cedyryn Libanus ta eshyn erna heiaghy.

English: 17 Wherein the birdes make their nestes : and the Firre-trees are a dwelling for the Storke.
Manx: 17. Aynshen ta ny héynli janw nan ídj : as ta ny bilchyn jẃys nan ynyd vaghi d’ yn stóyrk.

English: 18 The high hilles are a refuge for the wilde goates : and so are the stony rockes for the conies.
Manx: 18. Ta ny knwick árdy ynyd kemmirk dy ny góyr kýèi : as marshen ta ny kregyn klagh ghon ny koninyn.

English: 19 He appointed the Moone for certaine seasons : and the Sunne knoweth his going downe.
Manx: 19. Dordi é yn éask ghon shértayn d’ iérishyn : as sawn d’ yn grian y goll shíis.

English: 20 Thou makest darknesse that it may be night : wherein al the beasts of the Forest do moove.
Manx: 20. Tow janw dorghys gy vod e vé yn ýì : aynshen ta wlly béin yn klew[210] glýasaght.

English: 21 The Lions roaring after their praye : doe seeke their meat at God.
Manx: 21. Ta ny leionyn bwriẃgh nyre nan gregh : shyrre nan mi er Jih.

English: at God] 1662 from God
Manx: shyrre] ms. hyrre

English: 22 The Sunne ariseth, and they get them away together : and lay them downe in their dennes.
Manx: 22. Ta yn grian girri, as t’ áyd doll er shiul kẃjaght : as t’ áyd ly̌ei shíis ayns nan widjyn.[211]

English: 23 Man goeth foorth to his worke, and to his labour : untill the evening.
Manx: 23. Ta dwyne doll magh gâ obyr as dâ labraght : naggedere y faskyr.

English: 24 O Lord, how manifolde are thy workes : in wisdome hast thou made them all; the earth is full of thy riches.
Manx: 24. O Hiarn, gho ymmydi as ta t’ obraghyns : ayns krinyght ren ẃ ayd wlly; ta yn talw láyn dy tdy verchys.

English: 25 So is the great and wide sea also : wherein are things creeping innumerable, both small and great beasts.
Manx: 25. Marshen ta yn fárkey mẃar as léan níist : yn iynyd ta reddyn snáw gyn érif, béstchyn begy as mwary níist.

English: 26 There goe the shippes, and there is that Leviathan: whom thou hast made to take his pastime therein.
Manx: 26. Aynshen ta ny lonǧyn doll, as aynshen ta yn Leviathan shen : tow us erna ianw dy góyl y ghlwi áynshen.

English: 27 These wait all upon thee : that thou mayest give them meate in due season.
Manx: 27. T’ áyd shó wlly farkiaght oyrts : gy vod us bi y hoyrt daw ayns iérish ghẃi.

English: 28 When thou givest it them they gather it : & when thou openest thy hand they are filled with good.
Manx: 28. Nar tow dy hoyrt daw e, t’ áyd dâ haglym : as nar tow foskyly tdy law, t’ áyd lienitch rish mei.

English: 29 When thou hidest thy face, they are troubled : when thou takest away their breath, they die, and are turned againe to their dust.
Manx: 29. Nar tow fallaghey t’ edyn, t’ ayd sy̌it : nar tow goyl er shiul nan anel, t’ áyd marrw, as t’ áyd chyndait ríist gys an jann.

English: 30 When thou lettest thy breath goe foorth they shall bee made : and thou shalt renue the face of the earth.
Manx: 30. Nar tow ligge dy t’ annel doll magh, bíi áyd jant : as níit us nóo ríist edyn yn talwin.

English: 31 The glorious Majestie of the Lord shall endure for ever : the Lord shall rejoyce in his workes.
Manx: 31. Nií ýeslid gloróil yn Chiarn fannaghtyn erson gybragh : gowi yn Chiarn bogey ayns y obraghyn.

English: 32 The earth shal tremble at the looke of him : if he do but touch the hilles, they shall smoke.
Manx: 32. Níi yn tallw krá ag yn chilliy aggesyn : managh jean é agh benelt rish ny knwick, níi ayd jéagh.

English: 33 I will sing unto the Lord as long as I live : I will praise my God, while I have my being.
Manx: 33. Goyms oráyn dyn Chiarn ghowd as viim bio : mollym my Iíh, ghowd as bíìm er marn.

English: 34 And so shall my wordes please him : my joy shall bee in the Lord.
Manx: 34. As shen mar níi my góyn eshyn y vwiys : bíi my voggey ayns y Chiarn.

English: 35 As for sinners, they shall be consumed out of the earth, and the ungodly shall come to an ende : praise thou the Lord, O my soule, praise the Lord.
Manx: 35. As erson peki, bíi áyd er an gwrr mow as y tallw, as higg yn niawghráẃi gys kian : moll us yn Chiarn, O m’ anym, moll y Chiarn.

English: The xxi. day.
Manx: Yn xxi. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Aryn.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 105.
Manx: Confitemini Domino. psal. 105.

English: O give thankes unto the Lord, and call upon his Name : tell the people what things he hath done.
Manx: 1. O toergi bwias d’ yn Chiarn, as éigi er y enymsyn : insh[212] d’ yn phobyl kre ny redyn tê erna ianw.

English: 2 O let your songs bee of him, and praise him : and let your talking bee of all his wonderous workes.
Manx: 2. O ligg dy ny horányn aggwish ve jêsyn, as molligi é : as ligg e nan daglẃ ve ié wlly ny hobraghyn ientysagh aggesyn.

English: 3 Rejoyce in his holy Name : let the heart of them rejoyce that seeke the Lord.
Manx: 3. Bigi gannoil ayns y enymsyn kasserick : ligg e yn kri acksyn ve gannoil ta shyirre yn Chiarn.

English: 4 Seeke the Lord & his strength : seeke his face evermore.
Manx: 4. Shyrrigi yn Chiarn as y gniart : shyirrigi y edynsyn gybragh.

English: 5 Remember the marveilous works that he hath done : his wonders, and the Judgements of his mouth,
Manx: 5. Kwinigi er ny hobraghyn iéntyssagh ren eshyn : y ientyssyn, as brwinyssyn y véal,

English: 6 O ye seede of Abraham his servant : yee children of Jacob his chosen.
Manx: 6. O shiusse rass Abraham y herváynt : O shiusse ghlawn Iakob y ry̌isyn.

English: 7 Hee is the Lord our God : his Judgements are in all the world.
Manx: 7. She eshyn yn Chiarn nan Iíh : ta ny brwinyssyn aggesyn ayns y týyl wlly.

English: 8 He hath bene alway mindfull of his Covenant and promise : that he made to a thousand generations;
Manx: 8. Vê riu kwinaghtyn er y ghẃnaynt as ialtyn : ren e dy hẃsáyn shiloghyn.

English: 9 Even the Covenant that he made with Abraham: and the othe that he sware unto Isahac;
Manx: 9. Gy jarw yn kẃnaynt ren e rish Abraham : as yn lẃ, lẃ e dy Isaak;

English: Isahac] 1660 Isaac
10 And appointed the same unto Jacob for a Lawe : and to Israel for an everlasting Testament;
Manx: 10. As dordi e shen dy Iakob ghon lyěi : as dy Israel ghon chymné gybragh farraghtyn;

English: 11 Saying, Unto thee will I give the land of Chanaan : the lot of your inheritance;
Manx: 11. Grá, dwitch verrym tallw Ghanáan : kranghyr yn eirys agwish.

English: 12 When there were yet but a few of them : & they strangers in the land;
Manx: 12. Trá nagh row fóyst agh beggan jûsyn : as áyd nan jorinyn ayns y tallẃ;

English: 13 What time as they went from one nation to another : from one kingdome to another people;
Manx: 13. Yn trá ghái ayd vei yn átiẃn gys átiẃn elle : vei yn ririyght gys pobyl elle.

English: 14 Hee suffered no man to doe them wrong : but reproved even Kings for their sakes;
Manx: 14. Ghá ligg e [e] dwyne erbi dy ianw agáyr dáẁ : agh hwgg e aghsan dy riaghyn er ’an son-syn.

English: 15 Touch not mine Anointed : and doe my Prophets no harme.
Manx: 15. Na bennigi my alit : as na jeanigi veg y skeley dy my ’aderyn.

English: 16 Moreover, he called for a dearth upon the land : and destroyed all the provision of bread.
Manx: 16. Harrish shen, jei é er genniy er y tallw : as strwi é wlly yn arlaghy d’ áran.
arlaghy] ms. artaghy

English: 17 But hee had sent a man before them : even Joseph which was sold to be a bond servant;
Manx: 17. Agh hwgg e dwyney rẃỳmbwsyn : gy jarw Joseph, va erna ghreck dy ve na vóyndy.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: hwgg] ms. hwgge

English: 18 Whose feete they hurt in the stocks : the yron entered into his soule;
Manx: 18. Gorti áyd ny kassyn aggesyn ayns ny stokkyn : ghá[213] yn iern schiagh ayns y anym;

English: 19 Untill the time came that his cause was knowen: the word of the Lord tried him.
Manx: 19. Naggedere haink yn ierish gy row y ghẃish erna ianw fysseri : ren fokyl yn Chiarn y hyirre magh é.

English: 20 The King sent and delivered him : the Prince of the people let him goe free.
Manx: 20. Hwgg yn ríi fyss as lifre [e] eshyn : ligg kiannẃrtys y phobyl dasyn goll sýyr.

English: 21 He made him lord also of his house : and ruler of all his substance;
Manx: 21. Ren e Chiarn jeshyn niist dâ hei : as fer réel dâ ghwid wlly;

English: 22 That he might informe his princes after his wil : and teach his Senators wisedome.
Manx: 22. Gy vodagh é ý phrinsaghyn y yńsaghey nyre y agney : as krinyght y ýnsaghé dâ ’irr ghwrley.

English: 23 Israel also came into Egypt : and Jacob was a stranger in the land of Ham.
Manx: 23. Haink Israel niist gys Éjipt : as va Jacob na ’er jori ayns tallw Hamm.

English: 24 And hee increased his people exceedingly : and made them stronger then their enemies;
Manx: 24. As hwgg e er y phobyl gaás gy fíir vẃar : as ren e aydsyn naslaidjery na nan noidjyn.

English: 25 Whose heart turned, so that they hated his people : and dealt untruely with his servants.
Manx: 25. Hynda yn kri acksyn, marshen gy row dẃoi ačk er y phobyl : as ren ayd gy niaw irrinagh ra herváyntyn.

English: 26 Then sent hee Moses his servant : and Aaron whom he had chosen.
Manx: 26. Eish hwgg e Moyses y herváynt : as Aaron, ve erna ry̌i.

English: 27 And these shewed his tokens among them : and wonders in the land of Ham.
Manx: 27. As iagh áyd shó y ghoraghyn nan maskey-syn : as y ientyssyn ayns tallw Hamm.

English: 28 He sent darknesse, and it was darke : and they were not obedient unto his word.
Manx: 28. Hwgg e dorghys, as vé dorghy : as gha row áyd arrymagh gys y ’okyll.

English: 29 He turned their waters into blood : and slue their fish.
Manx: 29. Hyndá e nan wiskaghyn gys fwill : as varrw e ny hieskyn acksyn.

English: 30 Their land brought foorth frogs : yea, even in their Kings chambers.
Manx: 30. Hwgg nan dallw magh froggyn : [gy jarw,] ayns shiameryn nan riaghyn.

English: 31 Hee spake the word, and there came all manner of flies : and lice in all their quarters.
Manx: 31. Loyr e yn fokyl, as haink gygh wlly véney[214] ghorghwilagyn : as miylyn ayns nan gerifnyn[215] wlly.

English: 32 He gave them hailestones for raine : and flames of fire in their land.
Manx: 32. Hwgg e daw klaghyn snaghti erson flaghy : as losseryn d’ áinil ayns nan dallw.

English: 33 He smote their vines also and figtrees : and destroyed the trees that were in their coasts.
Manx: 33. Voàil e nan milchyn phiyn níist as nan milchyn fiygagh : as strwi e ny bilchyn va ayns [nan] jir.

English: 34 He spake the word, and the grashoppers came, and caterpillers innumerable : and did eate up all the grasse in their land, and devoured the fruit of their ground.
Manx: 34. Lóyr e yn fokyl as haink ny kellirennagh as brattagyn gyn éryf : as jí ayd sýas yn féyr wlly ayns nan dallw, [...][216].

English: 35 He smote all the first borne in their land : even the chiefe of all their strength.
Manx: 35. Vóàil e wlly na rwgg hossiagh ayns nan dallw : gy jarw áydsyn byrrymi[217] d’ an gniart wlly.

English: 36 He brought them forth also with silver and gold : there was not one feeble person among their tribes.
Manx: 36. Hwgg e magh ayd niist lesh argyd as áyr : gha row yn wyne anẃyn masky ny kinaghyn acksyn.

English: 37 Egypt was glad at their departing : for they were afraid of them.
Manx: 37. Va Éjipt níist ganoil d’ an immiaght er shiul : erson v’ ayd aglagh [rymbẃ].

English: 38 Hee spread out a cloud to be a covering : and fire to give light in the night season.
Manx: 38. Skýyl e magh bojal dy ve na ghwdey : as ainil dy hoyrt soilshe lesh[218] yíì.

English: 39 At their desire he brought quailes : and hee filled them with the bread of heaven.
Manx: 39. Ag nan agney hwgg e daw qaylyn[219] : as lién e áyd rish aran neawagh.

English: 40 Hee opened the rocke of stone, and the waters flowed out : so that Rivers ranne in the dry places.
Manx: 40. Doskyl e yn ghreg ghlagh, as liyn[220] ny hwiskaghyn magh : marshen gy ren oanyn[221] ry̌i ayns ynydyn chirrym.
