English: 41 For why? he remembred his holy Promise : and Abraham his servant.
Manx: 41. As kamma? ghwíni e er y iáltyn kasserick : as Abraham y herváynt.

English: 42 And he brought forth his people with joy : and his chosen with gladnesse;
Manx: 42. As hwgg e magh y phobyl rish bogey : as y sly̌ei ry̌it ry gann.

English: 43 And gave them the landes of the Heathen : and they tooke the labours of the people in possession;
Manx: 43. As hwgg e daw tallwinyn ny hangristín : as gow ayd obraghyn yn phobyl ayns éirys;

English: 44 That they might keep his statutes : & observe his laws.
Manx: 44. Gy vodagh áyd y lattysyn y riáal : as y lýòiyn y ghwmmel.

English: The xxi. day.
Manx: Yn xxi. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 106.
Manx: Confitemini Domino. psal. 106.

English: O give thankes unto the Lord, for he is gracious : and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1. O toergi bwias d’ yn Chiarn, erson te grasoil : as ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 2 Who can expresse the noble acts of the Lord : or shew foorth all his praise?
Manx: 2. Quei odys obraghyn ýasyl yn Chiarn y íinsh : na wlly y volley y hoyrt magh?

English: 3 Blessed are they that alway keepe Judgement : and doe righteousnesse.
Manx: 3. Baníit ta aydsyn ta goni frial briẃnys : as janw kayrys.

English: 4 Remember me, O Lord, according to the favour that thou bearest unto thy people : O visit me with thy salvation;
Manx: 4. Kẃini orryms, O Hiarn, nyre yn fóer tow dy ymmyrkey dy tdy phobyl : O jeagh orryms rish tdy haẃalys;

English: 5 That I may see the felicitie of thy chosen : and rejoyce in the gladnesse of thy people, and give thankes with thine inheritance.
Manx: 5. Gy voddyms maynre tdy rýèis y akin : as boggey y goyl ayns gann tdy phobyl, as bwias y hoyrt marish t’ eirys.

English: 6 Wee have sinned with our fathers : wee have done amisse, and dealt wickedly.
Manx: 6. Ta shwin ern ianw peky marish nan áeraghyn : ta shwin ern ianw fóil, as ren shwin gy holk.

English: 7 Our fathers regarded not thy wonders in Egypt, neither kept they thy great goodnesse in remembrance : but were disobedient at the Sea, even at the Red sea.
Manx: 7. Gha gow nan áeraghyn taskey dy t’ ientyssyns ayns Ejipt, ghamw drial ayd tdy veiys vwar ayns kwiney : agh v’ áyd miarrymagh ag yn arkey, gy jarw ag yn arkey Iarg.

English: 8 Neverthelesse, he helped them for his Names sake : that he might make his power to be knowen.
Manx: 8. Na iei, ghwyn e lieu erson grayi y enym : gy voddagh y phẃer y ianw fysserit.
ghwyn] ms. ghwym

English: 9 He rebuked the Red sea also, and it was dried up : so he led them through the deepe, as through a wildernesse.
Manx: 9. Hwgg e aghsan d’ yn arkey Iárg níist, as ve chirmit súas : marshen líid e aydsyn tréyd yn deifnid, mar tréyfd fásyght.

English: 10 And he saved them from the adversaries hand : and delivered them from the hand of the enemy.
Manx: 10. As haw e áyd vei yn law acksyn ta nan ýoi : as lifrée eshyn ayd vei law yn nóid.

English: 11 As for those that troubled them, the waters overwhelmed them : there was not one of them left.
Manx: 11. As er nan-son-syn ren áydsyn y hýaghyn, haink ny hwiskaghyn harrystw : gha row anáyn acksyn erna agáel.

English: 12 Then beleeved they his words : & sang praise unto him.
Manx: 12. Éish ghréd aydsyn ny fokelyn aggesyn : as gow ayd oráyn molley dasyn.

English: 13 But within a while they forgat his works : and would not abide his counsell.
Manx: 13. As er léyf stei dy gerid iarẃd áyd ny hobraghyn aggesyn : as gha vannagh ayd y ghórliy.

English: 14 But lust came upon them in the wildernesse : and they tempted God in the desert.
Manx: 14. Agh haink saint orřw ayns yn áysygh : as viowli ayd Jih ayns yn ’áysygh.

English: 15 And he gave them their desire : and sent leannesse withall into their soule.
Manx: 15. As hwgg e daw an agney : as ghwrr e kýylid níist ayns yn anym acksyn.

English: 16 They angered Moses also in the tents : and Aaron the Saint of the Lord.
Manx: 16. Ghwrr ayd korri er Móises níist ayns ny kabanyn : as Áaron, nẃ yn Chiarn.
Ghwrr] ms. kwrr

English: 17 So the earth opened, and swallowed up Dathan : and covered the congregation of Abiram.
Manx: 17. Marshen doskyl yn tallw as hlwgg e súas Dathan : as ghwdi e shessaght Abiram.

English: 18 And the fire was kindled in their company : the flame burnt up the ungodly.
Manx: 18. As ren yn áinil lossy ayns nan shessaght : as losk yn losser shúas yn niawghrawi.

English: 19 They made a calfe in Horeb : and worshipped the molten image.
Manx: 19. Ren ayd ly̌ei ayns Horeb : as ren ayd ammys d’ yn jallw liěitt.

English: 20 Thus they turned their glory : into the similitude of a calfe that eateth hay.
Manx: 20. Marsho hyndá ayd nan glóer : gys kaslys lyěi ta gii trágh.

English: 21 And they forgat God their Saviour : which had done so great things in Egypt;
Manx: 21. As iarẃd ayd Jih nan sawalagh : va erna ianw reddyn gho mẃar ayns Ejipt;

English: which] 1662 who
22 Wonderous works in the land of Ham : and fearefull things by the Red sea.
Manx: 22. Obraghyn iéntysagh ayns tallw Ham : as redyn aglagh ayns yn arkey Iarg.

English: 23 So he said he would have destroyed them, had not Moses his chosen stand before him in the gap : to turne away his wrathfull indignation, lest he should destroy them.
Manx: 23. Marshen dwyrt e gy beagh e er an strẃi áyd, managh bée[222] gy hass Moises y ’er ry̌it réyfsyn ayns y vayrny : dy hynda er shiul y ghorri jumẃysagh, nagh strwiagh é aydsyn.

English: stand, 1599] 1636, 1660 stood
Manx: gy beagh] ms. gebeagh

English: 24 Yea, they thought scorne of that pleasant land : and gave no credence unto his word;
Manx: 24. Gy jarw, by ghnáid lio yn tallw eunysagh shen : as gha dwgg ayd veg y ghredjel dâ okelsyn.

English: 25 But murmured in their tents : and hearkened not unto the voyce of the Lord.
Manx: 25. Agh ren ayd tallagh ayns nan gabbanyn : as gha ghlast ayd rish korá yn Chiarn.

English: 26 Then lift he up his hand against them : to overthrow them in the wildernesse;
Manx: 26. Eish hrogg e shýas y law nan yói-syn : d’ an dilge harrish ayns yn asygh;

English: 27 To cast out their seede among the Nations : and to scatter them in the lands.
Manx: 27. Dy hilge magh nan rass masky ny hatiẃni : as d’ an skely-syn ayns ny talwiniyn.

English: 28 They joyned themselves unto Baal-Peor : and ate the offerings of the dead.
Manx: 28. Ren ayd ayd héyn y hangly[223] ry Báal Peór : as ji ayd owrélyn yn varrw.

English: 29 Thus they provoked him to anger with their owne inventions : and the plague was great among them.
Manx: 29. Marsho grenni ayd eshyn gys farg rish y ghwmmey ack héyn : as va yn ghnapp mwar nan maskysyn.

English: 30 Then stood up Phinees & praied : & so the plague ceased.
Manx: 30. Eish hass Phineés shúas as gwí é : as marshen hwgg yn ghnapp nayrde.

English: 31 And that was counted unto him for righteousnesse : among all posterities for evermore.
Manx: 31. As va shen erna ghownty dâsyn erson kayrys : masky gygh wlly hilógh erson gybrágh.

English: 32 They angred him also at the waters of strife : so that he punished Moses for their sakes;
Manx: 32. Hwgg ayd korri ersyn níist ag wiskaghyn yn stry̌if : marshen gy gherri é Moises er nan-sonsyn.
gherri é] ms. ghorrié

English: 33 Because they provoked his spirit : so that hee spake unadvisedly with his lips.
Manx: 33. Erson gy grenni áyd yn spyryd aggesyn : marshen gy lóyr é gy mighielagh ra veliyn.

English: 34 Neither destroyed they the heathen : as the Lord commanded them;
Manx: 34. Ghamẃ strẃi aydsyn ny hangrístíin : mar hwgg yn Chiarn sáyry dâw;

English: 35 But were mingled among the heathen : and learned their workes.
Manx: 35. As v’ ayd máskit masky ny hatiẃni : as jinsi áyd ny hobraghyn acksyn.

English: 36 In so much that they worshipped their idoles, which turned to their owne decay : yea, they offered their sonnes and their daughters unto devils;
Manx: 36. Er ghẃis as gy dwgg ayd ammys dy ny jallẃnyn [acksyn], ren tynda gys an gwrr mow héyn : gy jarrw d’ówr áyd nan meck as ininyn gys jeowlyn.
d’ówr áyd] ms. d’-ówr-áyd

English: 37 And shed innocent blood, even the blood of their sonnes and of their daughters : whom they offered unto the idoles of Chanaan; and the land was defiled with blood.
Manx: 37. As giyrt ayd fwíll gyn loght, gy jarw fwill nan meck as nan iníinyn : ren ayd y owrel dy iallwnyn Ghánaán, as va yn chíir sallíit ry fwill.
iníinyn] ms. iníin

English: 38 Thus were they stained with their owne works: and went a whoring with their owne inventions.
Manx: 38. Marshó v’ áyd sallíit rish nan obraghyn héyn : ass ghai áyd er mardrys lesh an gwmmy héyn.

English: 39 Therefore was the wrath of the Lord kindled against his people : insomuch that he abhorred his owne inheritance.
Manx: 39. Shennyfá va korri yn Chiarn fadíit nyoi y phobyl : erson ghwish gy row dwoi agge er y eirys héyn.

English: 40 And he gave them over into the hand of the heathen : and they that hated them were lords over them.
Manx: 40. As hwgg e harrish áyd gys law ny hangristín : as va aydsyn va dwoi ack orrw nan jarnyn harrystẃ.
hangristín] ms. hangristí

English: 41 Their enemies oppressed them : & had them in subjection.
Manx: 41. Ren nan nóidjyn trynláys ořrw : as va ayd ack fow.

English: 42 Many a time did he deliver them : but they rebelled against him with their owne inventions, and were brought downe in their wickednesse.
Manx: 42. She immey kiyrt lifrée eshyn áydsyn, agh jirri ayd shýas na yoi rish nan gwmmey heyn : as va ayd er nan dóyrt shíis ayns nan olkys.

English: 43 Neverthelesse, when he saw their adversitie : he heard their complaint.
Manx: 43. Na iei, nar ghonick e nan sýaghyn : ghýyl e ’an akan.

English: 44 Hee thought upon his Covenant, and pitied them according unto the multitude of his mercies : yea, hee made all those that led them away captive to pitie them.
Manx: 44. Smẃni e er y ghẃnaynt, as gow e chimmey jusyn nyre ymmydi y vyghinsyn : gy jarw, hwgg e oriǔsyn wlly líid ayd er shiul an kappy dy góyl treyg jû.

English: 45 Deliver us (O Lord our God) and gather us from among the heathen : that we may give thankes unto thy holy Name, and make our boast of thy praise.
Manx: 45. Lifrée shwin, O Hiarn nan Iíh, as chiaggyl shwin vei masky ny hangrístin : gy vod meid bwias y hóyrt dy t’ enyms kasserick, as dy ianw nan moggesygh dy tdy vollys.

English: 46 Blessed be the Lord God of Israel from everlasting and world without end : and let all the people say, Amen.
Manx: 46. Banníit gy row yn Chiarn Jih Israel vei gybragh as sýyl gyn ghian : as ligg e wlly yn phobyl y grá, Amen. Moligi yn Chiarn.[224]

English: The xxii. day.
Manx: Yn xxii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 107.
Manx: Confitemini Domino. psal. 107.

English: O give thankes unto the Lord, for hee is gracious : and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1. O toergi bẃias d’ yn Chiarn, erson te grasóil : as ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 2 Let them give thankes whom the Lord hath redeemed : and delivered from the hand of the enemie;
Manx: 2. Ligg awsyn bwias y hoyrt, ta yn Chiarn er nan giannaghe ríist : as er nan lifré vei law yn nóid;

English: 3 And gathered them out of the lands, from the East & from the West : from the North and from the South.
Manx: 3. As er an jaglym magh ass ny tallwiniyn : vei yn gniarr, as vei yn gníirr, vei yn twoi, as vei yn jass.

English: 4 They went astray in the wildernesse out of the way : and found no Citie to dwell in;
Manx: 4. Ghái áyd er shaghran ayns yn ’aysygh magh as y ráyd : as ghá dóeyr ayd balle erbi dy vaghey áyn.

English: 5 Hungrie and thirstie : their soule fainted in them.
Manx: 5. Gakrys as páa : hwgg ’an anym náyrde ayndw.

English: 6 So they cried unto the Lord in their trouble : and hee delivered them from their distresse.
Manx: 6. Eish jei ayd er y Chiarn ayns nan syaghyn : as lifré eshyn aydsyn magh as ’an jenid.

English: 7 Hee led them forth by the right way : that they might goe to the Citie where they dwelt.
Manx: 7. Líid e aydsyn magh liórish y rayd káyr : gy vodagh ayd doll gys y valley ren ayd vaghey ayn.

English: 8 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnes : and declare the wonders that hee doth for the children of men.
Manx: 8. O gy jeanagh déney er y hon-shen yn Chiarn y volley erson y véiys : as y ientyssyn[225] y insh te dy ianw er klawn geney.

English: 9 For hee satisfieth the emptie soule : and filleth the hungry soule with goodnes.
Manx: 9. Erson te tóyrt gy lioyr d’ yn anym fallym : as liény yn anym akrẏsagh rish méiys.

English: 10 Such as sit in darkenes, and in the shadow of death : being fast bound in miserie and yron;
Manx: 10. ’An léidsyn as ta syei ayns dorghys, as ayns skáa yn váys : sickyr kanglit ayns treyi as iarn;

English: 11 Because they rebelled against the wordes of the Lord : and lightly regarded the counsaile of the most High;
Manx: 11. Erson gy ren ayd kagey nýoi goyn yn Chiarn : as ren ayd gy hedrym taskey y hóyrt dy ghowrley yn ier s’ ýrje;

English: most High] 1662 most highest
12 He also brought downe their heart through heavines : they fell downe, and there was none to helpe them up.
Manx: 12. Hwgg e núas níist nan griaghyn treyfd trimshey : hwitt áyd shíis, as ghá row veg dy ghwyne lio shuas.

English: helpe them up.] 1662 help them.
13 So when they cried unto the Lord in their trouble : he delivered them out of their distresse.
Manx: 13. Marshen nar jei ayd gys y Chiarn ayns nan syaghyn : lifrée eshyn aydsyn magh as ’an jenid.

English: 14 For he brought them out of darkenesse, and out of the shadow of death : and brake their bonds in sunder.
Manx: 14. Erson hwgg e aydsyn magh as dorghys, as magh dy skáa yn váys : as vrish e ny kanglaghyn acksyn as ’ygh elle.

English: 15 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnesse : and declare the wonders that he doth for the children of men!
Manx: 15. O gy jenagh déney er y hon shen yn Chiarn y volley erson y véìys : as y ientyssyn y insh te dy ianw erson klawn géney!

English: 16 For he hath broken the gates of brasse : and smitten the barres of yron in sunder.
Manx: 16. Erson te er mrissie ny dorsyn prass : as er moaly ny barryn iarn ayns ygh elle.

English: 17 Foolish men are plagued for their offence : and because of their wickednesse.
Manx: 17. Ta déney ammyjagh kerit erson nan loght : as kientagh rish ’an olkys.

English: 18 Their soule abhorred all manner of meate : and they were even hard at deaths doore.
Manx: 18. Hwgg yn anym acksyn dwôi dy dygh wlly vène dy víi : as v’ áyd gy jarw faggys ag dorrys y váys.

English: 19 So when they cried unto the Lord in their trouble : he delivered them out of their distresse.
Manx: 19. Marshen nar jei áyd gys y Chiarn ayns nan sýaghyn : lifrée eshyn aydsyn magh as ’an jenid.

English: 20 He sent his word and healed them : and they were saved from their destruction.
Manx: 20. Hwgg e y okyl, as lani e áyd : as va áyd sawchey vei nan gall.

English: 21 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnesse : and declare the wonders that he doth for the children of men.
Manx: 21. O gy jeanagh deney er y hon-shen yn Chiarn y voley erson y véìys : as ny hientyssyn y insh te dy ianw erson klawn geney.

English: 22 That they would offer unto him the sacrifice of thanksgiving : and tell out his workes with gladnesse.
Manx: 22. Gy nowragh ayd dasyn owrel dy vwias y hóyrt : as dy insh magh y obraghyn rish gann.

English: 23 They that go downe to the sea in ships : and occupie their businesse in great waters;
Manx: 23. Aydsyn ta doll shíis gys yn ’arkey ayns longyn : as janw ’an jwrryssyn[226] er ny hwiskaghyn mẃary;

English: 24 These men see the workes of the Lord : and his wonders in the deepe.
Manx: 24. Híi ny déney sho obraghyn yn Chiarn : as y ientyssyn ayns y deifnid.

English: 25 For at his word the stormie winde ariseth : which lifteth up the waves thereof.
Manx: 25. Erson agg y okylsyn ta yn gýe dyrrinagh girri : ta trógel shýas ny tonnyn agge.

English: 26 They are caried up to the heaven, and downe againe to the deepe : their soule melteth away because of the trouble.
Manx: 26. T’ áyd ymmyrkit shýas gys neaw, as shíis ríist gys y difníd : ta nan anym liéy er shiul erson yn sýaghyn.

English: up to the heaven] 1605 up the heaven
27 They reele to and fro, and stagger like a drunken man : and are at their wits end.
Manx: 27. T’ áyd goll nẃnn as nall, as bwnjernygh[227] kasly rish dwyne meistoil : as t’ ayd ag kian nan gáiliy.
gáiliy] ms. gáitiy

English: 28 So when they cry unto the Lord in their trouble : hee delivereth them out of their distresse.
Manx: 28. Marshen nar t’ ayd gemagh er y Chiarn ayns nan syaghyn : t’ é d’ an lifrésyn as ’an jenid.

English: 29 For hee maketh the storme to cease : so that the waves thereof are still.
Manx: 29. Erson te toyrt er y dorryn fé y góyl : marshen gy vell ny tonnyn aggesyn kiẃn.

English: 30 Then are they glad, because they be at rest : and so hee bringeth them unto the haven where they would be.
Manx: 30. Eish ta bogey ořw erson gy vell ayd agg fée : as marshen té d’ an doyrt-syn gys y vai[228] baliêu y vé áyn.

English: they be] 1662 they are
Manx: ořw] ms. óỳr

English: 31 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnesse : and declare the wonders that he doth for the children of men.
Manx: 31. O gy jeanagh déney erryfá shen yn Chiarn y volley erson y véiys : as ny hientyssyn y insh té dy ianw erson klawn geney!

English: 32 That they would exalt him also in the Congregation of the people : and praise him in the seate of the Elders.
Manx: 32. Gy jeánagh áyd eshyn y volley gy hárd níist ayns shessaght yn phobyl : as eshyn y volley ayns ýnyd ny shandiyght.

English: 33 Which turneth the floods into a wildernesse : and drieth up the water springs.
Manx: 33. Ta chyndá ny twillaghyn gys fáysygh : as chyrmaghy shuas ny fyrrányn wisky.

English: Which] 1662 Who
34 A fruitfull land maketh he barren : for the wickednes of them that dwell therein.
Manx: 34. Tallw meassoil t’ e dy ianw pháys : erson yn pecky acksyn ta vaghey áyn.

English: 35 Againe he maketh the wildernesse a standing water : and water springs of a drie ground.
Manx: 35. Ríist, t’ e janw d’ yn aysyght wisky shassẃ : as chibbryghyn wisky dy hallw chyrrym.

English: 36 And there he setteth the hungrie : that they may build them a Citie to dwell in;
Manx: 36. As aynshen te d’ an syiaghy aydsyn ta akrisagh : gy vod ayd ayrd valley y hrogel daw dy vaghey áyn.

English: 37 That they may sow their land, and plant Vineyards : to yeeld them fruits of increase.
Manx: 37. Gy vod ayd nan dallw y ghwirr, as garraghyn dy vŷilchyn phíỳn y heiaghy : dy hoyrt daw meass dy vishagh.

English: 38 He blesseth them, so that they multiply exceedingly : and suffereth not their cattell to decrease.
Manx: 38. Te dan managhey marshen gy vell ayd twilliw gy fíir vwar : as gha vell e swrrail dy nan ialagh dy goll er gẃll.

English: 39 And againe, when they are minished and brought low : through oppression, through any plague or trouble;
Manx: 39. As ríist, nar t’ ayd ’an lydygh as er nan doyrt ishyil : trýid [trynláys, trýid][229] phlóg[230] erbí na syaghyn.
phlóg] ms. pllóg

English: 40 Though he suffer them to bee evil intreated through tyrants : and let them wander out of the way in the wildernesse;
Manx: 40. Ga liggys e daw dy ve er nan láyght[231] gy holk ag tréni[232] : as ligge daw doll er shaghran as y rayd ayns yn aysyght;

English: 41 Yet helpeth hee the poore out of miserie : and maketh him housholds like a flocke of sheepe.
Manx: 41. Fóyst te kẃyny lesh yn voght magh as y voghtynys : as janw teiwsyn[233] dâ kasly rish shellw kyrragh.

English: 42 The righteous will consider this, and rejoyce : and the mouth of all wickednesse shall be stopped.
Manx: 42. Smẃni ny déney káyragh er shó as gowi ayd boggey : as bíi béal gygh wlly niawghrawiys erna iéi.

English: 43 Who so is wise wil ponder these things : and they shall understand the loving kindenesse of the Lord.
Manx: 43. Quei erbí ta kriny, smwni e er ny redyn shó : as twigi ayd keindylys graigoil yn Chiarn.

English: The xxii. day.
Manx: Yn xxii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Paratum cor meum. Psal. 108.
Manx: Paratum cor meum. psal. 108.

English: O God my heart is ready (my heart is ready :) I will sing & give praise with the best member that I have.
Manx: 1. O Iíh, ta my ghri arlw, ta my ghri arlw : goym oráyn, as verrym bẃias rish yn aylt sháyr t’ áym.

English: 2 Awake thou Lute and Harpe : I my selfe will awake right earely.
Manx: 2. Dwisk, us liut as krwit : dwisky̌ms mi héyn gy fíir voghey.

English: 3 I wil give thanks unto thee, O Lord, among the people : I will sing praises unto thee among the nations.
Manx: 3. Verrym bẃias dwitch, O Hiarn, masky yn phobyl : goyms oráyn dy volley dwitch masky ny hatiowni.

English: 4 For thy mercie is greater then the heavens : and thy trueth reacheth unto the clouds.
Manx: 4. Erson ta tdy vyghin nasmw na ny neawghyn : as ta t’ irrinys roschyn gys ny bojelyn.

English: 5 Set up thy selfe (O God) above the heavens : and thy glory above all the earth.
Manx: 5. Sei shúas ẃ héyn, O Iíh, erskyn ny neáwghyn : as tdy glóyr erskyn yn tallw wlly.

English: 6 That thy beloved may be delivered : let thy right hand save them, and heare thou me.
Manx: 6. Gy vod aydsyn shúney léts vé er nan lifré : ligg e tdy law iesh aydsyn y hawáyl, as klwin us mish.

English: 7 God hath spoken in his holinesse : I wil rejoyce therefore and divide Sichem, and mete out the valley of Sucoth.
Manx: 7. Ta Jih er loyrt ayns y ghassrikys : shennyfá góỳms boggey as renniym Sichem, as towshym magh kóyn Sukoth.

English: 8 Gilead is mine, and Manasses is mine : Ephraim also is the strength of my head.
Manx: 8. Sh’ láỳms Gilead, as sh’ láỳms Manasses : she Ephraym níist gniart my ghian.

English: 9 Juda is my lawgiver, Moab is my washpot : over Edom will I cast out my shoe, upon the Philistines wil I triumph.
Manx: 9. She Juda m’ ’er lyoi, she Moab my phàss níi : harrish Edom hilgym magh my vrayg, er ny Philistini niyms barriyght bogoil y góyl.

English: the Philistines 1599, 1636, 1660] 1605 the Philistims, 1662 Philistia
10 Who will leade me into the strong Citie : and who will bring me into Edom?
Manx: 10. Quei líidjys mi gys yn ayrd valley laidjer : as quei ver mish gys Edom?

English: 11 Hast not thou forsaken us, O God : and wilt not thou God goe foorth with our hostes?
Manx: 11 Nágh vel us er nan dregáel, O Iíh : as nagh jed us, O Iíh, magh márish nan shessaghtyn kagi?

English: thou God goe, 1599] 1636, 1660 thou, O God, go
12 O helpe us against the enemy : for vaine is the help of man.
Manx: 12. O kwin léyn nýoi yn noyid : erson sh’ fárdalagh kwyney dwǐyney.

English: 13 Through God we shall doe great actes : and it is he that shall tread downe our enemies.
Manx: 13. Tréyfd Jih níi meid redyn mwary : as she eshyn stampys shíis nan nóidjyn.

English: Deus laudem. Psal. 109
Manx: Deus laudem meam. psal. 109.

English: Hold not thy tongue, O God of my praise : for the mouth of the ungodly, yea, and the mouth of the deceitfull is opened upon me.
Manx: 1. Na kwmm tdy hangy, O Iíh dy my volley : erson ta béal yn neawghrawi, as béal yn kly̌ei maltoil foskilt oryms.

English: and the mouth] 1662 the mouth
2 And they have spoken against mee with false tongues : they compassed mee about also with wordes of hatred, and fought against me without a cause.
Manx: 2. As t’ áyd er lóyrt m’ yóìys rish chiangaghyn fallsy : ren áyd my ghymsheyn magiyrt níist rish fokelyn myskijagh, as kagẏ m’ yôi gyn oeyr.

English: 3 For the love that I had unto them, loe, they take now my contrary part : but I give my selfe unto prayer.
Manx: 3. Erson yn grayi va ayms oriûsyn, jeagh, nish t’ áyd góyl páyrt m’ yóis : agh ta mi dy my hóyrt héyn dys padjer.
va] ms. dâ; ta mi] ms. ta my

English: 4 Thus have they rewarded me evill for good : and hatred for my good will.
Manx: 4. Sho mar t’ áyd ern íik dwys olk erson mei : as myskid erson m’ agney mei.

English: 5 Set thou an ungodly man to bee ruler over him : and let Satan stand at his right hand.
Manx: 5. Tóeyr us dwyine niawghrawi dy réel harrishyn : as ligg e nóid ny hanmey shassw ag yn láw iesh aggesyn.
ag] ms. as

English: 6 When sentence is given upon him, let him bee condemned : and let his prayer be turned into sinne.
Manx: 6. Nar víis brwinys erna hóyrt ersyn, ligg e ve erna agáel mẃi : as ligg e y phadjer ve erna hyndá gys pecky.

English: 7 Let his dayes be few : and let another take his office.
Manx: 7. Ligg e y lághyn ve beggan : as ligg e anáyn elle y ghwrrym y góyl.

English: 8 Let his children be fatherlesse : and his wife a widow.
Manx: 8. Ligg e y ghlawn ve gyn áer : as y venn na ben treogh.

English: 9 Let his children be vagabonds, and beg their bread : let them seeke it also out of desolate places.
Manx: 9. Ligg e y ghlawnsyn ve gimiaght magíỳrt as jérig y hiyrry : ligg aw y hiyrre é níist ayns ynydyn phays.

English: 10 Let the extortioner consume all that hee hath : and let the stranger spoile his labour.
Manx: 10. Ligg e yn trenyder[234] wlly t’ agge y ghwrr mow : as ligg e yn jori y obersyn y rẃisky.

English: 11 Let there be no man to pitie him : nor to have compassion upon his fatherlesse children.
Manx: 11. Na ligg dwiney erbi y vê, dy goyl treyi jé : na dy goyl tashey[235] er y ghlawnsyn gyn áer.

English: 12 Let his posteritie be destroyed : & in the next generation let his name be cleane put out.
Manx: 12. Ligg e y lwght ve erna strwi : as ayns yn na shilógh ligg e y enym ve erna ghwrr ass glann.

English: 13 Let the wickednesse of his fathers bee had in remembrance in the sight of the Lord : and let not the sinne of his mother be done away.
Manx: 13. Ligg e pecky y áeraghyn ve ayns kwinaghtyn ayns shilliy yn Chiarn : as na ligg dy pheky y vwmmwg ve erna hóyrt er shiúl.

English: 14 Let them alway be before the Lord : that he may root out the memoriall of them from off the earth.
Manx: 14. Ligg ’âẃ ve gybragh feanish yn Chiarn : gy vodd e yn kwiny acksyn y rowry magh vei yn tallw.

English: 15 And that, because his minde was not to doe good : but persecuted the poore helpelesse man, that hee might slay him that was vexed at the heart.
Manx: 15. As shen, erson nagh row y agney dy ianw mei : agh deigyr e gy holk yn dwiney boght gyn ghwyne, gy vodagh é eshyn y varrw vá sýit ag y ghri.

English: 16 His delight was in cursing, & it shall happen unto him : he loved not blessing, therefore shall it be farre from him.
Manx: 16. Vá y agney ayns gwiaghyn, as taghri e dá : ghá byuney-lesh banaght, shennyfá bíi e foddey vei.

English: 17 Hee clothed himselfe with cursing like as with a raiment : and it shall come into his bowels like water, and like oyle into his bones.
Manx: 17. Hwgg é ymmish héyn gwiaghyn mar veagh ydagh : as higg e schiagh ayns y vynagh mar wisky, as mar ẃil ayns y ghnawyn.

English: 18 Let it be unto him as the cloke that he hath upon him : and as the girdle that he is alway girded withall.
Manx: 18. Ligg e ve da mar kloaky t’ aggé ymmish : as mar yn kryss té gybragh kiánglit rish.

English: 19 Let it thus happen from the Lord unto mine enemies : and to those that speake evill against my soule.
Manx: 19. Ligg e marshó taghyrt vei yn Chiarn dy my nóidjyn : as dawsyn ta loyrt olk nyoi m’ anym.

English: 20 But deale thou with me, O Lord God, according unto thy Name : for sweete is thy mercie.
Manx: 20. Agh jean us rwyms, O Hiarn Jih, nyre t’ enyms : erson she millish tdy vyghin.

English: 21 O deliver mee, for I am helpelesse and poore : and my heart is wounded within me.
Manx: 21. O lifrée mi, erson ta mi gyn ghẃyney as boght : as ta my ghri lottit er léỳf stei jîms.

English: 22 I goe hence like the shadow that departeth : and am driven away as the Grashopper.
Manx: 22. Ta mi doll as shó mar skáa ta doll er shiúl : as ta mi ymmanit er shiúl mar yn kellagh renni.

English: 23 My knees are weake through fasting : my flesh is dried up for want of fatnesse.
Manx: 23. Ta my glẃnyn anẃyn tréyfd troskey : ta m’ ’éyl chirmit shýas fegwis rawrid.

English: 24 I became also a rebuke unto them : they that looked upon me, shaked their heads.
Manx: 24. Ta mi níist er me ghon knáid dawsyn : ghrei áyd iagh orrym an giǎn.

English: rebuke] 1662 reproach
25 Helpe me, O Lord my God : Oh save me according to thy mercie.
Manx: 25. Kẃyn layms, O Hiarn my Iíh : as saw mi nyre tdy vyghyns.

English: 26 And they shall know how that this is thy hand : and that thou Lord hast done it.
Manx: 26. As bíi fys acksyn kyns gy níe sho tdy laẃys : as gy vel us, Hiarn, erna ianw é.
níe] ms. níi e

English: 27 Though they curse, yet blesse thou : & let them bee confounded that rise up against me; but let thy servant rejoyce.
Manx: 27. Ga ta aydsyn gwiaghyn, fóyst banni us : as ligg ’awsyn ve er nan doyrt gys narey ta girri shúas m’ yôis, as ligg dy tdy herváynt ve gannoil.

English: 28 Let mine adversaries be clothed with shame : & let them cover themselves with their owne confusion, as with a cloke.
Manx: 28. Ligg e my nóidjyn vé kẃrit rish náyre : as ligg aw ayd héyn y ghwdaghy rish an nayre héyn, marr ry kloky.

English: 29 As for mee, I will give great thankes unto the Lord with my mouth : and praise him among the multitude.
Manx: 29. As er my hons, verryms bwias mẃar d’ yn Chiarn rish my véal : as mollym e masky yn chessaght.

English: 30 For he shal stand at the right hand of the poore : to save his soule from unrighteous Judges.
Manx: 30. Erson shassi e er law iesh yn vôght : dy hawáyl y anym vei brẃinyn niaw gháyragh.

English: The xxiii. day.
Manx: Yn xxiii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Dixit Dominus. Psal. 110.
Manx: Dixit Dominus. psal. 110.

English: The Lord saide unto my Lord : Sit thou on my right hand, untill I make thine enemies thy footestoole.
Manx: 1. Dẃyrt yn Chiarn ry my Hiarns : sei us er my law iesh, naggydere niyms tdy nóidjyns yn stóyl kosse dw̌it.

English: 2 The Lord shall send the rod of thy power out of Sion : be thou ruler, even in the middes among thine enemies.
Manx: 2. Verr yn Chiarn slǎytt tdy phwyers magh as Seion : bíi us t’ er réel, gy jarw ayns yn véyn masky tdy nóidjyn.

English: 3 In the day of thy power shall the people offer thee free wil offerings with an holy worship : the dewe of thy birth is of the wombe of the morning.
Manx: 3. Ayns lá dy tdy phẃers oẃri yn pobyl dẃìtch owrel agnagh ry ammys kasserick : ta driwght t’ ymmyrkys ie brw ny madjyn.[236]
t’ ymmyrkys] ms. cymmyrkys

English: 4 The Lord sware and wil not repent : thou art a Priest for ever, after the order of Melchisedech.
Manx: 4. Lẃ yn Chiarn, as gha gow e arys : she sagyrt us erson gybragh, nyre ordyr Velkizedech.

English: 5 The Lord upon thy right hand : shall wound even Kings in the day of his wrath.
Manx: 5. Liotti yn Chiarn er tdy law iessys : gy jarrw ríiaghyn ayns lá y ghorri.

English: 6 He shall judge among the heathen; hee shall fill the places with the dead bodies : and smite in sunder the heads over divers countreys.
Manx: 6. Verr e brwinys masky ny hangristínyn; lieni e ny hynydyn rish kirpp marrw : as brishi e ny kíin as y ghielly harrish kyghla chiŕynyn.

English: 7 He shall drinke of the brooke in the way : therefore shall he lift up his head.
Manx: 7. Ivi e d’ yn trẃan ayns y ráyd : shenyfá hrogys e shuas y ghian.
shuas] ms. shus

English: Confitebor tibi. Psal. 111.
Manx: Confitebor tibi. [psal.] 111.

English: I will give thankes unto the Lord with my whole heart : secretly among the faithfull, and in the Congregation.
Manx: 1. Verrym bwias d’ yn Chiarn rish my ghri wlly : gy fallíit masky yn klyei kredjoil, as ayns y chesságht.

English: 2 The workes of the Lord are great : sought out of all them that have pleasure therein.
Manx: 2. Ta obraghyn yn Chiarn mwár : shyírit magh jûsyn wlly ta tatnys ack ayndŵ.

English: 3 His worke is worthy to bee praised and had in honour : and his righteousnesse endureth for ever.
Manx: 3. Ta y obyr fiw dy ve erna volley as ve ayns bói[237] : as ta y gháyrys farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 4 The mercifull & gracious Lord hath so done his marveilous workes : that they ought to be had in remembrance.
Manx: 4. Ta yn Chiarn myghinagh as grasoil marshen ern’ ianw y obraghyn ientyssagh : gy lessagh ayd vê ayns kwiney.

English: 5 He hath given meat unto them that feare him : he shall ever be mindfull of his Covenant.
Manx: 5. T’ e er doyrt bíi dawsyn ta goyl agyl reyf : bíi e gybragh agyntagh er y ghẃynáynt.

English: 6 Hee hath shewed his people the power of his workes : that he may give them the heritage of the Heathen.
Manx: 6. Te ern iaghyn pẃer y obraghyn dâ phobyl : gy vodd e y hoyrt dawsyn eiryght ny hangristíin.

English: 7 The workes of his hands are veritie & judgement : all his Commandements are true.
Manx: 7. Ta obraghyn y lawyn firrinys as brwinys : ta y abertsyn wlly firrinagh.

English: 8 They stand fast for ever and ever : and are done in trueth and equitie.
Manx: 8. T’ áyd shassw sićkyr erson gybrágh as gybrágh : as t’ áyd jeant ayns firrinys as korrymys.

English: 9 He sent redemption unto his people : he hath commanded his Covenant for ever; holy and reverent is his Name.
Manx: 9. Te er gwrr ransẃr[238] dys y phobylsyn : te er sayre y ghẃnaynt erson gybragh, s’ kasserick as arymagh ta y enymsyn.

English: reverent] 1660 reverend
10 The feare of the Lord is the beginning of wisedome : a good understanding have all they that doe thereafter; the praise of it endureth for ever.
Manx: 10. She agyl yn Chiarn tossiagh krinyght : ta twigel mei acksyn ta janw na ýre shenn; ta yn molley aggesyn farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: Beatus vir. Psal. 112
Manx: Beatus vir. psal. 112.

English: Blessed is the man that feareth the Lord : hee hath great delight in his Commandements.
Manx: 1. Baniít ta yn dwiney ta goyl agyl [reyfs] yn Chiarn : ta tatnys mwar agge ayns ny habeyrtsyn aggesyn.

English: 2 His seed shal be mightie upon earth : the generation of the faithfull shal be blessed.
Manx: 2. Bíi y rassyn gniartoil er y tallw : bíi shilógh yn klyěi kredjoil baníit.

English: 3 Riches and plenteousnesse shal be in his house: and his righteousnesse endureth for ever.
Manx: 3. Bíi berćhys as palchey ayns y heisyn : as farri y ghayrys-syn erson gybragh.

English: 4 Unto the godly there ariseth up light in the darknes : he is mercifull, loving, and righteous.
Manx: 4. Ta sóilshe girri shúas d’ yn dwyney ghraẃi ayns y dorghys : ta eshyn myghinagh, graiygh, as káyragh.

English: 5 A good man is mercifull, and lendeth : and will guide his words with discretion.
Manx: 5. Ta dwyne mei myghinagh, as toyrt er iésaght : as reeli e y okelyn rish kial.

English: 6 For he shall never be mooved : and the righteous shall be had in everlasting remembrance.
Manx: 6. Erson ghá bíi e gybragh erna skwghey : as bíi yn dwyne krawi ayns kwinaghtyn gybragh faraghtyn.

English: 7 He will not be afraid of any evill tidings : for his heart standeth fast, and beleeveth in the Lord.
Manx: 7. Gha bíi é aglagh er drogh naǐaght erbi : erson ta y ghri shassw dain,[239] as krediu ayns y Chiarn.

English: 8 His heart is stablished and wil not shrinke : until he see his desire upon his enemies.
Manx: 8. Ta y ghrí sickerit as gha skwgh e : nagge[240] vǎick e y agney er y noidjyn.

English: 9 He hath dispersed abroad, and given to the poore : and his righteousnesse remaineth for ever; his horne shall be exalted with honour.
Manx: 9. T’ e er skély gy lién as er doyrt dy ny boghtyn : as ta y gháyryssyn farraghtyn erson gybragh, bíi y ericksyn erna hrogel shýas ry bôi.

English: 10 The ungodly shall see it, and it shall grieve him : hee shall gnash with his teeth, and consume away; the desire of the ungodly shall perish.
Manx: 10. Híi yn niawghrawi e, as níi e y ghraíi[241] e : níi e snaggerni rá ’iékylyn, as keyf er shiúl; heyd agney yn niaw ghrawi mow.

English: Laudate pueri. Psal. 113.
Manx: Laudate pueri. psal. 113.

English: Praise the Lord, yee servants : O praise the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 1. Moligi yn Chiarn. shiusse herváyntyn : O molligi enym yn Chiarn.

English: 2 Blessed bee the Name of the Lord : from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 2. Banníit gy row enym yn Chiarn : vei yn iérish sho magh erson gy bragh.

English: 3 The Lords Name is praised : from the rising up of the Sunne, unto the going downe of the same.
Manx: 3. Ta enym yn Chiarn móllíit : vei irri shýas ny grieny gys y doll shíis agge.

English: 4 The Lord is high above all heathen : and his glory above the heavens.
Manx: 4. Ta yn Chiarn ayrd erskyn wlly ny hangristín : as y gloyrsyn erskyn ny neawghyn.

English: 5 Who is like unto the Lord our God, that hath his dwelling so high : and yet humbleth himselfe to beholde the things that are in heaven and earth?
Manx: 5. Quei ta kasly rish yn Chiarn nan Iíh, agg vell y vagheysyn gho ayrd : as fóyst ta dy íislaghe y heyn dy iaghyn er ny redyn ta ayns neaw as tallw?

English: 6 Hee taketh up the simple out of the dust : and lifteth the poore out of the myre;
Manx: 6. T’ é góyl shýas yn ímbli magh as y jann : as trogell yn voght magh as y lei;[242]

English: 7 That hee may set him with the princes : even with the princes of his people.
Manx: 7. Gy vodd e eshyn y heiaghe mâry ny prinsaghyn : gy jarw marish prinsaghyn y phobyl.

English: 8 Hee maketh the barren woman to keepe house : and to be a joyfull mother of children.
Manx: 8. T’ é tóyrt er y ven hast[243] dy riall týei : as dy vé na meier gannoil dy ghláwn.

English: The xxiii. day.
Manx: Yn xxiii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: In exitu Israel. Psal. 114.
Manx: In exitu Israel. psal. 114.

English: When Israel came out of Egypt : and the house of Jacob from among the strange people,
Manx: 1. Nar haink Israel magh as Ejipt : as tyei Jacob vei maskey yn phobyl jori,

English: 2 Juda was his Sanctuary : and Israel his dominion.
Manx: 2. Vá Judá y ynyd kasserick : as Israel y ynyd réel-syn.

English: 3 The sea sawe that, and fled : Jordan was driven backe.
Manx: 3. Ghonick yn farky shen, as ren e ché : va Jurdáyn erna imman er gẃll.

English: 4 The mountains skipped like Rams : & the little hils like yong sheep.
Manx: 4. Ren ny knwick mẃary brẃiskinaght mar reaghyn : as ny knwick beggey mar kirri ágy.
brẃiskinaght] ms. brẃikinaght

English: 5 What aileth thee, O thou sea, that thou fleddest : and thou Jordan that thou wast driven backe?
Manx: 5. Kre higg rw̌yts, Ó arkey, gy ren ẃ ché : as us, Iurdán, gy row er t’ imman er gẃl?

English: 6 Ye mountaines that yee skipped like Rammes : and ye little hils like yong sheepe?
Manx: 6. Shiusse ghnwick vẃary, gy léym shiu mar reaghyn : as shiusse ghnwick veggy, mar kirri ágy?

English: 7 Tremble thou earth at the presence of the Lord : at the presence of the God of Jacob;
Manx: 7. Krái, us hallw, ag fenish yn Chiarn : ag fenish Jíh Iacob;

English: 8 Which turned the hard rocke into a standing water : and the flint stone into a springing well.
Manx: 8. Hyndá yn ghregg [ghryoi] gys wiskey shassw : as yn ghlagh aínill gys chibbyr gell.

English: Which] 1662 Who
Manx: Hyndá] ms. Ta hynda

English: Non nobis Domine. Psal. 115.
Manx: Non nobis Domine. psal. 115.

English: Not unto us, O Lord, not unto us, but unto thy Name give the praise : for thy loving mercie, and for thy trueths sake.
Manx: 1. Ghanie dwiniyn, O Hiarn, ghanie dwiniyn, agh dy t’ enym toeyr yn molley : erson tdy vyghin graigwil, as erson grayi t’ irrinys.

English: 2 Wherefore shall the heathen say : Where is now their God?
Manx: 2. Kamma nabbyr ny hangrisstíin : kadje vell nish yn Jih acksyn?

English: 3 As for our God, he is in heaven : he hath done whatsoever pleased him.
Manx: 3. As erson yn Jih ainiyn, t’ é ayns neaw : t’ é ern’ ianw kre erbi balliesh-syn.

English: 4 Their idoles are silver and golde : even the worke of mens hands.
Manx: 4. Ta ny jallwnyn acksyn argyd as áyr : gy jarw obyr lawyn geney.

English: 5 They have mouthes, and speake not : eyes have they and see not.
Manx: 5. Ta béal ack as gha vel ayd loyrt : ta swilyn ack as gha vaick ayd.

English: 6 They have eares, and heare not : noses have they, and smell not.
Manx: 6. Ta klyeshyn ačk, as gha glwinn áyd : ta stroanyn ack as gha vell áyd sóyraghy.

English: 7 They have hands, and handle not; feete have they, and walke not : neither speake they through their throat.
Manx: 7. Ta lawyn ack, as gha vell áyd láyght; ta kassyn ack, as gha vell áyd gimmiaght : ghamw t’ áyd loyrt tréyfd nan skorniagh.

English: 8 They that make them, are like unto them : and so are all such as put their trust in them.
Manx: 8. Ta aydsyn d’ an ianw kasly riu : as margedyn ta wlly leid as ta toyrt nan dreistéel ayndẃ.
kasly] ms. é ta kasly

English: 9 But thou house of Israel, trust thou in the Lord : he is their succour and defence.
Manx: 9. Agh us, hyéi Israel, treist us ayns y Chiarn : she eshyn ’an gymmyrk as an vriály.

English: 10 Ye house of Aaron, put your trust in the Lord : hee is their helper and defender.
Manx: 10. Shiusse hyěi Áaron, toergi nan dreisteel ayns y Chiarn : she eshyn ’an ver kwyni as an fer frialy.

English: 11 Ye that feare the Lord, put your trust in the Lord: hee is their helper and defender.
Manx: 11. Shiusse ta goyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn, tóergi nan dreistéel ayns y Chiarn : she eshyn ’an ver kwýni as ’an ver friály.

English: 12 The Lord hath bene mindfull of us, and he shall blesse us : even he shall blesse the house of Israel, he shall blesse the house of Aaron.
Manx: 12. Ta yn Chiarn er gwinaghtyn orw̌iniyn, as bani é shwin : gy jarw banni é tyei Israel, bani é tyei Aaron.

English: 13 He shal blesse them that feare the Lord : both smal and great.
Manx: 13. Bani e aydsyn ta goyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn : begg as mẃar niist.

English: 14 The Lord shall increase you more and more : you and your children.
Manx: 14. Ver yn Chiarn erifs gáas nasmw, as nasmw : shiusse as nan glawn.

English: 15 Ye are the blessed of the Lord : which made heaven and earth.
Manx: 15. She shiusse aydsyn ta baníit d’ yn Chiarn : ren neaw as tallw.

English: which] 1662 who
16 All the whole heavens are the Lords : the earth hath he given to the children of men.
Manx: 16. Sh’ lesh yn Chiarn wlly ny neáwghyn slayn : t’ e er doyrt yn talw dy ghlawn geney.

English: 17 The dead praise not thee, O Lord : neither all they that goe downe into silence.
Manx: 17. Gha vel ny merw dy tdy vollys, O Hiarn : ghamw t’ aydsyn wlly ta doll shíis gys yn ynyd dy ve nan dost.[244]

English: 18 But we will praise the Lord : from this time foorth for evermore. Praise the Lord.
Manx: 18. Agh molli meyd yn Chiarn : vei yn trá sho magh erson gybragh. Moligi yn Chiarn.

English: The xxiiii. day.
Manx: Yn xxiiii.la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Dilexi quoniam. Psal. 116.
Manx: Dilexi quoniam. psal. 116.

English: I am well pleased : that the Lord hath heard the voyce of my prayer;
Manx: 1. Ta mi fíir vwiagh : gy gyyl yn Chiarn kora my phadjer;

English: 2 That hee hath inclined his eare unto mee : therefore will I call upon him as long as I live.
Manx: 2. Gy ghroy̌m e y ghlúesh hwyms : shenyfa êiym ersyn ghowd as víỳm bio.

English: 3 The snares of death compassed mee round about : and the paines of hell gate hold upon me.
Manx: 3. Ta ribbaghyn yn váys er my ghymshén[245] krwn magiyrt : as gow pien ’ifrin grěym oryms.

English: 4 I shal finde trouble & heavinesse, & I shal call upon the Name of the Lord : O Lord I beseech thee, deliver my soule.
Manx: 4. Ióỳm syaghyn as trimshey, as eiym er enym yn Chiarn : O Hiarn, ta mi gwi oyrts, lifre m’ anyms.

English: I shal call] 1662 I will call
5 Gracious is the Lord, and righteous : yea our God is mercifull.
Manx: 5. Ta yn Chiarn graysẃoil as kayragh : gy jarw, ta nan Iíh myghinagh.

English: 6 The Lord preserveth the simple : I was in misery, and he helped me.
Manx: 6. Ta yn Chiarn sawáyl yn boght : va mi ayns trei, as ghwyn e liam.

English: 7 Turne againe then unto thy rest, O my soule : for the Lord hath rewarded thee.
Manx: 7. Chyndá ríist éis gys t’ é, O m’ anym : erson ta yn Chiarn er dy ghwiliny.

English: 8 And why? thou hast delivered my soule from death : mine eyes from teares, and my feet from falling.
Manx: 8. As kamma? ta us er lifre m’ anym vei báas : my hwilyn vei jóeir, as my ghassyn vei twitchym.

English: 9 I wil walke before the Lord : in the land of the living.
Manx: 9. Immiym féanish y Chiarn : ayns tallw yn klyei vió.

English: 10 I beleeved, and therefore will I speak; but I was sore troubled : I said in my haste, All men are liars.
Manx: 10. Ghréid mi as shennyfa loyrym; agh vá mi er my syi gy mwar : dwyrt mi ayns my héir, ta dygh wlly gwyne nan mrágeryn.

English: 11 What reward shall I give unto the Lord : for all the benefits that he hath done unto me?
Manx: 11. Kre yn lúagh verryms d’ yn Chiarn : erson ny tóyrtyssyn wlly mei te erna ianw dẃys?

English: 12 I will receive the cup of salvation : and call upon the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 12. Goym kapan yn sawálys : as eiym er enym yn Chiarn.

English: 13 I will pay my vowes now in the presence of all his people : right deare in the sight of the Lord, is the death of his Saints.
Manx: 13. Ikym my vriaraghyn nish ayns feanish wlly y phobylsyn : fíir dýar ayns shilliy yn Chiarn ta báas y nẃyn.

English: 14 Behold (O Lord) how that I am thy servant : I am thy servant, and the sonne of thy handmaid; thou hast broken my bonds in sunder.
Manx: 14. Jeagh, O Hiarn, kyns gy vell mish tdy herváynt : she mish tdy herváynt, as mack t’ inivýyl; tow er mrishie my ghnawyn er y ghielle.

English: 15 I wil offer to thee the sacrifice of Thankesgiving : and will call upon the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 15. Owrym dwitch oẃrel dy vẃias y hoyrt : as eiym er enym y Chiarn.

English: 16 I will pay my vowes unto the Lord, in the sight of all his people : in the courts of the Lords house, even in the mids of thee, O Hierusalem. Praise the Lord.
Manx: 16. Ikym my vríaraghyn d’ yn Chiarn ayns shilliy y phobylsyn wlly : ayns kwrtyn tyei yn Chiarn, gy jarw, ayns dy véyn, O Ierusalem. Molligi yn Chiarn.

English: Laudate Dominum. Psal. 117.
Manx: Laudate dominum. psal. 117.

English: O praise the Lord all yee heathen : praise him, all ye Nations.
Manx: 1. O molligi yn Chiarn, shiusse wlly ny hangristíin : molligi e, shiusse atiwnyn wlly.

English: 2 For his mercifull kindnesse is ever more and more towards us : and the trueth of the Lord endureth for ever. Praise the Lord.
Manx: 2. Erson ta y gheindylys-syn trokróil gybragh nasmw as nasmw dwiniyn : as ta firrinys yn Chiarn farraghtyn erson gybragh. Molligi yn Chiarn.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 118.
Manx: Confitemini Domino. psal. 118.

English: O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is gracious : because his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1. O toergi bwias d’ yn Chiarn, erson te graysoil : erson gy vel y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 2 Let Israel now confesse, that he is gracious : and that his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 2. Ligg e Israel nish goyl rish gy vel é graysoil : as gy vell y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 3 Let the house of Aaron now confesse : that his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 3. Ligg e tyei Aaron nish góyl rish : gy vel y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 4 Yea, let them now that feare the Lord, confesse : that his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 4. Gy jarw ligg ’awsyn nish ta góyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn, góyl rish : gy vel y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 5 I called upon the Lord in trouble : and the Lord heard me at large.
Manx: 5. Jei mi er y Chiarn ayns sýaghyn : as ghýyl yn Chiarn mi gy lién.

English: 6 The Lord is on my side : I will not feare what man doeth unto me.
Manx: 6. Ta yn Chiarn er my heyf : gha góỳm agyl kre ta dwiney dy ianw rẃỳms.

English: 7 The Lord taketh my part with them that helpe mee: therefore shall I see my desire upon mine enemies.
Manx: 7. Ta yn Chiarn góyl liam mariusyn ta kwney liam : shennyfá hiyms m’ agney er my noidjyn.

English: 8 It is better to trust in the Lord : then to put any confidence in man.
Manx: 8. T’ e na sháyr dy hreistéel ayns y Chiarn : na dy hoyrt treistéel erbi ayns dwyney.

English: 9 It is better to trust in the Lord : then to put any confidence in princes.
Manx: 9. T’ e na sháyr dy hreistéel ayns y Chiarn : na dy hoyrt treistéel erbi ayns prinsaghyn.

English: 10 All nations compassed mee round about : but in the Name of the Lord will I destroy them.
Manx: 10. Ren gygh wlly atiẃn my ghymshén krwnn magiyrt : agh ayns enym y Chiarn strwiyms ayd.

English: 11 They kept me in on every side, they kept me in (I say) on every side : but in the Name of the Lord wil I destroy them.
Manx: 11. Drial ayd mi schiagh er gygh yn cheyf, drial ayd mi schiagh, ta mi grá, er gygh yn cheyf : agh ayns enym yn Chiarn strwiyms áyd.

English: 12 They came about me like Bees, and are extinct even as the fire among the thornes : for in the Name of the Lord I will destroy them.
Manx: 12. Haink ayd magiyrt ymmwym kasly rish shellianyn, as t’ áyd er an mwghy as gy jarw marr yn ainill maskey yn drein : erson ayns enym yn Chiarn strwiyms ayd.

English: 13 Thou hast thrust sore at mee, that I might fall : but the Lord was my helpe.
Manx: 13. Tow er séi ořrym gy dokragh, gy voddin twitchym : agh va yn Chiarn my ghwyne.

English: 14 The Lord is my strength and my song : and is become my salvation.
Manx: 14. She yn Chiarn my gniart, as m’ oráyn : as she eshyn my hawalys.

English: 15 The voyce of joy and health is in the dwellings of the righteous : the right hand of the Lord bringeth mightie things to passe.
Manx: 15. Ta korá bogey as slaynt ayns ynnydyn vaghey yn klyei kayragh : ta láw iesh yn Chiarn toyrt redyn gniartoil gy kián.

English: 16 The right hand of the Lord hath the preeminence : the right hand of the Lord bringeth mightie things to passe.
Manx: 16. Ta yn varriyght ag law iesh yn Chiarn : ta law iesh yn Chiarn toyrt redyn gniartoil gy kian.

English: 17 I wil not die, but live : & declare the works of the Lord.
Manx: 17. Ghá voym báys, agh biym bío : as íinshiym obraghyn yn Chiarn.

English: I wil] 1662 I shall
Manx: as] ms. agh

English: 18 The Lord hath chastened and corrected mee : but hee hath not given me over unto death.
Manx: 18. Ta yn Chiarn er my gherraghy as er my smaghtaghy gy géyr : agh gha dwgg e mi harrish gys báas.

English: 19 Open me the gates of righteousnesse : that I may goe into them, and give thankes unto the Lord.
Manx: 19. Foskyl dẃys dorlyssyn[247] ny kayryght[248] : gy voddym doll schiagh áyndw, as bwias y hoyrt d’ yn Chiarn.

English: 20 This is the gate of the Lord : the righteous shal enter into it.
Manx: 20. She sho dorlys yn Chiarn : heid yn slyei káyragh schiagh áyn.

English: 21 I will thanke thee, for thou hast heard mee : and art become my salvation.
Manx: 21. Verrym bwias dwitch, erson tow us er my ghlastchen : as vow us my hawálys.

English: 22 The same stone which the builders refused : is become the head stone in the corner.
Manx: 22. Yn ghlagh kedyn dobb ny maswni : t’ e er jít yn ghlagh ghíin ayns y ghornéyl.
Yn ghlagh kedyn] ms. Ny klagh kedyn[249]

English: 23 This is the Lords doing : and it is marveilous in our eyes.
Manx: 23. She sho janw y Chiarn : as t’ e iéntysagh ayns ny swilyn ainiyn.

English: 24 This is the day which the Lord hath made : we will rejoyce and be glad in it.
Manx: 24. She sho yn lá ta yn Chiarn erna ianw : gowi meid bogey as bíi méid ganoil áyn.
gowi meid] ms. gowim meid

English: 25 Helpe mee now, O Lord : O Lord send us now prosperitie.
Manx: 25. Kẃyn liaym nish, O Hiarn : O Hiarn, kwr hŵin nish rah.
rah] ms. rass

English: 26 Blessed be he that commeth in the Name of the Lord : we have wished you good lucke, ye that be of the house of the Lord.
Manx: 26. Baníit ta eshyn ta chíit ayns enym yn Chiarn : ta shwin er sowlaghy áyii mei difs, shiusse ta dy hyei yn Chiarn.

English: ye that be] 1662 ye that are
Manx: áyii] ms. áyn

English: 27 God is the Lord which hath shewed us light : bind the sacrifice with cords, yea, even unto the hornes of the Altar.
Manx: 27. She Jih yn Chiarn ta ern iághyn sóilshe dwiniyn : kangil yn oẃrell rish teddyn, she gy jarw gys erikyn ny haltyr.

English: Lord which] 1662 Lord who
28 Thou art my God, and I will thanke thee : thou art my God, and I will praise thee.
Manx: 28. She us my Iíh, as verrym bẃias dwitch : she us my Iíh, as molliyms w.

English: 29 O give thankes unto the Lord, for he is gracious: and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 29. O toergi bẃias dyn Chiarn erson te grásóil : as ta y vyghin faraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: The xxiiii. day.
Manx: Yn xxiiii.la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Beati immaculati. Psal. 119.1-8.
Manx: Beati immaculati. psal. 119.

English: Blessed are those that are undefiled in the way : and walke in the Law of the Lord.
Manx: 1. Baníit ta áydsyn ta glan ayns y ráyd : as gimiaght ayns lyoyi yn Chiarn.

English: 2 Blessed are they that keepe his Testimonies : & seek him with their whole heart.
Manx: 2. Banníit ta áydsyn ta frialy ny rikórtyn aggesyn : as dy hyrrey-syn rish nan grí wlly.

English: 3 For they which doe no wickednesse : walke in his wayes.
Manx: 3. Erson ta aydsyn nagh vell janw vegg yn olkys : gimmiaght ayns ny raydjyn aggesyn.

English: which] 1662 who
4 Thou hast charged : that we shall diligently keepe thy Commandements.
Manx: 4. Tóẁ er sáyre : gy jean meid gy hymnéagh t’ abertsyn y riál.

English: 5 O that my wayes were made so direct : that I might keepe thy Statutes.
Manx: 5. Ó gy béagh my raydjyn ernan ianw gho jíragh : gy voddym tdy liattyssyn y rial!

English: 6 So shall I not bee confounded : while I have respect unto all thy Commandements.
Manx: 6. Shen mar nagh bíims er my hóyrt gys nayre : ghóùd as víis taskey ayms dy t’ abertsyn wlly.

English: 7 I will thanke thee with an unfained heart : when I shall have learned the Judgements of thy righteousnes.
Manx: 7. Veřryms bwias dwitch rish kri firrinagh : nar viym ern’ ynsaghey brwinyssyn dy gháyrys.

English: 8 I will keep thy ceremonies : O forsake me not utterly.
Manx: 8. Frialyms t’ ordaghyns : O na tréyg mi glan.
BETH. ב.

English: In quo corriget.
Manx: In quo corriget. 2.
corriget] ms. corrigit

English: Wherewithall shall a yong man cleanse his way : even by ruling himselfe after thy word.
Manx: 9. Kre rish [níi] skallyg[250] áyg y rayd y glanny ? gy jarw liorish e héyn y réel nyre t’ okyls.

English: 10 With my whole heart have I sought thee : O let me not goe wrong out of thy Commandements.
Manx: 10. Rish wlly my ghri hyrr mi us : O na ligg dóẁ doll gy hagáragh as t’ abertsyn.

English: 11 Thy wordes have I hidde within my heart : that I should not sinne against thee.
Manx: 11. Ta mi er vallaghey t’ okylyns styei ayns my ghrí : nagh jeǎnin pecky t’ yois.

English: 12 Blessed art thou, O Lord : O teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: 12. Baníit ta us, O Hiarn : O ynsi mish ayns tdy lattyssyn.

English: 13 With my lips have I bene telling : of all the Judgements of thy mouth.
Manx: 13. Rish my veliyns ta mish er mé gins : dy wlly brwinyssyn tdy véyls.

English: 14 I have had as great delight in the way of thy Testimonies : as in all maner of riches.
Manx: 14. Va tatnys ghwish ayms ayns ráyd t’ enishyns : as ayns gygh wlly voney dy verchys.

English: 15 I wil talk of thy Commandements : and have respect unto thy ways.
Manx: 15. Níims loyrt dy t’ abertsyn : as bii taskey ayms dy tdy raydjyns.
After : ms. as gha jarŵdyms t’ okyls, which belongs, and appears, in the next verse.

English: 16 My delight shall bee in thy Statutes : and I will not forget thy word.
Manx: 16. Bíi my hatnys ayns tdy lattyssyn : as gha jarwdyms t’ okyls.
GIMEL. ג.

English: Retribue seruo tuo.
Manx: Retribue servo tuo. 3.

English: O doe well unto thy servant : that I may live, and keepe thy word.
Manx: 17. O jean gy mei dy tdy herváynt : gy voddym ve bío as t’ okyls y rialy.

English: 18 Open thou mine eyes : that I may see the wonderous things of thy Law.
Manx: 18. Foskyl us my hwilyn : gy voddym y akin ny redyn ientyssagh dy tdy lyois.

English: 19 I am a stranger upon earth : O hide not thy Commandements from me.
Manx: 19. Ta mi my ióri er y tallw : O na falli t’ abertsyn voym.

English: 20 My soule breaketh out for the very fervent desire : that it hath alway unto thy Judgements.
Manx: 20. Ta m’ anym brishie magh erson yn agney fíir che : ta agge goni gys tdy vrẃinys.
ta agge] ms. t’e agge

English: 21 Thou hast rebuked the proud : and cursed are they that doe erre from thy Commandements.
Manx: 21 Ta us er nayrághey yn slyěi morniagh : as kwsty[251] ta aydsyn ta goll er shaghran vei t’ anaghyn.

English: 22 O turne from mee shame and rebuke : for I have kept thy Testimonies.
Manx: 22. O chyndá vóỳms narey as aghsan : erson ta mi er vrial tdy rikórtyns.

English: 23 Princes also did sit and speake against mee : but thy servant is occupied in thy Statutes.
Manx: 23. Ren riaghyn níist sei as lóyrt m’ yei : agh ta tdy herváynt klaghtíit ayns tdy lattyssyn.

English: 24 For thy testimonies are my delight : & my counsailers.
Manx: 24. She tdy rikortyns my hatnys : as m’ ’irr korliy.
DALETH. ד.

English: Adhæsit pauimento.
Manx: Adhesit pauimento. 4.

English: My soule cleaveth to the dust : O quicken thou mee according to thy word.
Manx: 25. Ta m’ anym lianaghtyn gys yn ẃeir : O bioi mish nýre dy gwys.

English: 26 I have knowledged my wayes, and thou heardest me : O teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: 26. Ta mi ern’ góyl rish my ráydjyn, as ghýyl us mi : O ýnsh dẃỳs tdy lattyssyn.

English: knowledged] 1762 acknowledged
27 Make mee to understand the way of thy Commandements : and so shall I talke of thy wonderous workes.
Manx: 27. Kwrr orryms ráyd t’ abertsyn y hwigell : as marshen níỳms loyrt dy t’ obraghyn ientysagh.

English: 28 My soule melteth away for very heavinesse : comfort thou me according unto thy word.
Manx: 28. Ta m’ anym liéỳ er shiul erson fíir trimshey : gyrji us mish nyre t’ okyls.
liéỳ] ms. liéỳu

English: 29 Take from me the way of lying : and cause thou me to make much of thy Law.
Manx: 29. Gow voyms ráyd dy vrégyn : as kwrr orrym mẃar y ianw dy tdy lyeis.

English: 30 I have chosen the way of trueth : and thy Judgements have I layd before me.
Manx: 30. Ta mi er ryěi ráyd ny firriniy : as tdy vrwinyssyn ta mi erna [heiaghy] kiangoyrt rẃỳm.

English: 31 I have sticken unto thy Testimonies : O Lord confound me not.
Manx: 31 Ta mi er liántyn gys tdy rikoyrtyssyn : O Hiarn, na kwrr mow mi.

English: sticken] 1662 stuck
32 I will runne the way of thy Commandements : when thou hast set my heart at libertie.
Manx: 32. Ríiym ráyd t’ anaghyn : nar viis ẃ er séìaghey my ghri ag rémys.

English: The xxv. day.
Manx: Yn xxv. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.
HE. ה.

English: Legem pone.
Manx: Legem pone. 5.

English: Teach me, O Lord, the way of thy Statutes : and I shal keepe it unto the end.
Manx: 33. Ynsi dẃỳs, O Hiarn, ráyd dy lattyssyn : as fríalym e gys y jere.

English: 34 Give me understanding, and I shall keepe thy Lawe : yea, I shal keepe it with my whole heart.
Manx: 34. Kwrr dow twigel, as fríalym tdy lyei : ta mi grá, frialym e rish my ghri wlly.

English: 35 Make me to goe in the path of thy Commaundements : for therein is my desire.
Manx: 35. Kwrr orrym gimmiáght ayns kassan t’ abertsyn : erson aynshen ta m’ agney.

English: 36 Incline my heart unto thy testimonies : & not to covetousnes.
Manx: 36. Lwbb núas my ghri gys tdy rikóyrtyn : as ghanie gys saint.

English: 37 O turne away mine eyes, lest they behold vanitie : and quicken thou me in thy way.
Manx: 37. O chyndá as y ráyd my hwilyn, nagh vaick ayd fardálys : as biǒi us mish ayns tdy ráyd.

English: 38 O stablish thy word in thy servant : that I may feare thee.
Manx: 38. O sickri t’ okyls ayns tdy herváynt : gy voddym agyl y goyl royd.

English: 39 Take away the rebuke that I am afraide of : for thy Judgements are good.
Manx: 39. Gow as y ráyd yn aghsan ta mish góyl agyl jé : erson ta tdy vrwinyssyn mei.

English: 40 Beholde, my delight is in thy Commandements : O quicken me in thy righteousnesse.
Manx: 40. Jeagh, ta m’ agney ayns t’ anaghyn : O biǒi mish ayns tdy ghayrys.
VAV. ו.

English: Et veniat super me.
Manx: Et veniat super me. 6.

English: Let thy loving mercie come also unto mee, O Lord : even thy salvation, according unto thy word.
Manx: 41. Lig dy tdy vyghin graigẃil chíit hẃyms niist, O Hiarn : gy jarw tdy hawálys, nyre t’ ókyls.

English: 42 So shall I make answere unto my blasphemers : for my trust is in thy word.
Manx: 42. Shen mar níims fragyrt y hoyrt gys m’ árd valoghteryn : erson ta my hreistéel ayns t’ okyls.

English: 43 O take not the word of thy trueth utterly out of my mouth : for my hope is in thy Judgements.
Manx: 43. O na gow fokyl t’ irrinys glan as my véal : erson ta my hreistéel ayns tdy vrwinyssyn.

English: 44 So shal I alway keepe thy Law : yea, for ever & ever.
Manx: 44. Shen mar réylyms gygh wlly hrá tdy lyois : ta mi grá, erson gybragh as gybragh.

English: 45 And I wil walk at libertie : for I seeke thy Commandements.
Manx: 45. As immiyms ag remys : erson ta mi shirre t’ abertsyn.

English: 46 I will speake of thy Testimonies also, even before kings : and will not be ashamed.
Manx: 46. Lóỳryms dy tdy rikortyns níist, gy jarw fenish riyghyn : as gha góyms náyre.

English: 47 And my delight shal be in thy Commandements : which I have loved.
Manx: 47. As bíi my vían ayns t’ abertsyn : va gráyi aym orrw.

English: 48 My handes also will I lift up unto thy Commandements, which I have loved : & my study shal be in thy statutes.
Manx: 48. My lawyn níist hrogym shýas gys t’ abertsyn, býany liâm : as bíi my smẃnaghtyn ayns tdy liattysyn.
býnny] ms. býany
ZAIN. ז.

English: Memor esto verbi tui
Manx: Memor eﬆo verbi tui. 7.

English: verbi] 1662 servi
O thinke upon thy servant, as concerning thy word : wherein thou hast caused me to put my trust.
Manx: 49. O smwni er tdy hervaynt myghian t’ okyl : ayns tow er doyrt orrym my hreistéel y hóyrt.

English: 50 The same is my comfort in my trouble : for thy word hath quickened me.
Manx: 50. Ta shen my gyrjaghey ayns my hýaghyn : erson ta t’ okyls er my víoghy.
víoghy] ms. víaghy

English: 51 The proud have had mee exceedingly in derision : yet have I not shrinked from thy Law.
Manx: 51. Va mi gy fíir vwar ag y klyei vorniagh ayns faghid : fóyst gha skẃùgh mi vei tdy lyeis.

English: 52 For I remembered thine everlasting judgements, O Lord : and received comfort.
Manx: 52. Erson ghwini mi er tdy vrwinyssyn gybragh farraghtyn, O Hiarn : as gow mi gyrjaghy.

English: 53 I am horribly afraid : for the ungodly that forsake thy law.
Manx: 53. Ta mi fíir aglagh : erson y niawghrawi ta tregáel tdy lyeis.

English: 54 Thy statutes have bene my songs : in the house of my pilgrimage.
Manx: 54. Va ny slattyssyn ayds my oranyns : ayns tyei my ioriyght.

English: 55 I have thought upon thy Name, O Lord, in the night season : and have kept thy Law.
Manx: 55. Smwni mi er t’ enyms, O Hiarn, ayns yiérish ny hyi : as driall mi tdy lyei.

English: 56 This I had : because I kept thy Commandements.
Manx: 56. Shó va aym : erson gy drial mi t’ abertsyn.
Heth. ח.

English: Portio mea Domine
Manx: Portio mea domine. 8.

English: Thou art my portion, O Lord : I have promised to keepe thy Law.
Manx: 57. Ta us my arns, O Hiarn : ta mi ern’ gnialtyn dy rially tdy lyeis.

English: 58 I made my humble petition in thy presence with my whole heart : O be mercifull unto me according to thy word.
Manx: 58. Ren mi m’ aghyn ishill ayns t’ énish rish my ghri wlly : Ó bíi trokroil dẃys nyre t’ okyl.

English: 59 I called mine owne wayes to remembrance : and turned my feet unto thy Testimonies.
Manx: 59. Jei mi my ráydjyn héyn gys kwinaghy : as hyndá mi my ghassyn gys tdy rikortyns.

English: 60 I made haste, and prolonged not the time : to keepe thy Commandements.
Manx: 60. Ren mi seir, as gha ghwr mi shaghey yn iérish : dy rially t’ abertsyn.

English: 61 The congregations of the ungodly have robbed me : but I have not forgotten thy Law.
Manx: 61. Ta chymsaghy yn niawghrawi er my rwisky : agh gha iarwd mi tdy lýòis.

English: 62 At midnight I will rise to give thankes unto thee : because of thy righteous Judgements.
Manx: 62. Ag meyn yi irriym dy hoyrt bwias dwitch : erson tdy vrẃinyssyn kayragh.

English: 63 I am a companion of all them that feare thee : and keep thy Commandements.
Manx: 63. Ta mi [my] heshy dawsyn wlly ta góyl agyl rôyds : as frialy t’ abertsyn.

English: 64 The earth, O Lord, is full of thy mercie : O teach mee thy Statutes.
Manx: 64. Ta yn talw, O Hiarn, layn dy tdy vyghyns : O ynsi dwys tdy lattyssyn.
THETH. ט.

English: Bonitatem fecisti
Manx: Bonitatem feciﬆi. 9.
Bonitatem] ms. bonitalem

English: O Lord, thou hast dealt graciously with thy servant : according unto thy word.
Manx: 65. O Hiarn, tow ern’ ianw gy grasoil rish tdy herváynt : nyre t’ okyls.

English: 66 O learne me true understanding and knowledge : for I have beleeved thy Commandements.
Manx: 66. O ynsi dow twigel firrinagh as fysseri : erson ta mi er gredjel t’ anaghyn.

English: 67 Before I was troubled, I went wrong : but now have I kept thy word.
Manx: 67. Ma row mi er my hyaghy, gha mi er shaghran : agh nish ta mi er vrialy t’ okyls.
gha mi] ms. gha row

English: 68 Thou art good & gracious : O teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: 68. Tow us mei as grásoil : O ynsi dẃỳs tdy lattyssyn.

English: 69 The proud have imagined a lie against me : but I will keepe thy Commandements with my whole heart.
Manx: 69. Ta yn slyei morniagh er gwmmy bréyg m’ yôis : agh fréylym t’ abertsyn rish my ghri slayn.

English: 70 Their heart is as fat as brawne : but my delight hath been in thy Law.
Manx: 70. Ta yn kri acksyn gho rawr as sáil vwcky : agh va my vian ayns tdy lýòis.

English: 71 It is good for me that I have bene in trouble : that I may learne thy Statutes.
Manx: 71. T’ é mei dwys gy row mi ayns syaghyn : gy voddym tdy lattyssyns y ynsaghy.

English: 72 The Law of thy mouth is dearer unto me : then thousands of gold and silver.
Manx: 72. Ta lyei dy véyls nas tiéry[252] dwys : na milaghyn d’ áyr as d’ argyd.

English: The xxv. day.
Manx: Yn xxv.la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.
IOD. י

English: Manus tuæ fecerunt me
Manx: Manus tue fecerunt. 10.

English: Thy hands have made me and fashioned mee : O give mee understanding, that I may learne thy Commandements.
Manx: 73. Ta tdy lawyns er my ianw as er my ghẃmmy : O kwrr dow twigell, gy voddym t’ anaghyn y ynsaghe.

English: 74 They that feare thee, will be glad when they see me : because I have put my trust in thy word.
Manx: 74. Aydsyn ta góyl agyl royds, bíi áyd gannoil nar híi ayd mish : erson gy dwgg mi my hreistéel ayns t’ okyls.

English: 75 I know (O Lord) that thy Judgements are right: and that thou of very faithfulnes hast caused me to be troubled.
Manx: 75. Ta fyss áym, O Hiarn, gy vel tdy vrwinyssyn kayr : as gy dwgg us d’ yn íir irrinys [orrym] dy ve er my hyaghyn.

English: 76 O let thy mercifull kindnesse be my comfort : according to thy word unto thy servant.
Manx: 76. O ligg e tdy gheindylys myghinagh ve my gyrjaghy : nyrg dy gw dy tdy hervaynt.

English: 77 O let thy loving mercies come unto mee, that I may live : for thy Law is my delight.
Manx: 77. O ligg e tdy hrokryght grayigẃil chíit hẃyms, gy voddym ve bió : erson she tdy lyeis my vían.

English: 78 Let the proud be confounded, for they go wickedly about to destroy me : but I wil be occupied in thy Commandements.
Manx: 78. Ligg e yn slyei morniagh ve er an gwrr mow, erson t’ ayd doll gy niawghrawi magiyrt dy my strwi : agh bíim klaghtíit ayns t’ abertsyn.

English: 79 Let such as feare thee, and have knowen thy Testimonies : be turned unto me.
Manx: 79. Ligg e leid as ta goyl agill royds, as bawn tdy rikortyssyn : ve er nan jyndá hẃyms.

English: 80 O let my heart be sound in thy Statutes : that I be not ashamed.
Manx: 80. O ligg e my ghri ve slayn ayns t’ ordyghyns : nagh bíim nárit.
CAPH. כ.

English: Defecit anima mea.
Manx: Defecit anima mea. 11.
Defecit] ms. deficit

English: My soule hath longed for thy salvation : and I have a good hope because of thy word.
Manx: 81. Ta m’ anym goyl fodiaght erson tdy hawálys : as ta treistéel mei ayms erson t’ okyls.

English: 82 Mine eyes long sore for thy word : saying, O when wilt thou comfort me?
Manx: 82. Ta my hwilyn goyl vodiagh vwar erson t’ okyl : gra, kwyn ni us mish y gyrjaghy?

English: 83 For I am become like a bottel in the smoke : yet doe I not forget thy Statutes.
Manx: 83. Erson ta mish er jít kasly rish bottéel ayns y jéagh : fóyst ghanel mi jarẃd tdy lattyssyn.

English: 84 How many are the dayes of thy servant : when wilt thou be avenged of them that persecute me?
Manx: 84. Kavod ta lághyn dy herváynts : kwin víis us kwilinit oriusyn ta dy my eiyrts gy holk?

English: 85 The proud have digged pits for mee : which are not after thy Law.
Manx: 85. Ta yn slyei morniagh er glyei wigg my ghôwrs : nagh vel nyrg tdy lýeis.

English: 86 All thy Commandements are true : they persecute mee falsely; O be thou my helpe.
Manx: 86. Ta wlly t’ abertsyn firrinagh : t’ ayd janw eiyrts orrym gy fallsy; O bíi us my ghẃney.

English: 87 They had almost made an ende of me upon earth : but I forsooke not thy Commandements.
Manx: 87. Véagh ayd faggys ern’ ianw kiann orryms er y tallw : fóost gha hréeg mi t’ abertsyn.

English: 88 O quicken mee after thy loving kindnesse : and so shall I keepe the testimonies of thy mouth.
Manx: 88. Biói mish nyre tdy ghéindylys gráyigoil : as shen mar rielyms feanishyn tdy veyls.
LAMED ל.

English: In æternum Domine.
Manx: In eternum Domine. 12.

English: O Lord, thy word : endureth for ever in heaven.
Manx: 89. O Hiarn, ta t’ okyls : farraghtyn gybragh ayns neaw.

English: 90 Thy trueth also remaineth from one generation to another : thou hast layd the foundation of the earth, and it abideth.
Manx: 90. Ta t’ irrinys níist farraghtyn vei yn shilogh gys anáyn elle : tows er séìaghe bwnn y tallẃin, as t’ é fannaghtyn.

English: 91 They continue this day according to thine ordinance : for all things serve thee.
Manx: 91. T’ ayd fannaghtyn ju nyre t’ ordyghyns : erson ta dygh wlly redd dy dy hyrvés.

English: 92 If my delight had not bene in thy Lawe : I should have perished in my trouble.
Manx: 92. Agh y bé[253] va my hattnys ayns tdy lýeis : véìn er my ghalchey[254] ayns my sýaghyn.

English: 93 I will never forget thy Commaundements : for with them thou hast quickened me.
Manx: 93. Gha jarwdym gybrágh t’ ábertsyn : erson riusyn tow us er my vioghy.

English: 94 I am thine, O save mee : for I have sought thy Commandements.
Manx: 94. Sh’ latt mish; O saw mi : erson hyìr mi t’ abertsyn.

English: 95 The ungodly layde waite for me, to destroy me : but I will consider thy Testimonies.
Manx: 95. Ren yn niawghrawi lyei farkiaght orrym dy my strwi : agh smwniyms er tdy rikortyns.

English: 96 I see that all things come to an end : but thy Commandement is exceeding broad.
Manx: 96. Híim gy vell gygh wlly redd chiit gys kiann : agh ta t’ aberts fíir lién.
MEM. ם.

English: Quomodo dilexi.
Manx: Quomodo dilexi. 13.

English: Lord, what love have I unto thy Law : all the day long is my studie in it.
Manx: 97. Hiarn, kre yn grayi t’ aym gys tdy lyeis : fei yn lá ta mi smwnyghtyn áyn.

English: 98 Thou through thy Commandements hast made me wiser then mine enemies : for they are ever with me.
Manx: 98. Tow us tryeid t’ abertsyn er my ianw naskriny na my noidjyn : erson t’ ayd gybragh maryms.

English: 99 I have more understanding then my teachers : for thy Testimonies are my studie.
Manx: 99. Ta twigel smw ayms na agg m’ ’yíir ynsi : erson ta tdy rikortyns my smẃnaghtyn.

English: 100 I am wiser then the aged : because I keepe thy Commandements.
Manx: 100. Ta mi na skriny na yn hiéndiyght : erson gy vel mi frial t’ abertsyn.

English: 101 I have refrained my feete from every evill way : that I may keepe thy word.
Manx: 101. Drial mi my ghassyn vei gygh wlly grogh-ráyd : gy voddym t’ okyls y rial.

English: 102 I have not shrunke from thy Judgements : for thou teachest me.
Manx: 102. Gha nel mi er skyrr vei tdy vrwinys : erson tows dy my ynsaghe.

English: 103 O how sweete are thy wordes unto my throat : yea, sweeter then honie unto my mouth.
Manx: 103. O gho millish as ta [t’ ] okelyn dy my skorniagh : ta mi gra, na smillishy na mill dy my véal.

English: 104 Through thy Commaundements I get understanding : therefore I hate all wicked wayes.
Manx: 104. Trýid t’ abertsyn ta mi geadthyn twigel : shennyfá ta dwoi aym er dygh wlly grogh rayd.

English: wicked] 1662 evill
The xxvi. day.
Manx: Yn xxvi. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Áryn.
NVN. נ.

English: Lucerna pedibus meis.
Manx: Lucerna pedibus meis. 14.

English: Thy word is a lanterne unto my feete : and a light unto my paths.
Manx: 105. Ta t’ okyls lándér dy my ghassyn : as soilshe dy my ghassanyn.

English: 106 I have sworne, and am stedfastly purposed : to keepe thy righteous Judgements.
Manx: 106. Ta mi er lẃ, as ta my howlaghy gy sićkyr : dy rial tdy vrwinyssyn káyragh.

English: 107 I am troubled above measure : quicken mee (O Lord) according to thy word.
Manx: 107. Ta mi ayns sýaghyn erskyn tow̌ys : biôi mi, O Hiarn, nyre t’ okyls.

English: 108 Let the free will offerings of my mouth please thee, O Lord : and teach me thy Judgements.
Manx: 108. Ligg e owrel fríi my véal us y vwias, O Hiarn : as ynsi dw̌ys tdy vrwinyssyn.

English: 109 My soule is alway in my hand : yet do I not forget thy Law.
Manx: 109. Ta m’ anym goni ayns my law : fóost gha vel mi jarwd tdy lýòis.

English: 110 The ungodly have laid a snare for me : but yet I swarved not from thy Commandements.
Manx: 110. Tá yn niawghráwi er seiaghe ryǐbbe maghóẁrs : agh foost ghá jagh mí er shaghran vei t’ abertsyn.

English: 111 Thy testimonies have I claimed as mine heritage for ever : and why? they are the very joy of my heart.
Manx: 111. Tdy rikortyns ta mi erna hyrre mar m’ eíỳrys gybragh : as kamma? t’ ayd gy jarw boggey my ghri.

English: 112 I have applied my heart to fulfil thy Statutes alway : even unto the end.
Manx: 112. Hwgg mi my ghri dy liény tdy lattyssyn goni : gy jarw gys y jere.
ס.

English: Iniquos odio habui.
Manx: Iniquos odio habui. 15.

English: I hate them that imagine evill things : but thy Law doe I love.
Manx: 113. Ta dwoi aym oriusyn ta smẃnaghtyn drogh redyn : agh shúney liâm tdy lyei.

English: 114 Thou art my defence and shielde : and my trust is in thy word.
Manx: 114. She us my riál as my ske : as ta my hreistéel ayns t’ okyls.

English: 115 Away from me ye wicked : I wil keepe the Commandements of my God.
Manx: 115. As y rayd voyms, shiuss ta olk : friâlyms abertsyn my Iíh.

English: 116 O stablish me according to thy word, that I may live : and let me not be disappointed of my hope.
Manx: 116. O laidjeri mish nyre t’ okyls, gy voddym biô : na ligg dow ve er my ghwrr shaghey my hreistéel.

English: 117 Hold thou mee up, and I shall be safe : yea, my delight shall be ever in thy Statutes.
Manx: 117. Kẃm mish shýas, as biym sawchey : ta mi grá, as bíi my hatnys gybragh ayns tdy lattyssyns.

English: 118 Thou hast troden downe all them that depart from thy Statutes : for they imagine but deceit.
Manx: 118. Tóus er stampe shíis wlly aydsyn ta doll vei tdy lattyssyn : erson gha vel ayd smẃnaghtyn agh maltáryght.

English: 119 Thou puttest away all the ungodly of the earth like drosse : therefore I love thy Testimonies.
Manx: 119. Tóus kwrr er shiul yn niawghrawi wlly dyn tallw mar trystyr : shennyfá shúney liâm tdy rikortyns.

English: 120 My flesh trembleth for feare of thee : and I am afraid of thy Judgements.
Manx: 120. Ta m’ eyl krá erson agyl jíds : as ta mi goyl agyl dy tdy vrwinyssyn.
ע.

English: Feci iudicium.
Manx: Feci iudicium. 16.

English: I deale with the thing that is lawfull and right : O give me not over unto mine oppressors.
Manx: 121. Ta mi kwrr rish yn red ta lowel : O na kwrr mish harrish gys my hrynlási.

English: 122 Make thou thy servant to delight in that which is good : that the proud do me no wrong.
Manx: 122. Kwr er tdy herváynt tatnys y góyl ayns shen ta mei : nagh jean yn slyei morniagh veg yn iagáyr dow.
tatnys] ms. t’atnys; yn iagáyr] ms. y nia gáyr

English: 123 Mine eyes are wasted away with looking for thy health : and for the word of thy righteousnesse.
Manx: 123. Ta my hwilyn er gef er shiul rish jéaghyn erson tdy laint : as erson fokyl tdy ghayrys.

English: 124 O deale with thy servant according unto thy loving mercie : and teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: 124. O jean rish tdy herváynt nyre tdy vyghin grayigóil : as ynsi dwys tdy lattyssyn.

English: 125 I am thy servant, O grant me understanding : that I may know thy testimonies.
Manx: 125. She tdy hervaynt mi; O gial dow twigel : gy vod áynchys ve aym er t’ eanishyns.

English: 126 It is time for thee Lord to lay to thine hand : for they have destroyed thy Law.
Manx: 126. Sh’ mi dwitch, O Hiarn, dy hoyrt hwgge tdy law : erson t’ ayd er strwiel tdy lyei.

English: 127 For I love thy Commandements : above golde and precious stone.
Manx: 127. Erson shúne liam t’ anaghyn : erskyn áyr as klagh dýyr.
dýyr] ms. sýyr

English: 128 Therefore hold I streight all thy Commandements : and all false wayes I utterly abhorre.
Manx: 128. Shennyfa ta mi ghwmmell jíragh t’ annaghyns wlly : as wlly rajyn falsy ta mi gy glan toyrt dwoi daw.
mi] ms. my; dwoi daw] ms. daw dwoi
פ.

English: Mirabilia.
Manx: Mirabilia. 17.

English: Thy testimonies are wonderfull : therefore doeth my soule keepe them.
Manx: 129. Ta t’ iényssyn ientyssagh : shennyfá ta my anym dan vrial áyd.

English: 130 When thy word goeth forth : it giveth light and understanding unto the simple.
Manx: 130. Nar ta t’ okyls dol magh : t’ e toyrt soilshe as twigel dyn klyei imbli.

English: 131 I opened my mouth, and drew in my breath : for my delight was in thy Commandements.
Manx: 131. Doskyl mi my véal, as harn mi schiagh m’ ánel : erson va my hatnys ayns t’ anaghyn.

English: 132 O looke thou upon me, and be mercifull unto mee : as thou usest to doe unto those that love thy Name.
Manx: 132. O jeagh us ořryms, as bíi myghinagh dwys : mar tow klaghte y ianw dáẁsyn shúney lesh t’ ényms.
myghinagh] ms. myghniagh

English: 133 Order my steps in thy word : and so shall no wickednesse have dominion over me.
Manx: 133. Réel us my ghasmeidjyn ayns t’ okyls : as shen mar nagh bíi réel ag niaw-ghrawiys erbi orryms.

English: 134 O deliver me from the wrongfull dealings of men : and so shall I keep thy Commandements.
Manx: 134. O lifrée mish vei janw ágayragh géne : as shen mar rialym t’ abertsyn.

English: 135 Shew the light of thy countenance upon thy servant : and teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: 135. Jeagh soilshe t’ edyns er tdy herváynt : as ynsi dŵys t’ ordyghyns.

English: 136 Mine eyes gush out with water : because men keep not thy Law.
Manx: 136. Ta my hwilyns shyillie magh rish ẃisky : erson nagh vel deney frial tdy lýèis.
צ.

English: Iustus es Domine.
Manx: Iuﬆus es Domine. 18.

English: Righteous art thou, O Lord : and true is thy judgement.
Manx: 137. Tóẁs káyragh, O Hiarn : as sh’ firrinagh dy vrwinys.

English: 138 The Testimonies that thou hast commanded : are exceeding righteous and true.
Manx: 138. Ta ny feánishyn tóẁs erna háry : fíir káyr as firrinagh.

English: 139 My zeale hath even consumed mee : because mine enemies have forgotten thy words.
Manx: 139. Ta m’ agney ché gy jarw er my gheyf : erson gy iarwd my noidjyn t’ okelyns.

English: 140 Thy word is tried to the uttermost : and thy servant loveth it.
Manx: 140. Ta t’ okyls erna phrowel gys y ghwid soje : as shúney lesh tdy hervaynt é.

English: 141 I am small, and of no reputation : yet do I not forget thy Commandements.
Manx: 141. Ta mish begg, as beggan dy heiaghe jîms : fóost gha nell mi jarwd t’ abertsyn.

English: 142 Thy righteousnesse is an everlasting righteousnesse : and thy Law is the trueth.
