Manx: 142. She tdy gháyrys káyrys gybragh farraghtyn : as tdy lyeis yn irriny.

English: 143 Trouble and heavinesse have taken hold upon me : yet is my delight in thy Commandements.
Manx: 143. Ta sýaghyn as trimshey ern’ goyl grymm oryms : fóost ta [my] hatnys ayns t’ abertsyn.

English: 144 The righteousnesse of thy Testimonies is everlasting : O grant me understanding, and I shall live.
Manx: 144. Ta káyrys t’ éanishyns farraghtyn gybragh : O giall dow twigel, as biym biô.

English: The xxvi. day.
Manx: Yn xxvi. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.
ק.

English: Clamaui in toto corde meo
Manx: Clamavi in toto corde. 19.

English: I call with my whole heart : heare me, O Lord, I will keepe thy Statutes.
Manx: 145. Jei mi rish wlly my ghri : klẃin mi, O Hiarn, as frialym tdy lattyssyn.

English: 146 Yea, even unto thee doe I call : helpe me, and I shall keepe thy Testimonies.
Manx: 146. Ta mi grá, gy jarw hwyds ta mi gemagh : kwỳn liam, as frielyms tdy rikortyns.

English: 147 Earely in the morning doe I cry unto thee : for in thy word is my trust.
Manx: 147. Gy moghey ayns y voghre ta mi gemagh hwyds : erson ayns t’ okyls ta my hreistéel.

English: 148 Mine eyes prevent the night watches : that I might be occupied in thy words.
Manx: 148. Ta my hwilyn chiit réỳf arry ny hyi : gy voddin ve klaghtíit ayns t’ okelyn.

English: 149 Hear my voyce (O Lord) according unto thy loving kindnesse : quicken me, according as thou art wont.
Manx: 149. Klwỳn my ghorá, O Hiarn, nyre tdy ghéindylys grayigoil : biôi mish mar bollagh ẃ.

English: 150 They draw nigh that of malice persecute mee : and are farre from thy Law.
Manx: 150. T’ áyd tayrn argere ta dy ganlys janw drogh éìyrts orrym : as t’ áyd fodey vei tdy lýèi.

English: 151 Be thou nigh at hand, O Lord : for all thy Commandements are true.
Manx: 151. Bíi us faggys ag law, O Hiarn : erson ta wlly t’ anaghyn firrinagh.

English: 152 As concerning thy Testimonies, I have knowen long since : that thou hast grounded them for ever.
Manx: 152. My ghian t’ eanish-syn, bawn dow áyd fodey hénny : gy hei us ayd erson gybragh.
ר.

English: Vide humilitatem
Manx: Vide humilitatem. 20.
Vide] ms. vidi

English: O consider mine adversitie, and deliver me: for I doe not forget thy Law.
Manx: 153. O smwni er my hyaghyn as lifrée mi : erson gha vell mi jarẃd tdy lyei.

English: 154 Avenge thou my cause, and deliver mee : quicken me according to thy word.
Manx: 154. Kwilíin us my ghẃis, as lifrée mi : biôi mi nyre t’ okyl.

English: 155 Health is farre from the ungodly : for they regard not thy Statutes.
Manx: 155. Ta slaynt fodey vei yn niawghráwi : erson gha nell áyd janw friwys dy t’ abertsyn.

English: 156 Great is thy mercie, O Lord : quicken me, as thou art wont.
Manx: 156. Sh’ mẃar dy vyghin, O Hiarn : biôi mish mar ballagh ẃ.

English: 157 Many there are that trouble me, and persecute me : yet doe I not swarve from thy Testimonies.
Manx: 157. Sh’ ímmey aydsyn ta dy my hyaghyn, as dy my éìyrt gy holk : fóost gha vel mi dol as y ráyd vei tdy rikórtyns.

English: 158 It grieveth mee when I see the transgressours : because they keepe not thy Law.
Manx: 158. T’ e janw chinnys dow nar híỳm aydsyn ta janw gy holk : erson nagh vel áyd frial tdj lyôeis.

English: 159 Consider, O Lord, how I love thy Commandements : O quicken me according to thy loving kindnesse.
Manx: 159. Smwni, O Hiarn, kyns b’ uney liam t’ anaghyn : O biôi mish nyre tdy gheindylys grayigoil.

English: 160 Thy word is true from everlasting : all the Judgements of thy righteousnesse endure for evermore.
Manx: 160. Ta t’ okyls firrinagh vei riu : ta wlly brwinys dy gháyrys farraghtyn erson gybragh.
ש.

English: Principes persecuti sunt
Manx: Principes persecuti sunt. 21.

English: Princes have persecuted me without a cause: but my heart standeth in awe of thy words.
Manx: 161. Deiyr prynsaghyn gy holk mi gyn óyr : agh ta my ghrí shassw ayns agyl dy t’ okylyns.

English: thy words.] 1662 thy word.
162 I am as glad of thy Word : as one that findeth great spoyles.
Manx: 162. Ta mi gho gannoil dy t’ okyls : as anáyn ta geadthin kragh vẃar.

English: 163 As for lies, I hate and abhorre them : but thy Law doe I love.
Manx: 163. Erson breagyn, ta dwoi as fúa aym ořrw : agh sh’ úney liam tdy lyôei.

English: 164 Seven times a day doe I praise thee : because of thy righteous Judgements.
Manx: 164. Shaght kiyrtyn ’sŷ lá ta mi dy tdy volley : erson tdy vrwinys káyr.

English: 165 Great is the peace that they have which love thy Law : and they are not offended at it.
Manx: 165. Sh’ mẃar y shíi t’ acksyn sh’ uney lesh tdy lyoei : as ghanel ayd jẃmẃygh rish.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: sh’ uney] ms. sh’nney

English: 166 Lord, I have looked for thy saving health : and done after thy Commandements.
Manx: 166. Hiarn, ta mi ern iaghyn erson tdy láint sawálagh : as ern ianw nýre t’ anaghyn.

English: 167 My soule hath kept thy Testimonies : and loved them exceedingly.
Manx: 167. Dríal m’ anym tdy rikórtyns : as b’ uney lé àyd gy fíir vẃar.

English: 168 I have kept thy Commandements and Testimonies : for all my wayes are before thee.
Manx: 168. Ta mi er fríal t’ anaghyns as rikortyns : erson ta wlly my rádjyns t’ eanishus.
t’ eanishus] ms. t’ eanish us
ת.

English: Appropinquet deprecatio
Manx: Appropinquet deprecatio. 22.

English: Let my complaint come before thee, O Lord : give me understanding according to thy word.
Manx: 169. Ligg e m’ akkan chiit t’ enish, O Hiarn : kwrr dow twigel nyre t’ okyl.

English: 170 Let my supplication come before thee : deliver me according to thy word.
Manx: 170. O ligg e m’ aghin chíit t’ eanish : lifrée mish nyre t’ okyls.

English: 171 My lippes shall speake of thy praise : when thou hast taught me thy Statutes.
Manx: 171. Níi my véliyn loyrt dy tdy volley : nar víis ẃ ern ynsaghy dẃỳs tdy lattyssyn.

English: 172 Yea, my tongue shall sing of thy word : for all thy Commandements are righteous.
Manx: 172. Gy jarw, gowi my hiange oráyn dy t’ okyls : erson ta wlly t’ annaghyn káyroil.

English: 173 Let thine hand helpe me : for I have chosen thy Commandements.
Manx: 173. Ligg e tdy law kẃne liâm : erson ta mi er ryei t’ anaghyn.

English: 174 I have longed for thy saving health, O Lord : and in thy Law is my delight.
Manx: 174. Gow mi fodiaght erson dy láint sawálagh, O Hiarn : as ayns tdy lyoei ta my hatnys.

English: 175 O let my soule live, and it shall praise thee : and thy Judgements shall helpe me.
Manx: 175. O ligg dy m’ anym vé bio, as ní í us y volley : as kẃyni tdy vrwinyssyn láym.

English: 176 I have gone astray like a sheepe that is lost : Oh seeke thy servant, for I doe not forget thy Commandements.
Manx: 176. Ta mi er nol er shaghran kasly rish kirri ta kalchy : O shy̌irr tdy herváynt, erson ghanell mi jarwd t’ anaghyn.

English: The xxvii. day.
Manx: Yn xxvii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Ad Dominum. Psal. 120
Manx: Ad dominum. psal. 120.

English: When I was in trouble I called upon the Lord : and he heard me.
Manx: 1. Nar va mi ayns sýaghyn, jei mi er y Chiarn : ass ghýyl e mi.

English: 2 Deliver my soule, O Lord, from lying lips : and from a deceitful tongue.
Manx: 2. Lifrée m’ anym, O Hiarn, vei meliyn bregagh : as vei chiange maltóil.

English: 3 What reward shall bee given or done unto thee thou false tongue : even mighty and sharpe arrowes, with hote burning coales.
Manx: 3. Kre yn féaghyn[255] víis erna hoyrt na erna ianw dwitch, us hiange falsy : gy jarw seidjyn gniártoil as géyr, rish smaragyn che losky.

English: 4 Woe is mee, that I am constrained to dwell with Mesech : and to have my habitation among the tents of Cedar.
Manx: 4. Smárig[256] ta my vei[257], gy vel mi er m’ egnaghy dy vághey marish Mesech : as dy góyl my vaghey masky kabbanyn Kedar.

English: 5 My soule hath long dwelt among them : that bee enemies unto peace.
Manx: 5. Ta m’ anym er vaghey foddey nan maskysyn : ta nan noidjyn dy híi.

English: that bee] 1662 that are
6 I labour for peace, but when I speake unto them thereof : they make them ready to battell.
Manx: 6. Ta mi gobraghy erson shíi, agh nar liorym riusyn ié shen : t’ ayd d’ an ianw héyn arlw gys kage.

English: Leuaui oculos. Psal. 121.
Manx: Levaui oculos. psal. 121.

English: I will lift up mine eyes unto the hilles : from whence commeth my helpe.
Manx: 1. Trogym syas my hwilyn gys ny knwick : vei ta mi ghwyney chíit.

English: 2 My helpe commeth even from the Lord : which hath made heaven and earth.
Manx: 2. Ta my ghwyney chíit gy jarw vei yn Chiarn : ta ern’ ianw neaw as tallw.

English: which] 1662 who
3 He wil not suffer thy foote to be mooved : and hee that keepeth thee, will not sleepe.
Manx: 3. Gha vwlli é tdy ghass dy ve erna skwghey : as eshyn ta dy tdy ríals, gha jean e kadly.

English: 4 Behold, he that keepeth Israel : shall neither slumber nor sleepe.
Manx: 4. Jéagh, gha jean eshyn ta frial Israel : sevínagh na kadly.

English: 5 The Lord himselfe is thy keeper : the Lord is thy defence upon thy right hand;
Manx: 5. She yn Chiarn héyn t’ ’er kawdi : she yn Chiarn t’ endéel er tdy law iesh;

English: 6 So that the Sunne shall not burne thee by day : neither the Moone by night.
Manx: 6. Marshen nagh losk yn grian ẃ ayns y lá : na yn éask ayns yn yi.

English: 7 The Lord shall preserve thee from all evill : yea, it is even he that shall keepe thy soule.
Manx: 7. Frialẏ yn Chiarn ẃ vei gygh wlly olk : ta mi grá, she eshyn gy jarw rialys t’ anym.

English: 8 The Lord shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in : from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 8. Friali yn Chiarn dy goll magh as dy híit schiagh : vei yn iérish sho magh erson gybrágh.

English: Lætatus sum. Psal. 122.
Manx: Letatus sum. [psal.] 122.

English: I was glad when they said unto me : Wee will goe into the house of the Lord.
Manx: 1. Va mi gannoil trá dwyrt áyd rwyms : héid méid gys tyei yn Chiarn.

English: 2 Our feet shal stand in thy gates : O Hierusalem.
Manx: 2. Shassi nan gassyn aýn tdy gorsyn : O Jeriusalem.

English: 3 Hierusalem is built as a Citie : that is at unitie in it selfe.
Manx: 3. Ta Jeriusalem trogit mar ayrd valley : ta ag anánys ayns héyn.

English: 4 For thither the Tribes goe up, even the Tribes of the Lord : to testifie unto Israel, to give thanks unto the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 4- Erson aynshen ta ny kynaghyn dol sýas, gy jarw kynaghyn yn Chiarn : dy ymmyrke feanish dy Israel, dy hoyrt bwias dy enym yn Chiarn.

English: 5 For there is the seat of Judgement : even the seat of the house of David.
Manx: 5. Erson aynshen ta ynyd sei ny brwinys : gy jarw ynyd syěi tei Gavid.
tei] ms. dy

English: 6 O pray for the peace of Jerusalem : they shall prosper that love thee.
Manx: 6. O gowigi padjer erson shíi Jeriusalem : heid áyd gy mei ernan dossagh shuney lesh us.

English: that] 1605 tha
7 Peace be within thy walles : and plenteousnesse within thy palaces.
Manx: 7. Gy row shíi er leyf styei tdy vallaghyn : as palchys er leyf styei dy tdy phlásyn.
shíi] ms. Jih

English: 8 For my brethren and companions sakes : I will wish thee prosperitie.
Manx: 8. Erson gráyi my vráeraghyn as my hessaghyn : niyms ráh mei y howlaghey dwitch.

English: 9 Yea, because of the house of the Lord our God : I will seeke to doe thee good.
Manx: 9. Ta mi grá, erson tyei yn Chiarn nan Iíh : shyrrym dy ianw mei dwitch.

English: Ad te leuaui oculos meos. Psal. 123.
Manx: Ad te levaui oculos. psal. 123.

English: Unto thee lift I up mine eyes : O thou that dwellest in the heavens.
Manx: 1. Hwyds ta mí trogel sýas my hwilyn : O us ta vaghey ayns ny neawaghyn.

English: 2 Beholde, even as the eyes of servants looke unto the hand of their masters, and as the eyes of a mayden unto the hand of her mystresse : even so our eyes waite upon the Lord our God, untill he have mercy upon us.
Manx: 2. Jeagh, gy jarw mar ta sẃylyn shérvayntyn jeaghyn gys láẁ nan meistryn, as mar swilyn innivýyl gys law y ben veistyr : gy jarw marshen ta nan swilyn farkiaght er yn Chiarn nan Iíh, naggydere ní é myghin orwin.

English: 3 Have mercie upon us, O Lord, have mercie upon us : for we are utterly despised.
Manx: 3. Jean myghin orwin, O Hiarn, jean myghin ořrwin : erson ta róo vegg dy heiaghe juiniyn.

English: 4 Our soule is filled with the scornefull reproofe of the wealthy : and with the despitefulnesse of the proud.
Manx: 4. Tá nan anym liénit rish aghsan knáidjóil ny dene berchiagh : as rish sproght ny deney morniagh.

English: Nisi quia Dominus. Psal. 124.
Manx: Nisi quia Dominus. psal. 124.

English: If the Lord himselfe had not bene on our side (now may Israel say :) if the Lord himselfe had not bene on our side, when men rose up against us;
Manx: 1. Agh y be va yn Chiarn héyn er nan jef, nish ’odys Israel y grá : agh y be va yn Chiarn héyn er nan jeyf, nar jirri déney shúas nan nýoi;

English: 2 They had swallowed us up quicke : when they were so wrathfully displeased at us.
Manx: 2. Veagh ayd er nan slwggey sýas biô : nar v’ áyd gho fargẃyl jumwiagh rwin.

English: 3 Yea, the waters had drowned us : and the streame had gone over our soule.
Manx: 3. Ta mi gra, veagh ny hẃiskaghyn er nan máyg : as yn strẃ er noll harrish nan anym.

English: 4 The deepe waters of the proude : had gone even over our soule.
Manx: 4. Véagh wiskey doun yn slyei vorniagh : er noll gy jarw harrish nan anym.

English: 5 But praised be the Lord : which hath not given us over for a pray unto their teeth.
Manx: 5. Agh mollíit gy row yn Chiarn : nagh vel er nan doyrt shwiniyn harrish ghon krágh gys nan viěkylyn.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: krágh] ms. kráh

English: 6 Our soule is escaped, even as a birde out of the snare of the fouler : the snare is broken, and we are delivered.
Manx: 6. Ta nan anym er shaghny, gy jarw mar éyn magh as ribbe yn fer marw éyn : ta yn ribbe brist, as ta shwiniyn lifreit.

English: 7 Our helpe standeth in the Name of the Lord : which hath made heaven and earth.
Manx: 7. Ta nan gwney shassw ayns enym yn Chiarn : ren neaw as tallw.

English: which] 1662 who
Qui confidunt. Psal. 125.
Manx: Qui confidunt. psal. 125.

English: They that put their trust in the Lord, shall be even as the mount Sion : which may not be remooved, but standeth fast for ever.
Manx: 1. Aydsyn ta toyrt nan dreistéel ayns y Chiarn, bi ayd gy jarw mar knock Seion : nagh vodd ve er ny skwghy, agh shassw gy sickyr erson gybragh.
ny skwghy] ms. yn skwghy

English: 2 The hilles stand about Hierusalem : even so standeth the Lord round about his people, from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 2. Ta ny knwick shassw magiyrt Jeriusalem : gy jarw marshen ta yn Chiarn shassw krẃn magiyrt y phobyl, veí yn trá sho magh erson gybragh.

English: 3 For the rod of the ungodly commeth not into the lot of the righteous : lest the righteous put their hand unto wickednesse.
Manx: 3. Erson gha vell slatt y niaw ghrawi chíit gys kranghyr yn klyei ghrawi : nagh derr yn slyei ghráwi nan law gys olkys.

English: 4 Doe well, O Lord : unto those that bee good and true of heart.
Manx: 4. O Hiarn, jean gy mei : dawsyn ta mei as firrinagh dy ghri.

English: bee] 1662 are
5 As for such as turne backe unto their owne wickednes : the Lord shal leade them forth with the evil doers; but peace shal be upon Israel.
Manx: 5. Agh erson léid as ta chyndá er gẃl gys nan olkys héyn : líidji yn Chiarn aydsyn magh marish yn slyei ta janw olk; agh bíi shíi er Israel.

English: The xxvii. day.
Manx: Yn xxvii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: In conuertendo. Psal. 126.
Manx: In convertendo. psal. 126.

English: When the Lord turned againe the captivitie of Sion : then were we like unto them that dreame.
Manx: 1. Nar hyndá yn Chiarn ríist kapy Seion : éish va shwiniyn kasly riusyn ta brynládi.

English: 2 Then was our mouth filled with laughter : and our tongue with joy.
Manx: 2. Éis va nan méal líint rish géary : as nan jange rish boggey.

English: 3 Then saide they among the Heathen : The Lord hath done great things for them.
Manx: 3. Eis dẃyrt áyd masky ny hangristíin : ta yn Chiarn ern’ ianw redyn mẃary er-nan-son.

English: 4 Yea, the Lord hath done great things for us already : whereof we rejoyce.
Manx: 4. Ta mi grá, ta yn Chiarn ern ianw redyn mẃayry er nan son hanna : ie ta shwin goyl bogey.

English: 5 Turne our captivitie, O Lord : as the rivers in the South.
Manx: 5. Chynda nan gapy, O Hiarn : mar ny strẃanyn ayns y jass.

English: 6 They that sow in teares : shall reape in joy.
Manx: 6. Aydsyn ta kwrr ayns jóèyr : bwnni áyd ayns bogey.

English: 7 Hee that now goeth on his way weeping, and beareth foorth good seed : shall doubtlesse come againe with joy, and bring his sheaves with him.
Manx: 7. Eshyn ta nish doll er y ráyd kẃo, as ta jimmyrke magh rass méi : gyn ymné, higg é ríist rish bogey as ver e lesh y vwíninyn.

English: Nisi Dominus. Psal. 127.
Manx: Nisi Dominus. psal. 127.

English: Except the Lord builde the house : their labour is but lost that build it.
Manx: 1. Managh drogg yn Chiarn y tyei : gha vel yn obyr acksyn agh kalchey ta dy hrogyl é.

English: 2 Except the Lord keepe the Citie : the watchman waketh but in vaine.
Manx: 2. Managh vríal yn Chiarn yn ayrd valle : ta yn fer are dwyske ayns fardayl.

English: 3 It is but lost labour that ye haste to rise up earely, and so late take rest, and eate the bread of carefulnesse : for so he giveth his beloved sleepe.
Manx: 3. Gha vel e agh obyr kallchey gy jean shiu seir dy irri sýas gy moghe, as marshen gy hamnagh dy góyl fé, as dy íi aran yn ymné : erson marshen te toyrt kadly da er grayigoil.

English: 4 Loe, children and the fruit of the wombe : are an heritage and gift that commeth of the Lord.
Manx: 4. Jeagh, klawn as meass ny brónniy[258] : she eirys áyd as toyrtys ta chíit vei yn Chiarn.

English: 5 Like as the arrowes in the hand of the Giant : even so are the yong children.
Manx: 5. Mar ny seijyn ayns law foyr : marshen ta yn klawn agy.

English: 6 Happy is the man that hath his quiver full of them : they shall not bee ashamed when they speake with their enemies in the gate.
Manx: 6. Banníit ta yn dwyne ag vel y ghéver layn ju : gha gow ayd náre narr loyrys ayd rish nan noidjyn ayns y dorrys.
loyrys] ms. liórish

English: Beati omnes. Psal. 128.
Manx: Beati omnes. psal. 128.

English: Blessed are all they that feare the Lord : and walke in his wayes.
Manx: 1. Banníit ta aydsyn wlly ta goyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn : as gimmiaght ayns y raydjyn-syn.

English: 2 For thou shalt eate the labours of thine handes : O well is thee, and happy shalt thou be.
Manx: 2. Erson íit ẃ obeyraghyn dy lawyn : O s’ méi tóẁ, as smaynry víis ẃ.

English: 3 Thy wife shal be as the fruitfull Vine : upon the walls of thine house.
Manx: 3. Bíi tdy ven mar yn bille phieny messoil : er ballaghyn tdy hyei;

English: 4 Thy children like the Olive branches : round about thy table.
Manx: 4. Tdy ghlawn mar banglányn yn ólyf : krwǹ magiyrt tdy voyrd.

English: 5 Loe, thus shall the man bee blessed : that feareth the Lord.
Manx: 5. Jeagh, marshó víis yn dẃyne baníit : ta góyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn.

English: 6 The Lord from out of Sion shall so blesse thee : that thou shalt see Hierusalem in prosperitie all thy life long.
Manx: 6. Baníi yn Chiarn us marshen magh as Sion : gy vaick ẃ Jeriusalem ayns maýnrys ry dy hýyl wlly.

English: 7 Yea, that thou shalt see thy childrens children: and peace upon Israel.
Manx: 7. Ta mi grá, gy váick us klawn dy ghlenniy : as shíi er Israel.

English: Sæpe expugnauerunt. Psal. 129.
Manx: Sepe expugnauerunt. [psal.] 129.

English: Many a time have they fought against me from my youth up : (may Israel now say.)
Manx: 1. Sh’ immy kiy̌rt ren áyd kagey m’ ýoi vei m’ agid shýas : nish odys Israel y grá;

English: 2 Yea, many a time have they vexed me from my youth up : but they have not prevailed against me.
Manx: 2. Sh’ immy kiyrt, ta mi grá, t’ áyd er my hyaghyn vei m’ agidj shúas [: ...][259]

English: 3 The plowers plowed upon my backe : and made long furrowes.
Manx: 3. Ren ny hérynyn[260] tréaw[261] er my gryim : as ren ayd krighyn liáwr.

English: 4 But the righteous Lord : hath hewen the snares of the ungodly in pieces.
Manx: 4. Agh ta yn Chiarn káyragh : ern’ giarr̀y ribbaghyn yn niawghrawi nan stwćkaghyn.
stwćkaghyn] ms. skwćkaghyn

English: 5 Let them bee confounded and turned backward: as many as have evill will at Sion.
Manx: 5. Ligg aw ve er nan doyrt gys nayre as er nan jyndá er gẃl : ghwilin as ta drogh agny ack gys Seion.

English: 6 Let them bee even as the grasse growing upon the house tops : which withereth afore it be plucked up;
Manx: 6. Ligg aw ve gy jarw mar yn féer gáas er mẃlagh ny deiyn : ta fiogh ma bíi e erna harn shúas;

English: 7 Whereof the mower filleth not his hand : neither hee that bindeth up the sheaves, his bosome.
Manx: 7. Iê nagh vell yn phalỳder[262] liény y law : ghamw eshyin ta kaingly sýas ny bẃinninyn y oghrys.

English: 8 So that they who go by, say not so much as, The Lord prosper you : we wish you good lucke in the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 8. Marshen nagh vel aydsyn ta dol shaghey grá ghwish shen as, yn Chiarn dy riagh[263] reyf : ta shwin sowlaghy aií mei díífs ayns enym yn Chiarn.

English: PSALM 130.
De profundis. Psal. 130.
Manx: De profundis. psal. 130

English: Out of the deepe have I called unto thee (O Lord :) Lord heare my voyce.
Manx: 1. Magh as y díifnid jei mi hwyds, O Hiarn : Hiarn, klwin my ghorá.

English: 2 Oh let thine eares consider well : the voyce of my complaint.
Manx: 2. O ligg e tdy ghlúeshyn taskey mei y hóyrt : gys kóra m’ akkan.

English: 3 If thou Lord wilt bee extreme to marke what is done amisse : O Lord, who may abide it?
Manx: 3. Ma víist us, O Hiarn, róo hiǎn dy hoyrt taskey kre ta jeant gy hagáragh : O Hiarn, quei odys y hyrrell e?

English: 4 For there is mercy with thee : therefore shalt thou be feared.
Manx: 4. Erson ta myghin mayrts : shennyfá víis agyl erna góyl royds.

English: 5 I looke for the Lord; my soule doeth waite for him : in his word is my trust.
Manx: 5. Ta mi jeaghin erson y Chiarn; ta m’ anym farkiaght er : ayns y okylsyn ta my hreistéel.

English: 6 My soule fleeth unto the Lord : before the morning watch, I say, before the morning watch.
Manx: 6. Ta m’ anym getlagh gys y Chiarn : reyfs yn are voghrey, ta mi gra, roish are yn voghrey.

English: 7 O Israel, trust in the Lord, for with the Lord there is mercy : and with him is plenteous redemption.
Manx: 7. O Israel, treist ayns y Chiarn, erson marish yn Chiarn ta myghin : as marish-syn ta fýasly ríist palchey.

English: 8 And he shall redeeme Israel : from all his sinnes.
Manx: 8. As lifreei eshyn Israel : vei y pekaghyn wlly.

English: Domine, non est. Psal. 131.
Manx: Domine non eﬆ. psal. 131.

English: Lord, I am not high minded : I have no proud lookes.
Manx: 1. Hiarn, gha vel mi d’ agney ayrd : ghá vel vegg ny silliaghyn morniagh aym.

English: 2 I doe not exercise my selfe in great matters : which are to high for me.
Manx: 2. Gha vel mi dy my ghliaghty héyn ayns kwyshyn mẃary : ta róo ayrd dow.

English: 3 But I refraine my soule, and keepe it low, like as a childe that is weaned from his mother : yea, my soule is even as a weaned childe.
Manx: 3. Ta mi kwmmel m’ anym da ríal ishill, kasly rish lianw ta erna ghwrr vei kígh y váyry : gy sickyr, ta m’ anym gy jarw mar lianw chyrbáỳt.
kígh y váyry] ms. kig ’sy váyry

English: 4 O Israel trust in the Lord : from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 4. O Israel, treist ayns y Chiarn : vei yn ierish sho magh erson gybragh.

English: The xxviii. day.
Manx: Yn xxviii. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Memento Domine. Psal. 132.
Manx: Memento domine. [psal.] 132.

English: Lord, remember David : and all his trouble;
Manx: 1. O Hiarn, kwini er David : as y hyaghyn wlly;
hyaghyn] ms. syaghyn

English: 2 How he sware unto the Lord : and vowed a vowe unto the Almightie God of Jacob;
Manx: 2. Kyns lẃ e d’ yn Chiarn : ás hwgg e briéry dy Iíh wlly gniartoil Iacob:

English: 3 I will not come within the tabernacle of mine house : nor clime up into my bed;
Manx: 3. Gha jiggyms er leyf styei dy ghabban my hyěi : na gha jeyms shúas gys my labbi;

English: 4 I will not suffer mine eyes to sleepe, nor mine eye lids to slumber : neither the temples of my head to take any rest;
Manx: 4. Gha syrrym my hwilyn dy ghadly, na ferwghyn my hwyly dy ianw sevínaght : na chiampyl my ghiin dy góyl fe erbí;
hwilyn] ms. ghwilyn

English: 5 Untill I finde out a place for the Temple of the Lord : an habitation for the mightie God of Jacob.
Manx: 5. Naggedere ióỳms magh ynyd ghon chiampyl yn Chiarn : ynyd vaghey ghon Iíh wlly gniartoil Iacob.

English: 6 Loe, we heard of the same at Ephrata : and found it in the wood.
Manx: 6. Jeagh, ghýyl shwin iê shen kedyn ag Ephrata : ass heyr shwin e ayns y ghélliy.

English: 7 We will goe into his Tabernacle : and fall low on our knees before his footestoole.
Manx: 7. Heid meid schiagh ayns yn ghabban aglysh aggesyn : as twitt meid gy hishil er nan glẃnyn féanish stoyl y ghassyn.
Heid] ms. Híi

English: 8 Arise, O Lord, into thy resting place : thou, and the Arke of thy strength.
Manx: 8. Irri, O Hiarn, gys t’ ynyd fé : us, as arg tdy gniart.

English: 9 Let thy Priests bee clothed with righteousnesse : and let thy Saints sing with joyfulnesse.
Manx: 9. Ligg e tdy hagartyn ve komrit rish káyrys : ass ligg e tdy nẃghyn orayn y goyl rish bogey.
Ligg e tdy hagartyn] ms. ligge dy tdy hagartyn

English: 10 For thy servant Davids sake : turne not away the presence of thine Anointed.
Manx: 10. Erson grayi dy hervaynt David : na chyndá er shiul edyn tdy ghríist.

English: 11 The Lord hath made a faithfull othe unto David : and he shall not shrinke from it;
Manx: 11. Ta yn Chiarn ern ianw briar firrinagh dy Gavid : as gha jean e schyrr[264] vei.

English: 12 Of the fruit of thy body : shall I set upon thy seate.
Manx: 12. Dy veass tdy ghallyn : heiyms er t’ ynyd [syei].

English: 13 If thy children will keepe my Covenant, and my Testimonies that I shall learne them : their children also shall sit upon thy seat for evermore.
Manx: 13. Ma riélys tdy ghlawn my ghẃnaynt as my iénishyn ynsiym daw : syii yn ghlawn ack níist er t’ ynyd ýasyl erson gybragh.
riélys] ms. riéfs; iénishyn] ms. iéishyn; syii] ms. sydii

English: 14 For the Lord hath chosen Sion to bee an habitation for himselfe : he hath longed for her.
Manx: 14. Erson ta yn Chiarn er ry̌ei Seion dy ve na ýnyd vaghey da héyn : té ern góyl fodiaght er-y-son.

English: 15 This shall be my rest for ever : here wil I dwell, for I have a delight therein.
Manx: 15. Shó víis m’ éé erson gybrágh : aynshó níỳm vaghey, erson ta tatnys aym áyn.

English: 16 I will blesse her vitailes with increase : and wil satisfie her poore with bread.
Manx: 16. Baníim y bíi rish bishagh : as liénym y boghtyn rish aran.

English: 17 I will decke her Priests with health : and her Saints shall rejoyce and sing.
Manx: 17. Kařríỳm y sagartyn rish sláynt : as níi y nẃyn bogey y goyl as oráyn.

English: 18 There shall I make the horne of David to flourish : I have ordeined a lanterne for mine anoynted.
Manx: 18. Aynshen verryms er erick Gávid bláa y hoyrt magh : ta mi ern’ ianw arlw landéer dy my ghríist.

English: 19 As for his enemies, I shall clothe them with shame : but upon himselfe shall his Crowne flourish.
Manx: 19. As erson y noidjyn niyms aydsyn y ghomry rish nayre : agh er héyn níi y attaghan bláa.

English: Ecce quàm bonum. Psal. 133.
Manx: Ecce quam bonum. psal. 133.

English: Behold how good and joyful a thing it is : brethren to dwel together in unitie.
Manx: 1. Jeagh ghó mei as gannoil yn red as t’ e : bráeraghyn dy vaghey kwjaght ayns anánys.

English: 2 It is like the precious oyntment upon the head, that ranne downe unto the beard : even unto Aarons beard, and went downe to the skirts of his clothing.
Manx: 2. Te kasly rish yn ẃil gýèr er y ghian ren ryi shíis gys yn éssayg : gy jarw gys féssáyg Aaron, as hill shíis gys skýyrtyn y ydagh.

English: 3 Like as the dew of Hermon : which fel upon the hil of Sion.
Manx: 3. Kasly rish driŵght Hermon : shen hw̌itt er knock Seion.

English: 4 For there the Lord promised his blessing : and life for evermore.
Manx: 4. Erson aynshen iall yn Chiarn y vanaght : as béé erson gybragh.

English: Ecce nunc. Psal. 134.
Manx: Ecce nunc benedicite. psal. 134.

English: Behold (now) praise the Lord : all ye servants of the Lord;
Manx: 1. Jeagh nish, moligi yn Chiarn : wlly shiusse shervayntyn yn Chiarn;

English: 2 Ye that by night stand in the house of the Lord: even in the Courts of the house of our God.
Manx: 2. Shiusse ta ayns yn ýi shassw ayns ty̌ei yn Chiarn : gy jarw ayns kẃrtyn ty̌ei nan Iíh.
shassw] ms. (Moore) shassy

English: 3 Lift up your handes in the Sanctuary : and praise the Lord.
Manx: 3. Trogigi sýas nan lawyn ayns yn ynyd ghasserick : as molligi yn Chiarn.

English: 4 The Lord that made heaven and earth : give thee blessing out of Sion.
Manx: 4. Yn Chiarn ren neaw as tallw : dy hoyrt dwitch banaght magh as Seion.

English: Laudate Nomen. Psal. 135.
Manx: Laudate nomen. psal. 135.

English: O praise the Lord, laude ye the Name of the Lord : praise it, O ye servants of the Lord;
Manx: 1. Molligi yn Chiarn, molligi enym yn Chiarn : moligi é, O shiusse er-mwinjere yn Chiarn;

English: 2 Ye that stand in the house of the Lord : in the Courts of the house of our God.
Manx: 2. Shiuss ta shassw ayns tyěi yn Chiarn : ayns kẃrtyn tyi nan Iíh.

English: 3 O praise the Lord, for the Lord is gracious : O sing praises unto his Name, for it is lovely.
Manx: 3. O molligi yn Chiarn, erson ta yn Chiarn grásoil : O gowigi oráyn molley dâ enymsyn, erson te grayiygh.

English: 4 For why? the Lord hath chosen Jacob unto himselfe : and Israel for his owne possession.
Manx: 4. Erson kamma? ta yn Chiarn er rýèi Jakob da héyn : as Israel ghon y eirys heyn.

English: 5 For I know that the Lord is great : and that our Lord is above all gods.
Manx: 5. Erson ta fyss aym gy vell yn Chiarn mẃar : as gy vel yn Chiarn ayniyn erskyn dygh wlly iih.

English: 6 Whatsoever the Lord pleased, that did hee in heaven and in earth : and in the sea, and in all deepe places.
Manx: 6. Kre erbí by vẃias lesh yn Chiarn, shen ren e ayns neaw as ayns y tallw : as ayns yn arkey, as ayns gygh wlly ynyd dowin.
by] ms. y (preceding b deleted?)

English: 7 Hee bringeth foorth the cloudes from the endes of the world : and sendeth foorth lightnings with the raine, bringing the winds out of his treasures.
Manx: 7. Te tóyrt magh ny bojalyn vei kíin yn týyl : as te toyrt magh ainilyn tarniagh lesh flaghey, toyrt ny gý-yn magh as y haschaghyn.
y haschaghyn] ms. ny haschaghyn

English: 8 He smote the first borne of Egypt : both of man & beast.
Manx: 8. Voǎll e wlly rwgg hoshiagh ayns Ejipt : dy gẃỳne as dy véagh níist.
Voǎll e] ms. Voǎlly

English: 9 Hee hath sent tokens & wonders into the mids of thee, O thou land of Egypt : upon Pharao and all his servants.
Manx: 9. Hwgg e kowraghyn as ientyssyn ayns yn véan ayds, O us hallw Ejipt : er Pháro as y er mwinjere wlly.

English: 10 He smote divers nations : and slew mighty Kings;
Manx: 10. Voall e ymmydi atiẃnyn : as varrw e ríiaghyn gniartoil;

English: 11 Sehon king of the Amorites, and Og the king of Basan : and all the kingdomes of Chanaan;
Manx: 11. Sehon ríi dy ny Hammoritin, Ogg ríi Vasan : as wlly ririaghtyn Ghanáan.

English: 12 And gave their land to be an heritage : even an heritage unto Israel his people.
Manx: 12. As hwgg eshyn yn tallw acksyn dy ve na éirys : gy jarw éirus dy Israel y phobyl.

English: 13 Thy Name, O Lord, endureth for ever : so doeth thy memoriall, O Lord, from one generation to another.
Manx: 13. Ta t’ enyms, O Hiarn, farraghtyn erson gybrágh : margedyn ta dy ghẃney, Ó Hiarn, vei yn shilógh gys anáyn elle.

English: 14 For the Lord will avenge his people : and be gracious unto his servants.
Manx: 14. Erson níi yn Chiarn y phobyl y ghwilíny : as bí e grasoil dâ ’yr-mwinjery.

English: 15 As for the images of the heathen, they are but silver and gold : the worke of mens hands.
Manx: 15. Myghian jallwnyn ny hangristíin, gha vel ayd agh argyd as áyr : obraghyn lawyn déney.

English: 16 They have mouthes, and speake not : eyes have they, but they see not.
Manx: 16. Ta beíil ack, as gha vel ayd lóyrt : sẃylyn t’ ack, as gha vaick ayd.

English: 17 They have eares, and yet they heare not : neither is there any breath in their mouthes.
Manx: 17. Ta klúasyn ack, as fóost gha glwyn ayd : ghamẃ ta vegg yn anyl ayns nan meil.

English: 18 They that make them are like unto them : and so are all they that put their trust in them.
Manx: 18. Ta aydsyn ta d’ ’an ianw ayd kasly riu : as marshen ta aydsyn wlly ta kwrr nan dreistéel áyndw.

English: 19 Praise the Lord ye house of Israel : praise the Lord ye house of Aaron.
Manx: 19. Molligi yn Chiarn, shiusse hei Israel : molligi yn Chiarn, shiusse hei Aaron.

English: 20 Praise the Lord yee house of Levi : yee that feare the Lord, praise the Lord.
Manx: 20. Molligi yn Chiarn, shiusse hei Levi : shiusse ta góyl agyl d’ yn Chiarn, molligi yn Chiarn.

English: 21 Praised bee the Lord out of Sion : which dwelleth at Hierusalem.
Manx: 21. Mollíit gy row yn Chiarn magh as Seion : ta vaghey ag Jériusalem.

English: which] 1662 who
The xxviii. day.
Manx: Yn xxviii. la.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: Aspyrt.

English: Confitemini. Psal. 136.
Manx: Confitemini Domino. psal. 136.

English: O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is gracious : and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1. Ó kwrrigi bẃias d’ yn Chiarn erson t’ e grasóil : as y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 2 O give thanks unto the God of all gods : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 2. Ó kwrrigi bwias dy Iíh gygh wlly iíh : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 3 O thanke the Lord of all lords : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 3. O kẃrrigi bwias dy Hiarn gygh wlly hiarn : érson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 4 Who onely doeth great wonders : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 4. Ta na lymarkan janw ientyssyn mẃayry : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
5 Which by his excellent wisedome made the heavens : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 5. Ren liórish y ghriníd vẃar ny neaẃaghyn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
6 Which layde out the earth above the waters : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 6. Ghwrr magh yn tallw erskyn ny hwiskaghyn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
7 Which hath made great lights : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 7. Ren soilshaghyn mwary : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
8 The Sunne to rule the day : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 8. Yn grien dy réel yn lá : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: 9 The Moone and the starres to governe the night : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 9. Yn éask as ny rydlagyn dy réel yn ýì : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;
ny rydlagyn] ms. yn rydlagyn

English: 10 Which smote Egypt with their first borne : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 10. Voǎil Ejipt marish na rwgg hosiagh ack : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
11 And brought out Israel from among them : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 11. As hwgg e magh Israel vei nan masky : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 12 With a mighty hand, and stretched out arme : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 12. Rish law gniartoil as ri shínit magh : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 13 Which divided the red Sea in two parts : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 13. Réyn yn farkey Jarg ayns daa arn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
14 And made Israel to goe thorow the middest of it: for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 14. As hwgg e er Israel dol tryeid yn véyn agge : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 15 But as for Pharao and his hoste, he overthrew them in the red Sea : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 15. Agh erson Phaáro as y heshiaght kagi, hilg e harrish ayd ayns [yn] ayrkey Jarg : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: 16 Which ledde his people thorow the wildernesse : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 16. Líid y phobyl trýid yn ’asyght : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
17 Which smote great Kings : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 17. Voǎil riaghyn mẃary : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
18 Yea, and slew mightie Kings : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 18. As gy jarw, varrw e ríaghyn gniartoil : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: 19 Sehon King of the Amorites : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 19. Sehon, Ríi dy ny Hammoriti : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: 20 And Og the King of Basan : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 20. As Ogg, ríi Vásan : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 21 And gave away their land for an heritage : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 21. As hwgg e er shiul nan dallw ghon éirys : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: 22 Even for an heritage unto Israel his servant : for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 22. Ghon eirys dy Israel y ’er-mẃinjer : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: 23 Which remembred us when wee were in trouble: for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 23. Ghwini orrw̌in nar va shwin ayns syaghyn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
24 And hath delivered us from our enemies : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 24. As lifrée shwin vei nan noidjyn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh;.

English: 25 Which giveth food to all flesh : for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 25. Ta toyrt béaghy dy dygh wlly ’éyl : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
26 O give thankes unto the God of heaven : for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 26. O kwrrigi bwias dy Iíh ny neawaghyn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: 27 O give thankes unto the Lord of lords : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 27. O kwrrigi [bwias] dy Hiarn ny jarnyn : erson ta y vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh.

English: Super flumina. Psal. 137.
Manx: Svper flvmina. psal. 137.

English: By the waters of Babylon wee sate downe & wept : when we remembered (thee) O Sion.
Manx: 1. Liorish wiskaghyn Vabilon hei shwin shíis, as ren shwin kẃo : nar ghwini shwin oyrts, O Héion.

English: 2 As for our harpes, wee hanged them up : upon the trees that are therein.
Manx: 2. As erson nan grẃityn, ghrogh shwin shýas áyd : er ny bilchyn aynshen.

English: 3 For they that led us away captive, required of us then a song and melodie in our heavinesse : Sing us one of the songs of Sion.
Manx: 3. Erson aydsyn líid shwiniyn er shiul nan gimmi, hýrr ayd orwin eis oráyn as binnys ayns nan drimshey : gowgi dwiniyn anayn dy oranyn Seión.

English: 4 How shall we sing the Lords song : in a strange lande?
Manx: 4. Kyns góẁi meid oráyn yn Chiarn : ayns tallw jóri?

English: 5 If I forget thee, O Hierusalem : let my right hand forget her cunning.
Manx: 5. My iarẃdyms us, Ó Jeriusalem : ligg e my law iesh y sklyei y iarẃd.

English: 6 If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleave to the roofe of my mouth : yea, if I preferre not Hierusalem in my mirth.
Manx: 6. Managh gwiniym oyrts, ligg e my hiange lianaghtyn gys fyrrwgh my véal : ta mi grá, managh niarr liâm Jeriusalem ayn my iann.

English: 7 Remember the children of Edom, O Lord, in the day of Hierusalem : how they said, Downe with it, downe with it, even to the ground.
Manx: 7. Kwini er klawn Edom, O Hiarn, ayns lá Jeriusalem : kyns dwyrt áyd, shíis lesh, shiis lesh, gy jarw gys y tallw.

English: 8 O daughter of Babylon, wasted with misery : yea, happie shall he be that rewardeth thee as thou hast served us.
Manx: 8. O iniin Vabilon, kéistch rish boghtanys : gy sickyr, sh’ maynry víis na véi-syn ta dy ghwilinys, mar tow er nan shyrvées.

English: 9 Blessed shall he be that taketh thy children : and throweth them against the stones.
Manx: 9. Baníit víis eshyn gowys dy ghlawns : as hilgys ayd nyoi ny klaghyn.

English: Confitebor tibi. Psal. 138.
Manx: Confitebor tíbi. psal. 138.

English: I wil give thanks unto thee, O Lord, with my whole heart : even before the gods will I sing praise unto thee.
Manx: 1. Verřym bẃias dwitch, O Hiarn, rish my ghríi sláyn : gy jarw feanish ny jíaghyn goyms oráyn dwitch.

English: 2 I wil worship toward thy holy Temple, & praise thy Name, because of thy loving kindnesse and trueth : for thou hast magnified thy Name and thy word above all things.
Manx: 2. Níims ammys gys tdy hiampyl kasserick, as mollym t’ enyms, erson tdy ghéindylys grayigóil as tdy irrinys : erson tow us er molley gy mwar t’ enym as t’ okyls erskyn gygh wlly redd.

English: 3 When I called upon thee, thou heardest mee : and enduedst my soule with much strength.
Manx: 3. Nar jei mi oyrts, ghýyl us mí : as lien w m’ anym rish [...] gniart.

English: 4 All the Kings of the earth shall praise thee, O Lord : for they have heard the words of thy mouth.
Manx: 4. Níi wlly ríiaghyn yn tallẃin us y volley, O Hiarn : erson ghyyl áyd fokelyn dy véỳls.

English: 5 Yea, they shall sing in the wayes of the Lord : that great is the glory of the Lord.
Manx: 5. Gy jarw, gowi áyd oráyn ayns ráydjyn yn Chiarn : gy vell gloyr yn Chiarn mẃar.

English: 6 For though the Lord be high, yet hath he respect unto the lowly : as for the proud, he beholdeth them afarre off.
Manx: 6. Erson gy ta yn Chiarn ayrd, fóost te toyrt tasky d’ yn slyei imbli[265] : erson yn slyei morniagh, t’ e jaghyn oriǔ fodey vei.

English: 7 Though I walke in the mids of trouble, yet shalt thou refresh me : thou shalt stretch foorth thy hand upon the furiousnesse of mine enemies, and thy right hand shall save mee.
Manx: 7. Gy ta mi gimiaght ayns méan syaghyn, fóost níi us mish y ẃraghy : shíniit ẃ magh tdy law er kýeis my noidjyn, as sawi dy law iesh mish.
y ẃraghy] ms. wẃraghy

English: 8 The Lord shal make good his loving-kindnes toward me : yea, thy mercie, O Lord, endureth for ever; despise not then the workes of thine owne hands.
Manx: 8. Níi yn Chiarn y gheindylys grayigẃil y ianw mei dẃỳs : gy jarw, O Hiarn, ta dy vyghin farraghtyn erson gybragh; na syei begg eis dy obraghyn dy lawyn héyn.

English: The xxix. day.
Manx: Yn xxix. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Domine probasti. Psal. 139.
Manx: Domine probasti. psal. 139.

English: O Lord, thou hast searched mee out, and knowen me : thou knowest my downe sitting and mine uprising, thou understandest my thoughts long before.
Manx: 1. O Hiarn, ta us er my hyirre magh, as bawn dw̌it mi : sawn dwit my hyei shíis as m’ irri shúas; tow twigel my smwnaghtyn foddey reyf.

English: 2 Thou art about my path, and about my bedde : and spiest out all my wayes.
Manx: 2. Tows magiyrt my ghassyn as magiyrt my labbi : as fackin magh my raydjyn wlly.

English: 3 For loe, there is not a word in my tongue : but thou, O Lord, knowest it altogether.
Manx: 3. Erson jéagh, gha vel fokyl er my hiange : nagh náwn dy [...][266] e wlly kẃjaght.

English: 4 Thou hast fashioned me behinde and before : and layd thine hand upon me.
Manx: 4. Ta us er my ghwmmey er my ghẃlyw as er my vialw : as lei w dy law orrym.

English: 5 Such knowledge is too wonderfull and excellent for me : I cannot attaine unto it.
Manx: 5. Ta leid yn fysseri róo ientyssagh as róo ayrd dow : gha voddym roschyn hwgge.

English: 6 Whither shal I goe then from thy Spirit : or whither shall I goe then from thy presence?
Manx: 6. Kàrt[267] heyms eis vei tdy spyryd : na kàrt heyms éis vei t’ eanish?

English: 7 If I clime up into heaven, thou art there : if I goe downe to hell, thou art there also.
Manx: 7. Ma heyms shýas gys neaw, ta us aynshen : ma heyms shíis gys nifrin, tow aynshen níist.

English: 8 If I take the wings of the morning : and remaine in the uttermost parts of the Sea;
Manx: 8. Ma goym skeanyn yn voghre : as fwrraghtyn ayns ny hardjyn soje magh dyn arkey;

English: 9 Even there also shall thy hand leade me : and thy right hand shall hold me.
Manx: 9. Gy jarw aynshen níist líidji tdy law mi : as ni tdy law iesh my ghwmmell.

English: 10 If I say, Peradventure the darknesse shall cover me : then shall my night be turned to day.
Manx: 10. Ma jirrym, higgo[268] ni yn dorghys my ghwdy : eis bi m’ yi erna hynda gys lá.

English: 11 Yea, the darkenesse is no darkenesse with thee, but the night is as cleare as the day : the darknesse and light (to thee) are both alike.
Manx: 11. Gy sickyr, ghanié yn dorghys [dorghys] erbí mayrts, agh ta yn yi gho solys ass y lá : ta yn dorghys as y soilshe dwitch wlly mar anáyn.

English: 12 For my reines are thine : thou hast covered mee in my mothers wombe.
Manx: 12. Sh’ lâts my áreníỳn : tous er my ghwdyghy ayns brenn my váyre.

English: 13 I will give thankes unto thee, for I am fearefully and wonderfully made : marveilous are thy works, and that my soule knoweth right well.
Manx: 13. Verrym bwias dwitch, erson ta mi gy haggylagh as gy hientyssagh jant : sh’ ientyssagh t’ obraghyn, as shen sawn dy my anym gy fíir vei.

English: 14 My bones are not hid from thee : though I bee made secretly, and fashioned beneath in the earth.
Manx: 14. Gha vel my ghnawyn fallíit void : gy ta mi jant gynnys, as kwmmit híis ayns y tallw.

English: 15 Thine eyes did see my substance, yet being unperfect : and in thy booke were all my members written;
Manx: 15. Ghonick tdy hwilyn my vri, nar ve fóyst gynn ghwmmey : as ayns tdy lior va wlly my alltyn skriut;

English: 16 Which day by day were fashioned : when as yet there was none of them.
Manx: 16. Va y la gy la kwmmit : nar nagh row fóost vegg jû.

English: 17 How deare are thy counsels unto me, O God : O how great is the summe of them!
Manx: 17. Gho dyer as ta dy ghorliyn dwys, O Iíh : O gho mwar ta ny símín acksyn!

English: 18 If I tell them, they are moe in number then the sand : when I wake up, I am present with thee.
Manx: 18. Ma érivym áyd, t’ áyd nasmẃ[269] ayns erif na yn gennagh : nar ta mi dwysky shúas ta mi [...] ayns t’ enish.[270]

English: 19 Wilt thou not slay the wicked, O God : depart from me, ye bloodthirstie men.
Manx: 19. Nagh marr ẃ yn niawghráwi, O Iíh ? shiuligi voyms, shiusse géne ta páa nyre fwill.

English: 20 For they speake unrighteously against thee : and thine enemies take thy Name in vaine.
Manx: 20. Erson t’ áyd loyrt gy niaw ynrick t’ yôis : as ta dy noidjyn goyl t’ enym ayns fardáyl.

English: 21 Doe not I hate them, O Lord, that hate thee : and am not I grieved with those that rise up against thee?
Manx: 21. Nagh vel dẃoi áym oriwsyn, O Hiarn, ta dẃoi ack oyrts : as nagh vel mi jumẃygh riusyn ta girri shúas t’ yôis?

English: 22 Yea, I hate them right sore : even as though they were mine enemies.
Manx: 22. Gy sickyr, ta dẃoi [...][271] aym oriǔsyn : gy jarw mar as beagh áyd my noidjyn.

English: 23 Trie me, O God, and seeke the ground of my heart : prove me, and examine my thoughts.
Manx: 23. Prow mi, O Iíh, as shyirr dyifnid my ghrí : shy̌irr magh mi, as féyst my smẃnaghtyn.

English: 24 Looke well if there be any way of wickednesse in me : and leade me in the way everlasting.
Manx: 24. Jéagh gy mei ma ta ráyd erbí d’ olkys ayňyms : as líid mi ayns rayd gybragh farraghtyn.

English: Eripe me, Domine. Psal. 140.
Manx: Eripe me Domine. psal. 140.

English: Deliver me, O Lord, from the evil man : and preserve me from the wicked man;
Manx: 1. Lifrée mish, O Hiarn, vei yn dwyne olk : as friall mi vei yn drogh wyney;

English: wicked man] 1599 wicked men
Manx: yn drogh] ms. ny drogh

English: 2 Which imagine mischiefe in their hearts : and stirre up strife all the day long.
Manx: 2. Ta smwnaghtyn skèlley ayns nan griaghyn : as brosnaghy shúas ymmyr fei yn lá.

English: Which] 1662 Who
3 They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent : adders poison is under their lips.
Manx: 3. T’ áyd ern geryghe[272] nan janganyn kasly rish arnef : ta pyshyn adderyn fwo nan meyliyn.

English: 4 Keepe me, O Lord, from the handes of the ungodly : preserve mee from the wicked men, which are purposed to overthrow my goings.
Manx: 4. Friall mi, Hiarn vei lawyn y niaw ghrawi : fríal [mi] vei ny drogh ’éne, ta soẃlaghy dy hilge harrish my immíaghtyns.

English: which] 1662 who
5 The proud have layd a snare for mee, and spread a net abroad with cords : yea, and set traps in my way.
Manx: 5. Héi yn slyei morniagh ribbe ma ghowrs, as skéyl ayd [magh lién gy][273] lean rish teddyn : gy jarw as héi áyd ribbaghyn ayns my ráyd.
teddyn] ms. t’eddyn

English: 6 I saide unto the Lord, Thou art my God : heare the voyce of my prayers, O Lord.
Manx: 6. Dẃyrt mi rish yn Chiarn, she us my Iíh : klast rish korá my phadjeryn, O Hiarn.

English: 7 O Lord God, thou strength of my health : thou hast covered my head in the day of battell.
Manx: 7. O Hiarn Jíh, us gniart my láint : tow̌ er gẃdaghy my ghian ayns lá yn ghagi.

English: 8 Let not the ungodly have his desire, O Lord : let not his mischievous imagination prosper, lest they be too proude.
Manx: 8. Na ligg d’ yn niawghrawi y agnys y geadthin, O Hiarn : na ligg dâ grogh smwnaghtyn doll er hoshiagh, nagh bií áyd roó vorniagh.
d’ yn] ms. dy

English: 9 Let the mischiefe of their owne lips fall upon the head of them : that compasse me about.
Manx: 9. Ligg e olk nan meliyn héyn twitchym er ny kinn acksyn : ta dy my ghimshéyn magiyrt.

English: 10 Let hot burning coales fal upon them : let them be cast into the fire and into the pit, that they never rise up againe.
Manx: 10. Ligg e smarágyn che lossy twitchym oriusyn : ligg aw ve er nan dilge ayns yn ainill, as ayns yn lagg, nagh nirri áyd shýas ríist gybragh.

English: 11 A man full of wordes shall not prosper upon the earth : evill shall hunt the wicked person to overthrow him.
Manx: 11. Dwyne layn dy okelyn, gha jeid e er y hoshiagh er y talw : níi olk yn drogh ẃney y helg, dy hilge harrish é.

English: 12 Sure I am that the Lord will avenge the poore : and maintaine the cause of the helplesse.
Manx: 12. Ta mi sićkyr gy gwilíin yn Chiarn erson ny moght : as gy gwmm é shuas kwysh dwyney gyn ghẃyne.
gy gwilíin] ms. ny gwilíin

English: 13 The righteous also shall give thanks unto thy Name : and the just shall continue in thy sight.
Manx: 13. Ver yn dwyne kayragh bwias dy t’ enyms : as [...][274] yn dwyne kayragh ayns tdy hilliys.

English: Domine, clamaui. Psal. 141.
Manx: Domine clamavi. psal. 141.

English: Lord, I call upon thee, haste thee unto me : and consider my voyce, when I cry unto thee.
Manx: 1. Hiarn, ta mi gemagh oyrts; jean seir hwym : as smŵni er my ghora, nar eiym hwyds.

English: 2 Let my prayer be set forth in thy sight as the Incense : and let the lifting up of my hands be an evening sacrifice.
Manx: 2. Ligg e my phadjer ve erna hoyrt magh ayns t’ eanish mar soyr millys : as ligg e trogell shýas my lawyn ve mar owrell faskyr.

English: 3 Set a watch, O Lord, before my mouth : and keep the doore of my lips.
Manx: 3. Sei are, O Hiarn, reyf my véayl : as frial dorrys my veéliyn.

English: 4 O let not mine heart be inclined to any evill thing : let mee not bee occupied in ungodly workes, with the men that worke wickednes, lest I eat of such things as please them.
Manx: 4. Na ligg dy my ghrí ve erna lẃby gys drogh red erbi : na ligg dow ve klaghtíit ayns obraghyn niawghrawi marish ny déne ta obraghe olk, nagh niim dy leid ny reddyn níi aydsyn y vwias.

English: 5 Let the righteous rather smite mee friendly : and reprove me.
Manx: 5. Ligg e yn niaw ghrawi[275] naslýi my voally gy mwnjeroil : as aghsan y hoyrt dow.
aghsan] ms. haghsan

English: 6 But let not their precious balmes breake my head: yea, I will pray yet against their wickednesse.
Manx: 6. As na ligg [e] yn ẃil dýer acksyn my ghian y vrishié : gy sićkyr, níỳm padjer fóost nyoi ’an olkys acksyn.

English: 7 Let their Judges bee overthrowen in stonie places: that they may heare my words, for they are sweete.
Manx: 7. Ligg e nan mrîunyn ve er nan dilge harrish ayns ynnydyn klaghagh : gy vod ayd m’ okelyns y ghlastchen, erson t’ ayd millys.

English: 8 Our bones lie scattered before the pit : like as when one breaketh and heweth wood upon the earth.[276]
Manx: 8. Ta nan gnawyn nan lyi skěylt roish y lagg : nash mar nar ta anáyn brishie as gayrre fyei er y tallw.[277]

English: 9 But mine eyes looke unto thee, O Lord God : in thee is my trust, O cast not out my soule.
Manx: 9. Agh ta

English: 10 Keepe mee from the snare that they have laid for mee : and from the traps of the wicked doers.
11 Let the ungodly fall into their owne nets together : and let me ever escape them.
The xxix. day.
Evening prayer.
Voce mea ad Dominum. Psal. 142.
I cryed unto the Lord with my voice : yea, even unto the Lord did I make my supplication.
2 I powred out my complaints before him : and shewed him of my trouble.
3 When my spirit was in heavinesse, thou knewest my path : in the way wherein I walked, have they privily laid a snare for me.
4 I looked also upon my right hand : and saw there was no man that would know me.
5 I had no place to flee unto : and no man cared for my soule.
6 I cried unto thee, O Lord, and said : Thou art my hope and my portion in the land of the living.
7 Consider my complaint : for I am brought very lowe.
8 O deliver mee from my persecutors : for they are too strong for me.
9 Bring my soule out of prison, that I may give thanks unto thy Name : which thing if thou wilt graunt me, then shall the righteous resort unto my companie.

Manx: eis níi yn krawi chíit gys my heshiaght.

English: Domine exaudi. Psal. 143.
Manx: Domine exaudi. psal. 143.

English: Heare my prayer, O Lord, and consider my desire : hearken unto me for thy trueth and righteousnesse sake.
Manx: 1. Klast ry my phadjer, O Hiarn, as smwni er m’ akan : klast rwyms er grayi t’ irrinys as dy ghayrys.

English: 2 And enter not into judgement with thy servant: for in thy sight shall no man living be justified.
Manx: 2. As na gow schiagh ayns brwinys rish tdy herváynt : erson ayns tdy hilliys gha bíi dwyne erbi bio erna hyyre.

English: 3 For the enemie hath persecuted my soule; hee hath smitten my life downe to the ground : hee hath layd me in the darkenesse, as the men that have bene long dead.
Manx: 3. Erson ta yn noid ern eiyrts m’ anym gy holk; t’ e er moally my vee shíis gys y tallw : t’ e er my ghwrr my ly̌ei ayns y dorghys, mar ny deney ta fodey marrw.
moally] ms. m’ ’oally

English: 4 Therefore is my spirit vexed within mee : and my heart within me is desolate.
Manx: 4. Shennyfá ta my spyryd syaghnit[278] er leyf styei jíìm : as my ghri er leyf sty̌ei jíìm, t’ e fays.

English: 5 Yet doe I remember the time past; I muse upon all thy workes : yea, I exercise my selfe in the workes of thy hands.
Manx: 5. Foost ta mi kẃinaghtyn er yn iérish ta er noll shaghy; ta mi smwnaghtyn er wlly t’ obraghyns : gy jarw, ta mi dy [my] ghlaghty héyn ayns obraghyn dy laẃyns.

English: 6 I stretch foorth my hands unto thee : my soule gaspeth unto thee as a thirstie land.
Manx: 6. Híin mi magh my lawyn hwyds : ta m’ anym foskyly y veal hwyds mar tallw páagh.
my] ms. mi; foskyly] ms. foskyll

English: 7 Heare me, O Lorde, and that soone, for my spirite waxeth faint : hide not thy face from mee, least I bee like unto them that goe downe into the pit.
Manx: 7. Klwin mi, O Hiarn, as shen gy lye, erson ta m’ anym goyl anwniy : na falli t’ edyn voym, nagh bíim kasly riusyn ta doll shíis gys yn ýoi.

English: 8 O let mee heare thy loving kindnesse betimes in the morning, for in thee is my trust : shewe thou mee the way that I should walke in, for I lift up my soule unto thee.
Manx: 8. O ligg dwys tdy gheindylys grayigwil y ghlastcheyn gy lyé ayns y voghre, erson anyds ta my hreistéel : jeagh us dwys yn rayd leshin gimiagh ayn, erson ta mi trogel m’ anym hwyds.

English: 9 Deliver me, O Lord, from mine enemies : for I flee unto thee to hide me.
Manx: 9. Lifrée mi, O Hiarn, vei my noidjyn : erson ta mi ché hwyds dy my allaghey.

English: 10 Teache me to doe the thing that pleaseth thee, for thou art my God : let thy loving Spirit leade me foorth into the land of righteousnesse.
Manx: 10. Ynsi dwys dy ianw yn red ta dy tdy vwias, erson she us my Iih : ligg dy tdy spyryd grayigoil my liidjéel magh gys tallw ghayrys.

English: 11 Quicken me, O Lorde, for thy Names sake : and for thy righteousnesse sake, bring my soule out of trouble.
Manx: 11. Biói mi, O Hiarn, er grayi t’ enym : as erson grayi dy ghayrys, kwrr m’ anym magh as syaghyn.

English: 12 And of thy goodnesse slay mine enemies : and destroy all them that vexe my soule; for I am thy servant.
Manx: 12. As dy tdy véìys marr my noidjyn : as strẃi aydsyn wlly ta syaghyn m’ anym, erson she mish tdy herváynt.

English: The xxx. day.
Manx: Yn xxx. la.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: Ayryn.

English: Benedictus Dominus. Psal. 144.
Manx: Benedictus Dominus. psal. 144.

English: Blessed be the Lord my strength : which teacheth my handes to warre, and my fingers to fight;
Manx: 1. Baníit gy row yn Chiarn my gniart : ta gynsaghy my lawyn dy ghage, as my veyr dy gleck;

English: which] 1662 who
2 My hope and my fortresse, my castle and deliverer, my defender, in whom I trust : which subdueth my people that is under me.
Manx: 2. My hreistéel as m’ ynyd laidjerys, my ghastal as m’ endéel, m’ er friali ayns ta mi treistéel : ta smaghtaghy my phobyl ta fwoym.

English: which] 1662 who
3 Lorde, what is man, that thou hast such respect unto him : or the sonne of man, that thou so regardest him?
Manx: 3. Hiarn, kre ta dwyne, gy vell leid yn taskey shen ayd dâ : na mack dwyne, gy vel ẃ janw ghwis iesyn?

English: 4 Man is like a thing of nought : his time passeth away like a shadow.
Manx: 4. Ta dwyne kasly rish red gyn veg : ta y ierish doll er shiul mar skáyn.

English: 5 Bowe the heavens, O Lord, and come downe : touche the mountaines, and they shall smoke.
Manx: 5. Krwmm ny neawaghyn, O Hiarn, as tarr núas : benn rish ny mwinaghyn[279] as níi ayd jeagh.

English: the heavens] 1662 thy heavens
6 Cast foorth thy lightning, and teare them : shoote out thine arrowes, and consume them.
Manx: 6. Kwrr magh dy henè[280] tarniagh as [...]éys ayd : tilgg magh tdy heidjyn, as kwrr mow áyd.

English: 7 Send downe thine hand from above : deliver me, and take me out of the great waters, from the hand of strange children;
Manx: 7. Kwrr nuas tdy lawyn vei huas : lifree mi, as gow mi magh ass ny hwiskaghyn mwary, vei lawyn yn klawn jori.

English: 8 Whose mouth talketh of vanitie : and their right hand is a right hand of wickednesse.
Manx: 8. Ta an méal taglw d’ ’ardalys : ta yn law iesh acksyn law iesh d’ olkys.

English: 9 I wil sing a new song unto thee, O God : and sing praises unto thee upon a ten stringed Lute.
Manx: 9. Góyms oráyn noo hwwds, O Iih : as goym oráyn moli dwitch ar klayrsagh jei strengyn.

English: 10 Thou hast given victorie unto Kings : and hast delivered David thy servant from the peril of the sword.
Manx: 10. Us ta toyrt barriyght dy ríiaghyn : as ta er lifrée David tdy hervaynt vei gaw yn ghleiw;

English: 11 Save me, and deliver me from the hand of strange children : whose mouth talketh of vanitie, and their right hand is a right hand of iniquitie.
Manx: 11. Saw mish, as lifrée mi vei law yn ghlawn jóri : ta an méal taglw d’ ’ardalys, as ta yn law iesh acksyn law iesh dy vigháyrys.

English: 12 That our sonnes may growe up as the yong plants : and that our daughters may bee as the polished corners of the Temple.
Manx: 12. Gy vod nan meck gaás shuas mar banglányn ágy : as gy vod nan ininyn ve mar kornélyn karriit dyn champyl;

English: 13 That our garners may bee full and plenteous with all manner of store : that our sheepe may bring foorth thousands and ten thousands in our streets.
Manx: 13. Gy vod nan děin taskey ve láyn as palchey rish dygh wlly voney dy stoyr : gy vod nan girri y hoyrt magh milaghyn, as jei milaghyn ayns nan straydjyn.

English: 14 That our oxen may be strong to labour, that there bee no decay : no leading into captivitie, and no complayning in our streets.
Manx: 14. Gy vod nan ’éf ve laidjer d’ obraghey, nagh bíi vegg y ghwrr mow : na veg y tayrn gys kapy, na veg yn akan ayns nan straydjyn.

English: 15 Happie are the people that be in such a case : yea, blessed are the people which have the Lord for their God.
Manx: 15. Sh’ maynry ta yn pobyl [... :] gy jarrw, baníit ta yn pobyl, ag vel yn Chiarn ghon nan Iíh.

English: people that be] 1662 people that are; people which] 1662 people who
Exaltabo te Deus. Psal. 145.
Manx: Exaltabo te deus. psal. 145.

English: I will magnifie thee, O God, my King : and I wil praise thy Name for ever and ever.
Manx: 1. Niims us gy mwar y gloyraghey, O Iíh my ríi : as mollym t’ enyms erson gybrágh as gybrágh.

English: 2 Every day will I give thankes unto thee : and praise thy Name for ever and ever.
Manx: 2. Gygh wlly lá verrym bwias dwitch : as mollym t’ enym erson gybragh as gybrágh.

English: 3 Great is the Lord, and marveilous worthy to be praised : there is no end of his greatnesse.
Manx: 3. Ta yn Chiarn mwar, as ientysagh fiŵ dy ve erna volly : gha vell kian erbí d’ yn vodiyght[281] aggesyn.

English: 4 One generation shall praise thy workes unto another : and declare thy power.
Manx: 4. Níi yn shilogh t’ obraghyns y volly gys anáyn elle : as tdy phoeyr y hoilsaghy.

English: 5 As for me, I will be talking of thy worship : thy glorie, thy praise, and wonderous works;
Manx: 5. Er my hons, bíim loyrt dy t’ ammys : tdy gloyr, tdy volly, as t’ obraghyn ientysagh.

English: 6 So that men shall speake of the might of thy marveilous acts : and I will also tell of thy greatnesse.
Manx: 6. Marshen
